text: This nice little deli inside Atlantis provides generous delicious food with the entire range of deli NY style as the theme. The service is great. It is conveniently located on the main floor of the casino and actually worth the trip to Atlantis just to eat here. Recommended.

While spending the night between visits to California Historic Mission we needed to buy a twenty pack of water to see us through the trip.  We stopped here and found the water as well as a friendly helpful attendant.  We added some ice cream to out stop and recommend you do the same.

Before it moves next year make every effort to visit this fabulous collection of over 2500 art objects which includes 800 paintings estimated to be worth well over $25 billion.  Among the paintings are 181 works by Renoir, 69 by Cézanne, and 59 by Matisse,   Try to get tickets for a Saturday with an arrival at 1pm to line up for the docent tour at 1:30pm.  I can not recommend a museum more highly.  Get there before the collection is moved next year to Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

Just next to our hotel we did a walking tour then loaded up with a salad and some cheeses for our room.  Clearly a well earned reputation for a most-see spot in city center.  Lots of local color and foods with a mix of locally grown produce and fruits, plenty of places to eat diner style with counter and stool and a remarkable set of gourmet speciality shops with experts to help you with selections.  Fantastic place to checkout just as all the other reviews said.  Amazing!

Remarkable food with beach access for the whole family, flip flops acceptable.  You step up to the counter, order, get a number and bus you own food to a table inside or out.  The locals know about this place and really love it just as we did on our first visit.  Highly recommended.  Probably good enough to drive from Santa Barbara to eat here.  Local beer on tap, kids are more than welcome.

I loved everything about this lovely train station.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  The station was beautiful.  Every aspect of passing through was wonderful.  It is a great place.  Thank you Philadelphia for making our vacation special and providing such a great place.

The classic facade, built over an earlier facing, was copied from a first century Roman book, Spanish edition, published in Madrid 1787.  The three statues, left, right and top represent Faith, Hope and Charity.  The fourth added in 1927 is Santa Barbara.  Of all the 21 mission this one is the most imposing and offers a large open space in front for the admiration of this structure.

Older Residence Inn with air conditioner problems.  Located just out of town off freeway.  Staff was not very receptive.  The two people at the desk in the lobby always seemed to be playing a video game.  We stayed five days.  Got to know the routine.  Cleaning staff could not speak English, usually no problem, but we were not getting our roomed cleaned until after 4pm and on one day not at all.  Front desk said they would take care of it.  They did not.  We like the Residence Inn experience usually but this one is off our list.  Not recommended.

I love to go here for the sports book when in Reno. Plenty of scratch sheets and individual TVs at each desk. When you get hungry there are a variety of places to eat with each providing good service and delicious food. Recommended.

The location of this Residents Inn is perfect for a curious tourist in Philadelphia, city center near the famous historic sites. We were checked in with only a minor problem getting the key coded correctly. Elliott, our man helping with our bags, returned to the front desk and took care of the keys while we relaxed. Our one bedroom suite was perfect with a very comfortable and luxurious bed. Our two nights sleep was terrific, no noise, comfortable, wake up call on time, extra towels for the shower, kitchen perfect, coffee great. The free breakfast and evening buffets offered a selection of food helped us with weight management, were fresh and tasted great. Everything in the hotel was clean and in good repair. The staff was efficient but lacked the warmth we usually find at Marriott (minus one star). Next time we may try the Marriott Hotel around the corner but still recommend this place as above average.

GrubHub delivered quickly. Greek salad was not as described, greens and not much else. Grill cheese was simple but OK. Tune salad was nothing but white bread and thin tune salad mix spread. Large diet coke came as plastic vending machines 16 Oz. Total over $40 did not meet expectations. Try someplace else.
Walk down the steps to this little river park, enjoy the tinkle of the water, relax and enjoy a break for the busy activities of the downtown area.

This is one of the premier museums in the country with a continuous serious of exhibits that maintain the imagination and interest.  The current exhibition, Cezanne and Beyond, is certainly worth a trip to Philadelphia.  What can we see in Jasper John that evokes Cezanne?  Come to Philadelphia and take a look.  Remarkable exhibit, highly recommended.
Excellent service and great food.  I was very impressed with the French fries.  Locals and tourist both seem happy to enjoy this unique diner.  Recommended.

Wonderful cafe food, excellent service and Keno runners to help you stay connected.  We really enjoyed the friendly help by everyone.  Fast food service even with a full restaurant.  My fish and chips was delicious and the wife's BLT reported as very good.  We found out way through the free parking, down through the casino and into the restaurant with no problem and very quickly.  Highly recommended.

Very disappointed.  Odd outdated facility next to livestock lot.  We will not use this facility again. 1960's feel, older odd facility, strange decor, tight winding hallways, small rooms, built many years ago. Very different than the dozens of HIE facilities we have used. Broken inoperative refrigerator, staff moved us to a smaller room with operating refrigerator. Window opened to a livestock sales yard, flies everywhere, smell unpleasant. Single elevator was old smaller slow type. Everything felt old with attempt to maintain. Check in was not the normal "thank you for being a platinum member" and usual amenities. Checkout was even more odd without the normal bill under the door. Desk clerk laughed and said "we don't do that here". Tucson has a very high occupancy tax that adds to the unusually high room rates. We recommend you find another accommodation, perhaps one of the other 4 HIE facilities in Tuscon or even another brand. We will certainly never use this HIE again.

I had the biggest, fattest, freshest, juiciest oysters ever at Acme yesterday (see attached photos to see the plumpness I'm referring to).  I forgot to ask the server where the restaurant gets their oysters from because surely it can't be the Gulf with Louisiana still dealing with the aftermath of the oil spill.  A dozen fresh raw and iced oysters here are $13.50 served with a few lemon slices and cocktail sauce.  The oysters were delicious and I should have ordered more.  Instead, I tried a cup of their chicken and andouille (Cajun) sausage gumbo.  The bowl came out piping hot and the meat was tender and savory.  One of my friends ordered their world-famous "Peacemaker" po' boys, which is a giant po' boy with fried shrimp and oysters.  It looked awesome.

Acme is located just off Bourbon St, closer to the Canal side.  It's very popular with tourists, but for good reason (as stated above).  If you decide to visit, come early to avoid any long lines.  They do not take reservations and the lines start forming outside on the sidewalk.  The restaurant gets really busy so service can be spotty.  Acme is a casual eatery, divided into two main sections, and also has a bar and TVs.  They have an oyster-eating competition as well.  If you can finish 15 dozen raw oysters in one sitting, you get a plaque of your name on the wall.  Nice.

I told him not to, but my good buddy and fellow Yelper Tom E (https://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=g8j2ci2FcvmocszcO6ypNw) drove from the suburbs of Atlanta to my place in the city, during rush hour, to deliver a birthday gift that included one Pat's Original Philly Cheeesesteak. The cheesesteak had been flown in that same morning. Thank you, Tom.

For those who don't know, Pat's and Geno's are the most popular places to get a cheesesteak sandwich in Philadelphia. They are old and they are competitors. "Pat's King of Steaks" is the "inventor and originator of the cheesesteak sandwich." They've been in business since 1930. During one of my visits to Philadelphia, friends and locals steered me away from Pat's and Geno's, both of which are popular with tourists. Instead, I went to Jim's Steaks South Street: https://www.yelp.com/biz/jims-south-st-philadelphia.

It would not be fair to make a comparison of my experiences with Pat's and Jim's since I had to reheat Pat's cheesesteak at home while I had Jim's cheesesteaks fresh at the restaurant.

You can purchase Pat's cheesesteaks by mail-order through Goldbelly: https://www.goldbelly.com/pats-king-of-steaks. The cheesesteaks were shipped frozen with dry ice packs and reheating instructions. The cheesesteaks were already assembled and wrapped in Pat's signature logo'd white paper wrappers. The Cheez Whiz was packed in separate containers. At the time of writing this review, Goldbelly offered Pat's Original Philly Cheesesteaks in sets of four ($79 or $19.75 per sandwich), eight ($129 or $16.13 per sandwich), and 12 ($169 or $14.08 per sandwich). Shipping was included in the quoted prices.

Reheating was quick and easy. Instructions were to bake at 300 degrees for 10-14 minutes until the bread was lightly-crisped and the meat heated through. The Cheez Whiz could be reheated in the microwave or in a saucepan. I reheated the sandwich in my old toaster oven so it took a little longer than 14 minutes. I used the microwave to melt the Cheez Whiz.

I was impressed with how the sandwich turned out. It looked just like the cheesesteaks I saw of Pat's online. I had the "Wit" onions and Whiz version, but you can get "Wit-Out" onions and change the cheese to Provolone or American if you want. I think I may have baked the sandwich a little too long because the outside of the hoagie roll started to crack and it was extra crispy. That was okay, though, because the inside was warm, soft, and delectably chewy. The bread was good. There were plenty of tender morsels of quality ribeye, but what brought everything together was the melted Cheez Whiz. Mmm... That melted cheese coated the steak and eventually found its way to the bottom of the sandwich, soaking into the bread. This made each bite rich, flavorful, and really satisfying.

There aren't many ingredients - bread, meat, onion, cheese. Pat's found the right combination of quality, taste, and texture. If you're considering purchasing some of Pat's cheesesteaks via mail order, let this review be a vote of confidence. At the time of writing this, you can only get the Original Philly Cheesesteak via Goldbelly. The Mushroom Steak, Pepper Steak, Mushroom Pepper Steak, Pizza Steak, Fish Cake, Hot Dog, and Fries are not available online.

Enjoy.

On Friday, we moseyed on down to the roulette table and placed a split bet on 28 and 29.  17-to-1 payout on a split bet, 19-to-1 odds of winning.  Resulting three spins: 28, 29, 28.  Thanks Harrah's for paying a big chunk of our bachelor party weekend!

As a huge fan of the Rocky movies, from the original Rocky (1976), which won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1977, to the latest installment, Creed II (2018), visiting the Rocky Statue (https://www.yelp.com/biz/the-rocky-statue-philadelphia) and Rocky Steps were my biggest priorities on my first visit to Philadelphia. Yes, I love Rocky that much. The movies are entertaining, nostalgic, and inspirational and the music, especially the songs by Bill Conti, are iconic and some of the absolute best in cinematic history (and in all of music, in my opinion).

The Rocky Steps are located in front of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. There are 72 steps and they are very, very wide. Even if you're not a fan of Rocky, you owe it to yourself to visit the steps and climb to the top to take in the amazing views of Philadelphia. At the top of the steps, facing southeast, you can look down Philly's famous Benjamin Franklin Parkway (https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia). It includes historic circles, fountains, statues, and buildings such as Logan Circle (https://www.yelp.com/biz/logan-circle-philadelphia-2), Swann Memorial Fountain (https://www.yelp.com/biz/swann-memorial-fountain-philadelphia-2), and City Hall (https://www.yelp.com/biz/city-hall-philadelphia). The views of the Philly skyline are amazing and picturesque.

At the top of the center of the steps, on the ground, are foot markers for Rocky. You can stand where he stood to recreate his legendary victory poses with fists raised in the air. In addition to pictures at the top of the steps, you'll probably see people run up the steps just like Rocky did in his training montages: https://youtu.be/ABg0c_E7OOI. I did both and had a blast doing it. I want to go back and do it again. Haha.

There were Rocky lookalikes hanging out around the statue and steps. I happened to run into two that I know and met years ago at Dragon Con in Atlanta: @lonstermash and @thelordhumungus (on Instagram). What a small world. At the top of the steps, a man from South Africa (a solo traveler who told me his name was Kennedy), asked if I could help take some photos and videos of him running up the steps and raising his arms in victory. He had traveled all that way. I was more than happy to help out a fellow Rocky fan. The love for Rocky is universal.

My sisters and I grew up driving Subarus. For whatever reason, my dad loved them. We were a Mercedes and Subaru family in the 80s and 90s (the 2000s and 2010s were a different story). Due to nostalgia, Subaru will always hold a special place in my heart.

My first car was a white 1986 Subaru GL wagon. It was roughly 80-85 horsepower and used a carburetor. We bought the car used from the Hanes family of Hanesbrands in Winston-Salem, North Carolina. If I recall correctly, the car was Mrs. Hanes' winter/mountain car. Like most Subarus, the car was all-wheel drive (AWD). It could switch between 2WD and AWD instantly at the press of a button on the gear-shifter. We used it whenever it would snow (we lived in NC).

In all honestly, the car was cheap and a POS -- perfect for a high schooler like me at the time. When I was in high school, I got into three accidents in the car, two of which were my fault: (1) I spun out of control on a wet curve and jumped a curb (luckily, no other vehicles were involved), (2) I hit a Greensboro police officer while trying to make a left turn into a parking lot (a big pickup truck stopped to let me go and I didn't see the oncoming cop coming in the next lane over), and (3) someone rear-ended me near Hanes Mall. We got the car fixed up good as "new" every time.

A couple unique things about the car were (1) the spare tire was stored under the hood up front with the engine and (2) I could make the car backfire on demand. One time, I blew up the catalytic converter and muffler while trying to make the car do a huge backfire (all I had to do was get the RPMs up really high and then completely let go of the gas... BOOM!). It created a loud explosion. An innocent bystander described the sound like a shotgun blast. With a blown-out muffler, my little old wagon sounded like a muscle car.

I don't think the car had any airbags nor did it have anti-lock brakes, though I could be wrong. Also, the doors were incredibly light and flimsy. If I had ever been T-boned in that car, I definitely would have gotten seriously injured, if not, killed. Needless to say, I didn't feel very safe driving the car.

When I left North Carolina, I ended up taking the car with me to Georgia (Atlanta). In hindsight, I'm surprised the car made the 300+ mile trip. As soon as I arrived in Atlanta, the car developed transmission issues and lost its ability to reverse. We got it fixed, but that was effectively the end of my time the car. We sold it to a student in the NC mountains I estimate no more than one or two years after that.

Along with not being able to reverse, another memory I have of the car in Atlanta was trying to make it up a hill, from a stop, on to the interstate. The car was so weak that I frequently floored it and the engine would putter like a go-kart. It barely made it up the hill from Clairmont Road onto I-85 south. I associate that stretch of road with my struggling Subaru and will never forget it.

Other Subarus I drove were a gold 1990 (I think that was the year) Legacy wagon and a green 1998 Outback wagon. The Legacy was primarily driven by my aunt. I wasn't a fan of it, but it got the job done. The 1998 Outback wagon was my sister's and it was nice. It had a CD player and looked like a beefed-up wagon, approaching crossover territory. The Outbacks were sporty and trended towards the look and function of an SUV. My other sister had a mid-to-late 1980s Subaru wagon like mine as well. She drove it a lot between High Point and Raleigh (over 90 miles one way).

My cousins had Subarus too -- sedans. One of the sedans had a digital green speedometer which I though was cool. Another one of the sedans was a lemon and we returned it. It was a used sedan that kept having problems. One problem I remember was with the A/C. When one mechanic put the car on a lift and looked at the underside, it was revealed to us that the sedan was actually two different cars that were pieced/welded together. This was never disclosed to us by the seller, hence the return.

In the early 2000s, I really wanted a Forester or WRX. I guess you could say I was blindly loyal to Subaru. However, my parents gifted me a 2001.5 Volkswagen Passat which I have meticulously maintained and still drive to this day. Thanks for the good times, Subaru. Maybe we'll reunite someday.

We used Uber exclusively during our guys trip in Nashville this year. We had a car too, but when we needed to use a ridesharing service, we only used Uber.

Our Uber rides in Nashville, all within city proper, were incredibly affordable. All but one of our rides ranged in price from about $10 to $12 each. Our most expensive ride was $20. Each ride was split among 6 people, so it only cost a couple bucks per person per ride. Since we had 6 in our group, we had to call an UberXL each time. UberXLs have seating for up to 6 people. There are less UberXLs on the road compared to regular Ubers, but they were still pretty prompt in picking us up. We never had to wait long.

All of our rides were good except for one. We requested an UberXL. A driver showed up in a vehicle with enough seating. However, he was rude to us at the outset. When we opened the door to his car, he immediately leaned towards the open door, stuck his hand out, and adamantly told us to stop. He said he could only carry 6 people. Well that's how many we had. As he pulled his car up to us, I wonder if he miscounted or panicked when he saw our group on the sidewalk. When we told him we had 6 people, he let us into his car. He could have handled the situation better and been more polite.

The back seats of his car were uncomfortable. There was barely any legroom. All of the other UberXLs that we rode in were comfortable and had adequate legroom. I don't think this guy should have classified his vehicle as an UberXL even though his car technically had room for 6 passengers. Perhaps Uber should institute a legroom requirement for UberXL vehicles (if one doesn't exist already).

Aside from that one driver/vehicle, the rest of our Uber experiences in Nashville were fine. The other drivers were friendly.

Topgolf is great. I'm a big fan of the two locations where I live in Atlanta. So far, in my experience, all of the locations have been the same. They're pretty much carbon copies of each other. However, I believe Topgolf in Nashville is different than the other locations because it has a 600-person-capacity concert and event venue, called The Cowan, attached. This is the Music City after all.

This Topgolf is relatively new. It opened just a year ago, in September 2017, immediately north of downtown Nashville, next to the Cumberland River. The facility looks great with over 100 covered hitting bays, each with its own TV and seating. Some of the seats are lounge-style couches while others are more like a bar with high boys and tall chairs. This place offers more than just golf -- they have a full-service restaurant, multiple bars, and a rooftop terrace. Due to its size with multiple levels and private event spaces, Topgolf is great for parties. I've been to a Yelp event and a company party at Topgolf and had a blast.

You don't have to play golf to have fun here. It's a lot like going to a regular bar or sports bar, except this one is integrated with a cool-looking driving range.

If you've never been to Topgolf before, the concept is simple. This is more than just a driving range. It's similar to a bowling alley. Just like renting a lane at a bowling alley, you rent a hitting bay at Topgolf. Each bay can accommodate up to six players. Each player must purchase a Topgolf membership ($5). A membership to Topgolf is a one-time fee and your membership works at almost any Topgolf location. Prices per bay vary by time of day. The earlier you go, the less it costs.

Here are Topgolf Nashville's prices at the time of writing this review:

Open to 12pm: $25 per bay per hour
12pm to 5pm: $35 per bay per hour
5pm to close: $45 per bay per hour

You are charged per bay not per person, so the more people you have per bay (up to six people per bay), the less it costs per person. Conversely, the more people you have, the less balls each person hits. You can hit as many balls as you want per hour (unlimited).

We showed up around 12:40pm on a Friday and the place was already full. We had to wait about 15 minutes for a bay. We waited and ordered drinks at the main bar during that time. There are three levels. We were assigned to a hitting bay on the main (second) level. The first level is ground level. Levels two and three are elevated with, in my opinion, better views.

All the Topgolfs I've been to have nice views. The range looks neat because the targets are multicolored and each looks like a bullseye with several layers. Every golf ball at Topgolf has a microchip inside so that each ball can be tracked. This is how the system keeps track of your yardages and scores. Your scores and stats are recorded and saved to your membership which you can access online or via Topgolf's mobile app. Pretty handy.

There are many different types of golf games you can play. There's a touchscreen device at each hitting bay which allows you to pick a game and keep track of scoring. Scores are displayed both on the touchscreen and on a bigger screen for everyone sitting in the bay to see. There's a game for everyone, no matter the skill level. I think they're a lot of fun. Some games have you aim at certain targets while others have you focus on chipping or hitting long drives. The more accurate you are (the closer you hit your ball to the center of the target/right at the flag), the more points you get. You can also earn point bonuses and multipliers based on a variety of factors (type of game, consecutive hits, round number, etc.).

Each bay comes with its own set of men's and women's clubs. They're included with your bay rental. Each set for both men and women include a driver, 3-wood, 3-hybrid, 4-iron, 6-iron, 8-iron, and pitching wedge. Not a complete set, but good enough. There are also bag stands if you want to bring your own clubs. I've taken my own clubs before, but I don't really recommend it unless you're in a competition or really want to play with your own clubs. For casual fun, Topgolf's clubs are fine. I do suggest bringing a golf glove if you have one.

I don't recommend using Topgolf as a driving range to improve your golf game. Go to a standard driving range with real grass for that. It's cheaper.

Service was great. We ordered drinks, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic. They served rounds of canned Miller Lite beer in buckets of ice. I forget our server's name (a petite brunette with curly hair), but she was terrific; very kind and attentive.

If you're looking for a fun activity to do in Nashville, Topgolf fits the bill.

I'm giving Minibooths five stars mainly for the following three reasons:

1. They offer high-quality single image downloads.
2. They offer photo strips, with event "logo" and date, in both print and digital versions.
3. They offer animated GIF downloads of each session/strip.

I've experienced my fair share of photo booths at various events over the past 10+ years and I'm not sure I've encountered a photo booth company that offers all of the above download options like Minibooths does. I love sharing photos on social media and I appreciate how comprehensive Minibooths is in providing their customers/guests images in different formats.

As far as the photo booth experience itself, it's pretty much the same as photo booths by other companies. Minibooths had all the typical props such as funny headwear and goofy glasses. There was nothing too memorable or out of the ordinary. I remember masks for Captain America and Iron Man, Thor's hammer, a colorful plush hot dog, and a cartoony shark hat that looks like the shark is eating you when you put it on. The backdrop was physical as opposed to digital (green screen).

Four photos were taken per session/strip. The photo booth had an attendant and everything was controlled by the attendant (so no push-button-start, remote control, or anything like that). There were no options to enter our email address or phone number to receive pictures. We had to rely on the bride, who booked Minibooths, to provide us with a link and password to access the photo booth gallery on Minibooths's SmugMug site. Photos were available in a matter of days.

The attendant was nice and the quality of the photos was great.

We visited the Morris Arboretum of the University of Pennsylvania for a wedding and wow, what a venue. What was most impressive about this place, for a wedding venue, was where cocktail hour took place: on the "Out on a Limb" tree canopy walk 50 feet above the ground. How cool is that, to have drinks and hors d'oeuvres up in a tree canopy?

The setting was beautiful, especially at sunset, and it was unique. However, it wasn't perfect. The elevated walkways and standing areas were made of metal grates, so women couldn't wear stiletto heels. If you dropped a small object or something as thin as a phone (even with a protective case around it), the openings were big enough for you to lose them for good. Also, there was a bottleneck to the main platform. This caused problems when servers tried to pass around hors d'oeuvres. They sometimes couldn't make it past the narrow bridge to the main platform before running out of food. Finally, waste containers were few and far between. This caused used skewers, napkins, and cups to pile up on white tablecloth cocktail tables and that's not what those tables were meant for. Criticisms aside, I do think Out on a Limb was a really neat, memorable, and one-of-a-kind cocktail hour experience.

The wedding ceremony took place outdoors on the lawn in front of the arboretum's visitor center and shop. The lawn was on top of a small hill that had a nice view of the open blue sky. The weather was a little warm/hot, but otherwise sunny and perfect on this particular day. It was breezy during the ceremony. You could see it and hear it in the trees surrounding the lawn, and it was also picked up by the microphones. We sat near the front and could hear the couple recite their vows, but I'm pretty sure it was difficult for those sitting in the middle and back to hear. I'm guessing that's probably on the DJ and his equipment; just something to keep in mind if you're thinking about having a ceremony on the lawn.

From arrival before the ceremony through the reception, guests had access to the visitor center and shop, mainly to use restrooms. The visitor center has two floors and there are restrooms on both.

The time period before the ceremony was when we and other guests explored the arboretum. It normally costs $20 per adult to enter. I'm not a big nature/outdoors guy, so admittedly, I don't appreciate these kinds of places as much as others, like my fiancee (who once worked at a botanical garden), do. For those who don't know (I didn't), an arboretum is a botanical garden that generally showcases trees and other "woody plants" like shrubs and climbing plants like vines. We visited some gorgeous exhibits like the giant, whimsical willow sculptures (after searching online, I believe this exhibit may have been called "A Waltz in the Woods" by Patrick Dougherty) and the stately, ornate Rose Garden. We happened to catch both the bride and groom taking photos in both areas, so we must have stumbled upon two of the more picturesque places at the arboretum.

I recommend checking out Out on a Limb, A Waltz in the Woods, and the Rose Garden if you visit. They're all worth the time.

The reception mostly took place outside, around the back of the visitor center, in a covered patio space. There were about 150 guests. With the DJ, dance floor, and round tables, the space was fully utilized. It was a snug, but not uncomfortable, fit. Catering for cocktail hour and the reception was provided by Company's Coming Catering, one of the arboretum's five approved caterers. You can read my review of the catering company here: https://www.yelp.com/biz/companys-coming-catering-philadelphia-2. Both my fiancee and I, who are in the final stages of wedding planning ourselves, were impressed with Company's Coming, from the food to the service. The lower level space of the visitor center's interior was used for a wedding guestbook, gift/card reception box, bar, photo booth, and cake display/cutting.

All in all, we had a great time at the Morris Arboretum. I really enjoyed it. My fiancee said she "loved it" and considered this place a "hidden gem" (granted, we're not from the area, but this place had that kind of feel to her).

Benjamin Franklin's Burial Place is located within the Christ Church Burial Grounds (https://www.yelp.com/biz/christ-church-burial-ground-philadelphia-2). You can specifically find it at 499 Arch St, Philadelphia, PA 19106. The Burial Grounds are open, weather permitting, March-November, Monday-Saturday 10am-4pm and Sunday 12pm-4pm. While the grounds are only open limited hours, Benjamin Franklin's grave is viewable for free 24/7/365. He has a special fenced-in area that faces the sidewalk, street, and appropriately, the United States Mint, at the corner of Arch and N Independence Mall E.

We visited Benjamin Franklin's last resting place on a Sunday around 5:30pm. There was hardly anyone around. His grave consisted of a large, engraved marble slab with a bunch of coins - mostly pennies - tossed on top. The reason why is because Franklin (1706-1790) popularized the phrase: "A penny saved is a penny earned." Also, the "Franklin cent," the first official circulation coin of the US, was designed by Franklin and minted in 1787 (worth $0.01). On either side of the fence protecting the gravesite were brick walls and columns with honorary and informational plaques. One plaque included quotes about Franklin from George Washington, French Revolution leader Honore Gabriel Riqueti (Count of Mirabeau), and French statesman Jacques Turgot.

Franklin's wife Deborah Read is buried with him. His son, Francis Folger, and four other signers of the Declaration of Independence are buried nearby.

If you're visiting the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, you might as well swing by and visit Benjamin Franklin's Grave. It's only a couple blocks away. Other historic attractions nearby that are worth checking out include the National Constitution Center, Betsy Ross House, and Elfreth's Alley.

This place is awesome. One of the more memorable barbecue experiences I've had.

Martin's Bar-B-Que Joint has existed in the Nashville area since October 2006 with the opening of the company's first location in Nolensville, south of town. This location, in downtown Nashville, is relatively new. It opened in August 2016. At the time of writing this review, there are a total of five locations in and around Nashville and two in Louisville, Kentucky. Like Hattie B's, I hope Martin's opens a location where I live in Atlanta.

This downtown location is huge. It's probably the biggest barbecue restaurant I've been to. It's two stories with ample seating. This is a fast-casual restaurant where you stand in line, order and pay upfront, take a seat, and your food is brought to you. The first level contains a bar with 30 taps, a spacious dining room, and a covered and enclosed patio. It's all indoors. The second level is impressive. It's a large, indoor-outdoor space that contains two more bars (another one with 30 taps), an array of seating, a beer garden with a stage for live music, and games like table shuffleboard, table tennis, and darts (four boards). The decor upstairs is kitschy. One of the bars is decorated with pages and covers from professional wrestling magazines while one of the "rooms" consists of seating entirely from old automobiles. The seating upstairs is more communal with long picnic tables and high-tops. Overall, the atmosphere is relaxed and fun. It's one of the best things about this place.

This place is popular. We showed up on a Saturday shortly after opening (11am) and there was a small line. By the time we left, close to 1pm (we stuck around and played darts), there was a line down the sidewalk. The restaurant does not have dedicated parking. We parked in a nearby pay lot at the corner of 4th Ave S and Peabody St.

Martin's is known for West-Tennessee-style whole hog barbecue. They have four whole hog pits on-site. They don't freeze or microwave anything. Everything is cooked fresh daily.

Like other barbecue joints, you can get your barbecue served in a sandwich ($7.49-13.48 with or without a side) or on a tray ($11.99-17.99 with two sides). Meats include pulled whole hog, pulled pork shoulder, sliced beef brisket, sliced smoked turkey, bologna (sandwich only), smoked sausage, and chicken. There are also smoked wings (six for $7.99 up to 18 for $22.49) and ribs, both spares and smaller "babies" ($12.99 for four bones and two sides up to $25.99 for 12 bones and three sides).

There are apps like deviled eggs ($4.99) and catfish fingers ($7.99); salads and baked potatoes ($4.99-11.99); burgers and other sandwiches like a patty melt and pimento cheese club ($7.49-13.48 with or without a side); tacos, chicken tenders, and more ($12.99-14.99 with two sides). Desserts include items like pecan pie, strawberry cake (Saturday only), and Southern fried pie ($4.49-4.99). There's a kids menu, takeout-only family suppers (feeding anywhere from 2-12; $35.99-109.99), and sampler combos (feeding 1-7; $20.99-94.99).

Martin's has five barbecue sauces: (1) Jack's Creek - their signature sauce, (2) Sweet Dixie, (3) Alabama White, (4) Palmetto Gold - mustard-based, and (5) Devil's Nectar - spicy. Their menu has recommendations on what sauces go best with which meats.

Six of us shared the following for lunch:

* Big Poppa Sampler (feeds 6-7) ($94.99) - full rack ribs, 12 oz. pork, 12 oz. brisket, 1/2 chicken, and 3 pints of sides (we chose green beans, mac & cheese, and fresh-cut French fries)
* Six wings ($7.99) - tossed in Memphis dry rub
* Two orders of hush puppies - one order consists of four hushpuppies for $2.99
* Two cornbread hoecakes ($2.99 each)
* Drinks: assorted beer, bottles of Cheerwine, and water with nugget ice

We finished everything. I thought the meal was outstanding with eye-popping presentation.

I have to say the ribs were superb and probably my favorite meat followed by the wings. The ribs were covered in a generous amount of seasoning. They were meaty and delectable with great flavor and an appetizing consistency. The wings were terrific - crispy on the outside, moist on the inside. Very tasty. The brisket was my third-favorite. Thick-cut slices of beef with just the right amount of leanness and fattiness to each piece. The charred outer edges were wonderful as well. As for the chicken, it was a standout too. I had a thigh and was impressed with how flavorful and juicy the chicken was. Top notch. The skin had fantastic smoky flavor. The pork was good, pulled into tender and yummy strands.

Among the sides, my favorite, surprisingly, was the green beans. They were fresh, soft, cooked with onions and pork, and tasted excellent. The hush puppies were very good. They had a nice crunch and were warm and comforting. Both the mac & cheese and the fries were appetizingly addictive. The cornbread hoecakes were fine. Slices of white bread were also served with our order.

Service was great.

All time, the Philadelphia Union probably fall somewhere in the middle of Major League Soccer. In terms of number of seasons played (11 complete seasons to date), the Union are somewhere in the middle too.

2020 was the Union's best year yet. In 2020, the Union advanced to the semifinals of the MLS is Back Tournament. The team then went on to win the 2020 Supporters' Shield for having the best regular season record, as determined by the MLS points system. The Union finished with 47 points on the season with a 14-4-5 record during the pandemic-shortened 23-game season.

It's been a steady, consistent rise for the Union over the last four seasons under now seven-year head coach Jim Curtin. In 2017, the Union finished 16th out of 22 teams. In the years that followed, the Union finished 11th out of 23 teams, 5th out of 24 teams, and 1st out of 26 teams (2020). At this point, all that's missing is an MLS Cup win. Curtin has been head coach of the Union since June 2014.

Brazilian forward Sergio Santos, who made his first appearance with the Union in 2019, led the team in goals (11) during the team's Shield-winning season. French forward/winger Sebastien Le Toux leads the time all-time in goals (57; 2010-2011, 2013-2016).

The Union's home stadium is the 18,500-seat Subaru Park. The stadium was built for the Union and opened during the team's first season in 2010. It originally opened as PPL Park. Unlike Philly's other major pro sports teams' venues - the Eagles' Lincoln Financial Field, the Phillies' Citizens Bank Park, and the 76ers' Wells Fargo Center - Subaru Park is *not* located at the South Philadelphia Sports Complex. Instead, it's about a 16-mile, 20-minute drive down I-95 South in the city of Chester, on the other side of the airport.

Numerous pay parking lots surround Subaru Field. For a map, pricing, additional info, and to pre-pay and reserve parking in advance, visit https://www.philadelphiaunion.com/stadium/parking. Recently, the latest gameday parking prices have been anywhere from $32 to $45 per game.

One of my buddies moved to Nashville not too long ago and he chose to live at Element Music Row. It was easy to see why. This place was awesome. A group of us took a trip to Nashville and he set us up in one of Element Music Row's guest apartments. I enjoyed my stay.

Element Music Row opened in 2016 in the Music Row neighborhood of Midtown Nashville, just southwest of downtown. It's in the heart of Nashville's country music scene and situated in a prime location. The apartments are within walking distance to a lot of attractions and they're conveniently located just off the highway: I-40 exits 209A and 209B - Demonbreun Street. We walked to many restaurants and bars during our time here.

Element Music Row is a modern luxury apartment high-rise. The building is 19 stories tall and contains 431 apartments. On our first night, we grilled out on the patio next to the pool. The patio, along with the adjacent club room, had terrific views of the Nashville cityscape. The city views were definitely one of my favorite things about this place. There was a sink next to our grill which I thought was nice. The pool was a saltwater pool with cabana-style seating areas. It felt like a stylish resort.

We spent quite a bit of time in the club room. There, we played cards, shot pool, drank, and watched sports on TV. The club room, along with the rest of the property, was very modern and chic. I loved the clean and contemporary look of the building's interior. Whoever designed and decorated this place did a fantastic job. For such a modern apartment though, I thought it was funny they had a "Cyber Cafe" next to the club room.

The lobby was super bright and appeared to have a 24/7 concierge. The lobby had some comfortable seating areas and free Starbucks coffee. The self-serve, single-serve coffee machine had three roasts to choose from. The elevators had sleek displays playing the news and showing current date, time, and local weather information. As guests, we were able to park in Element Music Row's parking garage for free, but we needed to renew our parking pass (arranged for by our friend who is a resident) every 24 hours, if I recall correctly.

We paid $750 for three nights in our one-bedroom guest apartment ($250 per night). This wasn't a bad deal because this cost was split among multiple people. Three of us slept comfortably in the apartment: one in the bedroom, one on the pull-out sofa, and one in the walk-in closet on an air mattress (we had to bring the air mattress). The apartment was clean and quite spacious. The walk-in closet was big enough to be its own room, complete with power outlets. The apartment was nicer than the average Airbnb and it was almost like staying at a hotel. There were clean sheets, pillowcases, towels, and even soap, shampoo, and conditioner for us. No housekeeping or room service though.

Overall, I was pretty happy with the apartment and would stay here again.

The George Jones is many things. They include a:

1. Barbecue restaurant
2. Bar with live music (there are actually two bars and two stages)
3. History museum
4. Gift shop
5. Event space

The George Jones is named after a famous country singer by the same name. He's regarded by many to be the greatest country singer of all time. I'd never heard of him until my friend, who lives in Nashville, brought a group of us here for drinks late on a Friday afternoon. (I'm not a fan of country music.)

This is an ambitious business with a lot to offer. It's relatively new, having opened in 2015. It's located in downtown Nashville just off Lower Broadway. The place is multistory and looks nice. It's fairly spacious and modern with a cool rooftop patio that overlooks the Cumberland River and East Bank, directly across from Nissan Stadium (where the Tennessee Titans play).

There's a lot going on when you first enter from the street. You'll find the gift shop which has assorted George Jones merchandise and souvenirs. There's a big stage, bar, TVs (including a wall of connected TVs that form a single giant display), a variety of seating (communal and private tables, high boys, booths, etc.), and retractable garage-style doors that open up towards the river. It's somewhat of a sensory overload initially.

Aside from barbecue, the restaurant serves breakfast and brunch, soups, salads, and sandwiches, tacos, apps and sides, and desserts. These guys are on OpenTable if you want to make a free reservation and earn points that can be used towards future discounts at other restaurants or an Amazon gift card. This place works well as a sports bar because of all the TVs.

Admission to the museum costs extra -- $17 per adult, less for others like seniors, students, AAA members, military, and youth. You can purchase admission to the museum at the gift shop.

We spent most of our time hanging out on the rooftop patio where there's a second stage and bar. We accessed the rooftop from the main floor via elevator. A large portion of the rooftop is uncovered though several of the tables are covered with umbrellas or canopies. The patio has great views of the river and downtown. The stage and bar portion of the rooftop are covered. It was really hot the day of our visit so the staff had multiple misting fans running which was nice. Shade from the umbrellas and canopies was much-need (and appreciated) too.

Service was fine.

There were bands playing on both stages, upstairs and downstairs, which was kind of neat.

Overall, coming from someone who isn't much of a bar or country music person, I thought The George Jones was A-OK.

It doesn't take a Jack White fan to realize this place is pretty cool. This is the world headquarters of Third Man Records, Jack White's record label. I should preface this review by saying I am not a Jack White fan nor am I a huge fan of his genres of music, though I do like a couple of his songs: "Seven Nation Army" (2003) and "Another Way to Die" (2008). I came here because one of my buddies, who is a big Jack White fan, wanted to come here. He ended up buying some merchandise to take back home to Brooklyn.

Currently, there are two Third Man Records retail storefronts: this one in Nashville which opened in 2009 and one in Detroit which opened in 2015. This store is located in the SoBro (south of Broadway) neighborhood of downtown Nashville. There is no dedicated parking for customers, but there is plenty of free street parking on both 7th Ave S and Middleton St. We parked on Middleton. There were lots of spots available when we visited around 1:30pm on a Saturday. This isn't the nicest part of town, but we felt safe enough walking around the area in broad daylight.

The building looks cool. It looks like an old studio or warehouse that has been painted black/dark gray with bright solid yellow, red, and blue garage doors. The storefront looks like an album cover itself.

There's a lot going on at this location. It's a record store, "novelties lounge," offices and distribution center, photo studio, and live music venue. My friends and I only spent time in the record store and novelties lounge. It was packed when we arrived because a bunch of people had gathered to take a tour. According to Third Man Records' website, the store offers tours on Fridays and Saturdays at 2pm for $20 per person (first come, first served) with a limit of 10 tickets sold per tour. There were definitely more than 10 people taking the tour we saw and it started around 1:30pm instead of 2pm.

The record store and novelties lounge aren't very big. It was quite crowded and snug with all the customers, but once the folks on the tour left, there was much more space for us to spread out and explore. Both the record store and the novelties lounge are eclectically and uniquely decorated. I'm not quite sure how to describe it other than to say it's a combination of retro and kitsch... perhaps?

The novelties lounge is neat. It opened in 2012. It's called the "novelties lounge" because it has a bunch of working vintage machinery that you can actually use. They include a Scopitone 16mm film jukebox, a classic "fully automatic" photo booth where you can do "4 different poses" in only "2 minutes," a two-person listening booth with two turntables where you can preview records, and a really nifty 1947 Voice-O-Graph. For $20, you can use the Voice-O-Graph to record anything you want, up to about two minutes, on a 6-inch record.

You can hear what customers have recorded using the Voice-O-Graph on Third Man Records' website here: https://thirdmanrecords.com/locations/nashville-storefront/record-booth.

Another fun fact: Third Man Records is the only music venue in the world that records live performances directly to vinyl records.

Bertucci's is a Massachusetts-based brick oven pizza and pasta chain with numerous locations throughout the Northeast. You can find this one at Plymouth Meeting Mall in the northwest Philadelphia suburb of Plymouth Meeting. Bertucci's has an exterior storefront and patio on the north side of the mall near mall entrance #4.

We visited with a large group for Sunday lunch and I enjoyed it. The pizza and Coke hit the spot for me.

This is a spacious restaurant with an open kitchen and attentive staff. It's a great place for groups. There were over 20-30 in our group. We were seated in a separate, semi-private room off to the side. The fenced-in patio has several umbrella-covered tables. The open kitchen showcases the restaurant's brick oven. You can walk right up to it and the pizza and pasta prep counter. The lady that was doing the baking during our particular visit was friendly. It was fun watching the staff prepare ingredients and use the peels during the baking process.

Bertucci's offers about 10 different kinds of pizza with small sizes costing about $13-14 each and most large sizes about $22 each. You can also create your own pizza starting at similar prices. Their dough is made from scratch in house.

I had multiple slices of both the classic Bertucci pizza and the popular Sporkie pizza. The Bertucci is made with extra pepperoni, housemade tomato sauce, and extra mozzarella. It was good. You get pepperoni in every bite which I liked. The Sporkie comes with sweet Italian sausage, ricotta, mozzarella, and housemade tomato sauce. I can't say I preferred one pizza over the other. They were equally tasty. I really enjoyed the smooth, creamy clumps of ricotta and the piquant, savory pieces of Italian sausage. The pizza and ingredients tasted freshly made. The pizza slices were soft and floppy with nicely charred outer crusts, so they had a hint of smoky/burnt flavor. I piled on the red pepper flakes and couldn't stop eating. I kept grabbing slice after slice.

Along with pizza, Bertucci's menu features an assortment of Italian cuisine including apps like bruschetta and burrata ($8.99) and pan-sauteed mussels ($13.99), soups and salads, calzones ($13.99), entrees such as chicken Parm ($18.99) and grilled shrimp risotto formaggi ($18.99), pasta, and desserts (cannoli, tiramisu, etc.).

The restaurant was clean and the interior felt up-to-date. It also felt formulaic and like a chain (which it is).

In the end, I thought this place was fine (A-OK). It satisfied our pizza cravings in a clean and comfortable atmosphere.

At the time of writing this review, Reading Terminal Market (pronounced "Redding"), has over 5,100 Yelp reviews. That's a lot. It's easily one of the most-reviewed places I've visited. It's one of those popular "public" markets with a food hall and a bevy of vendors selling everything from fresh produce and flowers to handmade crafts and jewelry. A lot of big cities have them. Comparable markets include Chelsea Market in New York, the Ferry Building in San Francisco, and Pike Place Market in Seattle. In Atlanta, where I'm from, Reading Terminal Market ("RTM") reminds me most of Sweet Auburn Curb Market. New developments have popped up around the country in recent years that try to emulate a sort of old-school municipal market feel.

RTM is different because, unlike its newer counterparts, its atmosphere is genuine and not manufactured. The market opened in 1893, making it one of the country's oldest. Some of the market's vendors have been around since the very beginning, over 100 years, like Bassetts Ice Cream. You can find them just inside one of the 12th Street entrances on the west side of the market. This is where we entered.

This is a Philadelphia hot spot and one of the most recommended places for out-of-towners to go. We visited over the weekend and the market was crowded with tourists and locals alike. It should definitely be high on any foodie's Philly to-do list. There are so many food stalls here and the selection is eclectic, from Amish-style rotisserie chicken, sourced regionally, from Dienner's Bar-B-Q Chicken to Peking duck from Sang Kee Peking Duck (an RTM outpost of a Philly Chinatown favorite).

In all, there are over 80 vendors packed onto one floor. They're classified into the following categories: bakeries, beverages, dairy & cheese; housewares, books, crafts, etc; meats & poultry, Pennsylvania Dutch (note the PA Dutch vendors are closed every Sunday), produce, restaurants, seafood, and specialty foods. The market is laid out in a grid with four large aisles going north-south, and 11 smaller aisles going east-west. There are a handful of communal seating areas (almost all seats were taken during our visit), restrooms (clean enough), and an attended welcome booth if you'd like to pick up a map and/or ask for recommendations. Some of the vendors also have their own dedicated seating.

A few recommendations:

1. Roast pork sandwich at Tommy DiNic's Pork & Beef. Perhaps the most popular vendor here. They offer wraparound counter service.

2. Pretzel from Miller's Twist. These are fresh-made, Amish-style pretzels. They're also known for their cheddar-jalapeno pretzel dog and breakfast foods. (Note: Miller's Twist is a PA Dutch vendor and is closed on Sundays.)

3. Scrapple from Down Home Diner. Also known as Pannhaas by the PA Dutch, this is basically pork scraps made into a savory pate. Reminds me of the Neese's liver pudding (livermush) I ate growing up in North Carolina.

Surprisingly, there's not really a well-known or recommended vendor for cheesesteaks here though there are some who sell them (e.g. Carmen's Famous Italian Hoagies & Cheesesteaks). Bring cash because some vendors, like Carmen's, are cash-only. A couple places that caught our eye that we didn't get to try were Pearl's Oyster Bar and Mueller Chocolate Co. (featured on Food Network).

There are two parking garages, one at 12th and Filbert (Parkway Garage) and the other at 11th and Arch (Hilton Garage). Signs posted at each entrance to the market advertised 2-hour discount parking with $10 market purchase and validation at the vendor.

If you're pressed for time in Philly, Reading Terminal Market is a great place to visit since there are so many vendors all in one place. If you're from out of town, be sure to visit the northwest corner of the market where all the PA Dutch vendors are located. They're unique.

When I first moved to Atlanta in the early 2000s, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers were often a formidable opponent. The Bucs and the Falcons have been in the same division, the NFC South, since 2002. They formed the NFC South division with the Falcons, Carolina Panthers, and New Orleans Saints that year. That same season, the Bucs won the Super Bowl (Super Bowl XXXVII) against the Oakland Raiders, 48-21.

Coincidentally, that was coach Jon Gruden's first year with the Bucs after spending the first four years of his NFL head coaching career with the Raiders. Gruden would eventually wind up with a 57-55 record with the Bucs, spanning seven seasons (2002-2008). Over that period, the Bucs won the division three times (2002, 2005, 2007).

My favorite Madden NFL game by EA Sports was Madden NFL 2004 for the PlayStation 2. I liked that edition the best because it featured Mike Vick on the cover and he was awesome to play as in a video game. He played for the Falcons at the time. The game was released in late summer 2003 which meant the Bucs were good. They were the reigning champs.

The 2000s Bucs had players like Derrick Brooks (LB), Warren Sapp (DT), Mike Alstott (FB), John Lynch (SS), Ronde Barber (CB), and Simeon Rice (DE).

At the time of writing this review, the Bucs all-time record against the Falcons is 25-28 so it's been a pretty even and competitive series between the two teams.

Unfortunately, the Bucs haven't done much since the Gruden era. After losing in the Wild Card playoffs in January 2008 (2007 season), the Bucs have routinely finished in 3rd or 4th place in the NFC South. Granted, the division has been quite strong and competitive some years such as in 2010 when the Falcons went 13-3, the Saints went 11-5, and the Bucs went 10-6, but more often than not, the Bucs have been well below .500. Since Gruden, they've had five different head coaches in 11 seasons -- that's roughly one coaching change every two years.

In the 2015 NFL Draft, the Bucs drafted QB Jameis Winston with the 1st overall pick. In 2013, as a redshirt freshman, Winston led Florida State to the national championship. I thought the Bucs made a good pick. However, for various reasons (including playing through injury), Winston's career with the Bucs never panned out. He led the Bucs to only one season above .500 (and it was just one game above .500, 9-7, in the 2016 season). He made the 2016 Pro Bowl (2015 season). In the 2019 season, Winston threw seven pick-sixes which set an NFL record. After that season, he became a free agent.

On March 20, 2020, the Bucs signed QB Tom Brady to a two-year deal that included both no-trade and no-tag clauses. Brady had spent the first 20 (!) years of his legendary career with the New England Patriots. He begins his first season with the Bucs at age 42. About a month after Brady's signing, his former Pats teammate Rob Gronkowski announced he was coming out of retirement. On April 21, 2020, the Pats traded Gronk to the Bucs so he could rejoin Brady. Also, on September 2, 2020 (the date of this review), the Bucs signed Leonard Fournette to a one-year deal. It's like the Miami Heat over here.

We had a wonderful dinner at The Pharmacy Burger Parlor & Beer Garden in East Nashville. If you like burgers, fries, soda, ice cream, shakes, and beer, then this is the place for you.

The Pharmacy opened in December 2011 and is sort of a throwback to the old-fashioned soda fountains that drugstores used to have, hence the name of the business. They make their own sodas, which they call "phosphates," and associated syrups in-house. In addition to the food and drink mentioned above, The Pharmacy also specializes in German sausages. So, along with the outdoor beer garden, this place has a German slant to it.

The Pharmacy is located in a primarily residential neighborhood. There's really no dedicated parking lot for the restaurant, except for maybe in the back. Plenty of free street parking exists in the immediate area. We parked along W Eastland Ave, right in front of the restaurant.

We showed up around 7:30pm on a Saturday night, peak dinner time. The restaurant was slammed with lots of customers waiting on the sidewalk outside. The Pharmacy doesn't take reservations. You can, however, use the Nowait app to get on their wait list before you arrive. This is what we did and it saved us a lot of time. Our party was called shortly after we arrived, so we hardly had to wait.

The restaurant is fairly spacious with multiple sections of seating, inside and out. There are two bars, one inside and one outside. We sat outside in the beer garden which I thought was pleasant thanks to the cooperating weather. The beer garden, which is fenced-in, contains many picnic tables with trees and various shrubbery surrounding. Some of the tables have umbrellas. String lights decorate the space. Overall, it's a laid back, casual atmosphere.

Sausages, which are housemade, come with sauerkraut, mustard, and a side for $11 each. They have a half-dozen different kinds of sausage. The Pharmacy's burgers and chicken sandwiches come on buns made fresh daily by Provence Breads & Cafe, a local artisan bread baker. The burgers are made from beef from Tennessee cattle. There are over a dozen burger and sandwich offerings priced at $9-11 each including a side. You can customize any burger or sandwich with extra toppings costing anywhere from $0.50 to $2 each. Sodas cost $2.50 to $3.50 each with ice cream sodas, shakes, and malts $5 each. The ice cream comes from The Pied Piper Creamery, a local handmade ice cream parlor.

The beer menu is sizable with many German beers on tap and bottled. They carry a lot of local and domestic craft brews too. In addition, they offer cider and a handful of wines, both by the glass and bottled.

We ordered a Biergarten Platter ($17) for the table. It's a sausage sampler that comes with any three wurst, kraut, horseradish mustard, beer mustard, and a side. For our wurst, we chose Jagerwurst (pork wurst with coriander, garlic, mustard seed, nutmeg, and ginger), Currywurst (classic brat poached and simmered with pils beer, topped with curried paprika and tomato sauce), and Bockwurst (beef and pork wurst with schwarzbier - black beer, dark lager). For our side, we chose tater tots. The platter also came with a couple pieces of grilled bread which the menu didn't specify.

The Biergarten Platter was delicious and I recommend it. I can't say I preferred one sausage over another because they were all equally good. Each sausage was flavorful and savory and each had its own distinct taste. The sausages were served up hot. They were firm on the outside and delectably soft on the inside. They had some nice char too. The mustards and kraut paired well. I liked the thicker horseradish mustard over the beer mustard, but both were yummy. The tots were par for the course which means they were scrumptious. I haven't encountered many places with bad tots.

I ordered a Pharmacy Burger ($9) for myself. The Pharmacy cooks their burgers medium well by default so that's how I had mine (I normally like to order my burgers medium or medium rare). The Pharmacy Burger is pretty basic. It comes with yellow cheddar, iceberg lettuce, tomato, onion, pickles, and yellow mustard. I got hand-cut fries for my side. The portion size for this meal was large. The burger was big and filling. While I wouldn't put it among the best burgers I've had, it was still quite enjoyable and memorable. The bun was certainly unique. It was soft and buttery. The fries were fine. They were more on the soft than crispy side.

I had to try one of the sodas so I got the Creamiscle ($3.50). The Creamsicle is made with orange soda, cream, and vanilla syrup. It was excellent. I'm really glad I got it. It was ice cold, refreshing, sweet, creamy, and had an appetizing bite to it. The Pharmacy's sodas are made without any preservatives, caffeine, corn syrup, or artificial flavorings. I suggest trying one.

"Grace Anatomy" was our server and she did a great job. All of our orders came out in a reasonable amount of time and we had no issues service-wise.

Aside from the New York Yankees, no team in baseball has won more World Series titles than the St Louis Cardinals. The Cards have won 11 titles which is more than storied franchises such as the Athletics (9), Red Sox (9), Giants (8), and Dodgers (7). It's the most championships of any National League team. Since their first championship in 1926, the Cards have had a long, sustained success with multiple World Series appearances in every decade except for a few (1950s, 70s, and 90s). The Cards' latest World Series wins were in 2006 and 2011 and the team's last appearance in the Fall Classic was in 2013.

The Cards' success in the 2000s and 2010s has been under current owner and chairman Bill DeWitt Jr. DeWitt, along with other partners, purchased the team from Anheuser-Busch in 1995. Since then, the Cards have won the two aforementioned World Series (2006, 2011) and four NL pennants (2004, 2006, 2011, 2013) and made the postseason 15 times. Also during this span, Cards players and managers have racked up numerous awards, most notably Albert Pujols.

Pujols is a for-sure future Hall of Famer. With the Cards, he was named the NL MVP three times (2005, 2008, 2009) and was the unanimous NL Rookie of the Year in 2001. To go along with Pujols' MVP award in 2005, Cards starting pitcher Chris Carpenter won the 2005 NL Cy Young Award. Both Pujols and Carpenter were on the 2006 and 2011 championship teams. Additionally, Cards shortstop David Eckstein was named World Series MVP in 2006 and third-baseman David Freese was named World Series MVP in 2011. In the DeWitt era, former manager Tony La Russa (2002) and current manager Mike Shildt (2019) have been named NL Manager of the Year.

The Cards' current home, Busch Stadium III, is the biggest stadium in the NL Central Division and it's one of the biggest in the National League at approximately 45,500 seats. The current stadium opened in April 2006, just in time for the Cards' 10th World-Series-winning season. To date, the Cards have a 7-3 record at home at Busch Stadium III in World Series games.

Parking at Busch Stadium is available in the Starr Lot across from Gate 2. For a map and to purchase parking passes in advance, visit https://www.mlb.com/cardinals/tickets/parking. Parking passes are now delivered digitally via MLB's Ballpark app. It's the same app you use for tickets. You can also find, pay, and reserve parking using the app SpotHero.

Masala Kitchen Kati Rolls and Platters really hit the spot after a long day of traveling. The rolls here were cooked to order and delicious. They were also affordable and served up fast. What more can you ask for?

We had a late check-in at our hotel and were hungry. We ended up leaving our hotel for dinner around 11:15pm. I looked on Yelp for a good, quick, casual place to eat that was also open late. We were tired and I didn't feel like eating at a sit-down restaurant. Masala Kitchen popped up and checked all the boxes. They're open until 3:30am on Friday and Saturday nights. A friend also recommended this place to us.

This is a small fast-casual restaurant located in Center City, just four blocks from Philadelphia City Hall. It's right next to the entrance of a public parking garage. Seating inside is limited to about 24 seats. They have standard two-tops with Tolix chairs and a couple long high-tops with Tolix stools.

During our visit late on a Friday night between 11pm-12am, there was a small, but steady stream of customers. Most of the orders were takeout and delivery. We were the only dine-in customers at the time. The restaurant had plenty of staff on-hand. The kitchen is open. Bottled and canned drinks (from a fridge), sauces, eating utensils, and napkins are self-serve. The space itself is simple and looked relatively new and clean. The ambiance is that of a takeout joint. Since this restaurant is close to a lot of bars, it's perfect for those wanting a late-night snack or meal after a night on the town.

The menu is in the business name: kati rolls and platters. Kati rolls are an Indian street food from Kolkata (Calcutta), West Bengal. Masala Kitchen offers 14 varieties of kati rolls, ranging in price from $4.50 to $5.75 a roll. Buy two kati rolls, get $1 off. One or two rolls is good enough for a meal for most people. Ingredient options include chicken, beef, lamb, paneer (cheese), egg, vegetables, potatoes, Indian spices, and more.

The platters remind me of the platters you can get from The Halal Guys. For example, they have a Chicken-N-Rice platter ($8.75) and the self-serve sauces are similar too -- creamy white and spicy red. In addition, you can get biryani ($9.25-$10.00 each) and a paneer platter ($10). Drinks include mango and rose lassi ($3.70 each), chaas (an Indian yogurt drink, $3.70), masala chai ($3), and more.

The two of us ordered and split the following three rolls:

* Chicken Masala ($5.75) - marinated grilled chicken with Indian creamy tomato sauce "Makhani" and crispy onions
* Achari Paneer ($5.50) - marinated paneer with hint of mango pickle sauce, fresh mint-coriander chutney, and crispy onions
* Mix Veggie ($5.50) - fresh pea, carrot, and green bean mixture cooked in Indian spices with fresh mint-coriander chutney and crispy onions plus egg (+$0.50)

These rolls were great. My favorite was the achari paneer, but I'm fan of paneer. Everything was made fresh to order and came out piping hot. Each roll was wrapped in brown paper and Sharpied to identify the rolls.

The kati rolls are wrapped in what the restaurant calls a "tawa roti." Traditionally, tawa refers to the round, flat metal griddle used in Indian cooking. The roti here had a nice thickness to it, soft, and kind of fluffy with a sort of pillowy texture, lightly charred and appetizing. I like to describe Masala Kitchen's kati rolls as the Indian equivalent of the Taco Bell Chalupa or Gordita. In terms of the shell/wrap, they are more similar to the Gordita (softer, less crispy, not deep fried).

Each of the rolls was packed with flavor. If you like Indian food, I don't think the kati rolls here will disappoint you. The authentic, aromatic, and mouthwatering flavors were all there. The Mixed Veggie roll had a mushier consistency than the other rolls, but that wasn't surprising given the ingredients. I think adding egg to that roll really enhanced it. On the menu and item descriptions above, "crispy onions" refer to fresh, raw slices of red onion.

For sauces, I recommend getting a cup of the white sauce, adding a little bit of red to it, and mixing them together. The red sauce is quite spicy so a little goes a long way. The sauces by themselves are tasty too, so really it's a matter of personal preference. I dipped the rolls into the sauce mixture each time I took a bite. Yum.

Vaishali was our server and she was nice. Masala Kitchen uses the Revel POS system. Transactions, including tipping, are handled on a tablet and you can send yourself an itemized receipt.

The Praline Connection makes a mean po' boy.  The restaurant is located just outside the French Market on Frenchman St, in a lower-key, musically-influenced area of town.  I was looking forward to trying out their fried oyster po' boy, but unfortunately, the restaurant was out of oysters.  They use only Louisiana oysters and because of the oil spill in the Gulf, they cannot serve any dishes with oysters.  Boo.

I subbed in a fish (catfish, I assume) po' boy instead and it was delectable.  It had catfish, shredded lettuce, slices of tomato, mayo, and pickles, inside a loaf of French bread.  With a side of fries, it was yummy and filling.

Small note on the fries: the menus have printed the fries are only $1.50 extra when ordered with a po' boy.  However, the restaurant charged us $2.00 and the server told us there was a sign out front that noted the change.  The menus still say $1.50 though.  The restaurant needs to correct this.  How are you just going to leave incorrect pricing in your menu (50 cents isn't a lot, but it's the principle)?

We were told by our waitress to try their fried chicken next time.  The waiters and waitresses are dressed in white dress shirts and black slacks with black top hats and suspenders.  The floor is tiled in black and white tiles.  The restaurant is connected to a small praline/candy shop where you can buy fresh daily-made pralines.  The pralines are about $2 apiece.  I bought a few of the original on my way out and they were pretty good.  Super sugary for sure.

We walked over to Tennessee Brew Works, one of Nashville's popular craft breweries, after hitting up Jack White's Third Man Records shop nearby. Both businesses are located in Pie Town, a neighborhood on the southern edge of downtown Nashville. There's not a whole lot of stuff in this part of town. These are definitely two of the highlights.

Tennessee Brew Works opened on August 18, 2013. It's popular. This place has won numerous awards and earned plenty of recognition including the best brewery in Tennessee according to Yelp. These folks are all about being local, green, and sustainable. The taproom is two stories with views of the brewery from both floors. There's a patio with both covered and uncovered spaces (mostly uncovered) as well as a small, string-lit rooftop patio. As this is a brewery, the property has an industrial, warehouse feel to it, much like the other businesses in Pie Town. It's clean and modernized. The first floor of the brewery features a small stage for live music (a band was setting up on our way out) and the room upstairs, which is much more spacious, has TVs playing sports and nice overhead views of the brewery floor below.

Brewery tours take place every Saturday at 3pm, 4pm, and 5pm. It costs $10 plus tax and a fee per person. Tickets for the tour can be purchased online.

Along with high-quality craft beer, the brewery also serves food. Their limited menu includes apps/snacks like Baja fish tacos, Springer Mountain chicken wings, salads, burgers, and sandwiches (including a Nashville Hot Chicken Sandwich). Food prices range from $8 to $18 per plate.

We grabbed a few beers and hung out inside the taproom downstairs. Downstairs, they use barrels (some with tabletops) for tables with bar stools. We showed up around 2pm on a Saturday and the place was busy. It wasn't slammed or jam-packed, but most of the tables upstairs and downstairs were taken. Our group of six was lucky to find a table in a corner next to some brewery windows. The atmosphere was very relaxed and laid back. The staff was cool and friendly. We all enjoyed our time here.

I don't think Tennessee Brew Works has dedicated parking. We parked for free on the street (Middleton Street because we also went to Third Man Records). This isn't the nicest neighborhood so I wouldn't leave any valuables in your car.

Logan Circle, also known as Logan Square, is a public park located in the center of the Logan Square neighborhood (yes, same name) in Philadelphia. It's managed by the city's Parks & Rec department. This is a great sightseeing spot in Philly. I recommend it. The views are beautiful.

Some quick Q&A:

1. Why is it called Logan Circle?

Because it serves as a major traffic circle for Benjamin Franklin Parkway (https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia), connecting it to North 19th Street, Vine Street, and Race Street.

2. Why is it called Logan Square?

Because it was one of five squares originally planned for the city in 1864 by William Penn, founder of Pennsylvania.

3. Who is the circle/square named after?

James Logan, 14th mayor of Philadelphia.

Logan Circle is actually surrounded by three other parks: Aviator Park, Sister Cities Park, and Shakespeare Park (small). Combined, the land area for these four parks, including the roads (Benjamin Franklin Parkway is wide and scenic) is about four city blocks. So for a city park, it's not huge, but not small neither.

The highlight of Logan Circle is a large fountain in the center called the Swann Memorial Fountain: https://www.yelp.com/biz/swann-memorial-fountain-philadelphia-2. We visited on a bright and sunny Sunday afternoon and the park was filled with people, both locals and tourists. Even though there were signs that said no swimming in the fountain, I can't tell you how many kids I saw swimming and playing in the fountain. A lot. It almost looked more like a pool or water park than a historic fountain.

Logan Circle is centrally-located between Philadelphia City Hall and the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Rocky Steps: https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia). Benjamin Franklin Parkway connects all of it. If you've never been to Philly before and want to sight-see, I think walking the parkway between city hall and the museum is a must. Including the aforementioned adjacent parks, Logan Circle is surrounded by sights and attractions including the Franklin Institute, the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University, and the Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul.

Note: At the time of writing this review, there's another Yelp listing for Logan Circle. It's called Logan Square Park: https://www.yelp.com/biz/logan-square-park-philadelphia. Technically, the two listings should be merged, but the Yelp moderators disagree.

I had a great experience with Assurant. I purchased my old Google Pixel phone from the Google Store (online). One of the options I could add to my phone was Device Protection for $99. Device protection is the same thing as phone insurance and Assurant was the provider.

The coverage I purchased was good for two years from the date I received my phone. The maximum number of accidental damage repairs or replacements under Device Protection was two during the coverage period. My Pixel's camera lenses, both front and back, got scratched. The scratches caused light streaks in my photos and videos so I decided to file a claim and get a replacement.

Per the Device Protection welcome and terms and conditions email I got from Assurant, I filed my claim at https://mydeviceprotect.com/. It was really quick and easy to do, especially since Assurant had most of my information on file from my phone's IMEI/serial number. I filed my claim on a Friday night. In less than 24 hours, someone from Assurant called to verify my information and approve my claim. I received a claim approval email after the call and a shipping notification that Monday (first business day after my claim was approved). I received my replacement Pixel on Tuesday afternoon; basically, in two business days. Fast!

I did have to pay a $79 deductible, but it was totally worth it to me. It was like I got a brand new Pixel for only $178 ($99 for Device Protection + $79 deductible). Technically, the phone was refurbished, but it looked and worked like new - the battery too, which was huge, since my old battery was on its way out. Considering my particular phone model at the time, a 32-GB Pixel 1, originally retailed for $649, I thought this was a good deal. Plus, I had one more replacement remaining on my contract before my two years were up. It was nice to have that peace of mind.

Google made it easy to transfer all of my apps and data from my old Pixel to my new Pixel. I just connected the two phones with a USB-C cable and followed the prompts. The entire transfer took about an hour (my new Pixel had to download and install almost 100 apps). I was really pleased with how simple and seamless the transition was. My old phone was essentially mirrored to my new one which was exactly what I wanted. I did have to set up new fingerprint recognition and log in to all of my apps again, but that was it. I was back up and running with a "new" phone with hardly any interruption.

I returned my old Pixel in the same packaging that my new Pixel came in. Assurant emailed me a shipping label to print and tape to the outside of the box. I had to return my old Pixel within 14 days from the date my new Pixel was shipped. Otherwise, I could've been charged an "unrecovered equipment fee" of up to $2,000.

In the end, I am very happy with the Device Protection I purchased from Assurant. I already bought it again for my latest phone, the Pixel 3, for $129 (unsurprisingly, the insurance price went up).

The Philadelphia Phillies are one of the oldest American professional sports franchises, established in 1883. Unlike other storied teams, the Fightin' Phils have never left their original city.

It took nearly 100 years, but the Phillies were able to win their first World Series championship in 1980 and then again, 28 years later, in 2008. In 1980, future Hall-of-Famer and perhaps the greatest third baseman of all time, Mike Schmidt, led Philadelphia to a 4-2 series win over the Kansas City Royals. In 2008, four-time All-Star pitcher Cole Hamels led Philly in a dominating series performance over the Tampa Bay Rays, 4-1. (Since 2020, Hamels has played for my favorite team, the Atlanta Braves.)

The Phillies play at Citizens Bank Park, located in South Philly. The ballpark opened in 2004 and is part of the South Philadelphia Sports Complex which includes the adjacent Lincoln Financial Field (home of the NFL's Philadelphia Eagles) and Wells Fargo Center (home of the NBA's Philadelphia 76ers).
