Oh, and did I mention the coffee is INSANELY good? Because it truly is.

Okay, back to feigning the francais.  7 years of French classes have left me with only a gaping void.  Apparently, no one in the Midwest speaks French.  Not that I really can anymore, either.  But to snag a table at City Coffee House & Creperie, with my reporter's notebook in hand, feels... well, French.  Or at least channels a throwback to the "Sex and the City" episodes in which Carrie briefly lived in Paris.

If you want to sit outside, get here early (read: before 9:30 am).  My sister and I easily accomplish this as her 17-month-old daughter wakes up at the crack of dawn on the weekends, er, 7 am.  If you don't have one of those, be sure to set your alarm because the Creperie draws a crowd.

And don't get discouraged by the line at the counter-- this moves very quickly.  Crepes are thin, so they cook fast.  Use this time wisely to study the elaborate menu, which is scrawled out on a chalkboard!  Tres francais! Though they also serve sandwiches and pastries, order a crepe and some coffee.  Do as the name suggests and you won't be disappointed!

The crepes run the gamut from savory to sweet.  My personal favorites are the Clayton Club, the Banana with brown sugar and sour cream, and the classic Nutella. The Lemon Curd is also fantastic, but for some reason, they skimp on the decadently rich yet tart filling. A perfect portion if you're not ravenous, though.

If you're hard-pressed to make a decision, I'd recommend the Banana with brown sugar and sour cream crepe. Actually, I order this one time and time again :)

Parking is easy as meters abound on Brentwood and there is also a metered parking lot adjacent to the Creperie.

Bon Appetit!

One large group + light but insistent rain + an overly-crowded Whiskey Kitchen = After-dinner drinks conundrum.
 
Ack.

We were ready to give up and head back to the Hutton for drinks in the lobby bar, when our lovely local tour guide nudged us next door to Virago. And I'm glad she did for otherwise we would've missed a real Nashville hot spot!

So baby, it's a scene all right - it's dark and slick and sophisticated, but still tinged with that unmistakable Southern hospitality. Seriously, are all Nashvillians born with honey in their voice? Right off the bat, our sweet server offered to take separate checks for our group of 10 or so. Thanks, but luckily we've got some manners, too! 

I ordered a drink with strawberry puree, St. Germain and cava... easy does it! I believe it was called a Strawberry Sparkle. Or maybe it was Strawberry Smash. In any case, it's delicious alliteration. If I ever get asked 'if you were a drink, which one would you be?' in an icebreaker game again, I now know the answer! 

So they do sushi, too. Go see. Be seen. Check the scene. Sex and the city? Oh yes.

I've been going to Kaya's for a decade now. Yes it's in a strip mall, but once inside, you'll find a collection of wine and spirits that will make you forget you're in South County. Personally, I frequent Kaya's for the extensive selection of Croatian wine, beer and liquor, but they do a swell job of stocking other worldly spirits.

Every Friday from 5-8pm, Kaya hosts a wine tasting and also serves complimentary cheese, sausage and crackers. Check it out! You're also welcome to purchase a bottle onsite and enjoy it without being charged a corkage fee. 

Don't be surprised if you find yourself walking out with gifts for every family member... Kaya's has something for the imbiber in everyone!

There's a time and a place for a large local supermarket like Schnuck's and a time and a place for Starrs.

Starrs time:
- You'd like some personalized advise on selecting wine or craft beer.
- You're searching for a hard-to-source wine or beer.
- You'd like to take your time to shop sans crowded aisles and grocery cart bumps.
- You enjoy supporting small local businesses.
- You want to impress your boss/potential girlfriend/family with a unique buy.
- You're an oenophile or craft beer connoisseur.

Schnuck's time:
- You're nowhere near Starrs.

I was bamboozled.

Well, not really as I walked out of Saks with an *enhanced* appearance (courtesy of loads of Chanel make-up), but all that prettification sure did cost a pretty penny.

Because I put together a half-assed halfway to Mardi Gras costume consisting of only a long, light purple wig, I needed a dramatic face that could pull its weight. One with super long, fluttery eyelashes (read: faux) and smoldering eyes. I, unfortunately, am not competent when it comes to fake lash application nor at creating the smoky look... sigh.

I first stopped by the MAC counter, knowing full well that they make the best fake lashes and are awesome at creating a theatrical look (also - they're relatively inexpensive among department store cosmetics brands). But alas, they were booked solid and a sales associate at Chanel coaxed me to her chair. After asking what the minimum spend would be to get my make-up done (3 products or $75), I restrained my inner thriftonista, remembering I was also on a strict time budget. Proceed, lady in black!

And so she did. 45 minutes later, I was transformed into a va-va-voomin' vixen with a sexy, smoky eye, mile-long eyelashes (purchased from MAC), what appeared to be cheekbones (oh, hello!) and a demure, rosy lip to balance the strong eye look. Now, for my (not really necessary) product picks: blush, liquid eyeliner and a Glossimer lip gloss. Total cost? $112. Gulp.

But my make-up endured the test of 12 hours out and my new Chanel products will last much longer. When shopping at pricey department stores like Saks, it's best to go in knowing exactly what you need as saying 'yes, I'll take that!' just one too many times can easily result in a 4-digit spend. While the sales associates warm up as you spend some time with them, I did find their reception initially chilly... and a bit too 'sales-y' for my taste. Guess I'll always be a Nordstrom kind of gal - all the brands I want without the pressure or pretense!

Sugga, sugga!

Just because I ended my meal with a dessert (an oversized slightly gooey sugar cookie) doesn't mean I can't start my review with an homage to the sweet. Well done, Fido!

So Fido is this totally cute, totally happenin', totally cool coffehouse/eatery. There's tons of space so you can grab your co-workers for a group meal or to sprawl and sneak in a working lunch. Or, you can do like us and accomplish both!

They serve breakfast all day (huge plus for me, as sometimes I like to have pancakes for dinner), as well as a strong collection of specialty coffee drinks, artisan sandwiches, salads and larger plates. I tried the flank steak sandwich with swiss, roasted onions, garlic mayo, lettuce (hold the tomatoes) on herbed focaccia. GONE in 10 minutes flat... take that Nic Cage!

Yet another reason to frequent Fido? Their mission to find homes for displaced dogs. A feel-good operation right here in Nashville, indeed!

Why why why why why? Why do I continue to eat here?

It's a love/hate relationship.

Rationale: they've got a 24/7 drive-thru (I've never seen them close) that happens to be around the corner from my brother's abode. Convenience is the name of this late-night game... oh Del Taco, you're my faux Mexican booty call!

True story: I found my little dream home driving to Del Taco hungover one morning in a quest for a breakfast burrito. Saw an open house sign, wandered in, fell in love, called my parents and the rest is history! I lived in this cute little house for 4 years before moving, and now it's my brother's nest. Thanks Del Taco!

I'm almost reticent to ask, but does a better beer garden than McGurk's even exist? Anywhere?

Whether I'm craving a liquid lunch or a low-key evening out, McGurk's is my go-to pub in St. Louis. They do reubens and fish and chips well, hell, even the most discriminating Irish lad would be proud. And the live music-- the bands actually hail from Ireland and if you stick around late enough, you may find yourself in a battle of shots type o'war. Proceed with caution ;)

The service can be spotty... I lounged in the beer garden this past Friday afternoon and the late lunch rush left us waiting... and waiting... but 9/10 times, I'm a happy, full and sometimes tipsy girl.

Lots of good beer on draught. And did I mention the beautifully landscaped beer garden? Come, sit and tip back a perfect pour of Guinness with me... on that note, I may be heading there right now!

Solid dive-o-rama fun.

Pitchers for $5.50, a jukebox full of gems, GREAT wings and a staff that will remember your name and save your bar stool! Though the management has changed, you'd be hard-pressed to NOT find the same guys perched at the end of the bar on the stools closest to the door.

Back when I lived in this 'hood, we'd trudge through almost a mile of snow for a blissfully low-key night at J & A's. Oh how I miss Mary the bartender! But still a great spot to catch up with friends while putting away cheap brew and good eats. And, for you single ladies out there, local rugby teams such as the Bombers have long made J & A's their after-game destination. Cheers!

When I'm in a bind and can't think of anywhere I'd like to go for dinner, it's usually 'let's just go to Olympia!'.

And no, that's not a bad thing. It's a GREAT thing.

Olympia provides the perfect setting for a low-key dinner with friends. Big plates of food ideal for sharing, large oak booths, and it's seat yourself. As close to the bar as possible :)

Oh, and did I mention the Deluxe Gyro? Mmm, a fantastically delicious display of excess. REALLY. And the calamari is spot-on too.

The patio is one of my favorites, on the real. Just be careful crossing the street to and fro the parking lot as others mention-- it's truly dangerous. Run don't walk please.

Looking for a spot for a large group, but can't deal with a wait? Blackstone is just the spot to bring 'em. A table for our group of eleven hungry colleagues was quickly set up... impressive!

Blackstone is the kind of brewery that turns out hearty pub fare. They even have Shepherd's Pie, which I greatly miss from my days as a New Englander. We tried the nachos (the black beans in this dish are so good!), thin crispy onion rings and pretzels for an appetizer. For my main, I went with the chicken, cheddar and bacon sandwich served with fries. The woodsmoked flavor of the chicken was slightly overwhelming, but the honey whiskey dressing I ordered on the side balanced things out a bit. 

The house brewed beer is solid (I tried the Oatmeal Stout and the Coffee Stout) and our server dealt with our large + loud group without skipping a beat. Best of all. Blackstone is walking distance from the Hutton Hotel so if I get a hankerin' for those nachos, I can rest easy knowing I'm only a hop, skip and a jump away.

A cute shop for when you feel like outright spoiling the little ones in your life. Floral frocks galore, preppy Fair Isle sweaters and tiny matching accessories such as frilly barrettes and dog-printed rubber boots. Granted, paying $188 for a toddler-sized dress is absurd, but believe me, it's possible to find good end-of-season deals here.

Dependable and delicious, McArthur's has been churning out great memories for 50+ years now. My mom has been taking my sister and me to McArthur's since we were tykes, back at the old location. I started with creme horns and gooey butter cake here, my sister, meanwhile, has always been a fan of the raspberry-cream cheese pastries. Then my brother arrived and soon my mom was making twice-weekly trips for the double chocolate chip cookies. 

These days, our trips to McArthur's usually involve their specialty, birthday cakes. We ordered a custom "Barney" cake for my niece's 2nd birthday, which we all loved. Especially the birthday girl!

As tradition dictates, my Mizzou college pals and I are STILL meeting here every year right before Christmas Eve to celebrate shenanigans past. Last night marked a momentous 5 years straight of meeting at J & A's! Though our favorite dive bar still allows smoking inside (ugh), I think we'll continue meeting here until the end of time. Why?

- It's fun watching the sole bartender take care of a room of 40+ people with ease. Impressive, indeed!
- The bar now boasts one of those ultra modern, shiny new jukeboxes. However, the sticky old one seemed much more apropos for J & A's um, ambiance.
- You'd be hard-pressed to find better pizza made in a bar!
- Beers range from $2.25 to $2.50/bottle; pitchers are $6-7.
- This is a REAL dive, people. Randomly situated in the heart of the sophisticated Central West End, it's truly an unexpected treat.
- They now feature a tiny table-top Christmas tree in response to our group's unintentional affiliation with the former larger one's untimely demise. The staff is obviously in tune with the needs of their client base. 

Tip: If you're a wine drinker, make sure they open a new bottle for you as that current bottle may be flatter than still water. Something tells me that wine isn't a beverage often requested at J & A's ;)

I'll always have room in my heart for the magic that is J & A's (supposedly, the oldest bar in St. Louis).

I swear I really do other things besides primp and preen while in NOLA (like eat and drink excessively), but any New Orleanian will affirm that wigs are indeed important in the city that celebrates the year-round fanfare of costume!

Luckily for me, I didn't even have to lift a finger to search for where I'd buy a costume wig on my trusty Yelp mobile app. Instead, I turned to the always well-costumed and perpetually stunning Joi B who insisted I check out Fifi's for a showstopper of a wig.

When I arrived, the sales associates were busy assisting a mom and her 3 daughters with trying on wigs of all different colors, lengths and textures. Curl, straight or wavy - you've got it. Natural shades of red, brunette, blonde and raven-hued wigs dot the walls, but theatrical colors such as pink, purple, yellow, blue and green also live here!  I naturally gravitated toward a light pink hue in the impossibly long and sexy Ginger wig but ended up leaving as a lilac-headed seductress in the same style (looks like this: http://www.polyvore.com/cgi/img-thing?.out=jpg&size=l&tid=22056505).

The staff stuffed my crazy-thick head of hair into the wig cap, carefully pinning everything in place. They also offered to give ol' girl Ginger a free bang trim but I decided to work the flirty, brow-skimming sideswept fringe as is. Even though I wore my wig out of the store 7 hours before the Halfway to Mardi Gras event began, it stayed in place all night, into the wee hours. Work!

It was great fun darting through the Quarter, collecting the approving (and/or curious) glances of many passerby as I hurried to find a cab in between raindrops. And I can't wait to do it again - I think buying a new wig (and a different, more mysterious 'me' for just one night!) on every trip to NOLA is a tradition worth adopting.

Nail Club is the crème de la crème of nail salons. Honestly, I've never experienced a salon where the technicians are so detail-oriented and customer-focused. They offer a menu of deluxe pedicures, and I think the Milk and Money is my favorite. Their foot massages are neverending and so very blissful. I would come here just to purchase a stand-alone foot massage, they are that good! 

Awesome spa chairs, super clean salon and a fantastic array of nail colors. Nail Club has won over my heart and my toes!

Because I don't care for the long, haphazard lines, the gobs of tourists or the camp of pigeons at Café Du Monde, getting my hands on a beignet and café au lait then escaping to nearby Jackson Square is top-of-mind when I awake in New Orleans.

Café Du Monde's to-go window alleviates much of the irritation but then there's still the line: You have to put in your time; there is no other way. The wait eventually produces a bag of beignets and I smugly trot off, fleeing the coop of crowds and chaos.

Jackson Square is the destination and I find an empty bench, take a bite of my beignet and savor this arcane view of the world through the patchy fog. The illuminated lamps, the wrought iron architecture, the Andrew Jackson statue and the silhouette of the beautiful St. Louis Cathedral... baby it's a scene, all right.

But unlike a photo, this scene is best viewed blurry. Come early morning so you can catch fog's blanket cradling the lovely square before she wakes up - it's worth staying up all night for.

Laid-back bar meets gastropub-level food.
Cozy booths.
Good crowd.
Specials every day of the week.

These are a few of my favorite things (when it comes to finding the ideal bar, anyway) :)

My cousin and I wandered into the Red Lion on a lazy Sunday evening (thanks to a quick search on Yelp, natch). We were quite hungry, and in the mood for a good beer. His only real requirement: a bar with TVs suitable for catching the football game. Well, Red Lion has a huge projection screen and a few plasmas so no suffering was endured. 

Our server gave us the best news of the night: happy hour specials run all day on Sundays! Half off all beer and appetizers... score! We split the toasted ravs (not your mama's toasted ravs, mind you, these are filled with pork and beef and served with a cheese dipping sauce). We then moved on to California burgers for both of us. The burgers were delicious and cooked to perfection, our only gripe was that we didn't see/taste any of the promised avocado paste on 'em. Still very good, though.

Service was super friendly and despite having only three beers on draft, they've got a decent bottled beer selection. Love the New Belgium 1554!

If you're looking for atmosphere, then keep walking. But if you're looking for a strong cup of coffee, a spot to get your gossip on with friends and you don't mind feeling like you're in a different world for a few hours, then you'll be quite happy at Korzo.

The coffeehouse is Bosnian-owned, so you can expect a lot of smoking as well as Bosnian music (this afternoon, we heard Croatian music). It's cash only, with a smattering of tables to engage in aforementioned gossiping (for us people from the Balkans, it's a legitimate pastime). The digs may not be fancy, but you'll never feel rushed. Free wi-fi, too! It can get a bit too smoky in the winter so stop by in the summertime for an outdoor table if you're easily affected. Me? I can deal.

I mean.... G&W is a local legend! Not only do they produce an outstanding portfolio of encased meats, but simply visiting the shop is an experience. If you're lucky, you'll be offered an ice cold can of Busch beer whilst waiting in line. While I no longer drink beer, I still appreciate the kitschy locally-relevant gesture. And if you check in on Yelp (at press time, anyway), you'll get a free G&W branded koozie. Too fun!

Back to the sausage: you MUST get the jalapeño cheddar bratwurst! Best bratwurst on earth. They also sell wonderful kraut which we use to make our take on the Bavarian-style with G&W knockwurst at home. Make sure to browse the shelves, where you'll find a smattering of authentic German products, from spätzle to mustard.

Pro tip: arrive right when they open to avoid waiting in a long queue! This place is legit and immensely popular with in-the-know locals. Trust.

Who knew you could get timeless, funky, hip and modern furniture under one roof? At Good Works you can.

I spent a decently large wad of dough here about five years ago (relative to my salary at the time) and my sofa/overstuffed chair set still look and feel as plush as the day I bought 'em. My coffee table is living a reincarnated existence in my brother's abode, only because I feared moving the glass to Chicago. Recently, my brother purchased his entire bedroom set from here per my recommendation. He's a picky one and finally settled on a set after weeks of (until now) fruitless searching.

Lasting impressions, chic style. Good Works is good stuff indeed.

Mud House: you have a new fan!

I rolled in here a bit hungry, and sadly under-caffeinated. Though Abby S isn't a coffee drinker, she promised me good joe. Besides espresso drinks, they also offer French Press served with a bottle of water and a housemade pastry for $7. Sweet deal!

Mud House serves breakfast all day long, and I opted for the granola with yogurt and fresh fruit. It was a perfect portion of gooey granola goodness -- sweet satiation.

If you're working, they offer free wi-fi as well as outlets aplenty. Cozy, comfy and a bit quirky... I like your digs, Mud House.

Okay, I do NOT do the Landing. Bachelorette party headquarters on cobblestone? Methinksno. 

So, naturally I was a bit apprehensive post-football tailgate. But we're all super casual, with sweatshirts to keep warm, wet hair and the look of... inebriation?

Enter Joey B's. From their 120 shot concoctions to their hair-metal spiked with bouts of hip hop music billing, Joey B's is plain ol' dirty fun. Loud, brazen and raw. Don't think I've ever had so much fun at a bar in St. Louis!

Yes, there were staffers dancing on the bar. Just know, coming in, that this is a classic die-hard Landing bar. And let the good times roll!

Great little spot in the Quarter if you're seeking a classic po' boy, strong cocktails and a lively scene but sans the heavy overtures of eau de tourist - what a happy find!

We came in on a Saturday, without much time but plenty hungry... and because we only had about 45 minutes before we needed to jet to our next destination, our lunch had to be a somewhat snappy one. The very antithesis of Louisiana dining, yes?

But our bartender extraordinaire hooked us up with front row seats at the bar and got to work on our drinks stat - a strawberry Covington ale for me and a fancy Mardi Gras-themed cocktail for my friend (maybe a bit too sweet for my taste, but he seemed to really enjoy it).

And oh wow, the food. Admittedly, I was a bit put off when I saw that po' boys here will run you $13-$16, but luckily, they were good. VERY good. Try the French Fry po' by with roast beef 'debris' gravy or the fried shrimp laced with rosemary... we couldn't put 'em down. And even the sweet potatoes were perfect - no sog; just the perfect balance of crispy and chewy.

In the end, lunch can get somewhat spendy here but the space is a reprieve from the typical tourist-laden joints in this neighborhood and the drinks and food are spot-on.

Balkan food alert!

Because both of my parents are from Croatia, I grew up on Balkan dishes such as sarma, cheese pita, pršut, punjena paprika, and fritule. I actually didn't try ćevapčići until I was well into my teens - once the Bosnians started settling in the St. Louis area during and after the Yugoslav Wars, they brought with them Balkan food of their own flavor. And while some Croatians do make cevaps, I've always considered them to be much more of a thing within the Bosnian and Serbian households - where they're considered a national dish. And I'm not too big to admit that they do make them better :)

Politics aside, ćevapčići are one of my favorite Balkan treats. These skinless sausages are made with minced beef and lamb (Serbians and Croatians often add pork as a third meat) served on top of a grilled homemade flatbread called lepinja, along with accoutrements such as chopped white onions (raw), ajvar (roasted red pepper and eggplant spread), and/or kajmak (similar to clotted cream but a bit saltier). Curious now?

My parents recently dropped by Biser to surprise my sister, me and her kids with a few orders of cevaps. While the sausages were a little dry, the flavor was great and the lepinja bread was perfectly baked and then finished on a hot grill. They were served with sour cream instead of kajmak, but that's a typical substitute in St. Louis as kajmak is quite labor-intensive. 

Next time, I hope we can get our hands on some of their freshly-baked burek and pita! Last time they were sold out of these popular items, which I'll take as a good sign.

So the decor is straight from an 80s flick (bright jewel tones on the walls do not a gem make) but Fitz's is a St. Louis institution. Ever try Fitz's cream soda or rootbeer? They have pretty decent distribution in the Midwest and they actually bottle it on-site here at the restaurant.

Order a bottomless frosty mug of the popular sugary soda for $2.25. A steal, as you'll probably down three mugs. Well, I did. I'm a fan of the burgers here and opted for the Quesadilla burger, which sat between two grilled flour tortillas and was topped with cheese, chipotle sauce and shredded lettuce. Delicious, and I was able to devour the entire sandwich without the bulkiness of the bun.

My brother tried the Breakfast burger-- grilled sourdough bread, cheese, bacon and a fried egg. He's super picky but absolutely loved it.

All in all a great late lunch on Christmas Eve. However, their service is filled with holes (um, waiting 15 minutes for the check as my server unabashedly flirts with his co-worker is annoying).

Have you ever went for a drink of water in the middle of the night, only to spit it out because it turned out to be Sprite? The taste isn't bad; it's just that you weren't expecting it.

That's how I feel about this property - it's much different than other Aloft properties, but that's also a-okay. Until very recently, this hotel was a Hotel Indigo and though it may pass as all Aloft in the lobby, once you get to your room you might find yourself scratching your head, 'did I check into the wrong hotel?'. 

The room is very nicely-appointed - in fact, it's a much more sophisticated design scheme than the typical Aloft style. Better linens, hardwood floors, Keurig coffeemaker, chic lamp... and, the water pressure is strong enough to get your hair squeaky clean and the bathroom comes equipped with a freakishly-strong hairdryer. I approve!

Despite all the niceties, something is still lacking... part of the reason why I really enjoy staying at Starwood properties is their employee culture positively impacts every one of my stays. I realize the transition just happened several months ago, but there's still some lingering customer service issues (there was a mix-up on their part in which they only booked me 1 night instead of 2, though I had the email confirmation) and a certain warmth is missing. For just a few bucks more, you could stay at the Hutton across the street and get an A+ boutique hotel experience. Though I love my SPG points, the savings aren't deep enough to justify a ho-hum stay.

Sorry guys - I generally adore Aloft properties but this one is just a little off.

One of the best patios in St. Louis! Seriously, if people-watching was a sport, then Bar Italia's patio is the World Cup champion.

I've been coming here for so long that it makes me feel old. My sister even had her college graduation dinner here! This is the kind of spot that everyone loves - from tourist to urbanite to suburban dweller!

Food. Ah, the food. I like that it's not as heavy as the Italian fare you'll find on the Hill. Rather, the portions are smaller here (i.e., what a serving size is meant to be) and the focus is on light, fresh ingredients. More Mediterranean than say, Sicilian. Some of my favorites include the carpaccio, the Tuscan tuna salad with thyme and cannellini beans, the pasta with Italian sausage in a tango tomato sauce and the grilled eggplant with herbed ricotta (YES!). 

The wine list is extensive and covers all price points - all of the servers are very knowledgeable and I usually have one of them decide my vino fate for the evening. You just can't go wrong at Bar Italia!

Still cool as all hell.

Vegan friendly! Fantastic beer list! Designer throwback cocktails!

And the food is something to write home about. I've branched out beyond the burgers and this last time, I went Mediterranean. We split the hummus as an appetizer (wonderful with its olive tapenade topping in addition to feta crumbles and olive oil) and I tried the Mediterranean chicken pita.  Perfection on a lunch plate!

Service can be a bit too cool for my tastes, but if you have time, then it's a great spot to linger. And there's free wi-fi for the taking should you feel the need to work it out.

A taste of the avant-garde in St. Louis.  Hip art gallery meets Indie music second stage at Lollapalooza.  Both the DJ's and live music deliver.  Come to Atomic Cowboy for the art, the music, the great libations and the mellow vibe. In Chicago, people would be quick to label the Cowboy a hipster/scenester bar, but really, it's just authentically cool.

Oooh, and there's a bonfire outside.  Does cool get cooler than that?

This review is for the pool only at the YMCA Carondelet Park Rec Plex... like Abby S, I'm a huge fan!

My sis and I brought her two young children here for a reprieve from the blistering heat. There's plenty of lounge chairs if you wish to soak up the sun (some shaded by umbrellas), as well as a brand-new, modern pool with all the stops: a water slide, lazy river and even a fun area with various misters for the kiddies to run through. 

There's a concession stand with soft drinks and light snacks, but I also noticed a few people set up shop at patio tables with what appeared to be BYO lunches. 

My only gripe: my sister has a family pass but for me to come in as a guest, I had to pay $10. That's somewhat hefty for a St. Louis city pool in my opinion! But, it is rather difficult to get pool privileges in the city vs. the county so maybe the price is fair if you factor in supply and demand. Still, it's a beautiful pool and I know I'll return with my family.

I love Chicago, but local grocery stores like Jewel legitimately make me miss St. Louis. Specifically, the greatest grocery store ever - Schnuck's! No, it's not fancy-pantsy like Straub's or or Whole Foods. But, they only make the best deli chicken salad ever! I've tried to replicate it many times without success - the base is a blend of sour cream, mayo, lemon juice and white pepper. It's simply magnificent on whole-grain bread! And recently I purchased a new contender - the honey mustard chicken salad. Well, it may not be 'new' actually, but for a girl who hasn't lived in St. Louis since 2004, it's new (and delicious!) to me.

Schnuck's has also revamped and inflated their beer selection. Over 100 microbrews to choose from now! They even stock Unibroue Maudite and Blanche de Chambly. Pretty freakin' awesome, but if I may make a suggestion: please, please, PLEASE stock my favorite beer in the entire world, Unibroue's La Fin du Monde. Thanks for listening. 

Plenty of self-checkout lanes and the employees are still as friendly as ever. Will always love my Schnuck's!

After passing the new Houlihan's on my last few visits to St. Louis, decided to come through for lunch.  This is definitely not your average Houlihan's-- both the facade and the interior reflect a modern, much-needed design overhaul.  So, though I'm not a fan of supporting corporate chains, 'specially not in my beloved hometown, the aesthetics caught my eye.

The menu is essentially the same, save for some enhancements.  Safe bet, Houli's-- hold on to your loyal clientele and maybe attract some new ones.  I'm talking subtle upgrades that still spell refinement: gouda vs. swiss, sides such as Mediterranean Orzo and pats of red wine and garlic wine butter.

My brother enjoyed his half-slab ribs, though prefers to have a selection of sauces.  I had the Southwest Chicken wrap, which was a perfectly-sized lunch portion.  And really good!  Sister and mother rocked the Brentwood Chicken Sandwich.  A souped-up take on the classic that they both loved.  Emily tried the fish tacos which made me wish I had ordered the same. Filled with tons of the good stuff-- chipotle mayo, tilapia breaded in flaky Panko breadcrumbs, napa cabbage, pico, and sweet honey-cumin dressing.

All in all, a very good experience except for the end.  Got our bill, and my sis noticed we were charged for every refill, though they are complimentary.  Not cool to have to mention that to our server, but he did apologize and remove the errant refills from our tab.

It's Christmas Eve, you've got one more on your shopping list (and they're super picky) and the last thing you want to do is make another trip to the mall. What to do? You head to Schnucks! 

Turns out, Schnucks has a deep selection of gift cards to cover everyone on your list. Nordstrom's, Macy's, Gap, Forever 21, restaurants, American Express, you name it! 

So next time you find yourself in a bind, just head to your hometown grocery store to do your shopping. And while you're there, you can pick up a greeting card too. Easy peasy!

So, here's the thing: The food was borderline awful. But the live music... oh, the music! 

I walked into Tootsie's with some time to kill at the airport and quickly snagged a seat at the bar. Within minutes, I was set up with a cold pint and turned my attention to the stage area. You see, every time I hear the Willie Nelson-penned and Patsy Cline-sung 'Crazy', I can't help but stop whatever I'm doing and just smile (despite the bittersweet lyrics). The chanteuse gave it her best in an admirable rendition - voluptuously-voiced and armed with one creative arrangement after another, 45 minutes passed like no time at all.

Which brings me to - leaving! Though I still had a good 20 minutes before my flight would start boarding and my gate was conveniently located next to Tootsie's, it took about 20 minutes and a steady campaign of 'please look at me!' pleasant but increasingly insistent stares to get the bartender to finally acknowledge me and my outstanding tab.

Bottom line: This isn't the original Tootsie's Orchid Lounge but for an airport incarnation, it'll do. Beers are pricey, the food is barely passable and the service is hit-or-miss. The live music, however, rocks!

Am I back in college? Because I think I dreamed I was at a bar with $2 you-call-its last night. No wait, I was!

So the deal is, every Thursday you can drink anything you want (shots, cocktails, beer, spirits straight up) for $2. Nicks has a pretty sweet beer line-up too... a few good craft beers and all the usual STL favorites such as Schlafly and Budweiser products.

The reggae band that plays here regularly is insane! Really great. Though this bar is filled with frat boy types that look like they'll be hugging a toilet really soon, don't let them put you off from enjoying the down and dirty diveness of Nick's!

There's a $5 cover on Thursdays, not sure about other nights. If you're looking for some tomfoolery at a 3am bar, welcome... you've found it!

I love my Schnucks.  The only supermarket-chain that even comes close is Super Stop & Shop on the East Coast.  This location is centrally-located, huge but easy-to-navigate and has an enormous parking lot.  But Schnucks' real claim-to-fame is their white meat chicken salad.  RIDICULOUS.  And I'm super picky when it comes to chicken and tuna salad.  What makes Schnucks' chicken salad so spectacular?  The mostly sour-cream with a touch of mayo recipe.  I've tried to replicate it but failed miserably!

I like pretty, whimsical things. Jilly's Cupcake Bar is exactly that-- pink, white and cute all over. 

I also like bee stung lips... Ryan Phillippe, anyone? 

So naturally I HAD to try Jilly's 'Bee Sting' cupcake. Standing at about 5 inches tall including its tower of lemon cream cheese frosting, sometimes more IS more. 

Yep, this luxe cupcake set me back $4.25. But when you consider the ingredients-- Madagascar vanilla cake, honey syrup, toasted almonds, honey lemon curd filling, lemon candy dust, a sugar bee, and a white chocolate and lemon honeycomb bark-- you realize that this cupcake isn't just a pretty face. This is the Bentley of all cupcakes. 

Other premium toppings for the glorious confections include Tahitian vanilla buttercream, mango cream cheese frosting, key lime custard, dark chocolate ganache and marshmallow buttercream. Jilly's also serves a full brunch and lunch menu as well as specialty coffee drinks. 

Now please excuse me while I finish off my 'Bee Sting' and put on my stretchy pants! Sigh.

I love Tarantino. True Romance and Pulp Fiction are two of my favorite flicks, EVER. So imagine how satisfying it was for me to come to The Royale, order their signature Kobe burger, and get to utter:

'I'll have the Royale with cheese.'

YES!

Uh, no. They were out of their aptly named 'Royale' on this sad Tuesday afternoon. Frown. Okay, so what's a burger lovin', hunger-driven girl to do? She orders the next best thing: the Kingshighway. This domestic Angus burger was cooked perfectly to medium, juices intact with housemade sweet potato chips on the side. Plenty of toppings to choose from, including roasted red peppers, feta, artichoke hearts, and my choice, a generous dollop of goat cheese. Deeeelicious.

My only regret is not ordering off the drink menu. The Royale might serve up some of the best crafted cocktails (based on friends' opinions and the menu offering) I've come across in St. Louis. Think champagne with fresh-squeezed (for reals) pear juice. Or the 'Ville': Bombay Sapphire, fresh lemon juice, sugar, dash of vanilla, club soda. Simple but ohsofreakinggood. Impressive draught beer and bottle list, too (though you won't find A-B products much to my old man's dismay).

Everything here is just... interesting. As in wonderfully. The music, the decor, the food, the people. Voilà: my new StL hangout. 

Street parking only kids, so it can get tricky.

It's undeniable: Brennan's is one cool little bar.

It's filled with eclectic artwork and the patio tables offer some of the best people-watching in the CWE. Awesome wine + beer offerings and cigars too if that's your vice. 

Really solid music selections and the downstairs bartender knows her stuff.

I'm really digging on this space-- you'll probably see me here this weekend when I head back to St. Louis. Gemtastic!

I met my friend Andrew here on a Sat. evening.  It's rare that I meet a pub I don't like and Scottish Arms is the ONLY watering hole Andrew frequents these days. Easy decision!

Kilt-wearing staff. 22 beers on draught, a good many of them hailing from Scotland. Cozy, dim lighting highlighting the Scottish decor and servers knowledgeable about their drink and food. Fantastic fish and chips! They've got Scottish eggs and haggis, too... supposedly a very respectable American rendition.

I heard bits of Portuguese as well as 3 different takes on English: Irish, British and Australian! I forgot I was sitting on a bar stool in the heart of the Midwest for 3.5 hours. Really, I'm so impressed with the authenticity Scottish Arms has brought to a quiet corner in midtown St. Louis.

It's time to bump The Royale up to that fifth star.

Why? The Wagyu Kobe burger, cooked to medium rare. This may be a bold statement to some St. Louisans who live for their Blueberry Hill and O'Connell's burgers (and rightfully so), but this is my favorite hometown burger. 

And, both the Dark and Stormy and the Mr. Smith are straight up delicious! (what can I say, I do adore my ginger). 

Stick around after dinner for one of the best bar scenes in town - there's plenty of seating and though it fills up pretty good, you'll never feel a tinge of claustrophobia. Oh, and the music: If this is your iPod and you're male, straight and single, call me 'cause I'm crushing on you. There aren't many bars that can keep my attention for five hours, but The Royale does exactly that!

I usually love this pub. Extensive selection of draught beer, great food and lots of nooks and crannies to get lost in. But mostly, I come here because it is calm and laid back. However, what happens to this pub on the weekends? Warren G's 'Regulate', for serious? Hmmm.... methinks a 'British' pub should not be playing a smattering of hip hop hits circa 1994. 

I still had fun lounging in my oversized brown leather chair upstairs. The Guinness pours were very sloppy, but one of them was delivered in a 20-oz. glass (bonus!) so that was the saving grace. Take note that the crowd is also much younger on the weekends. 

Llywelyn's. It's always good fun listening to people butcher the name, too.

Bravo, Merchants... Bravo!

The food was killer, the ambiance remarkable and the drinks? Legendary. I usually don't do cocktails but downed THREE. I'll forever remember Merchants as the place where I popped my Dark and Stormy cherry. This is my signature cocktail now until the end of time. Melodramatic, perhaps, but completely true. Mixology is taken seriously here and both the know-how and the elbow grease show. 

To touch upon aesthetics - I loved the brooding vintage insides, perfect for one of those long, winding dinners when you try just about everything off the menu. A dream dinner party destination! From drinks to dessert, I felt fireworks. Big, over-the-top 4th of July fireworks! 

I promise: You won't be, can't be disappointed.

Are you a vegetarian or vegan? I'm not, but I'm still obsessed with this restaurant and would choose it over most!

As most reviewers mention, you should absolutely try the Brussels Sprouts salad. Uniquely satisfying with its high crunch factor: red and green cabbage, shallots, fresh herbs, jalapeño and sweet chili vinaigrette - and it's both vegan and gluten-free. Score!

For my main, I tried the "chorizo" tacos with fried plantains. This is a dish I'd order again and again, as it's so full of flavor that you forget it's vegetarian. Tree House crafts all of their seitan, vegan cheese, pickles, sauces, dressings, and desserts IN HOUSE. And every one of their sauces and dressings is vegan!

Tree House is known as not only being the premier veggie/vegan restaurant in the StL, but one of the best in the country. Pro tip: make a reservation as the eatery is quite cozy!

Seoul Taco successfully marries Korean and Mexican food and it's tasty AF.

We recently checked in on a busy Saturday evening for some spicy comfort food after catching a show at Cicero's. Though the queue was dauntingly long, we moved through it in about 20 minutes. Once your food is ready, one of the staffers calls out your name. Correction: a staffer will YELL out your name as loudly as possible. This part of the experience was jarring, and made eating in a bit unpleasant.

Moving on to the good stuff: my cousin inhaled her burrito and I loved my nachos with Bulgogi Beef. They're not your typical Mexican nachos, and are made with corn tortilla chips, Queso Blanco cheese, green onions, roasted sesame seeds, kimchi, and sour cream. They're extra cheesy and gooey, just the way I like them!

This is one of the best casual meals I've had as of late considering quality, creativity, and the price. I'm impressed, St. Louis. Next time I'll bring ear plugs!

Sheesh, guys.

What's going on with the formerly fast and painless security at the East Terminal? 

I arrived for my 40-minute jaunt back to Chicago an hour and 20 minutes before flight time, with just a small duffel bag. Should be plenty of time, right?

Sadly, it took me more than 40 minutes to get through the winding security line. Only 4 of 6 lanes were open, and not until the area completely filled up with angry passengers did they finally make an executive decision to open up the additional lanes.

When I arrived here on Sat., I also noticed a crazy long line. Nope, not full of students traveling on Spring Break, but a bunch of adult travelers. I also made friends with some of my line companions and they noted that it's almost always this way.

Time to get your act together! Otherwise, the 6-hour Amtrak ride is actually a more attractive option. Who would have thought?

I support this happy marriage of laid-back pub feel with upscale trimmings.

Soft-lit oversized booths line the perimeter of the space... really, these booths feel like Paris at night. ROMANTIC. Though this pub always packs a crowd, its well-planned space never feels crowded. 

Our service was a bit slow on a busy Sat. evening, but turns out I was mere moments from a beautifully poured Guinness, with thumbnail head perfection. Some things in life ARE worth the wait.

Fantastic menu reaches beyond the typical pub fare. Live Irish music on the weekends. And they serve Hot Toddys! I've found the quintessential winter pub.

"What can I get you?"

"We'll take a Grey Goose and soda and a Golden Draft Light, please."

:::7 minutes elapse, nothing seems to be happening:::

Gentlemen on our behalf: "We'll take a Grey Goose and soda and a Golden Draft Light, please."

"Sure, coming right up."

:::another 7-9 minutes elapse as we witness a flurry of activity, none of which involves getting our drinks:::

"Um, what about that Grey Goose and soda and a Golden Draft Light, please?"

:::radio silence; eye contact is refused:::

Lights flick on.

Bar is closed.

One and done drink FAIL.

The giant rice paper wrap with brisket is easily one of the most unique and delicious items I've ever eaten. And take it from the staff, dipping the wrap in peanut sauce takes the sublime flavor profile up another notch.

In fact, I now attempt to replicate the wrap at home (since I don't live in St. Louis). While my rendition isn't even close to the perfection that is Lona's, it still scratches the itch.

But I have figured out what makes these things so damn good. It's the smoked vinaigrette! I create my version of the vinaigrette at home using a smoked paprika imported from Spain. 

I may even move back to St. Louis just so I can eat at Lona's more often - it's really that good!

When you elect to get a semi-permanent procedure done on your face, you want it to be perfect. And Niki is a true perfectionist!

I first got my eyebrows microbladed by Niki 2 years ago. I had no idea what to expect, and she was patient with me as I showed her photos of microbladed brows that I liked. We looked at the photos together and discussed shape, arch, and color. I felt at ease and soon a felt a flurry of ticklish activity on my face, as Niki designed my new brows.

The procedure itself is mostly comfortable - at times (near the beginning of my brow, for instance) I felt practically nothing. However, as she approached the tail end of my brow I did find it to be a 3-5 on my personal pain scale. However, Niki works quickly and within a couple of minutes, the worst of the pain is over. The numbing cream certainly takes the edge off, and you'll be most comfortable if you abstain from alcohol and aspirin for several days prior to your appt. And take it from me: do NOT schedule your appt during "that time" of the month, as pain is heightened.

Your initial visit includes a touch-up several weeks later, where you discover what the final brows will really look like. Use this appointment to point out any area that you feel needs to be more pronounced! I love that Niki sends you home with a small vial of Hustle Butter, a gentle but super-moisturizing balm which I swear has kept my healing process to a minimum. I'm only red for one day, and have experienced no scabbing!

I recently went in for a touch-up 2 years later though I truly could have waited 6-12 more months. The pigment was barely fading and only in a few spots, and this is following a summer of swimming in the salty sea daily for 3 months. Despite what you may hear from ladies who swear by monthly tinting, microblading lasts! And how convenient that you get it done and won't have to mess with your brows for 2 years. Occasionally, when I want to define them a bit more for a night out I use my Anastasia brow pencil (but I promise it's not necessary). I get so many compliments on my brows and that's huge coming from a 90s skinny brow victim! Niki stands by her work and if you have any issues, she will make it right.

I recently took my 4-year-old nephew here for a day date and he couldn't stop smiling... which means I couldn't stop smiling, either.

Though it's an overused term, there really is something for everyone. Pumpkin patches, apple orchards, berry fields... and a tractor trailer to pull you around the sprawling property in charming fashion. And just when you think you've experienced it all, the smells of home-cooked comfort food beckon you to one of the two restaurants on the property. 

I decided on the more traditional (read: less 'country') grill restaurant, only because I know my nephew would rather have pizza over comfort food staples like fried chicken and meatloaf. The best part of our meal? The housemade biscuits with Eckert's own apple butter! Seriously - I couldn't put them down.

On our way out, I stopped by the country store to purchase a jar of that stick-to-your-ribs apple butter just so my sister would know exactly what she missed.

A St. Louis-area day trip staple!

Eeeeeesh.

Believe me when I tell you that holding out for an in-flight cheese plate is a MUCH better option than grabbing a pre-flight bite at Beers of the World. Because it's near impossible to screw up a quesadilla, I ordered that over the burger and sandwiches once I noticed their low Yelp rating. I thought to myself, 'how bad can it really be?'

Really bad. The chicken tastes straight out of an Oscar Mayer ready-made pouch... you know the kind, the one you find in your grocer's refrigerated aisle? I carefully picked each chunk out and tried to make the best out of crunchy tortilla, cheese and tasteless salsa. Guys, don't make the same mistake and pay $10.99 for a heap of glaring apathy.

As for the beers - with a title boasting 'Beers of the World', I'd expect much more than their weak international line-up of Heineken, Beck's, Leffe, and Hoegaarden. Though I will give them 2 nostalgic stars for carrying Leffe Blonde... not because it's a particularly good beer, but it does remind me of good times in Croatia where it's everywhere.

The too-dim lighting and the grim service made for a depressing encounter. Hell, even this review is depressing. Onward!

Cuban/Cajun/Creole/Spanish fusion? Believe it.

Also surprising were the bar stools meet swings on the one bar side - interesting, and I'm sure this could be a bit dangerous when throwing back a mojito. But fun and super kitschy!

Boogaloo offers a small but thoughtful menu. There's a collection of tapas, sandwiches and entrees as well as soups. I sprung for the $7.95 lunch special pick two (your choice of soup, small salad and half a sandwich). My salad was filled with a generous portion of fresh mozzarella in addition to tomatoes, cucumbers and balsamic viniagrette. The Cubaniche sandwich was stacked with braised pork, ham, swiss cheese, pickles, mayo and mustard. Wow on the braised pork! The bread was also perfectly crusty... what a lunch special! Is it authentic Cuban like I can find in Chicago? No! But is it still satisfying to the palate... why certainly, yes!

I tried a sip of my cousin's mojito and it passed all of my tests. Next time, I'll make sure to return in the evening so I can imbibe! Our service was stellar and I managed to stay on my swing the entire time without defaulting to my klutz mode... and that my friends, is QUITE a feat.

What does Lumiere Place have going for it?

Proximity. To legions of drunks on both Washington Ave. and the Landing. And in St. Louis, we know that cabs are rare... very rare. To be able to walk to a casino is golden.

It's also a shiny new quarter. Glistening and delightfully tacky, as casinos usually are.

I'm a roulette player myself and immediately scoped out the $5 minimum roulette table. But not tonight baby. I talked myself into watching my friend throw down at the blackjack table and staying out of trouble.

The dealer was cool/friendly/funny, and didn't even mind me sitting next to my friend for a few hours despite not playing. Then again it was 4 am. Cocktail service was tough to come by, but I was damn near gleeful when I discovered Hoegaarden on tap at the bar. Was it expensive? I think $6 and some change? Not terrible by my Chicago standards but overpriced for the Lou.

No wait to cash out. 50/50 odds that I'll return.

If ever there was an institution that's magically equal parts tourist magnet and legitimately awesome, then Acme is it. 

To echo the very wise wordsmith Peter D: I fucking love this place. I've been coming here since 2000 and not too much has changed - you can always expect a wait, but typically it isn't too bad if you come alone and request a seat at the bar. And, it's worth noting that the bar is THE place to sit - not only does your bar stool perch offer a prime viewing opportunity of oyster-shucking, but you get to talk with the good folks behind the bar. They've stories a-plenty between them if you're up for some real talk, local-style!

As you'll read in just about every review, you MUST try (err, inhale) the chargrilled oysters. They're topped decadently with cheese and served in a bed of garlic butter sauce and kissed with just the right amount of smokiness. French bread is at the ready to sop up the juices of this adventure in culinary hedonism that you may just want to ride again... so, do yourself a favor and order the full dozen from the get-go!

I've also had the shrimp po-boy, which is truly overstuffed with loads of golden shrimp, seasoned to perfection and served with Tabasco mayo (optional, but I say this is mandatory).

Two hours of oysters, terrific bloody marys and an Abita Purple Haze will leave you pondering, what else could you possibly want in life? Absolutely nothing; it really all is right here.

I stayed here in August or September 2007 when I had to go to Tampa for some training.  

Due to the proximity of this hotel to the Nielsen Company location on Brooker Creek, this place should just rename itself "The Nielsen Dorm Facilities."

A jewel in Ybor City, La Creperia Cafe's specialty are crepes... both sweet and savory.  But if you don't like crepes, they have an extensive menu that includes panini, pastas, salad, wraps, and a myriad of beverages.  

The crepes are large and made fresh to order in the window at the front of the store.  I had the Turkey a la Brie, packed with roasted turkey, creamy Brie and tomatoes with a small side of lettuce, tomatoes and cucumber.  It was sooo yummy, but I couldn't finish it because it was so large!

I was tempted to order the "Latin Lovers," a sweet crepe with Nutella and bananas, but I figured I should have something more substantial than dessert for dinner.

This review is for the TechSheraps Ybor City LOCATION, not for a TechSherpas class.  

My company arranged a training at this facility, taught by an outside (not TechSherpas, not my company) instructor.  Since the class and the instructor is not from TechSherpas, please note that this is a review of the Ybor location.  

This seems to be an unlikely place for a "techy" company, but you will find TechSherpas located on 7th street.  I was told that this is a temporary location, but that they've already been here for more than 2 years.

Their facilities are located on the second floor and they have several classrooms + a small kitchen area (that I've seen).  When the instructor for our class got delayed due to a bout with food poisoning (DOH!), the TechSherpas folks were friendly, accomodating, and kept us updated on the situation.  

Then they let us sit in the classroom and fool around online while we waited for an update.  When it turned out that the instructor's company was going to buy us all lunch for all the trouble, the TechSherpas staff took care of all the details.  That was in addition to the coffee and muffins they provided in the early morning and then the snacks (Otis Spunkmeyer cookies!, chocolate, chips) they had out for us in the afternoon.  

The room we're in is comfortable and fits about 20 people.  The computers in the training room are standard Dell desktops.

The Don Vicente is a beautiful boutique/historic inn.  As such, the amenities are not new, but the place was recently updated and the rooms are in good condition, and there are only 16 guest rooms in this place.  If you are staying in Ybor City and don't want to stay at a boring ol' Hilton or Hampton Inn, go off the beaten path and stay here.  
Rates are reasonable and comparable to the other hotels in the area.  It's a wonderful change of pace.  

The lobby is beautiful; it's used often for weddings and corporate events.  In the mornings, they provide a simple breakfast (fruits, cereals, etc.); an easy way to start the day.  The staff is lovely and friendly.  

Hi-speed internet is available in the rooms (they offer cables if you didn't bring yours) and the decor in the rooms is charming.  For some reason I couldn't figure out how to get hot water in the shower, but since it's August in Florida, I didn't die from having a cold shower.  

Another plus = a great location; enjoy all the fun stuff and good eats of Ybor City with just a short walk.

Had dinner here with a friend tonight.  Nice atmosphere and since it's not too busy on a Monday night, it was a perfect place to sit and chat.  The staff was nice enough to let us dawdle there since it wasn't busy.  

The food was not too bad; a nice diner-type menu (burgers, sandwiches, salads, fries, etc.) and the prices are really reasonable.  Food + drinks for two less than $25 including tip.  

But there are so many places around here to eat, I'm not sure it's worth it to go out of the way to come here, though.

My girls and I hit up Clear Sky for breakfast before going to the beach. The patio is beautiful, and I loved relaxing out there. It took a little while for someone to come to the table, but after that, the service was good.

The food is fine. Nothing to complain about. I went with the chicken ranchero crepes and  didn't find them all that flavorful, plus they could've used more filling. I'd probably try a different option upon returning. My friends order egg-based dishes, and seemed to like them.

I was impressed by the drink menu. It's on a tablet, and it is extensive. I didn't know what to order. I don't even remember what I did order, but it was something cold and fruity because hey...vacation. It was fairly strong too (or maybe that was because it was 10 a.m. and I hadn't eaten). But, drinking seems welcome at all times here. 

Seems like their lunch and dinner may be better, and I'm guessing I'll be returning. There aren't many breakfast options in Clearwater Beach and Clear Sky is an OK choice.

I quite enjoy pralines, and I clearly love the name of this place. I sampled a variety of options, but their traditional was my favorite, so I took a few of those home. I also bought some of their hot sauce and their red beans and rice mix. Haven't used the mix yet, but the hot sauce (I got extra hot) is super good and I highly recommend it. Now that I reflect on it, I wish I had bought more from Leah's. Next time!

This Hyatt Place is fantastic.  Yes, it's not a high-end hotel, but is nice and well-maintained.  And that staff is great--super friendly and more than willing to help in anyway possible.  And they were so sweet to send a little birthday gift to the room for Stacey M.

I do recommend asking for something as soon as you need it--I asked late in the day (afternoon) for the makeup lamp to be fixed, and it was not fixed until the next day.  Speaking of makeup, we had the unfortunate luck of staying while a Mary Kay convention was in town and that was annoying as hell, and I'm not just talking about the bad makeup.  But, the staff was so great, that it outdid any challenges due to the influx of saleswoman. 

I didn't love the continental breakfast, though it wasn't awful.  I just really don't eat anything offered at continental breakfasts.  Beds were comfy and rooms are decently-sized.  

Besides the staff, and the awesome location (so close to Broadway and in nice weather, you could walk to The Gulch), I loved the fruit infused water, because I'm bougie like that, and also, they had a strawberry version. 

I'd stay here again in a heartbeat. In fact, if ever visited Nashville again, I wouldn't even look anywhere else.

The only reason this place has business is because of their location across from the convention center. The convention center food is awful and there are no other restaurants close enough for lunch. I had a chicken sandwich that was fine and filling. Service was friendly but the owner is incredibly rude. He screams at you and refuses to seat you if you don't reply to him in the right way. It's awful but given your choices it's the best you might be able to do.

When the name of this place popped up in my to-review lists I was taken aback. I hadn't gone to an Italian market recently. But, once I read reviews, I remembered. Well, "remember" might be a strong word, because I was drunk.

Anyway, after a night of bar hopping in St. Pete, this place hits the spot. I liked it better than D.C.'s jumbo slice, and remember it being cheesy enough to think, that, at least for drunk food, it was pretty good. 

I was the table-finder, so I had no staff interaction. Bathrooms weren't the cleanest, but were not awful. Tables were sticky. It's a no-frills, sober-you-up type place.

I'll be back next time I'm drunk in St. Pete.

What a fantastic seafood market! They have everything one could hope for, including prepared foods and a kitchen. And, the staff was very friendly. 

We bought shrimp (which they peeled and deveined) and some Scottish smoked salmon. Both were excellent. Whenever I'm in the area, I'll be back here to pick up some fresh fish.

After being completely drained from boozy brunch and walking around outside for hours, we decided sangria was in order, and, per Yelp, this was the closest place that had it.  Mixto has some outdoor seating, and the inside is dim, with a huge open window.  We ordered a pitcher ($30) of sangria, thanks to Victoria's wisdom.  

Now, normally I would not write a review having only tried one dish or one drink.  However, once the server realized we were only going to order one pitcher, he became quite distant and we rarely saw him.  Also, the sangria was not good.  I'm not even sure there was any alcohol in the sangria.  I think it was just fruit juice and sparkling water/club soda.

So, I write to warn you.  To warn you that their sangria is awful and if you are not spending tons of money here, the service will be awful too.

I loved this museum. It was the last stop on a tour with Mardi Gras King Hollis so we could see his costumes. He told us all about his costumes (and his queen's) and then we got to explore the museum. We interacted a bit with museum staff and they were super nice. It's small, but I could probably see myself staying in here about 40 minutes--maybe more if there is a full guided tour. I super appreciate the Mardi Gras Indian costumes (which are required to be hand-sewn and beaded) and the Cajun Mardi Gras ones as well. All the costumes are insanely gorgeous. I didn't get to see everything, so I would come back to learn more.

Restaurant Rebirth was a fast favorite. Not only do I love the name, but I loved the vibe and the service. The food and drink are excellent. We ate at the bar, which was perfect. I had the Sazerac, my first one in New Orleans, and I couldn't have wished for a better introduction. My duck entree was great--super flavorful and filling. My friend loved her steak. I wish I'd had room for dessert or time to return and try more menu offerings. But since I didn't, I'd definitely be interested in returning if in the area again.

Wandered in while on Frenchman and I am glad I did. This market is fantastic. There are so many funky, hip local artisans, selling a variety of creations. My favorite was clearly the jewelry, but I truly loved all of the art. And the creators were so friendly. It's open daily, which is helpful for mid-week visitors like me, who otherwise might not have been able to visit a local market. 

Supporting local artisans wherever I am is so important to me and I'm happy I found this market where I was able to do so. I will definitely return to Palace Market.

When Sank suggested we stop at the bakery for breakfast, I was game. I'd never been to a Colombian bakery before and was thrilled to stop. He just pointed and I went along with it. Aside from the empanadas, I don't know the name of anything we ordered, but it was all delicious. And still hot when we got it back home. 

I loved the spicy green dipping sauce, which I used on everything. My favorite was definitely a round ball filled with some type of hard cheese. It had a good texture and was tasty. The empanadas were well-filled and excellent; I super enjoyed everything else, too.

Now that I'm in the know, I'll be on the look out for Colombian bakeries wherever I go.

When we went to Nashville, my sister had to go to The Wild Cow.  She talked about it for months.  But I just wasn't that excited because when I eat out, I want something I don't make at home.  And I make plenty of vegan dishes.  Located in East Nashville (which I wish I could've explored more), it's a bit out of the way for tourists without a car, but it is next to Jeni's, so you can kill two birds with one stone, as non-vegans would probably say.  I wouldn't add it to my Nasvhille see/do/drink/eat list unless I was vegan or had a car and was looking for reasonably priced food.

However, the food is good, and if I lived here, it would be a different story.  This place would be great in a business district for lunch, or to grab dinner after work.  I ordered the Far Eastland Bowl, which is kale, tofu, and carrot-daikon slaw over quinoa (my choice) with peanut sauce and sesame seeds.  I eat more peanut-based sauce than anyone I know.  This bowl was tasty and hearty, and even I hadn't just come from Jeni's, I think I'd still be full from it.  Of course, eating just before meant that was all I could try on the menu, besides some of Stacey's dish.  I had a bite of her veggie burger and a chip with lemon garlic hummus, and both were good.

Staff wasn't super friendly and The Wild Cow is a bit hipster, which is unfortunate but not unexpected.  It's also ridiculously popular.  Again, if I lived here, The Wild Cow would end up replacing my beloved sweetgreen.  Actually, if The Wild Cow ever opened in DC, it would replace sweetgreen for me here, as well.

I've been having a hard time finding a good brunch spot, until I found Jones.  Unfortunately for me, Jones is a 3 hour drive.   So I will not be frequenting it - but one can dream.

We sat upstairs, which I recommend - a little quieter & you can watch everyone below you.  We were there around 11:30 on a rainy Saturday, and were sat immediately.  Service was fine, and fast.  Decor is super cute.

I had the French toast with tater tots.  Tater tots, you ask?  Yes, because where I'm from, they are not quite ubiquitous.  My Philly friend (aka tour guide) also had the French toast, and my husband had the avocado sandwich with fries.   The French toast was thick and tasty, and probably the biggest piece of French toast I've ever seen.   I enjoyed the tater tots.  My husband liked his sandwich and fries, but the fries went cold fast.  

Perhaps a second location in DC or Boston is needed?

I don't always get drunk and go to clubs, but when I do, I like to make sure I'm on vacation in a different city and pay a cover.

I remember mostly EDM with some hip-hop, a lot of dancing, and it being super crowded. Floor was sticky. Definitely a dressier crowd. I don't miss my club days.

I had fun, but keep in mind, I was feeling the effects of alcohol. I'd probably not choose to go here sober, however, I didn't see many other dancing options in the immediate vicinity.

My iced almond milk caramel latte was fine, as was my friend's cortado and bagel. Four stars for the overall atmosphere, decor, and service, but three for the coffee. I've had better, and I've had worse. I prefer a strong coffee/espresso flavor, and my latte was missing that. It was more milky than anything, so the overall balance was off. Pastries (not bagels) looked tasty, and if I did happen to stop in again, I'd grab one.

Muriel's is a fine dining gem. I had been wanting to visit and finally, on my last night in New Orleans, I did. I enjoyed the fantastic service and delicious food.

I hadn't yet had a Hurricane and figured this would be the perfect place to get one. I definitely enjoyed it. The bread is addictively good and I couldn't stop eating it. I ordered my new standard--greens and redfish courtbouillon. I love redfish. Both the items were great. I loved the greens and the popcorn rice paired well with the redfish and sauce. I was too full for dessert, but I definitely want to return and will definitely be ordering dessert.

If you are looking for fine dining and excellent NOLA cuisine in the French Quarter, Muriel's is your spot.

This shop is fantastic. It's very welcoming and not gimmicky. I felt like the staff was really knowledgeable and helpful. You could tell they love talking about and teach about voodoo. My interaction was great--I told the super nice gentleman what I was going through and he recommended the perfect item. My Oya doll and I haven't been separated since. I really appreciate that he took the time to explain her protections and offer other suggestions as well. I'm looking forward to returning here on my next visit.

Our iced caramel soy lattes were OK. Something was missing--perhaps a stronger coffee flavor? Their hot lattes may be better, as some places are better at hot lattes than cold ones.

However, I did love the fun, eclectic vibe, and the food we saw looked delicious. I'd come back to try some noshes, keeping in mind that the line gets long and parking will take a few circles around the block.

We all really enjoyed Pho Street. We didn't plan our visit, but were happy to have happened about this place. It's casual with plenty of seating and you can order at a kiosk, which is much appreciated.

I did a quick scan of the reviews to know not to order the pho. I ordered the grilled pork vermicelli bowl (bun thit nuong with cha gio), my sister had the Vietnamese hoagie (banh mi thit nuong), and my brother-in-law ordered the broken rice (com tam) with a cha gio side. Everything was excellent. The pork was super flavorful and there were tons of fresh vegetables and herbs in my bun. My sister said the bread on her banh mi was great. And my BIL loved his perfectly cooked and delicious com tam. We all appreciated the crispness of the cha gio. Even my baby niece enjoyed the vegetables we gave her. I love that they have a house-made fish sauce, which add depth to everything.

I'd stop here again if craving Vietnamese in Center City.

This bustling station is beautiful. It probably works well if you know your way around, but as a visitor, it's frustrating, due to lack of available information. Directional signs are not clear. The website is basic, at best (given that it is run by Amtrak, that is no surprise), so finding information prior to visiting is a chore. A quick peruse of the food court options also proved to be basic and most close early. No place to grab a great coffee in the morning. Bathrooms are fine and at least there's an ATM and a convenience store, but this place could be better.

I could've skipped this and would've been OK in life. Anyone who tells you need to do a cemetery tour in New Orleans is lying, unless they are are really boring or really into history. The tour was good, but I was bored. You can walk around a free cemetery and see some graves--no need to pay. You can see a bit of this particular cemetery from outside the walls (this one you have to pay for and can only get in with an official tour) and that's all you really need in life. Save your money and your time for the important things, like drinking.

Hipster heaven, but my barista was surprisingly friendly.  Very good lattes, though I definitely needed sugar for mine.  Cool atmosphere, and the pastries looked amazing.   Definitely better than going to a Starbucks.

I was struggling with what was going to be review #1500. Would I go try a new place? Would I seek out something unique and fun to celebrate? I contemplated it. But I decided I'd rather review Wat Mongkolratanaram, a Buddhist temple in Tampa that offers a lovely Thai market on Sunday mornings. It's not something you come across too often.

I had been looking for cool things to do in Tampa, which are hard to come by, as I left the city somewhat indifferent about it. Luckily, before I left, I had found out about this place on the Tampa talk threads. From what I can tell, you need a car to get here.

I agree with much of what has been said: come here early (parking is rough and food runs out), bring plenty of cash, and plan to grab some small items to eat while you stand in line for the noodle soup. I missed out on the noodle soup because of poor planning. Do not let this happen to you. Also, come with people that like to eat and understand waiting in line for food.

Food wise, we tried various spring rolls and dumplings, beef satay, pumpkin curry, and chicken basil. Everything was great, and I'm fairly obsessed with the spring rolls. I also tried the papaya salad, and that was the only thing I did not really care for, and normally, I love it.

The grounds are idyllic, and the temple is gorgeous. There's really no other way to describe it. Ideally, when I return, I'll return alone, and be able to stay for services, which all are welcome to join. 

As a visitor to the area, I definitely recommend finding a way to get here. It was a highlight of my trip.

Not sure what else I can add, except the gelato is delicious.  A little pricey, but they let you try as many flavors as you like.  After trying a few, I had the bacio (dark chocolate & hazelnut) and cashew.  So amazing.  I also had a cappucino, which was good as well.

This Hyatt Place is fine. It's clean and comfortable, but not at the height of luxury or at all trendy. Beds are comfortable. Wifi was good. I was on a low floor, so it was a bit loud. Elevators are slow and constantly busy. Staff was super friendly and helpful.

The location is only good if you are going to a convention. It's not far from some good restaurants, but you can find hotels that are much closer to the fun. 

I'd not stay here again, but if you end up here (remember, for a convention only), it should be fine.

This was my worst JetBlue experience, and I normally love JetBlue. Curbside check-in is appreciated, though the staff does not speak well and was extremely rude. Gate staff was also impolite, while the flight crew were unprepared and kept barking orders at everyone. The on-time departure was nice, but I'd appreciate a calm, prepared, friendly crew in the future. I hope my future flights will be with a different Tampa-based crew.

Saint Lawrence is cute with a friendly staff but I was underwhelmed with the food. We ended up here due to location and the fact that it was open a bit later than other places. The food is fine, but there are better options. I didn't love my drink--it was a little sour. My red beans and rice, collards, fried chicken, and cornbread were OK, but a bit lacking in flavor. I needed hot sauce on everything. I'd go somewhere else before returning here.

Herbsaint is the first restaurant I visited in New Orleans and my first true experience with Cajun/Creole cuisine. It was an amazing introduction to the cuisine of the region. My only goal for my day was to eat amazing food (I left D.C. at 6 a.m. and was at Herbsaint by 11:30 or so--I literally flew to New Orleans, dropped my belongings in my room, changed, and headed here) and that is what happened.

This restaurant is exactly what I imagined a restaurant in New Orleans to be. It's hard to explain, but the decor and ambiance, along with the patrons (mainly a business crowd during lunch), created a charming, relaxed atmosphere. And the hospitality and service was amazing. From the lovely hostess to the skilled servers, everything was exceptional. 

I couldn't drink, which is too bad. I would have liked to try their cocktails, but will save that for next time. I ordered the gumbo, gnocchi, and fried apple pie. There was also bread and an amuse bouche. The bread was delectable. The amuse bouche, a marinated clam on a cracker, was the perfect morsel of deliciousness. And their gumbo remains in my dreams. It was so flavorful and so hearty and is definitely my favorite version of this dish. The gnocchi was light and tender and I appreciate the cloud of Parmesan. I couldn't finish it as I knew I wanted dessert, which I also couldn't finish. I had no idea what fried apple pie was, but it's basically an apple empanada, and since I love carbs that have been stuffed, rolled, and fried, this was a great dessert for me. It was definitely rich and I recommend splitting it with someone (though I mostly dine alone so that doesn't work for me). 

Herbsaint is fantastic and I highly recommend everyone experience it while in New Orleans.

Great museum for the little ones! We had so much fun here. My friend who lives in Philadelphia has two young children and has a membership, and I can see why. I feel like if you live close by and have children, it's definitely worth it. The kids love this place. And it works for a range of ages, from my then 8-month old niece to my friend's early school-age children, everyone had a good time. I think we spent ~2.5-3 hours there, and I was ready to leave (and drink) at that point, so it's a good amount of time. 

The exhibits are interesting and interactive. It really is a "please touch" place (I brought hand sanitizer and hand sanitizer wipes). It's also really pretty and well-laid out. A few spaces may be a bit cramped, but overall, it worked. You can park on the street if you don't want to pay for parking, which is great. 

I'd love to return to see the new exhibits and see the children in my life really enjoy themselves and run around and just be children.

I did not want to go to the Country Music Hall of Fame.  Truth be told, I didn't really even want to be in Nashville.  I mean, I'm a city-loving R&B girl, and had no idea why I'd want to learn about white people singing songs I can't relate to.  Watching trains go by in the middle of the night and drinking muscadine wine isn't even something I'm remotely interested in and I don't know all the words to every Tanya Tucker song (but, you can often find me drinking from a red Solo cup).

However, country music is part of the fabric of American life, and I loved the Country Music Hall of Fame.  You'd be remiss if you spend time in Nashville without visiting.  It's chock full of history and interesting facts, and it's great to see how and where country music started from, and where it is today.  The exhibits were very nicely done, with my favorite being the Crystal Gayle one (I will always want her hair).  They have a few of Elvis' cars, which are super cool and very detailed.  It takes a good 2--3 hours to get through everything, so don't go hungry (like we did).      

And while I didn't leave a lipstick tube on the bathroom floor, I was a bit sad to leave this place.  You definitely realize the significance part this musical genre plays in other types of music, and in American history.

The food and service at Melograno were great.  They open at 5:30 on Saturdays, and at 5:25, there were already people inside! Because we were early, they seated us with one person missing, but I hear that is not the norm.  It definitely filled up quickly.
