Our server was friendly and good, though there were minor mistakes - automatically pouring the wine (not everyone was drinking), credit card slips in wrong jacket.  The decor is really pretty - we were seated right by the big chandelier.  

Food was great - my husband & I were still talking about it the next day.  Between four of us, two had the wild boar bolgnese, one had the mushroom app with the ravioli entree, and I had the ravioli special: cocoa ravioli filled with rabbit and topped with the brown butter sauce.  It was delicious.  Bread was also good, and you can't beat BYO.  I absolutely love the idea of BYO - it was the first restaurant I've been to that does that.

Why not 5 stars?  The foyer needs to be cleaned - I noticed spiderwebs (with spiders) in the corners.  My wine glass was dirty.  And one hostess was rude (though the first one was nice).

This was the closest Cuban restaurant to my dad's place, so we decided to check it out. It's definitely popular and does a good take-out business. We sat at the small bar, and became quickly disappointed to find they do not have liquor (only beer and wine). It took a while for someone to take our orders, but staff is friendly.

I ordered a chicken empanada and lechon asado with rice and beans and tostones. I was hoping for Cuban bread, and it actually comes on the platter, not before the meal, so don't get disappointed. The empanada was tasty and crispy. I was underwhelmed with my platter. The bread was good and so were the tostones. But the rice and beans and lechon were not super flavorful and sort of dry. I asked for a side of mojo, which made it better. I was also unimpressed with my friend's ropa vieja.

I might try a sandwich from here, as the bread was really good, and I noticed many take-out sandwich orders. But I wouldn't get a full entree here again.

I will visit Longwood Gardens anytime - it is absolutely beautiful. I was here in early November, on a rather rainy day, unfortunately. I had been wanting to visit, especially due to the perfume exhibit, and luckily, Ariela M. had the same day off as I did, so a quick trip to Philly & Longwood Gardens was in store for me. 

The outside grounds are gorgeous, even without flowers and waterfalls in November. The inside gardens were just as amazing. My favorite was the orchids, of course! 

I had been wanting to see the perfume exhibit, as I am obsessed with perfumes. It was small, but with nice information on scents and perfumeries, as well as a beautiful perfume bottle display of some of the most popular perfumes and prettiest perfume bottles. Though I had been to a perfume bottle museum before, I never tire of seeing the bottles and thinking about new fragrances. 

The cafe was nice and the meals looked tempting, though we only split a slice of pecan pie. The Pierre du Pont house was also nice to walk through, especially as we needed to get out of the cold. A really cute cat lives there! The shop had some really pretty home decor, if you are into flowers. I must get back in the summertime!

I really enjoyed Dook's Place. To clarify, since I couldn't find a website for them, the MSY website sucks, and Yelpers, per usual, are confused: this is NOT Dooky Chase's airport location, which is close to Concourse C. This is an offshoot from his grandson, and is before security in Concourse B, the Southwest terminal. It looks like the only good place to eat, aside from its more famous namesake.

Dook's Place is nice. It's well-lit with a nice bar and colorful artwork. The R&B was bumping and service was good. They kindly made the modifications to my chicken sandwich with no problem. I didn't get to try a drink, but from what I saw, they looked good. I loved my fried chicken sandwich and fries. That sandwich was on point--the chicken was hot, crispy, and flavorful. Fries were great. I'd be happy to return and try more on the menu.

MSY lacks in many areas, most notably dining. If you are going to be hungry before or after your flight, come early/stay late to eat here. The food and ambiance are great and it's also one of the only good options.

I've been to my share of convention centers and this is one of the worst. Yes, it's one of the biggest, but who cares? I never attend a convention here. The design, both interior and exterior, is extremely dated. The food court offerings are awful. In a city known for it's food, at least you could offer excellent food, but not here. And there isn't even any good food right outside, so if you are at the center, you can't leave to grab something good (unless you have plenty of time and can hit up Cochon). It's not in an awful location, but you do have to walk at least a few blocks to find some good food. 

A convention center, much like an airport, can really represent a city, and this one (also much like the New Orleans airport), does not. At least it's named for Morial (the first African-American mayor of New Orleans) and you can hire a jazz band. That's all I got.

I was super hungry and Royal House had no wait, so I stopped in. I was excited to try the shrimp Creole, as it was near the end of my trip, and this was one dish I still had yet to try. I thought it was was just OK. The shrimp were not the big, beautiful Gulf shrimp I was expecting and the sauce had little flavor. It also took a really long time to prepare, given that the restaurant was not that full. Those around me mostly ordered sandwiches, and I wish I had gone that route. Service was really good, though. There are better restaurants in the Quarter.

Backatown is a really cute coffee shop. It's warm, with great music and a great vibe. It's also popular. I was there around 9:30 a.m. on a weekday and it was fairly full. I ordered an iced caramel latte with almond milk. I tried to get a pastry, but they were out of everything except for like a random muffin. The barista was super rude and unfriendly. All she did to make my latte was pour some coffee from a pitcher in the fridge and add milk and caramel sauce. It was as gross as it sounds. Someone told me this place isn't even owned by a local. There's definitely better coffee in New Orleans.

When heading to New Orleans, Commander's Palace was my absolute must-go. I did not care where else I ate, but I knew I had to eat here. What I wish I had done was watched "Ella Brennan: Commanding the Table" before dining here. If you choose to dine here, or anywhere in New Orleans, really, it should be required viewing. As someone who heavily follows food and dining culture (many don't really have food knowledge and understanding but consider themselves "foodies"), I of course knew bits and pieces of the Commander's Palace story, but the documentary really brings everything together.

You need reservations and you need to be dressed appropriately. I recommend calling, as I had trouble with their website. The reservationists are amazing. The service here is nonpareil. I've dined in several fine dining restaurants, throughout the world, and have had excellent service, but it goes above and beyond at Commander's. What they understand is that there is a proper way to serve, but that fine dining is never haughty. It's elegant and refined, yes, but never pretentious. And that right there is crucial. It's what makes Commander's Palace shine. From before I entered the building to when I entered my rideshare, the service was superior, but I always felt welcomed.

The entire restaurant is opulent. From lush gardens to a gorgeous dining room and a beautiful tablescape, it's exactly what I expected. I dream of dining in the courtyard and at the chef's table in the kitchen. 

It goes without saying that the food was fantastic. I had one a drink, that classic New Orleans Sazerac, and it was perfection. I really appreciate the offering of a prix-fixe menu, and my companion and I went with that option. It had exactly what I was looking for: gumbo, redfish, and the bread pudding. The gumbo was rich and hearty and I had all I could do not to eat it all, or all of the warm bread served with it. I love, love, love redfish, and this preparation with potatoes and vegetables was well-sauced and well-seasoned, and the crab topping gave the dish extra panache. For dessert, I actually wanted the strawberry shortcake or pecan pie, but decided I should go with the bread pudding souffle. It was sweet and delicious, but I personally would have been happier with the aforementioned options. However, if you are a bread pudding fan, you must order it here. 

The entire Commander's Palace experience was incredible. I don't often revisit restaurants in cities which I do not live; however, I will be returning each and every time I visit New Orleans.

Zahav, long-known as one of the premier dining destinations in the United States, was recently bestowed yet another award, this time as the 2019 James Beard's Outstanding Restaurant. Zahav has also long been on my list of places to dine and while I do not get to Philadelphia as often as I'd like, I did vow that the next time I was there, I would go to Zahav, and I made good on that promise.

I love Israeli cuisine and Zahav offers a comprehensive tour of its many delights. Between Cook's and Solomonov's restaurants and cookbooks, along with "In Search of Israeli Cuisine", these two have positioned themselves as experts in this cuisine, which is clearly depicted in this award-winning restaurant. 

As for Zahav's infamous wait, I got there at 4:00 p.m. on a Friday (albeit, the day after Thanksgiving) and was the third party in line (the two prior parties had just arrived). I was in a party of two and we were in the first bar seating. There are 16 bar seats and four chef's counter seats, so do note for a visit without reservations.

The service, drink, and food were nonpareil. The hospitality was apparent from when were warmly and kindly welcomed into the restaurant, with the hostess noting how pleased they were to have us, along with greeting us with bags of spiced, roasted chickpeas. The bartenders do a great job of explaining the drinks and the tasting menu. We did the Tayim (tasting menu) and I wasn't sure it was going to be enough food, but it was more than enough. It really doesn't make sense not to do the tasting menu, which at the bar and with three drinks each took us about two hours or so.  

An amuse bouche of pickled vegetables was perfect to whet the appetite. The standouts include the warm, seasoned laffa and creamy, delicious Turkish hummus, along with the crispy haloumi and the delectable fried cauliflower. The savory salatim accompanied everything nicely. I loved our desserts--a decadent chocolate konafi and a sweet apple cake. Plus, you leave with a to-go cookie, which is, as we say in Hebrew, "sababa". Our drinks were great too, with my favorite being the Z&T, an za'atar-infused gin and tonic. I'm za'atar obsessed so this was great. They also offer wine from my favorite Israeli vineyard, the gorgeous and excellent Golan Heights Winery.

Zahav means "gold" in Hebrew; here, you will be treated to a golden experience. I'm looking forward to visiting again whenever I return to Philadelphia (and hopefully trying the lamb and the hazelnut cake).

I think this is apropos for review #1400.  After all, it's me writing about alcohol, my second favorite subject (makeup being the first).

The Corsair Distillery tour is fun and light-hearted, and full of lots of information about the distilling process.  I can't remember our guide's name, but he was great.  The tour doesn't last long, but it's interesting.  You can bring a beer from the taproom in with you.  

After the tour, you get samples in the beautiful tasting room.  My favorite was the Triple Smoke Whiskey.  It's smooth and smoky, and I'm obsessed.  You can stay for a cocktail after the tasting, but we did not, because that was enough hair of the dog for me, but I now wish I had.  All of the staff we encountered were friendly.  If you love whiskey, you must do this tour.

I've had hot chicken once, so I don't have much to compare to.  And unfortunately, I still really don't, because staff at my hotel recommended the mild version, saying that it was still quite hot.  I did not find the mild version to have any amount of spice, whatsoever.  So, if you have any type of tolerance for heat, start with the hot (200 degrees).  

However, the chicken itself was super crisp outside and still tender inside.  And the leg quarter with crinkle fries was huge.  I could not stop eating it, and even though I wanted more, I was super full when I was done.  The chicken takes about twenty minutes to make, so do not go here completely famished, like I did.  

I cannot say enough about the friendliness of the staff.  I think I even got to chat with the owner briefly!  I'm just sad I didn't get back to try the spicier version.

I'd actually say more like 3.5 stars.  It's really good ice cream, but I was not floored by it.  If you're an ice cream fanatic like me, I definitely recommend checking out Jeni's.  The flavor combinations are interesting, which I love.  I went with the brown butter almond brittle and wildberry lavender.  It was a nice a mix, because the sweet berry flavor definitely balances the richer brown butter.  The cone piece was a nice add-on, and probably the best waffle cone I've tasted.

Staff was extremely kind and patient as we tried many flavors.  They were also very explanatory, which is helpful.  The line moved fast and I appreciate the cucumber infused water.

I love Philadelphia because of the historic character, the shopping, and most importantly, BYOB.  And if BYOB brunch doesn't sound fantastic, I don't know what does.  

Wedge+Fig is an extremely cute restaurant in the Old City.  It's back patio can only be described as charming and intimate, with small tables and trellised brick walls.  Service was attentive and friendly.

Three girls brought two bottles of champagne to brunch and we weren't sure it would be enough (but since we all like our mimosas with just a splash of orange juice, it was).  They'll chill your bottles for you, which is a nice touch.  Everything on the brunch menu sounded fantastic, but I went with something I so rarely find:  a make-your-own breakfast sandwich (brunch bar).  It comes with greens and potatoes, which is great.  And Sahar and Victoria went with the same, though someone (Sahar, I believe) ordered double cheese, and that's the way to go.  My sandwich was gouda, tomato, and bacon on white and was delicious.  Potatoes were crisp and greens were fresh.

We ended up getting kicked out because we had a Tanqueray nip with us, and during our last round of mimosas, topped it off with the gin.  While I suppose that's our fault for not reading the rules, I wish we were not lied to and told it was because there was a wait.  There was definitely no wait.  

Not sure I'd return because of that, but I might because Wedge+Fig is definitely delicious.

This is basically an outdoor mall, with plenty of chain restaurants and bars that were open, yet empty on a Saturday night. It was after 9 p.m. and a handful of patrons were in each restaurant, plus there were children running around. 

It's in a good location, and it's nice, plus there's parking, but there's no need to ever come here, unless perhaps you are starving after an aquarium or arena visit.

This was my last stop on my way out of town. I love carousels, so the idea of a carousel-themed bar was definitely appealing. It's in the Hotel Monteleone and I walked through the hotel lobby to get to the bar (not sure if there is a separate entrance as well, but I also needed luggage storage). The staff of both the hotel and the bar provided amazing service. 

I was going to sit at the bar, but then decided a window alcove with plush seating was preferable. I ended up just having one fantastically-made Vieux Carre, though I wanted two. The window seat was nice because I could people-watch those both outside and inside. The bar chairs are ornately painted, so it was fun to watch those go by, though the well-lit, intricately-designed top of the bar is the most reminiscent of a carousel.

I visited around 1:30 p.m. on a Thursday afternoon. There were a few seats at the bar, as well as a few window seats, so that seems like a good time to visit, though it's too early for the live music. Since it's touristy, it's not a dressy spot, despite being a high-end bar (and hotel). I look forward to returning next time I'm in New Orleans.

No frills, low-key sports bar in Clearwater Beach. Friendly staff and inexpensive food and drink make it a chill place. Late on a Wednesday night, this place had a decent crowd and was still serving. And, I did see a tropical bird, which I guess is a toucan.

Drinks are strong, which is always a plus. Typical bar food is good, and my chicken sandwich was one of the better versions I've had. However, it doesn't come with fries, so be sure to ask if you are ordering a non-burger sandwich. My friends shared their fries, and they were tasty.

If you need a place to relax and have a drink, visit Toucans.

Cute, bright, cozy coffee shop that we found on our way to brunch.  Hipster staff was super friendly, so I was happy and impressed.  You usually don't get that with the hipsters.  They have almond milk, which is awesome, and my iced almond milk mocha latte was delicious.  There was plenty of seating, which is nice, though we didn't stay.  I'll keep Menagerie in mind during future Philadelphia visits.

This store is really cute.  They offer a great selection of OPI, NYX, and Essie, along with a myriad of other products, such as Deva and Smith's.  It's not a beauty supply, so prices are retail.  The discounted OPI bin was not really that cheap, so that was disappointing. Staff was friendly enough. But I'd visit again when in the area.

Great liquor store. They have everything you need, in a variety of sizes, and more, plus the prices are fantastic. My only suggestion would be to carry more local/Florida beers. They also sell some tasty look snacks--cheese, crackers, etc., which is helpful.

I found the younger staff to be friendlier and more helpful than the older staff, so if you have questions, ask them. The older staff was a bit rude and failed to answer my questions or help me find what I was looking for. However, it's a great store for all your boozy desires.

Crema makes a fantastic latte.  I had a plain latte with the almond-coconut milk, and loved it.  It was strong and a tad bitter, so I added some sugar in the raw, which helped.  I loved it though, and there was a great foam on top.  The chocolate croissant was flaky and filled with a fantastic rich chocolate.  I highly recommend getting your caffeine fix here.

This is the place to get your day party on. Right on the water, it's the perfect spot to drink, eat, and play volleyball. With the music blasting and drinks flowing, it was a good time. Well, from what I remember of it anyway.

Our service wasn't the best, and in general, it's slower service than I'm used to, so I recommend ordering right away. Drinks are strong--I don't remember what I ordered, but it was whatever drink special they had going ($6 Stoli or something, I believe). 

Food was typical bar food. I thought the calamari was great. Too many mussels were cracked/unopened for my liking. Pizza was fine. You really come here to drink, in case you haven't garnered that by now.

I really look forward to coming back here during my next visit.

This truck offers pierogies and empanadas.  Empanadas have some unusual fillings while the pierogies are your classic potato and cheese, albeit deep fried.  The pierogies are good and well-filled, but could use way more cheese.  The 20 minutes wait (line plus cook time) isn't great, but if you don't mind waiting, it's a good snack.

Both the food and service at Barbuzzo were outstanding. Our server was over-the-top friendly and helpful and extremely knowledgeable about the menu. The restaurant is very small and tables are very close. Low lights and wood decor lends itself to a hip, relaxing ambiance. 

We shared the sheep's milk ricotta appetizer (server's recommendation), and then I had the pacherri and my friend had the ravioli.  The ricotta was salty and creamy, and great on the toasted bread.   I was hoping for more burratta in the pacherri, but it was rich and filling anyways. Ravioli was excellent as well. Portions are small and meant to be shared, but the pasta was filling and the perfect size. We shared the caramel budino for dessert - it was delicious and I do not like pudding type desserts at all. Cocktail list was small, but very interesting - as in I want to go back to try one!

I love this bridge. It's super cool looking and really fun to drive over. Speed limit is low though. The views are amazing. I'm always taken aback by how beautiful this area is. I definitely look forward to driving over this bridge on my road trips.

I really loved my walking tour. Two Chicks was recommend by my sister and I did their St. Louis Cemetery #1 tour. Now, I do regret going to the cemetery because it was boring and a waste of my time. But the tour guide, Steve, was great. And he lives in New Orleans, which I appreciate. I don't want a tour from someone who doesn't live in the city. He was funny and knowledgeable and could answer our questions. Plus, I didn't have cash on me and he took Venmo for my tip, which was super appreciated. I would absolutely do a Two Chicks Walking Tour again (they offer a variety of tours to choose from), but just for something I actually want to see.

Morimoto has the uber-chic, trendy atmosphere that I love, but here, that comes with the uppity service that I hate, which is not always the case at a restaurant like this.  Hosts were not friendly.  The server's attitude was that of "If you have questions about the menu, I don't care to answer, and if you aren't spending hundreds of dollars, I don't care to be friendly".  You know that saying of "looking down your nose at someone"?  That's exactly how I felt with our server here (once it was obvious that our bill was only going be in the low hundreds).  The only good thing about our server was that she knew correct service style and placement. 
 
The food was very good, with the whitefish carpaccio with yuzu being the favorite.  It really does melt-in-your-mouth (as did the other dishes) and I recommend eating the pea shoot accompaniment with the sauce as well.  My hamachi rolls were mostly hamachi, which is appreciated.  I love black cod, and this version, paired with a miso mustard, disappeared quickly.  It's obvious that all of the fish here is super fresh and tasty, and I would expect nothing less.  The carafe of sake held a decent amount, and the one we chose went well with our entire order.  Dessert was great--miso honeycake with shiso, vanilla ice cream, fruit compote, and spun sugar.  Honeycake was delicious and the vanilla ice cream rich and flavorful.  Yet, for as tasty as the food was, I remain underwhelmed.    

Dim lighting, sleek design, and ambient music are nice touches, but awful service and paying for a name brand didn't impress me.  There are better restaurants to choose from in Philadelphia.

We stopped in for a brief snack before going to Corsair.  I and another friend had the Ahi tuna tacos, and another companion had the ceviche.  The ceviche and tuna were super fresh, which is appreciated, and overall, we liked our snacks  The chips and salsa were delicious, as they use a thicker chip, which I love.  The menu is not as pricey as I would expect, given the modern, upscale feel of the place.

Service was slow, and after we mentioned we had a time limit, our server seemed to have an attitude.  I don't recommend making this a destination, but if you need to stop in, you probably wouldn't be disappointed.

Being one of the newest places in Nashville, Acme is extremely popular.  While we were standing in line to order (you order at a counter and then sit at a table and wait for your food), I noticed the hostess, mocking a patron who had left in the midst of some type of tantrum or breakdown, to the security guard.  My friend noticed as well, and that sealed the deal of us not eating here.  It's too bad, because the menu looked interesting and the place had a fun vibe.  However, that type of behavior, while not acceptable from the patron, was extremely unacceptable and inappropriate from Acme staff.

This is such a cute little shop in the French Quarter. I wasn't hungry, but wish I had been, as the food menu looked good. I did have a great, well-made almond milk caramel latte. Staff was friendly and I'd return if in the area.

Not the worst tacos, but not the best either. They are alright, and I'm guessing had I been drinking, these would be better.

I tried a few tacos (al pastor, chicken, fish) and chips with salsa and guacamole. Chips/salsa/guac was good. Tacos are bland and not all that exciting. Even my sister, Stacey M., who had been on a hunger strike all day, was less than impressed.

However, I would not turn away after a late night.

I flew Southwest for both my arrival and departure at MSY. Concourse B is entirely devoted to Southwest, which is nice. The concourse is large, quite cold, and a bit dated. Bathrooms are small and far apart (one bathroom only has three stalls), but they were clean and I appreciate the automatic seat covers. I also appreciate that Southwest offers skycap service here. There's two Hudson stores, which is nice. And a Benefit kiosk. But that's about all that's good there. I arrived early for my flight to eat (Dook's Place, just before security) and work. I couldn't connect my phone or my laptop to the wifi or VPN. The waiting areas at the gates are small.

I'll repeat what others have said: it's disappointing that MSY lacks any notable food options, besides Dooky Chase's and Dook's Place. It's also surprising, given the food-focused nature of the city. Also, the airport website is incredibly dated and sorely needs updating. 

I thought the ground crews were a bit slow, as it took a while to get luggage. Directions to the rideshare area are extremely poor and hard to find.

MSY desperately needs modernizing. New Orleans is a hip, funky city and the airport in no way reflects that. An airport is usually a traveler's first impression of the city and MSY leaves a poor one.

I love Ensemble.  It's a cute boutique with amazing prices and a friendly, welcoming owner.  I ended buying some cold-weather accessories and a foundation piece here.  The clothes are cute, and I'd describe them as trendy with a bit of a Southern/country flair.  It's a great place to shop, and I wish there was one in DC.

What a great place to grab a slice or two (or a whole pie). I was somewhat boring and just got two cheese slices, but they were great. Crust could've been a bit crispier, but they were served piping hot and with plenty of cheese. 

It's nothing fancy, but I'm reminded of the pizza parlors of my childhood. I'm told they deliver, but not sure what the area is. Staff was very gracious and friendly.

Cochon is excellent. I walked in during a convention Sunday without a reservation. Wait for one was about an hour, but I was able to get a seatt at the bar in less than ten minutes, so I ate at the bar.

I started with the Smoke on the Water, a mezcal based cocktail with smoked salt. It wasn't as smoky as I had hoped, but it was refreshing, and strong. I ordered the cochon as my main, with a side of greens. It was a tough choice, as the rabbit and dumplings was super appealing and I love a good courtbouillon. But I figured that I needed to order the namesake dish.

They start you with a soft bread and creamy butter that is out of this world. I could've eaten that and died happy. The cochon is huge, smoky, and flavorful. The cracklins and cabbage provide a delicious textural contrast. And the greens are perfectly tender. I ordered the German chocolate cake to-go and that was underwhelming. It was bad, but just compared to how amazing everything else was, I would order an appetizer instead of dessert when I return. 

I would also definitely make a reservation to sit at a table. The bartenders were fine, but a packed bar, with most patrons eating dinner, is tough on service. But they were friendly enough, my order was correct, and my drink was great.  

When in New Orleans, Cochon is not to be missed.

Honeymoon Island is beautiful, and I felt like I was on a tropical island. Well, somewhat, anyway. The water is not as pretty as some pictures make it seem, and the beach (we were in the Oasis part, I believe) had nice sand, but the shore was rocky. It was quiet and relaxing, and alcohol is not allowed (not that I tried to bring any). 

I'd love to get back and check out the trails, though the rattlesnake signs scare me. I did think it was prettier than Clearwater Beach, though, and it is worth a trip if you are visiting the area.

Best place to eat in Terminal E - the other options are quite lame.  They were out of Shocktop; I had a 6 row honey weizen that I liked.  

Food menu was limited; I went for the pulled pork sandwich and fries.  It was small, so if you are ravenous, you might need something else.  But it was tasty - the roll was toasted, which is always appreciated, and the beer-based BBQ sauce on the shredded pork was thick and tangy.  Fries were crisp.

Service was awful (not friendly, dirty tables) and it took 45 minutes for my food to arrive.  However, the small restaurant and bar were packed, with one server and one cook, so I blame poor management, not the staff.  If ever at STL on a layover again, I'd go here.

Dooky Chase's storied reputation made it a must-stop on my trip to New Orleans, and I'm glad it was. Not only to honor Leah Chase, but to honor everything this restaurant stands for. And because I really liked the food.

I went for the lunch buffet and quite enjoyed it. It's reasonably priced and has a variety of offerings, and I'd stick to that. I went with the greens, fried chicken, red beans and rice, and salad. The soup was chicken vegetable and the dessert was peach cobbler. The greens and fried chicken were great. I could barely eat and still had to get seconds. The chicken vegetable soup was extremely fresh. And the peach cobbler was rich and flavorful, and one of my favorite versions.

The decor is is nice, but worn. The artwork is great. The hostesses are insanely nice and friendly--I tried to be as nice to them as they were to me. My server was good, but I experienced what others have--she disappeared. And when I needed hot sauce it was a while before I saw anyone on the floor that I could flag. So service could definitely be more attentive. I arrived around 11:40 on a Wednesday, and in about ten minutes, Dooky's was packed, so that seems to be the right time to arrive. 

I'd go back for the lunch buffet anytime and you can find me dreaming about that cobbler.

Three stars because this store isn't great. It's still a La Colombe and I love it but it's tiny and it was crowded and noisy at 2 p.m. Nowhere to sit and you could barely get in line. I much prefer the Rittenhouse location. This location is convenient but the setup is awful and combined with the crowds, it was hell. Staff was friendly despite the out-of-order espresso machine, which was impressive. I guess that's when the draft lattes truly come in handy. Great staff but I'd skip this location in the future.

The Row was a good choice for lunch.  Our server, whose name I wish I remembered, was fantastic, especially when I need to sample several beers before choosing.  I eventually chose a Yazoo, but forget which one--it was great though.

We started with the fried pickles, which I never like, but these were super tasty, and as a non-pickle eater, I would eat these again.  I ordered the Nashville hot chicken with a spicy corn cake and bacon mac and cheese.  The chicken was good--I ordered a heat level of hot, which was spicy, but not overly so.  However, the bacon mac and cheese was perfect, with the right amount of bacon and well-cooked macaroni. My sister liked her veggie burger (and I liked her fries) and our friends enjoyed their chicken-fried chicken.

The whole vibe of The Row is friendly and welcoming, and it's definitely music-themed, which I loved.

The coffee here is great. Totally not what I was expecting--off a busy road, with not a lot of parking, and not much else nearby. But we all got iced lattes and loved them. It was a well-balanced, tasty drink.

Pastries looked great, and staff was friendly. It was better than the two coffee shops I tried in Tampa, and I'd go here over those two any day.

I love a great sandwich and DiNic's shaved pork with provolone is one of those sandwiches.  It's huge and filled with plenty of delicious pork and cheese.  The bread is great, too.  My only regret?  Not adding the broccoli rabe.  But I will next time.

Whiskey Kitchen seems to be Nashville's hot spot, in one of the hottest neighborhoods, The Gulch.  While I can't figure out why The Gulch is so popular (maybe because it's new?), I can see why Whiskey Kitchen is popular.  The hip, sexy vibe inside and relaxed patio make it a fun choice.  Would I deal with the two hour wait time if I lived here?  Absolutely not--this isn't a restaurant that warrants that long of a wait, but it is good.  But since I was visiting, I didn't care.

We ended up snagging some spots on the patio in about 40 minutes.  I love the heat lamps that make the patio open year-round.  Our server was really sweet.  I started with the blackberry julep--tasty, but not strong.  Maybe skip the drinks here.  For food, we started with yam fries.  It's a huge serving, and even with four famished females, finishing it just wasn't in the cards.  I got the shrimp and grits with a side of the Tennessee cheddar bacon ale soup as my main course.  The shrimp were decently-sized and not overcooked.  The entire dish was flavorful with the right amount of heat.  But that soup.  I'm not soup person, but when I saw that it was made with Yazoo, which I'd had a day earlier, something told me to try it.  It was rich and the perfect balance of tangy and savory.  I found a lone fry to dip in it, and that was a fantastic choice.  Get the soup. I tried my friend's mac and cheese which was also great. And my sister and friends enjoyed their meals, as well.   

But get the damn soup.

Since we were attending a conference in Biloxi, we decided to stop by a couple of casinos on the way there from New Orleans.  This casino is located in downtown New Orleans.  It's been over 10 yrs since I've visited the casino.  I remember when it was brand new and visiting it the weekend after grand opening.

I was pleased to see that it was very similar to what I remember.  It's large with a lot of slot machines  and table games to choose from.  The casino lacked the "vibe" that I remember from a long time ago.  It's not as exciting as it used to be.  It seemed like everyone in there wasn't having any fun.  There was no "electricity" in the air.  Perhaps I was there on the wrong night?  I don't know.

We didn't stay long.  Just long enough to lose a few buck giving Lady Luck a chance.  We left empty handed.

Return Factor - 70%

This golf course is simply amazing.  One of my favorite golf courses in the State of Arizona.  I was lucky enough to play it just before it opened and the design and layout of the course is really unique to the Tucson area.  When you're on the course, it doesn't feel like you're in the desert.

You have to bring your A-game because the layout can be deceiving, which is what makes it fun.  Easy golf courses are not fun golf courses...at least to me.  This one is truly a great experience and if you're a golfer in the area, you'd be missing out if you didn't play here.

I can't wait to come back to Tucson to play again.

Return Factor - 99%

Stayed here for 4 nights on a business trip.  The property is kind of old, but has been renovated and is very comfortable.  I would have rated the property 2 Stars, but the items highlighted with the asterisk (*) below pushed it up to 3 Stars.

Here's what I LIKED:
- *Soft, pillow top beds.

- Comfortable pillows.

- *Player's Sports Pub in the lobby was a great place to eat.

- The fresh cookies.

- The reasonable prices for the sundries....not great, but they aren't too high priced.

- The linens were soft & fresh.  Bathroom linens were comfortable.

- The service at the front desk & the lounge was exceptional.....good people with great personality.

Here's what I DIDN'T LIKE:
- The Air Conditioner unit was very loud.  If you raised the volume on the TV to overcome the noise it was all of a sudden too loud when the AC shut off....maddening.

- The parking was atrocious.....finding a spot in the lot was impossible.  The parking garage had plenty of spaces, but guess what??  No elevators!  Have you ever tried walking down 3 flights of stairs with all of your luggage in the Florida heat/humidity?  This one thing alone really pissed me off.

- High Speed internet was FREE in the lounge, but you had to pay in your room.  Nonsense.

- Small bathroom.

Will I return?  I'm on the fence with this......it depends on my other options.  Definitely way better than the La Quinta I stayed at the last trip to Tampa.

During a recent trip to the Gulf Coast, we flew into New Orleans and made the drive into Mississippi.  Before we left the State of Louisiana, we stopped by this casino in Kenner.  It's near the airport, so it was convenient for us.  It's been over 10 yrs since I've been here....and from the looks of it, they haven't replaced the carpet or painted the casino.  It was dirty and smokey.  A far cry from the bustling riverboat I remember in the late 90's and early 00's.

Most of the slot machines were the older variety, with very few of the newer games available.  It was just a sad vibe, so we didn't stay long at all.  We also passed on eating here as the restaurants didn't look appetizing.

Return Factor - 5%

The rooms here are very nice and the property appears to be relatively new and in good shape.  However, the following prevented me from rating this 3 stars:

- The A/C unit in the room doesn't have a thermostat.  It is one that is attached to the wall under the window.

- The window doesn't have Blackout drapes....the sun is going to shine right through.

- The gym is very small & has crappy equipment.  The elliptical machine is the worst I've ever used.

On the positive side....the front desk staff was very friendly, continental breakfast is served daily, and the rates are really good.

Will I stay here again?  Not if I can find a Hilton Garden Inn for a similar rate.

After a couple of hours in the Dali Museum, I decided to walk next door to grab a quick bite to eat at this place.  I saw the sign for it on the way in to the museum.  There is a small yacht sales office adjacent to the deli.

You can have a beer with your meal.  You order inside and a server takes your order to your table if you decide to eat outside.  The weather was perfect, so I sat outside.  Lots of nice yachts are around.

I had the turkey club on a hoagie roll w/chipotle mayo & mustard.  The sandwich was delicious.  Not the best I've had, but good.  Standard bag of chips and sodas are available as well.  There were hot/cold sandwiches on the menu.

Would I return?  Yes, the next time I visit to the Dali Museum I will stop by for a quick snack.

My business partner grew up in Atlantic City and spent a lot of time in Philly growing up.  So when we made a business trip out to Philly & AC he took me for a tour of his old hangout spots.  One of the stops was Manny Brown's.

Since we just loaded up on Roast Beef sandwiches at Nick's in South Philly, we weren't hungry but were parched, so we decided to saddle up to the bar and grab a few drinks.

They have a pretty extensive beer selection both on tap & bottled.  Since it was Happy Hour and select draft beers were 1/2 OFF, I decided to with that....I had a Franszikaner Hefeweizen to start and my 2nd choice was a Bell's Oberon Ale, recommended by the bartender.  Both were amazingly good....and it was 1/2 OFF too!  Yeah baby!  I love Philly!

Will I come back?  If I can remember how to get there, I will!

I travel a lot and normally rent from Hertz.  However, this trip Enterprise beat Hertz by 30% on price, so I couldn't justify the added expense.

Usually the service at most Enterprise rental locations is slow.  However, that was not the case with this one.  There was a team of people who greeted us coming off the airport shuttle ready to assist.  They quickly got us registered and walked us out to the car, which is standard Enterprise procedure.

The girl who helped us was very friendly and informative.  The place was clean and they even had complimentary snacks (pretzels & water) available...(see pics for details).

Also, a huge plus was the poster of Rocky Balboa in the lobby (see pics)....you know you're in Philly Baby!!!  Yo Adrian!!

Will I return?  Next time I'm in Philly...you bet!

I heard about this place from a friend (@amandastewart) on Twitter.  I am a huge fan of Salvador Dali.  When I found out it was only 30 min away from where I was staying in Tampa, I had to go there.

The drive from Tampa wasn't bad.  The weather was perfect.  Parking for the museum is available in two parking lots.  The parking lot located next to the museum building is very small and packed.  I had to park in the dirt/sand lot across the street.

When you walk into the museum you are inside of the Dali store.  Adult entry is $17.  The store had plenty of Dali merchandise at reasonable prices.

The museum features 6 of Dali's Masterworks.  They are breathtaking.  There are other works of art that Dali created, however I left wanting more.  I thought there would be many more pieces on display.  

There are several guided tours available throughout the day.  I tried to follow one, but it was too slow for me and I couldn't hear what the guide was saying.  It was difficult to see the works of art during the tour, so that was another reason why I ditched the tour in favor of exploring on my own.

Cameras and cell phones are not permitted inside the gallery area.

My business partner grew up in Atlantic City and spent a lot of time in Philadelphia.  So, when I found out we were going to come out this way for a business trip, he said that we must stop by Nick's for Roast Beef....that there was nothing like it.

So, we did.....and Nick's delivered!  The beef sandwich was very juicy and had the right amount of beef in it....not too much and not too little.  We ordered the combo, which basically meant with cheese.  We ordered 2 each that's how good they were.  Additionally, I ordered a side of Italian Hots...which are grilled hot Italian peppers....they hit the spot!

And what did we chase it down with?  Why a pitcher of Yuengling of course!

Good times!

Will I return? Only if I have my buddy with me....there is no way I'm venturing into South Philly on my own!

Visiting Tampa for the second time, our colleagues here decided to take us out to Boizao.  I've never been to one of these Brazilian Steakhouses, but have heard a lot about them.  I knew that I was in for a lot of food.

Food - The amount of meat that you eat here is ridiculous.  14 different types of meat is offered to you throughout the evening.  There is a cardboard circle in front of your seat that is red on one side and green on the other.  If you place the green side up, they will offer you a piece of meat....if you have the red side up, they will pass your table.  I had the green side up most of the evening. I think I sampled everything except one or two types of meat.  Here's what I tasted:

Filet Mignon
Filet Wrapped in Bacon
Lamb Chops
Leg of Lamb
Pork Tenderloin
Ribs
Prime Rib
Picanha
Picanha com alho (with Garlic)
Top Sirloin
Bottom Sirloin
Brazilian Pork Sausages
Chicken Legs marinated with beer

Yep....I pig'd out!  I passed on the salad bar though....as I knew I would have to save room in my stomach for all of this food.  I even had a little room for a Tiramisu for dessert.

Service - I thought the service was excellent.  There were 7 of us and we never had an empty glass of wine, water, or food.  The servers were very attentive and cordial.

Atmosphere - The dining room is large and dark.  Nice setting for a dinner.  The tables are spaced appropriately....what I mean is that they aren't too close together.

Parking - There is valet parking that's available.

Special Offers - I hear that kids under 7 eat FREE.  That's what my colleague who lives in Tampa tells me.  He says they come here once a month with his 5 kids.  That's a great deal.

Will I return?  Only when I'm in the mood for massive amounts of meat....which is not too often.  That's not because I don't like the restaurant, it's because I don't eat meat that much.

This place is a dump.  It's basically a gutted warehouse that looks like it was built in the 1960's and hasn't been updated since.  We came here for a gun show, which had very few vendors.  The parking is small and the entry to the expo center is weird....it's on the right side near the back of the building.

If I was a meeting planner, I wouldn't hold any meetings here unless it was for a swapmeet.

Return Factor - 1%

Ok, so I found this place using Yelp.  I was in town on business and my hotel was only a couple of miles away.  After reading the excellent reviews, I decided to give it a try by myself.  Here are my thoughts.....

Service - Everyone was friendly and knowledgeable.  I was greeted by the host and seated immediately.  My waitress was on top of things and the food came out on time an fresh.

Food - I had the Tomato & Feta Bruschetta w/Baked Tortilla for an appetizer....it was awesome!  I highly recommend it.  The bread was fresh and delicious.  For an entree, I had the cheeseburger....I would have tried something else, but I really wanted to try the bruschetta appetizer and I didn't think I could eat that and an entree by myself.  The burger was excellent....just the right size, not too large and not too small.  The fries were steak-cut fries and cooked perfectly....not too hard/soft.

Atmosphere - I was here in the Spring time and the weather was awesome....so I ate outside on the patio.  I'm glad I did....it was very relaxing.

Wine - The wine selection was decent....not great, but decent.  I had a glass of the Malbec....don't remember what the vineyard was though.

While I was dining....there were no more than 5 tables occupied in the joint.  I heard that lunch and brunch are much busier.  So, I guess if you want to enjoy the place and have a nice, relaxing time.....go at dinner.

Will I return?  If I'm in the area.....For Sure!

Stayed two nights here.  Rooms are very nice, but the bathroom is a little small.  They're modern and clean, which is very important to me.

They have a very good selection of restaurants.  We dined at the Buffet, Steakhouse & Mexican joint during our stay.  Reviews on those are here:

PY Steakhouse
http://www.yelp.com/biz/py-steakhouse-tucson#hrid:8KJbPpTCgqNlNOgIBiLAWw

Tequila Factory
http://www.yelp.com/biz/tequila-factory-tucson#hrid:32_J-W-4rNrDap9JNFCmog

Festa Buffet
http://www.yelp.com/biz/festa-buffet-tucson#hrid:bGixUWahY--pO_K9AC42-w

The staff is very friendly.  They greeted you at every guest touchpoint and asked if you needed assistance.

Overall, this was a very cool place for a short weekend getaway.

TIP - Be careful of the speed traps on the road to/from this place.  There are photo/radar speed traps that will nail you if you are not careful.  Signs warning you about it are small and difficult to read...easy to overlook.  A friend got a ticket during our trip

Return Factor - 88%

This bar was located in the lobby of the hotel I was staying at.  The place is decorated with sports memorabilia and the banners of the local teams. 

Food - The food here is ok.  I tried the Angus Sliders, which were good and the nachos, which were bleh.  The menu is an extensive bar menu with all of the typical bar menu items.

Drinks - It is a full bar, so they can make all types of drinks.  The one thing that surprised me was that they didn't have Shock Top....which is a wheat beer.  You can find Shock Top all over Tampa, but not here for some reason.  Instead, they have Blue Moon....which is very good, but I enjoy Shock Top when I'm in Tampa.

Service - The waitresses and bartenders here are very friendly.  However, at times they can forget about you and leave you with an empty glass for a while.  One good thing is that there are tons of TVs in the bar, so if there is a game you want to watch that's not on one of the TVs, they will put it on one for you.

Will I return?  If I'm staying in the area.....yes.

Amazing find on Yelp....my business partner and I were in Tampa for a business meeting and decided to get some Italian Food....found The Laughing Cat and were glad we decided to take the trip to Ybor City.

Food - I had a Caprese Salad for an appetizer while my friend had the Mussels with Marinara sauce.  The portions were huge.  

For entrees, I had the Lasagna while he had the Veal Parmigiana....again, both huge portions.  The Veal was really big....there was no way we were going to finish.

The food was excellent.  The only thing that I would have liked done differently is that I like my pasta al dente.  The Lasagna was a little overcooked in my opinion.....great flavor though.

Service - The service was awesome.....can't complain.

Atmosphere - The place is a hole in the wall.....not upscale by any means, but the food is worth it.

Will I return?  If I'm back in the area....you bet!

On the way back to Phoenix, I searched the Yelp app for a Sandwich joint nearby to grab some lunch before the trip.  This place had 4 & 5 Star reviews, so I thought I found a winner.  I ordered:

8" Deluxe Grinder, $4.89
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eegees-tucson-4?select=5GUDytvicuMtazmAP7_uhg#5GUDytvicuMtazmAP7_uhg

French Fries, $2.29
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eegees-tucson-4?select=hUcEgMIuvWuP_URura7TAw#hUcEgMIuvWuP_URura7TAw

The Grinder was just ok at best.  I thought the Bread was too soft and sweet for my tastes....almost like Wonder Bread, but shaped like a Hoagie.

The Fries were nothing to brag about either.

Overall, it's a 3 Star joint for me....would have given 2.5 Stars if Yelp had 1/2 Stars available.

Return Factor - 10%

On the second night of our trip, we decided to give this joint a try.  The standard complimentary Chips & Salsa are served when you sit down.  We asked the waiter for extra spicy Salsa and he gladly obliged with a Habanero Salsa that kicks your heiney....yum!

After browsing the menu, we decided to order:

Cheese Crisp, $3

2 Crispy Tacos & 1 Bean tostada, $12
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=pCI5eN2ZiGzVnJl7ppauDg#pCI5eN2ZiGzVnJl7ppauDg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=pufGHErnon1I3FlCCnL8Eg#pufGHErnon1I3FlCCnL8Eg

Chicken Arizona (Chicken Breast, Avocados, Tomatoes, Green Chile, Pepper Jack Cheese, Veggies, Spanish Rice), $10
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=mTrEqN0RXH7ONKqdI2B6Yw#mTrEqN0RXH7ONKqdI2B6Yw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=OIhripvCwd2wcqxbnsUTtQ#OIhripvCwd2wcqxbnsUTtQ

Number 6 - 3 Soft Tacos (Carne de Cabeza, Trepas de Leche, Chicharron), $12
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=WozpsO6J77Zhvwx6PblT8Q#WozpsO6J77Zhvwx6PblT8Q
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tequila-factory-tucson?select=hcM2oHdeErA9yjzcjf2vIw#hcM2oHdeErA9yjzcjf2vIw

The Cheese Crisp was ok.  So was my Tacos & Tostada.  I wasn't overly blown away with it.

The Better Half had the Number 6 combo and it was a little to exotic for her.  She didn't realize that she was ordering Cow Brains, Cow Stomach, and Pork Skins....LOL  

Kiddo had the Chicken Arizona and he was very pleased with it.

Overall, it's an OK dining experience.  

Return Factor - 60%

Located near the Tucson airport, this casino is nice, but very small.  Self parking is kind of far from the entrance.  We walked from the hotel to the casino and it was a bit of a walk....not sure why they didn't make it closer.

The machines were so/so...it's all luck anyway, but the selection of machines were quite limited.

Return Factor - 50%

I am visiting Tampa for a week on a business trip and asked the front desk clerk at the hotel where I'm staying where I should go for dinner.  She referred me to The Green Iguana, which is located near the Football and Baseball Stadiums.  I decided to go check this place out.

Food - I asked the bartender what their most requested dish was....she said the "Cheesiest Cheeseburger"....so, I decided to give it a shot.  Here's what the menu says about it:

"CHEESIEST CHEESE BURGER - $7.49
Nobody - but nobody - puts more cheese on a burger than the Green Iguana. Triple-cheesed with American, Cheddar, Provolone and mayo."

The burger was very good.  Not the best I've ever had, but very good.

Service - Since I was eating alone, I ate at the bar.  The bartender was very friendly and was very helpful in helping me choose.  She made sure that my glass of beer was never empty.  Overall, the service was above average.

Atmosphere - From what I've heard, this place can be really fun.  But since I went there on a Tuesday night, it was relatively calm.  It reminded me of a bar you would see in Mexico or somewhere Tropical.....kind of like a Jimmy Buffet meets Cabo type of thing.

Would I come back?  Yes, but would prefer to be there with some friends or my wife.....felt kind of uncomfortable being there alone.  Although, I overheard some interesting conversations at the bar...LOL.

One of the worst airports I've ever been to.  Main reason is because it's $7.95 for WiFi here....#fail

If it wasn't for the food & music in the bars/restaurants, I'd give it 1 star.  The worst part is that I actually like Nashville the city, so I'll probably have to come here again.

Return Factor - 90%

We were in Montecito for a weekend trip and were staying next door at the Montecito Inn.  On the way to meet some friends for Breakfast, I walked by this store.  It piqued my interest, so I dropped in.  The lady working that day was very friendly and greeted me as soon as I walked in.  There is a large selection of Balsamic Vinegar & Olive Oil.  I was actually looking for a Balsamic Reduction, which is very thick and sweet.  I asked her if she had any and she said "no", but that they had an alternative option that might work for me.

She poured a sample for me to taste and I took a little sip....I didn't dip Bread into it because I wanted to taste it without any else....well, the verdict was...amazing!  I bought a bottle and a pouring spout.

I'm so glad I found this store...just wish it was closer to home!

Return Factor - 100%

What a great hole in the wall place to have a drink.  I stopped here with a friend to have a few drinks after dinner.  Great Irish Pub.....they have Wednesday Night specials with $.50 Pabst Blue Ribbon Beer specials.....where are the Rockabillys??

On Friday, they have $4 Jameson shot specials and a 60 oz Drink Special....granted, its' $25-$30 depending on the alcohol you order.

Will I return?  Sure.

On a recent trip to the Gulf Coast we were planning to do quite a bit of driving, so I rented a car through Hertz.  I'm a Gold Member, so it's really easy to pick up a vehicle....you just walk up to the one assigned to you in the lot.  Unfortunately, this didn't work out on this trip.  The car assigned to me wasn't ready.  This was the first time that's ever happened in over 100+ rentals from Hertz.  However, this was my first time renting from this location since pre-Katrina.

They offered a different vehicle, which was a full size car.  However, that didn't work for me because I had 4 other colleagues with me and I needed the SUV that I reserved in order for us to fit all of our luggage into the vehicle.  After 20 minutes and a lot of apologizing, they finally pulled up the SUV I ordered.

This was the worst experience with Hertz I've had in over 15 yrs as a regular customer.  I hope it was an anomaly and not a habit.

Return Factor - 30%

This airport really disappointed me.  Here's my experience with it:

Pro's
- It has Jet Rock Bar & Grill which is a great place to grab a beer & food (the only thing that prevented me from rating 1 Star)
- Security line moved pretty quickly

Con's
- Baggage claim took F-O-R-E-V-E-R!
- No FREE Wireless Connection, you have to pay via AT&T....#FAIL
- Not enough seats at the gates, some gates didn't have seats
- Super long wait to take off, congested (see pics)...pilots said it was par for the course here

If I can avoid this airport, I would.....unfortunately, if I'm doing business in the area, I can't avoid it.

Read the reviews on Yelp and decided to give it a try.  Growing up in Southern California and living in the Southwest for 30 yrs, I'm familiar with good Mexican food.  Was hoping to find some here.

The weather was awesome, so I sat outside on the patio.

Chips & Salsa - They were a little too salty for my taste.  The chips are very thin...I prefer thicker chips.  The salsa was very mild....had no bite to it.  I like spicy salsa, or at least the option to get spicy salsa.

Entree - All of the entrees looked very appealing.  The waiter told me that they now offer Kobe beef as an option for fajitas, tacos, carne asada, and a couple of other beef dishes.  I decided to go with the Pollo Fundido Chimichanga.....this is a queso topped chimichanga (fried burrito) filled with cream cheese & chicken breast.  It comes with a side of rice/beans on the plate.  The dish was very tasty.

Service - The waiter was friendly & helpful.  The food came out fast and I was able to be seated quickly.  I thought the staff was excellent.

If the Pollo Fundido wasn't really good, this place was headed for 2 stars in my book.  I will have to try a few more dishes before I can give it a definitive rating....it gets 3 stars for now.

Will I come back?  Yes, I probably will if I'm in the area.  Although there are a few more places that I wanted to try.

This was the 3rd restaurant we tried during our stay at Casino del Sol.  We had the Breakfast buffet.  It was OK.  Your standard breakfast fare was available.....Eggs, Bacon, Sausage, Omelet station, etc.

The line for the Omelet station was long.  My recommendation is that you place your Omelet order first, then go around to the other stations to fill up your plate.  By the time you're done, your Omelet will be done and you'll have a nice, hot Omelet to go with your plate.

There was no line the morning we went, which was a Saturday.  The service was pretty good.  Our drink glasses were kept full and our server checked on us often to ensure we were ok.

Overall, a decent buffet experience.

Return Factor - 60%

There is no way I could visit the South and not have BBQ.  I searched Yelp and found this listed as a 4 Star restaurant.

When I arrived, I was pleased to see that they had an option for small or large sandwiches.  This allowed me to try more than 1.

Food - I had a small Sliced BBQ Beef and a small BBQ Pork sandwich.  Both sandwiches came with 1 Hush Puppy and a mustard cole slaw for spreading on the sandwich.  I ordered some fries as well.

The flavor of the pork sandwich was very good.  I was pleased to see that the meat wasn't doused in BBQ sauce.  I hate it when places do that.  They give you a bottle of their house BBQ sauce with your order so that you can add it to your meal as you see fit.  It had a nice smoky flavor.  The size of the sandwich was perfect....approx 4-5 oz of meat on a med sized bun.  The mustard cole slaw was an awesome touch to the sandwich.

The flavor of the Sliced BBQ Beef sandwich was just as good.  There was no BBQ sauce at all on the sandwich and was slightly dry...which is how I like it.   Again, the mustard cole slaw was a great add-on to the flavor.  I added a little of the house BBQ sauce to both sandwiches.  

The only thing was I wish there was a spicier option for the sauce.  I like BBQ sauce with bite.  There were bottles of tabasco and peppers on the table....but I think a BBQ restaurant should have a spicy house sauce.

The fries were fresh cut steak fries.  They were fried just right...not too soggy and not too crispy.  Good level of salt added too.  They get an A+ here.  The same for the Hush Puppies...they were fried just right.  I hate when Hush Puppies are over or under cooked.  That wasn't the case here.

Service - The staff there was very friendly.  They asked if that was my first time visiting them and offered a few suggestions.  They were also very friendly to the other patrons in the restaurants, so that was a huge plus in my book.

I gave them 4 Stars....would have given them 5 Stars if they had spicier sauce options.  I also would have liked to see a hot links sandwich....but I understand that you can't find that in all restaurants.

Will I return?  If I have the opportunity to come back to Tampa, absolutely!

On a recent trip to Nashville my colleagues decided to make dinner reservations here.  I'm very familiar with their restaurant in Vegas and knew that the quality of the food and service was excellent so I agreed to come with them.

I'm glad I did.  There was a concert across the street that evening, so the place was packed.  Luckily, we had reservations, so we were seated promptly.

Hungry for some Steak, I ordered the 9 oz Filet, $44.90 with a side of Three Cheese Potatoes Au Gratin, $7.90.

The food and service was excellent.  Exactly as I would expect from a Palm Restaurant.

Next time I'm in Nashville, I will definitely return.

Return Factor - 90%

Had a 2 hour wait before my flight back to Vegas, so my business partner & I stopped here for a few drinks and to get some work done.  We found a table with outlets nearby for our laptops.

They have a pretty large selection of beer, which is impressive.  I ordered a tall Shock Top.  The waitress was very friendly and fast with her service.  Since we ate a whole pizza in Atlantic City, we weren't hungry, so I can't comment on the food.

Will I return?  If I'm in this airport, you bet I will.

Had a business meeting in the area, so we stayed here for 1 night.  The hotel is relatively new and very clean.  The girl who checked us in at the front desk was very friendly and helpful with directions.

There is complimentary continental breakfast & FREE Wireless Internet.  Huge bonus there.

The fitness facilities are adequate and there is an indoor swimming pool!  Too bad I'm not staying here long enough to use either one of those amenities.

Great value and good place to stay if you're in the area.

Will I return?  If I have to return for business, you bet.

I am in Tampa on business and went to this restaurant based on a recommendation from a colleague.  He invited to come check out the Hard Rock Tampa style.

The restaurant is very upscale and reminds me of many of the restaurants in Las Vegas.  You can watch the butcher cut the beef at the front of the restaurant.....I'm not really into that, but it is interesting.

The restaurant is decorated in a modern decor....don't know how else to describe it.  They have an action kitchen where you can see what they are doing.

Appetizers - I had a Caprese Salad, which was very good.  My colleague had the crab cakes....he said they were delicious.

Entree - I had the New York Strip.  They serve dry aged beef.....I ordered mine medium-well....and it came out slightly overdone...but it still tasted wonderful.  Sides are ordered separately.  I ordered Au Gratin Potatoes.....yum!

The wine selection was decent....could have been better.  The wines by the glass was good.

Will I return?  Yes....but it's kind of pricey, so only if I want to impress a client or come with my better half.  Would not come back for sport.

For some reason I thought I reviewed this airport.  I guess I forgot to....

I flew in/out of this airport 4 times this year.  The airport has great food options with TGIF being my favorite place to hang out while I was here.  I grabbed a Beer and jumped on my laptop to get some work done.  There's plenty of seating around the gates and it's easy to find information regarding your flight.

They have FREE Wireless here, so that's always a bonus that bumps it up a Star.

The one BIG negative to this airport is that it's very, very confusing to drive in/out of this place.  If you're a local, it might be easy, but for non-locals it's not intuitive and you can easy jump on the wrong freeway and turning around to correct a mistake is not convenient.  If you're driving, do your homework before you leave the airport and don't rely on your GPS as there are some quick decisions you have to make with several choices for turns.....the GPS doesn't work well, trust me on this.

Will I return?  I hope so, I enjoyed the Tampa area.

On the way home, we came to the airport a little early.  We decided to park ourselves somewhere to grab a drink or three.  We walked around the airport and found this lounge near our gate.  There was a guy playing acoustic guitar and singing and the joint was packed.

We waited for a table of 4 to get up and we quickly swiped it before the server could clean it off.  It was a madhouse, if we didn't do that we'd be left standing.  After we settled in, we noticed that the performer was in the band that played at the Honky Tonk Central the night before.  We confirmed that when we asked him during one of his breaks....awesome.  Only in Nashville have I seen quality entertainment like this at an airport!

We drank some Beers and had Chips & Salsa, $4.99 w/Cheese Sauce, $1.50 until we were ready to board our plane.

What a cool place to get your drink on before a flight.

Return Factor - 80%

This place is the ultimate college bar.  It's next to campus and Greek row and gets packed with college kids.  We parked nearby when we went to a game down there and stopped by on the way back to our hotel.  We were lucky and found a table of four next to the bar.  

We downed a couple of pitchers, then called for a cab to drive us back to the hotel.  It was fun to people watch....and damn, I felt old after leaving the place.

Return Factor - 50%

On a recent trip to the Gulf Coast, we flew into Louis Armstrong Airport.  I've always known it as MSY.  It's been over 10 yrs since I last flew into town.  When I arrived, I was surprised to find an old, run down building.  Much worse than I remember it.  I guess post Katrina hasn't been too good to it.

It was nice to see the Jazz musicians playing at the baggage claim area.  That's a nice touch that's unique to NOLA.  There's free WiFi here, but I didn't have time to use it as I was barely in time for my departing flight on the way home.

Return Factor - 60%

One of the things that I absolutely have to have is a car that I enjoy driving.  I spend a lot of time in my car and I don't want to be miserable.  A few years ago I bought a G35 Coupe.....it is an understatement when I say that I L-O-V-E driving my G35!  I will invent reasons to drive places just so I can get on the road with my car....here's why:

- It has some giddy-up.  Yes, I like to drive fast....in a safe way of course!  This car is not only fast, but also quick....there's a difference.  Getting up to highway speeds from an onramp traffic light is so easy.  One of my favorite things to do...heh!

- It handles well.  There are times where I actually believe my car is on rails.....enough said.

- Comfortable interior and cockpit.  I love sitting in the driver's seat and feeling the car take you along for the ride.  The controls are intuitive and easy to understand.

- Design.  I love the design of the G35....disappointed with the look of the G37 though.  I think the G37 is too 'curvy'....I like the sharper edges on the G35.  Hopefully, Infiniti will correct this in future designs.

- Rear seat legroom.  You probably think there's no room for passengers in the back seat.....that's not the case with this car.  I've had people as tall as 5'10" sit in the back seat with enough leg and head room to feel comfortable. Over that height and it gets cramped.

Overall, this is one of the best value sports/luxury cars you can get for the money.  It's reasonably priced and a lot of fun to drive!

This place is antiquated.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/arizona-stadium-tucson?select=FghoBNkBDCEX4dN5zb1auw#FghoBNkBDCEX4dN5zb1auw

Parking is atrocious and there's no decent tailgate areas around the stadium.  We tailgated at a bar called Dirtbag's near the campus.

The food options were worse than a high school football stadium with very little room to move around, especially pre-game and at halftime.  The bathrooms were very tiny too and if you went during halftime the line was wrapped around the corner....it was better to leave the stadium, walk downstairs to the entrance and use one of those facilities.  

There seems to be an expansion going on at one of the end zones.  I hope they upgrade the existing facilities while they're at it.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/arizona-stadium-tucson?select=d5ZB75zKWD2CY1hJdXVOxA#d5ZB75zKWD2CY1hJdXVOxA

Return Factor - 100% (there's no alternative)

We dropped in here during a recent trip to Nashville.  What an awesome place to drink a few Beers and listen to music.  I know there's 100's of these joints around town, but this was around the corner from our hotel and was a ton of fun.  There were multiple levels, I think at least 3 maybe 4, I can't remember exactly.  The band on the main floor was a ton of fun.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZhA88ILcgEP9DNwZDx7f0A?select=So23CpKLJ7aYIlj3Bwxrfg#So23CpKLJ7aYIlj3Bwxrfg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZhA88ILcgEP9DNwZDx7f0A?select=OYjeqpbup17ahf9Z1DullQ#OYjeqpbup17ahf9Z1DullQ

The girl playing the Violin was awesome.  She jammed and had the place on their feet all night long.  It's too bad I can't remember the name of the band....funny thing is that one of the guys in the band playing the night we were here was playing at one of the bars in the airport when we left the next day...awesome, that's why I love Nashville.

Return Factor - 80%

Ate here during our recent stay in the resort and was seriously impressed with the joint.  The dining room is much smaller than I expected, but they deliver great service and awesome food.  They have Steak & Tapas on the menu.  Here's what I ordered:

Tapas
Chorizo, $4
Jalapeno Bacon Wrapped Dates, $4
Manchego Cheese, $4

Main Course
Gorgonzola Mashed Potatoes, $5
10 oz Filet - $38

The Tapas were very good, especially the Jalapeno Bacon Wrapped Dates.  A spicy twist on the Bacon Wrapped Dates concept, they are full of flavor.  I could eat a large plate of these all day long...ha!

The Filet was cooked just the way I like it, with just a little pink in the center.  It was very tasty.  The Gorgonzola Mashed Potatoes are ridiculous....how come I haven't thought of that before?!  I love Gorgonzola Cheese and to make Mashed Potatoes with it is pure genius!  I'm jonesing for them right now...

The service was impeccable.  When 2 friends joined us late into the dinner because they were in the casino gambling, they didn't miss a step.  They easily adapted to this situation and made us feel comfortable.

Next trip to Tucson it will be on the list.

Return Factor - 90%

"Stormin Norman" keepin' it real at the bar.
Talk about oyster shuckin' madness.
This place is probably one of the most talked about places to eat oysters while in New Orleans, but apparently, people should be talking about Stormin Norman who is world famous for his oyster shucking skills.

The line was down the block , but lucky for me, a party of one or two can scoot right up to the front of the line if willing to sit at the oyster bar. I don't like to wait in line, so I would have sat on the curb to eat oysters that day.

So fresh and so good!

It's packed inside, and loud, but the energy is that of New York or any city where time is money and people love your food.

2 words...Do IT!!

It is the fastest food outside of fast food for lunch that I have ever experienced. 
The food was OK.
I ordered the Pick Two (standard Panera bread menu). The tortilla soup was more tortilla strips than soup and the sandwich was about the size of a dollar coin.
Luckily they give that extra piece of bread with your meal. I could have put my sandwich inside that piece and made a real half a sandwich.
The location (right in front of the hospital) is great if you are not into hospital cafeteria food.
It was aiight.

Nothing wrong with this hotel at all. Although the decor is a bit boring and standard (nothing special or interesting), the rooms are comfortable.
The staff is so nice. Everyone. Front desk, van drivers, restaurant, everyone.
Wonderful breakfast buffet with hot food as well as the freshest fruit selection I have seen across the country.
The pool is small but nice.
The fitness center, also small but well equipped.
Two thumbs up for business travel and priced well!
Love me some Hilton...

Ultra Lounge...very cool environment. A little more upbeat than some of the other cool cat joints on Frenchman Street.
It was super busy and seemed a bit more trendy than some of the live music spots.
All good.
A great place to meet friends and party.

For a chain, I likey. What my son wants, my son gets. Well, not really, but...I think about it. 
We were recently in the Lou for a mini vaca, long weekend, family thingy. We had about 40 minutes between events & he was hungry...again. So, we swept into the Factory for a quick lunch.
Wings, fries & a coke for the kid. Ahi, salad & a pinot grigio for moi.
Perfect service. Attentive & smart server. Good food.
Bueno.

Never been to this location, but knew about it via FB so I went to check it out, as I have to get my Fleurty Girl fixwhenever I am in town.
Great gifts and novelty items, and the best Tee's for girls ever!
I always find something good here.
This time I bought a Fleur de lis sparkly headband for those Saints games! But there were frames, and art, and even a phone cover that caught my eye, but alas, they did not have one for the droid, only the iphone :(

The salesgirl was wonderfully friendly and I could have stayed and chatted all morning.
I love what Fleurty Girl is up to and I love NoLa!

Cash only
Aggressive, Bitchy local girls
Super small
I've been twice now and both times the music was just OK. The crowd seemed transient and the energy was just plain weird. Not my favorite place.

We were in here all of 3 minutes. Long enough to order to-go cocktails and hit the streets of New Orleans. Yeaaaa.
TV's - looks like a great place to watch the Saints play.
Prompt service. This is all.

Pretty good. The food is actually really good, but there were so many things missing, that it's hard to give a better review.
The menu is limited. The tapas plates are sooo overpriced.
The pitcher of sangria was more expensive then the by the glass pricing. We barely got 4 glasses of sangria out a pitcher that was over 4 times the glass price. This place just makes no sense to me.
The waitress was OK.
It was freezing inside - which made me rethink my choice to sit outside, even though it was more windy than comfortable to sit on a patio.
There were quite a few ceviche options, but I tried the house ceviche because it had different types of seafood and seemed  a reasonable choice. The calamari seemed frozen then fried. It was just ok.
The skewers were interesting, but again, just OK.
I like the concept, but in this case, stick to what you know: ceviche!

Best lunch sirloin I have had, reasonably priced, great sides, and salad...professional staff, and the wine, albeit not the best, was perfect for the food choices, if you decide against the house brews.
It was a casual environment but still professional.
The staff was very friendly. It is on a main street downtown, and the mall is just a block or so away. It is walking distance from Colts Stadium.
Quite decent.

I really enjoyed my visit here. I love the idea of 3 Happy Hours a day, but did not like the concept of HH only existing in the bar and on the outer patio area (which is not outside, but outside the restaurant, within the confines of a mall, and overpowering and obnoxious earshot of the radio station across the mall walk).
Makes no sense.
But, the waitress Stephani was fantastic! She explained everything on the menu to my mom. She was sweet and aware of my mom's desire NOT to eat anything raw. She offered suggestions for rolls with cooked fish as well as items on the menu which were cooked as well.
We tried a little bit of everything from edamame and baked mussels, to rainbow rolls, octopus handrolls, shrimp tempura handrolls, and a wonderful butterfly roll which we both enjoyed.
 Hot sake on HH was well priced - actually everything was well priced at HH. It was well worth the visit and the price.

Uptown, how I love you! This location is setup just like the restaurant in the Quarter. The service was amazing(and entertaining), of course. 
The food was not as good as in the Quarter, but it was delicious and a mighty fine breakfast.
A beautiful neighborhood and a NoLa staple.

What do I like better than restaurants that offer raw oysters, serve late, sit on the water, offer sand volleyball, and live music?
Restaurants that have local fare, ie alligator bites.
Oh! yes.
It is what it is, loud and kinda tacky but in a fun way.
If I was 19, I'd love it, but since I'm not, I'll go with, I enjoy the energy and it reminds me of high school...with food...and beer.
The stars are indeed for the location and the vibe. The food was average to bad both days I ate there. Something called Cleveland oysters should be buried in Cleveland and never baked again. It all balances out.

Major props to these guys. I had to rent a snowboard for my 10 yr old.
We were charged for an adult setup & then the sweet cashier couldn't figure out how to credit back the difference to my credit card. They asked us to resolve it when we were done skiing & brought the equipment back.
When we got back there was a bit of confusion about why we were requesting the refund, but all in all what they gave us was a free rental for next time, so all is good.
The service is always good. Everyone who is fitting renters seems to know what they are doing and I appreciate the quality of knowledge about the area and skiing/ riding in general.
Plus, the equipment is great. I couldn't buy such awesome gear for my kids (nor would I) so it's nice to get to ride something amazing every once in a  while.

Well, the decor was cool. I love rich decor. I love russians. I love vodka.

BUT, this bar and the people in it were a little stuck on themselves.
It's like the hot girl at the party that won't talk to anyone because she thinks she's too hot. 

Maybe Pravda is too hot for the quarter, but I beg to differ.

They do serve drinks though, so I won't go on.

This is my favorite ski rental place in Colorado. The service is fast and efficient. The guys really know how to suit you up and always encourage me to have great ski days. They are courteous and friendly and I opted to rent here for my kids and took all my friends here after consistent great experiences.
On one occasion the ski outfitter took my 5 yr old son in the back and let him pick his own skis and then gave him a quick talk on safety - it was such a great experience for him. Now I never have to ask him to wear his helmet, he can't wait to get it on.
