They are lifer-skibums and know more about the hills than anyone else has ever volunteered, and are eager to share their knowledge. They can size you up without two blinks and are always on point.
Love these guys!

This is a standard classy joint.
The bartenders are cool, professional gentlemen.
Mr B's caters to a sophisticated business clientele, but still has the New Orleans flavor.
I was lucky enough to be sitting at the bar next to a self proclaimed, "conservative bastard". Awesome! Welcome to New Orleans.

The seafood gumbo is delicious(bowl licking good). I didn't, but I thought about it. Solid cocktails - an enjoyable experience whether there for business or pleasure.

Don't want to be in the Quarter?
Don't want to listen to drunks and clowns all night long?
Great location - walkable to the Quarter and Convention Center, and the trolley.
Good rooms, but bad beds. I don't even know what to think about the beds except they felt like prison beds with an extra coverlet. Major Fail!
But, Staff was amazing - every single one! The bellmen, the front desk ladies, especially the server who came out and made us bloody mary's before the bar opened. I am telling everyone I know about this location, because not only am I a loyal Saints fan and a loyal Hilton member, I love this location. Boom!
They have a breakfast buffet, free wireless, and fridges and microwaves in the rooms. A decent workout room and pool.
This is a good spot for grownups.

Let's start with slowest free wifi ever.
But, as I sit in my room, which over looks the ocean and the best sunset I've seen in a  very long time, and I listen to covers of Bob Marley being sung from across the water, there is nothing better right now.
This is a cool spot. The location is righteous. Average restaurant attached, but great happy hour, and good snacks. Very reasonably priced.
The rooms are dated. but clean. Old school and prob perfect for a family vacation. Each balcony which overlooks the water is superb. The view is money. 
If you face the parking lot...so sad, too bad. 
Even the shittiest hotel is most awesome with a waterfront balcony, reggae music, and a glass of vino.
Done!

My bff recommended this place and I was so excited to get my NoLa eat ON.
Alligator cheesecake. Watermelon mojitos. The lamb sirloin entree with greens and mashed potatoes on the side. Honestly, one of the best damn meals I have ever had.
Great service. Charming environment. Off the beaten path location, uptown on Oak St. Took the trolley back down to the Quarter easily.
Not only a recommend, but a Must-Go!

Fantastic service!
You can choose between bistro (bar) seating or the fine dining area. You can still get the fine dining menu in the bistro area but there are plenty of choices on both menus.
The lamb lollypops were delicious - the pesto was a nice touch.
The crab cakes had a spicy kick. Great for a little snappy appy with a glass of wine.
Te chicken mushroom Caesar  salad had great flavors and was plenty for one or two to share. Good wine list and   plenty of options for steak or small plates.
Good variety. Good westport option.

Day trip. Average girls...almost too young to look at.

I got carded and I know I'm old enough to mother the bartenders. The theme is the same as the rest of the chain.
They did have a super cute collection of hard hats which I wanted to take home. 
Other than that, it's a pit stop on the road to live music.

It leaves a lot to be desired, but the food is good. Cooked right in front of you on one of those grills I don't think ever gets really cleaned, that's probably why the food is so "tasty".

They have something on the menu called "scrapple". Described on the menu as sausage & hash browns dipped in pancake batter, fried & covered in gravy.
I had a ham and tomato omelet, with a side of hash browns. You can pick items ala carte to add to your 2 egg/ cheese omelet. Very good.
Very small, limited seating, but a family atmosphere. The bar seating was a tad too close to the griddle for me, but again, a family feel.
It almost reminded me of a truck stop without the showers and convenience store registers.

Quick service and good food.
We ordered toasted ravioli (Oh I miss you St Louis!), and then each had the soup/ salad combo. Great prices for good food. 
A few soups to choose from, we had clam chowder and chicken tortilla soup, which was prepared with actual tortilla chips (not strips), but had a cheesy bottom and was really good. We chose caesar salads over the house salad, and it was a good size - great lunch portions.
Pleasant staff. Great location - a quick walk to the arch grounds - right on Laclede's Landing.

Listed as one of the top 25 things to do in St. Louis...Amazing!!
Great for kids of all ages. A brilliant, clue finding, Sherlock Holmes exhibition with secret hideaways, double mirrors and hidden laboratories.
This is only one section of one wing.
There is history, games, all interactive fun times and frolic.
Climbing and discovery - a full afternoon of fun.
Super cool music displays - all interactive. Kaleidoscopes. Train exhibits. Dress up bays. Science corners. Slides all over this house.
An entire wing modeled after the Oval office, a courtroom, and the senate. Tons of information on the House and Senate, Presidential trivia, and podiums for kids to stand up and speak up!
This Magic house is brilliant.

This place reminded me of an old school, Boston mafia restaurant where the big boys hang in the back room smoking cigars and drinking hard liquor while the music out front keeps their tales hushed. ha!
But, the boys in the back weren't that cool.
The music is great - Frenchman St at it's best.
Cool atmosphere for grownups.
Nuff said.

LOVED IT!!
Frenchman Street at it's best. The music is consistently good. Love me some horns (and horn players).
Great energy here.
Good people.
It is probably one of the places I will remember as a "must-go" next time I am there. 
OUTSTANDING!

Gotta love live music...

New Orleans does it and does it well.

This is an upscale (pricey) experience for Frenchman Street. The band that was playing had a $30 cover. Downstairs, you could sit and watch on TV what was going on in the other room, but it doesn't compare to the other venues along the same Avenue.

If it's a special occasion, do it, but just wandering around...pass.

One thing I noticed about St. Petersburg is that there are more ice cream stores than people it seemed, but they were all busy. Weird.
I walked in initially because it had a serious Italian feel, and I thought maybe there would be some pizza in there too. ha! 
Not my lucky day.
This ice cream shop had wonderful flavor choices, and a sweet, funny staff. I appreciated the independent shop feel. Great location and a great people watching patio.
I am not a fan of ice cream, but if I was this would be where I would always find something good.

Great rate thru expedia.com. The staff was courteous but not overzealous about their job. The room we had was huge and had a long hallway reminiscent of the old movies where someone gets killed in the Quarter and a fine mystery ensues. 
More character than most places I have ever stayed. Traditional southern charm and architecture made me really happy we chose this place.
The courtyard was sweet and there was so much appeal to stay here over the chains in the area that hold no charm whatsoever.
Sits on the riverfront, and walking distance to everything in the Quarter, Frenchmen St, and the financial district - including access to the trolley stop on Canal St which will take you uptown for something different.
The bed was comfortable, the rooms were cool and dark, like I like my sleeping quarters to be.
Perfect.

3-4-1 hh whoa!
Karaoke
Cool crowd. Fun times in the Quarter! 
There are so many bars to choose from, but this is one of the good ones.

I haven't been here since I was a kid, and to be honest I was not looking forward to going up in the arch. I had slight memories of it being shaky and creeping me out. But, my kid wanted to go up in that tiny little elevator to the top of the arch, so we did.

The TSA reminiscent line out the door of the Memorial was almost a deterrent.
Especially after coming back from D.C. and not having these lines or the premise of terror in the nations capital, I hardly expected this here.
The lines moved quickly but the times were off after entering the hold stations for the ride to the top.

The grounds were clean. The view was amazing. It is a mini historical tour of the St Louis landmark. Well worth seeing, but be prepared for unnecessary hassle prior to entrance.

The room was comfortable. Close to the airport, with  free shuttle (always a bonus). Unfortunately, the days I was there, the van was without a/c, and it was about 99 degrees at 5p. Hot and sweaty is no way to kick off your New Orleans adventure.
It is about 20 minutes to the French Quarter via cab.
The staff was a little tense, may have been the heat, but very informative.
It was a pretty quiet location which is always my choice for any hotel.

It was like a ghost town upon entry.
The front desk guys were awesome. Friendly and cordial. Easy check in process.
The rooms were OK. The setup is similar to other Renaissance properties. This one is not as glamorous, but it was fine.
After 2 fire alarms and loss of sleep I will never get back, I will say, I left cranky.

and the restaurant...after a lecture on ordering meat the way they would cook it, ie "rare means rare", we received a very overcooked burger and a slightly over cooked burger. Um, yeah. Not to mention one of the poorest cabernet's I have ever tasted at the pricepoint of a reasonable Zin. Never again.

My stay was not the best and outside of the proximity to the airport, and the staff, there were few things that stood out as a reason to return.

Love me some Deanie's. Our server was sweet. Our bartender...not so much.
Great food. Straight up New Orlean's flavor.
Fried catfish, oysters, crawfish. The goods!
Good drinks! 
My definite go-to place whenever I am in town.
On the far side of the bar action in the Quarter, but I think this is a good thing ;)

Um, I loved it.
I loved the men's.
I called it, "Bear's on Bourbon" because that's the 1st impression I got after strolling in, initially only attracted to the South beach color scheme and art deco furniture.
Then I noticed there were 6 men, 5 of them gay and 1 actually a woman.
And I decided to stay here all afternoon on my last afternoon in New Orleans.
They have a fantastic martini menu. The bartender took his time, with each and every drink - a true mixologist. Best martini's I've had in  looong loong time. Bravo!
Then we talked about all the fantastic gay bars in Denver, and the Bear's (in from Dallas) told birthday stories.
Great daytime bar to have GREAT drinks and enjoy the street sights walking by.
Local clientele, and their little dogs also added to the ambiance.

This was the highlight of Indianapolis...outside of the Colts stadium, that is.
Good bar food...really! The stuffed breadsticks were the best thing I ate all week. The service was consistent. The prices were decent.
My crew ate here on an overnight and everyone was pleased. There was a variety of choices for everyone. Salads, meat and more meat ...welcome to the midwest.
The feel of a sports bar with  great service.
Thanks Indy!

Loved it just as much this time as I did the first, but this time I actually tried the food. Good baked oyster dish, although the Rockerfeller oysters were a bit much - heavy on the spinach - the saffron choice was delectable though.
Good beer. Good food. Great location across the street from the river.
The bartender was funny and a fine tradesman to say the least.
Outside of the cockroach the scurried across the bar, the experience was great.

Straight up dive bar!
Cash only.
NoLa locals.
Tiny wall space, but check out the back - some of the best Po-Boys int he city.
Bounce in for food...bring cash.

This is one of those places that you remember by the decor alone - the jelly fish lights reminded me how much I love the beer here.
Great beers. I did not eat, but if I ate at every bar I crossed in New Orleans I'd be about 40 lbs heavier right now.
Good environment - typical brewery.
Next time I will have to try all the good plates I noticed in passing.
Crescent City.
Indeed.

Best damn breakfast! Spicy bloody mary's.
I enjoyed a eggs Benedict po' boy with the most delicious hollandaise sauce I have experienced in years. The poached eggs were perfection.
The side potatoes were soft and delicious and were seasoned like my mama's.
Well worth the short wait, and glad we walked by and saw the plates inside and changed our mind about waiting. Everything was fantastic.

The only downside to this meal was the proximity the tables are to one another. I do not need to sit that close to my neighbor. It is just plain unnecessary. I get it, more tables, more patrons, faster turn around, but damn, I would wait the extra 20 minutes for this meal - just sayin'.

I don't get it.
There were tables and tables of post collegiate aged men wearing shorty shorts that said "Who Dat"...granted they were all in for the LSU/ Bama game, and I'm seriously hoping at least one of them lost a bet, but I have an idea that it was all for sport.

The atmosphere screams "frat party gone on too long".

The food was average.
The drinks were average.
The service was great. And for patio time, it's A-OK, but there is so much better to be had. This city is sooo much better.

p.s. the bar will give you a rebate on your glassware if you return it on your way out.

This place is a straight up hole in the wall. With a great group of friends, anything is alright, but I would not advise checking it out alone.
I got more dirty looks and rude comments from drunk locals than I've seen/ heard since high school. Yeah.

It was karaoke night and the sound was so loud and so annoying we had to shout over each other to even order food.
That said, the bartender had an amazing voice, sounding similar to Reba McIntyre and she was super fun to watch sling drinks and sing. Our waiter was also super cool and as usual the service and kinsmanship in New Orleans is outstanding. 

The nachos I ordered were typical bar fare and kind of gross, but I had no expectations of great food once I stepped inside. My friend ordered the steak, on the suggestion of our hotel personnel and said it was great! So, there you go.

Stiff drinks and very entertaining, if you're not scurred.

I had gotten shirts from here before from friends who were kind enough to bring me back something good from New Orleans. I knew I had to pop in the next time I was in town...especially after seeing my boy Drew Brees sign his new contract wearing the #NolaLove tee. Awesome.
Love the concept.
Love the accessories.
Love the baby clothes.
Love the tees.
Everything about this place is good.

Had heard about this place over and over again by many different people.
The appeal: dive bar. Cheap drinks. Good music.
They are also dog friendly.
The music: Tues night the Rebirth brass band. If you like that southern Nola jazz, you will be happy. A great go-to place to get off the Quarter and out of downtown. A short trolley ride from the madness of the Quarter and well worth the diversion.

This may be one of my favorite hotels of all time.
Thank you company that I work for, for putting me up in this fantastically decadent treat of a hotel even if for only one night.
If I had to spend my very own, hard earned money in Philly, it would be here.
It's modern and trendy and oh so fabulous. Yet fireplaces in all the main rooms warm it up and welcome you in.
The couches are fantastic - the lobby/bar itself is probably my favorite lobby in the world now.
The bartenders are beautiful men of all shades heights and what do you like, they have it. 
The rooms. Simply marvelous. Wonderful wallpaper and paint schemes. GRRRREAT beds. Best bathrooms ever.
Oh and location, location, LOCATION. Ya' hear me?
I just love it here. This was the first hotel I have ever been sad to leave. Truly sad.

This may have been the funniest experience this go- round in New Orleans.
It was pouring rain int he city the couple days we were there, so we ran from corner to corner from our hotel in the convention center looking for breakfast.
Small sign "Good Eats". Looks local. Looks good. Regardless, a little hungover, we were starving, so we jogged over like wet cats hoping for something delicious.
We got inside, were immediately told, no table service - order at the counter. No problem.
We check out the menu's. 3 breakfast choices. Eggs with bacon or hot sausage, add grits and a biscuit, and something else I don't remember.
I ordered the eggs, with bacon, add grits...but stuck with toast. I asked, "Can I get my eggs over medium". The counter girl looked at my third eye...then finally said, "uh, she only scrambles...".
 Oh, OK.
I guess I'll take scrambled.
My friend whispers, "I guess they probably won't substitute chicken for the bacon/ sausage". We both laugh.
Yeah. NO.
All in all, it was cheap. It was decent. It was fast, and once the counter girl realized we were not the typical tourist douches, she was cool as hell. Glad we went in.
Even though I'd still like eggs, my way. Just sayin'.

It's also some sort of convenience store, so the have pop and chips too.

One of my favorite art spots in the country. I visit every time I am in the Quarter.
Local art. 3 separate areas - the main store, the back outdoor garden area, and a studio in the rear.
Great souvenirs and knick knacks. Prints, post cards, Artsy garden items and home goods. Magnets, coasters - all NoLa local artist driven.
Then there is the studio in the back. Pure original talent. Sketches, oil, photo, multi media area driven art housed in the perfect environment for people who just want to soak in some sincerely good art.
Love this place.

What I loved about this bar was the absinthe drinks and the fireplace. The bartender was odd. The end.

It is in a great location, but is so filthy inside I was sure dust bunnies would jump from all the helmets and football paraphernalia and catch fire at the fireplace where I was sitting.
The crowd was dead.
Boring and possibly dead.
I would advise one drink and move on.

I found the service to be outstanding. We were upgraded to a mini suite and the room was great. Spacious, and we appreciated the fridge.
Free wifi is always a bonus.
I found the staff to be accommodating and gracious. The concierges and porters were exceptional.
Except for one disgruntled server in the bar area everyone made our experience pleasant and special.
Although the rooms were spacious the building is old...very old. We could hear every voice from every room as they exited the elevator, or their room, as I am certain they could hear ours. Awkward.
I don't necessarily want to be worried about being quiet on vacation, in the Quarter.

The wedding we attended was in a sweet courtyard in the rear of the hotel premises. The band was lovely. The food was traditional. The service was good.
Overall it was a good experience and I would absolutely recommend the hotel to future visitors.

Time warp alert!
The smoke...THE SMOKE!!
Who still smokes?
This place smells like an ashtray...let's start there.
I don't even know how my company found this place and why they would ever contract rooms here.
Shootouts in the lobby...the strangest people wandering around...and some of them work here...I did not feel safe even remaining on site.
This city is a hole and this hotel is just plain bizarre.
The gym equipment is as old as the wallpaper in the rooms, and half of it didn't work. The pool looked enticing, but alas, it's december.
My view was split. Half mountains and a wonderful sunset...resting atop train tracks, warehouses, and bums.
Keepin it weird...and trashy, Reno(Sparks).

Live music, great food and genuinely friendly service. I got to try crawfish and grilled cajun oysters. I love any place that has local favorites.
The location is awesome - right on the riverfront, and the band plays right outside. Even though the swamp heat did not allow me to sit outdoors to enjoy the music, I was quite fine with listening from my air conditioned seat right inside the patio windows.
Typical New Orleans specialty drinks. The Saints were on TV.
It is a fun place!

I do not remember this place right now - I will have to return to this review after checking out my pictures. hahaha!

I have a feeling this was the place with the surly bartender who would not take a picture with me...damn tourists.

Bourbon!

ah yes, a corner bar, location location location...
The entire staff seemed disgruntled. The bartender was not feeling the sherri-love, and didn't feel like talking with myself and the 1 or 2 other people at the bar.
The outdoor patio with live music is set up for a no lose situation. It's one of those places you can hang on the street and listen to great big band music - LIVE on the corner.
It's got the whole city feel, but I did not want to spend more money there because it just didn't have the personality of every other bar in the city.

So, check it out, from outside, I thought, typical tourist chain - when I got inside, that was exactly what it was.
But, great points: not-so-typical-fare like gator cakes, and gator bites. Great seafood gumbo, and the service was on point.
Live reggae music on Sunday night and a gift shop for t shirts and hats and such.
Honestly, the bartender rocked and the food was good. The mussels were good enough for me to eat all of them and not regret one morsel.
It's a fun place if you happen to be in Tampa and have nothing else to do.

So, they have updated the joint. The lines are reasonable(but I do have a crew badge). The food courts are limited. The issue I have with Lambert is the surly ass employees. 
Ghetto and surly.

This is one of my favorite overnights. Plenty to do, right on site.
Lots of restaurants, entertainment, and bars. If you are into gambling, there is that too. 
The pool area and gym and great for a hotel. I love the beach/ sand concept at the pool area.
The gym is spacious and well maintained.
There is a spa where I have gotten my hair done, and accommodates last minute appointments for hair, nails and massages (when there are openings). I find this entire establishment extremely accommodating and the staff is very friendly.
The bathroom is also spacious - which I appreciate when traveling. Any extra space is a bonus for me.

The breakfast sandwich I got was good. Crispy bacon. Egg cooked perfectly. The coffee was bitter. My tots were burnt.
So, for $7(with my discount) w t f!!

...but, it was fast.

Mmmm, here we go.
I love good food, and a restaurant that not only knows the quality of good food, but the clientele that they are serving, the culture of their city, and the value of outstanding service is #1 in my book.
We were given a heads up on this place, from a  Denver local who happened to be sitting next to us at Camilla, another favorite eatery in Nola. So, it was at the top of the must try list. Turns out it was right around the corner from the hotel and had a great ambiance.

I started out with a glass of wine, but was enticed into the signature drink by everyone in the joint that had one in hand. It wasn't my favorite, but I love a place that has a specialty. Classic.
I also heard over and over again about this fantastic bread pudding. I don't eat sweets but when in Rome...
Well done Bon Ton.
Every dish was prepared to my liking. I will admit, I was kind of bored with the whole creole - gumbo- N.O. typical menu, but Bon Ton does it and does it well.
Shit was good.

Great service! The wait and the air of a chain was an initial let down after hearing about how great the food was going to be, but no doubt, everything lived up to the expectations.
The food was f'ing great!
Great, I say!
Everyone told me about the crawfish bread which is well worth the trip to the south. I had blackened catfish, actually, everyone at the table had catfish in one form or another.
And Gawd damn! It was fantastic! 
Every dish had the southern flavor that we came down to experience.
You can order sides ala carte and everything is well worth a taste.
So Good!

Amaaaaaazing!
I don't even know where to start. The seafood (tower) appetizer with everything from crab legs, to oysters, to lobster claws was so frickin good I could barely control myself.
The service was impeccable.
Hostess, waitstaff, bar - ALL GOOD!
The steaks...Shut the Front Door!!! 
like Buttah!
in my mouth
on my tongue
I could do a dance...
but I won't
But I should
It it where I would like to be buried please
Mmmmmm heaven in Philly
Indeed

Oysters oysters oysters!
The interior resembles a Bubba Gumps or other chain, but we sat at the bar and simply enjoyed the food despite the average ambiance.
We tried 3 different types of oysters here. Fried oysters, oysters on the half shell and baked oysters that were so frickin delicious, we could have eaten 3 more dozen.
I would absolutely go back again and again to get my oyster fix.
The bartender was a treat as well. Informative and a great mixologist - she made our experience even better.

Melange was another fine dining experience. The food just got better and better everywhere I went.
I started with the shrimp remoulade, moved on to the duck and andouille gumbo, and then had a seafood dish I can't remember the name of but every bite of every dish was spectacular. Absolutely fantastic!
The cocktails were fun and the wine list was above par. Well matched with all the food items, every taste was a treat.
Traditional N'awlins fare with a gourmet twist. Lucky me.

It's a diner...
with drinks...
I spent about 5 minutes here and ran into the Quarter.

I like it.
Generates an air of politics.
Decent prices.
Cool bartender.
I had one of the best grilled cheese (w/ bacon and tomato) sandwiches I have ever had. Fries are good too. Great downtown location. Walking distance to the State House, and to Colts Stadium.

Ooooh Lawd! When I saw the line outside I knew there was something good inside. I had been joking with one of my crewmates about how, you know a city has good food when you run out of seatbelt extensions on the plane. There are also other indicators of amazing food, especially in a hidden little joint like this place.
Deanie's is kinda far from town.
It looks like an updated shack in the middle of the back woods on Louisiana (but well kept).
It has a front porch.
On this front porch were numerous couples waiting to get a seat inside and be served.
My sweet friend asked me if I wanted to stay, since there would obviously be a wait. I usually have good luck with situations like this, and I would definitely wait for the goodness I was sure was inside. We went in and the wait was an hour. But, they had a bar, and I had nothing better to do than catch up with my friend.  
When we stepped up to the bar I suggested just hovering as names were being called and eventually these people in the bar would get a table...and they did...and we bellied up to eat. We waited all of 3-5 minutes for a seat at the bar and we had drinks and dinner right there, with the most attentive bartender(s) and one of the owners.
I ordered the combo plate with oysters and catfish. My friend ordered some sort of crab souffle. 
DA BOMB!!!
Talk about ridiculous.
The potatoes were brought out first with our drinks - boiled in spicy crab seasoning, they were the best little red potatoes I've ever had.
The combo plate was tasty and the catfish was actually breaded more lightly than I anticipated and made for a delicious "typical" southern plate. The oysters were just damn good.
I tasted the crab souffle thingy and O M G! Melt in yo mouth goodness!
I don't know that I've had better southern cookin' and I know that I never should again, unless I give up on my body and decide to just go with the big panty look for the remainder of my life, because nothing good can come of eating meals like this more than once, than a big, fat ass.
And I mean that in the most respectful way.

ps they have a full service bar and Jack Honey drinks...What Da' hell!! Heaven in New Orleans I tell you!

pps the servings are huge

I haven't spent time here since I graduate from UCSB in 2002 (before Yelp existed).  My gentleman friend and I stayed two night the other weekend and had a very memorable time.  We enjoyed the pool and even received vouchers for the lovely breakfast buffet.  It wasn't a cheesy one, classy with smoke salmon bar with capers, red onions, lemons and cucumber slices... I'm on the GAPs diet so I just filled my plate full of bacon and fruit.  We were pretty happy campers.

Warm and cozy place to meet up with friends to "study".  Yeah until they started transforming the place.  First there were cozy big chairs placed sporadically places throughout the store.  Within the first month of opening they took them away.  Surprised there was no riot.
You were either a Giovanni's girl or Woodstock's girl.  I always hated picking sides.  Probably the best pizza to scarf down when sober.

Party Hard and then Work Hard is the mentality at this school  Although the student have recently evolved into more disciplined bookies, it is still one of the top places to be during your 4 years (7 for some).  As I mentioned earlier, traditions are fading away for UCSB student and IV.  No more couch burning, Haloween is lame, I don['t hear about 10 keggers, Monday Night Margaritas and open keg parties everyday of the night.  My sister signed up for my experience and got something completely different.  It is a great place to be not just because of the fact that it was on the coastline or that I could wake up from my $500/mo. rent to share a 10x10 room in '95 over looking the water, the hotties everywhere, Bagel Cafe, the Bob Marley House and the fact that Jack Johnson wrote his tunes up while a Gaucho but because it is truly more than a party school.   We are home to several Nobel Prize Laureates, a fabulous Bio program and we were one of the forefathers of the major: Global International Studies.
Best Bin Candy.  Neat little market.
Blenders rocked IV.  Possibly because there was no Jamba near campus but the smoothies tasted different.  Definitley more natural and delicious!

I was there the year they super-sized their menu from cheap mini burros to gi-normous burritos.  Opened 24 hours a day so you could enjoy them when you are wasted at 2am and the following day when you are recovering for lunch at 4pm.   YOU MUST GET THE NACHOS!  Serves 4 but serves 1 wasted student .

2 words.  Toilet Paper.

When you are a Gaucho or going to SBCC and you live nearby... this is the place to go for TP.  I'm not kidding.  Unless you are stealing if from the bathrooms at Campbell Hall or the HSSB building or any for that matter, this is probably the second least expensive way to horde a vast amount of soft tissue paper to wipe your stinky butt.

Super impressed with the food and the service.  I've been here before but I don't remember having such a solid dining experience.  We rode beach cruisers in non-beach cruiser riding apparel (and shoes) from Montecito Inn to State Street then walked over 6 blocks to enjoy some lunch.  The girls wanted either Arigato Sushi (which didn't open until after 5pm) or Cafe Buenos Aires for their sangria but right when we walked up to Andersen's and saw all the people enjoying their food and basking in the sun all of a sudden we wanted nothing more than to sit and enjoy a meal here.

We sat in the shade since we were burning up from our walk and ride... within 5 minutes we were cold so we moved in after ordering our beverages... normally you see services throw a mini-fit when people do this as usually servers are assigned to a certain area of a restaurant.  Well when it is not too busy this restaurant will share their areas and the responsibility of checking in with their customers (which makes perfect sense and happy customers)... everyone that came by our table was lovely, professional and had a nice smile.

We ordered a Louie Salad w/Grilled Chicken, Smoked Scottish Salmon an opened face sandwich, a French Dip au Jus and I ordered the Club 1000 Sandwich and we all shared.  I got my club on whole wheat although I was tempted to get the French Roll or Croissant and my steak fries were amazing (probably too soft for many but perfect for me) especially dipped in their even killer ranch dressing (I know so ghetto!)... the coleslaw I didn't get since it had mini chunks of pineapple... everything else made sense...

Curry Chicken sounded good as did the Schnitzel and can't forget the 
Euro Iced Coffee (espresso & vanilla ice cream) so hopefully I will have a chance to try them soon.  Great place to pick up a dessert or two for a friend or yourself... and they serve wine and beer.  A cold Stella was perfect after that bike ride.

Probably one of the nicest boutique hotels in Nashville.  If I was to visit again, I would definitely stay at this posh hotel.   Great bar and a overall sexy appeal to this hotel.  Too bad not everyone made it back to their hotel room.

Just not the same anymore, made a nachos run last night and the nachos just weren't the same.  When I used to go on a regular basis (about 9 years ago) they used top those chips with a shiite ton of queso.  What the F?  We ordered 2 nachos last night and combined didn't have as much cheese as they did in one order back in the day.  

"Back in the days when I was young I'm not a kid anymore
But some days I sit and wish I was a kid again
Back in the days when I was young I'm not a kid anymore
But some days I sit and wish I was a kid again"

Formerly Mac's Market.

This place has definitely changed a lot since it was called Mac's.  More booze that's for sure, the hard liquor decorated the walls and all the way to the ceiling and they have some high ass ceilings.   

Lost its old school feel though.

So... my sisters and I are all Gauchos... c/o 2002, 2006 and my youngest will be graduating from the class of 2011!!!

Kick-ass University.  Period.

Highly recommend Santa Barbara Sailing Center and I wish I knew about it when I was a Gaucho.  We went on a Catamaran Cruise after my sisters graduation.  The service on the dock and on the boat was awesome and the cruise is very affordable especially if you are a student so bring your school id. The cruise was about 2 hours and we enjoyed some adult beverages and when it got chilly which was real quick it was nice to know that they had dozens of warm blankets to break the cold wind.  During our excursion we chatted with some sea lions (no really we did... we can bark too, we are from Monterey and there are tons here), saw my future home (on Channel Drive that enormous dark adobe Spanish Style home with the white trim second floor patio) and celebrated my sister and her friends graduation from UCSB.  

She learned about the cruise from one she had take a week or two before... it had rained during the ride but they still had an unforgettable time so I'm glad she signed us all up.  It was a beautiful experience all around.
Small Japanese Market in Goleta.  They have your basics.  I think this is the only place that sold Japanese goods when I went to UCSB back in the day.

Bosco's is where we had our final brunch in Nashville.  The service was good and the food was pretty tasty.  Their drinks could have been a bit stronger though.  The atmosphere is great for big groups and is family friendly.  I proabbly should have tried the beer but for some reason Double Greyhounds sounded really good at the time.

Good friendly service and great selection.  My family enjoyed the gelato but I ordered the Coconut and Panna Cotta (since we just shared a killer one at Trattoria Mollie's a few minutes beforehand).  The coconut was okay but my dad kept saying that it tasted like sunscreen so that kind of killed it for me but the Panna Cotta didn't taste like any Panna Cotta I'd ever had (and it's not like I was expecting that unique texture or anything) and I felt like everything I sampled was too buttery... especially their vanilla which was almost a bright golden yellow.   

Great concept, cute disposable cups, pricey gelato but if I enjoyed the flavors more then it would be worth the price.

I don't know if I have been living in Denver to long but I sure do miss gas stations in Cali.  Not only do they sell red party cups here but they have a rack fully stocked with Big Foot Wine.  Now, I know not the best wine but they don't sell wine in general on Sundays in Colorado.  They don't even sell alcohol in Safeway or at Seven Elevens, if they do its the reduced alcohol stuff.  I don't touch that stuff.

Holy Expensive!!!  But if you crave the goods and you want it you will pay it.  It's all about supply and demand (thanks Dr. Krouch)... these "Asian" products are hot right now (in demand) and you cannot find them anywhere else unless you drive to another price local Asian Market or hours away (so the supply is low) hence they can charge whatever the F they want and that's fine with me.  This phenomenon happens everywhere, everyday around the world!

When I lived in IV I frequented this place since it was kind of like a place filled with comfort food, well not really but a few things and brands here reminded me of stuff my Mom would use to cook an Authentic Japanese meal or remind me of good times in Japan - like my summer time visits when I was a young kid and my Mom would through me on JAL solo.

So I had some time to kill and I visited yesterday to pick up some things for my sister.  Didn't really find anything besides over prices beautiful Japanese tea cups and bento sets but I did find a mini box of those tropical umbrellas that you use to decorate a fruity cocktail for less than $5 (which is a good deal) and my favorite COCONUT WATER!  I asked for a case and what they had out was out but I left with about a dozen.  These particular ones are hard to find as are most brand since my local Wholefoods doesn't keep them stocked all the time (I heard various rumors why) and so I really wanted to stock up.  There are several kinds out there but I find the ones in the paper cartons the best.  Not sweet at all and a good source of nutrition.  Not cheap but at $1.99 (same price as WholePaychecks), I was stoked! My sister was coming down with a sore throat so I grabbed a stick of Japanese "no do ame" or throat candy that looked strikingly familiar for $1.50.

Friendly service and they also offer a very small select few but brilliant Japanese cookbooks.

Had a killer time not only tasting their fun wines but instagram-ing the crap out of this hip place.  Their wine club is dubbed "Club Awesome" ... need I say more?

#santabarbara #municipalwinemakers
My sister joined the wine club at Kalyra's and I'm glad she did.  Their white  wines are young and refreshing.
My Mom was stoked to hit this nursery up while were waiting to eat at Via Maestra 42.  She was a bit dissapointed as the selection is very small and we walked around the nursery in a couple minutes.
I never cared about E Bar.  Reminds me of dining at Denny's but not just any Denny's.  The one you find after being lost in a jungle after your jeep breaks down during your safari tour.

I woke up here one day after a night of drinking.  My friend had an "open bar" party and the next thing I know I am being poked and prodded by nurses.  Apparently I didn't wake up after taking a little napsky on Sabado or was it Trigo in IV.  Since they couldn't wake me up they took me to the hospital.  I was going through a rough time in my life so I was really angry... I remember spitting and apparently cussing everyone out.  Horrible.

Within a few hours of being admitted by roommate came to pick me up and I went home to take a nap.  I woke up to take a shower and once I took my clothes off I screamed.   Cheyenne laughed so hard as I couldn't figure why I had metal nipples all over my chest.  She thought it would be funny if the nurses left those on me (since she figured I would black out again).  Yeah, I didn't grow metal nipples but those were the little stickies that attached me to the monitors via lines.

I learned my lesson.  After that incident I made sure I ate before I went out and didn't over do it with hard liquor.  I actually was on a sport team and I showed up to practice and luckily it rained so practice was called off.  I was one lucky lady.

My apologies to the staff that had to deal with me but I'm grateful for their assistance and have become a more responsible person.
Okay, I'm pretty sure I remember this place because it was the only place that I visited with a big red door.  I remember it was a spacious bar but not much else.  Good times though!

I used to frequent this place as a Gaucho ever since I lived in FT (F*&% Towers) which has been renamed to Catalina something I hear... anyways, this place was clutch this weekend when my sister who is 9 years my minor graduated from UCSB... we were supposed to make leis but we didn't have time and there were a bunch of cops (I'm talking 6 cop cars) parked outside an area where were thinking about picking some so we went to Costco and they had just sold out of leis... luckily Albertsons still had some.  They were only $18.99 and were double leis (not just a single strand a more fuller version).  We were stoked.

I found out the cake we had the night before a graduation party was made at Albertson's (I'm guessing this one) and it was pretty delicious.  Chocolate pudding and fresh strawberries sandwiched in between white cake and then iced with whipped cream.  Awesome, fresh strawberries were unnecessary to me but added a nice touch... the cake was so soft and delicious almost reminded me of a Boston Cream Pie.  The party had two cakes one half sheet pan and another full... it could have fed a hundred people... no joke.

I was shocked to see a sushi take-out joint inside this Albertson's as well.  Boy have times changed...

What a lovely restaurant.  Solid service and wonderful food and best enjoyed eating family style.  Everything we ordered was tasty and the portions were a good size (not too big) so the five of us picked something off the menu to share.  We got a nice sampling from the Spinach soup, Minestrone Soup, thin crusted pizza with Bresaola and Arugula, Linguine alle Vongole, Spaghetti with Pancetta & Ricotta Salata and her famous pasta with Meatballs.   These balls of meat were something special, made with raisins and packed with a little heat.  Killer and a flavor combination that I will never forget.

Although I'm not a desert person we did devour (I apparently did) the Panna Cotta.  Simply delicious.  We enjoyed some wine that we brought in 2007 Artemis from Stag's Leap, corkage fee was $25.  

The only things that caught us off guard is that 1.) the Minestrone arrived without noodles (which is fine) and the server said if we wanted noodles in we had to request it when we ordered which we found unique so just a heads up and 2.) we also ordered some risotto and the Ossobuco but the waiter wasn't sure so he didn't place the order which worked out since we were stuffed from all the other stuff we got to enjoy.

Overall we had a lovely dining experience and I cannot wait to go back.  This was my first time but most have my family have been here before and they were happy to return.

Wow!  Very impressed with Via Maestra 42.  I come from a restaurant family and my Mom and sisters were raving about this quaint Italian Deli the whole drive down to Santa Barbara from Nor  Cal.  This place is a hidden gem on upper State Street.   I guess my family hits this place up a couple time every time they are in town.  And it was no different this time around as my sister grabbed a lovely Milano which had the Prosciutto Cotto, Raschera Cheese  on a Filone Rustico for shits and giggles an hour before we were plannin on a having a relaxing lunch.  

An hour later we were back ordering almost everything off the menu.  I ordered the Zuppa di Farro and I cannot wait to try and make this at home.  It was a light tomato based vegie soup with barley, carrots, fresh parsley and topped with shaved parmesan cheese.  SO GOOD!

Then I had the Carpaccio Bresaola Con Rucula.   Cured thin slices of meat served with pannini toast and a arugula salad dressed with lemon vinaigrette.  We also had the Penne a la Vodka and Carbonara.   Of course, we had wine to go with our meal.  I had the Trami Pinot Grigio which had a good floral nose and crisp finish.  The Falesco Merlot was good too.   Obvi we had to have some sorbetto... the Coco was a delightful coconut sorbet and the Blood Orange Sorbet was the ultimate sorbetto with mild tangy flavors and it wasn't too sweet.  

Strongly recommend this Italian deli, counter service until 4pm and after they will seat you and take your order from your table.  The staff is good looking too.  Just adorable.

French fries were solid (although the menu said "seasoned" and they weren't) and the pulled pork was ok.  I love a good pulled pork sandwich.  Service was friendly and for $3 more you can make it a double.  Great deal! Also if you order a beer you can get a shot of anything for $3.

Bought my first bike here freshman year (1998) and the staff built it and I was good to go until someone stole it which is fine because it wasn't a beach cruiser. I had my second bike (a cruiser) until the day I graduated... in 4 years not 5... and ended up leaving it for a friend.

I never got over the whole cruiser phase and owned one that sort of looked like a cruiser in Kyoto while I was teaching English there for 2 years where'd I'd bike 15 minutes to a high school while biking through the little town of Fushimi and passing by several sake breweries.  Then I lived in Denver and my friend Megan (also a Gaucho - who randomly lived in the same house as I did 6709 DP aka Pink Taco a year after - didn't know her at the time) and I cruised the streets of Denvy with travelers in tow.  My bike was named Blue Steel and Megan's Hermosa for lovely in Spanish for those of you who are non-speakers.  I'm back in Monterey and I couldn't help but purchase another cruiser... Champagne in color and so far it's name is Champy (Shampy) until I think of a better one.  

Anywho, both my sisters went to UCSB as well (class of '06 & '11) and I'm pretty sure they both purchased their cruisers there too.  I highly recommend them!

Hands down the best restaurant in the 805 in terms of flavor, ambiance, fun, family friendly, indoor and outdoor seating, bar and more.  I recently learned about Chef Damon Murphy taking over and I couldn't be more pleased.  

I stop at Cielito every time I'm in SB.  If I'm there for 2 days I'm there at least twice, 3 days maybe 4 times.  It's a little bit of everything, they have a raw bar, a classy bar (literally the bar dates back quite some time), and the food is progressive and most importantly for my body gluten free (naturally).  GF might sound like a fad but really it means less processed and less fillers and you are eating the good stuff.  Everything that I've consumed here has been above my expectation.  

IF you don't believe me check out their happy hour.  Bites and drinks, affordable in a casual but somewhat upscale and welcoming atmosphere.  They make a mean margarita and offer a solid wine list and I've yet to have an average experience.  I can't  wait to go back!

One of my all time favorite place to go with a group.  I don't care for the show and the atmosphere but the teppanyaki style is delicious.  They have the BEST dipping sauces for the meat and veggies!  I wouldn't recommend this place as a great place for Japanese food nor for sushi but I do give it props for their grilled items.
Great place to go for non-pizza and burrito cravings.  Hamburger, fries, chicken sandwiches... you want greasy comfort food, they've got it.

Solid not going to complain, I mean they are doing it... bringing pho to mainstream America (well UCSB that is).  I wish they were here when I attended UCSB but better late than never.  

I had the Pho Tai and if you are craving pho then this may satisfy your craving.  However, I prefer my thin slices of meat rare and thin.  My noodles were a bit limp and I like my bean sprouts crisper.  I also would have loved me some more jalapeno, limes and Thai Basil.  Can't get enough of the Thai Basil.

My sister got her usual bowl and WOW that was amazing.  I would definately reccommend that.  Ban Cha Gio Tom Thit Nuong a lovely medley of Rice noodles, egg roll, grilled shrimp choice of pork or chicken served atop of lettuce, cucumbers, bean sprouts, cilantro, crushed peanuts and served with a ddipping sauce (containing fish sauce I'm guessing).  Solid.  It's also called the #32 in case you are wondering.  This bowl is bursting with flavors.  My sister got the pork and it was tender and full of flavor.  Addiciting.

The 2 young men behind the counter were very sweet and lovely.  Although I'm more of a salty girl but when it comes to Vietnamese Coffee, I go all out.  Give me the 2 inches of condensed milk.   They go light here, maybe just looking out for you.

Yeah a bit pricey for a Vietnamese joint but I'd rather spend 10 bucks on a meal here then spend $7 at a drive thru.  Much better for you and go ahead and titilate your senses.  You can alwasy douse your pho with Siracha or Hoisin Sauce.

The windy road seemed awkwardly familiar and although I hadn't driven down this particular path in almost a decade but I was ready...The young man taking my order before the first window was adorable, "The three please with a Dr. Pepper."  

I had been craving InNOut ever since we left Monterey, my sister had returned home for a family emergency (our first and hopefully last) and she had to get to her Global Environmental Politics Final by 4pm.  I got her to UCSB and dropped her off by Campbell Hall by 2:15pm.  There are several of these fine burger joints on the route down the 101 but we kept missing each and every single one so you can see how I was hungry to floor it to this particular location off Turnpike.

The ladies at each window were beautiful and customer service was impeccable.  My "car ready" meal and I (with onions nothing animal style, that's a bit much for me esp. since my sister was having major gas issues on the drive down and she said if I had ordered animal style and she had to smell it that she might poop in her pants and the thought of that well you can see how I wouldn't want to order anything, fries included animal style.)  I drove a few exits south and parked in a parking lot.  I had devoured my little heavenly balance burger (crunchy fresh cool onions and lettuce, warm beef patty, juicy tomato and tight slightly toasted bun and the sauce is killer, next time I will ask for extra sauce.  That alongside a few fries while sucking down a packet of ketchup and a few sips of nice cold Dr. Pepper.  I was happy but felt slightly bad that my little sister was taking a final and I was in pure bliss.

We stopped in for a quick lunch and I was craving Fetuccini Alfredo.  I ordered the closest thing to it on the menu and it was the Cajun Pasta.  It was actaully pretty good.  However, we foudn hair in our food.  Our group expereinced hairy food at every restaurant we stopped in.  No joke.  I don't think hair nets are necessary in TN.  They should be.  

A very casualy bar/restaurant that you can get rowdy in if you want to.

When I was getting my nails did in walking distance at Famous Nails yesterday the ladies that were working got a snack at Jack's... totally brought back memories from when I used to have the munchies and was at FT (Fuck Towers now Santa Catalina Dorms) or when I was filling up my gas next door at Chevron and skipped over for a Spicy Chicken Sando (those are the best!).

Hot, quick and greasy... what more could one ask for (question mark).

One of the best places to go if you are out of the dorms and fending for yourself out in IV or if you are too cool and mature and move out near State St. or the city college.  

Cheap eats and affordable booze, it doesn't get much better than this.  Besides the one closer to campus on Calle Real, this was my go to market until I graduate in 2002.

The views are gorgeous and the outside seating is perfect on a warm day but the food is below par.  My friend and I both tried the Cheese Tortellini with a Marinara and Bolognese Sauce Combo.  I just expected it to taste a little better considering it is served on paper plates and puts you back eleven bucks.  I'd rather hit up the Hot Dog Haus located somewhere on the lower half of the mountain.  They serve Elk Chili and their hot dogs are off the hook... not to mention super long and delicious for only $5.50.  The hot dogs at Two Elk starts at $8.

As Sam stated when we first sat down at one of the casual picnic style tables in the middle of the restaurant- we are a group of, " dietary restriction (shrimp as he pointed to himself), dietary restriction (gluten as he pointed at me), dietary restriction (gluten as he pointed to my partner), restaurant owner/chef (as he pointed to my Dad - it was our Father Daughter Ski Weekend), and I forget what he said about my sister but you get the point. Not an easy party to deal with especially at an Asian restaurant (where shrimp can be found in some fish sauces and gluten hidden in many others). 

Our server's customer service skills were on point and she went above and beyond to accommodate us without making a fuss. We were beyond grateful.

Pho bowls here are double the size of any pho restaurant i've ever been to before in my life. I ordered the oxtail pho because it was seasonal as did our father. We both though the oxtail could have cooked slightly longer as it would have made the near fall off the tailbone but other then that the broth was super rich, had solid depth, and full of flavor.

The shrimp summer rolls were enjoyed by all minus Sam (shellfish allergy) and they made one of the specials GF for our table. If you see it on the specials board, I would highly recommend trying it out... the sautéed eggplant served in a hot clay pot with the optional minced pork meat was divine! With a side of rice this would feed 2 to 3 people. I hope they have it next time we head up to Reno to ski Mt. Rose

Nothing better than a bowl of hot noodle soup and some specialty comfort food eats after skiing a perfect 
bluebird but cold ski day, best snow, and even better company!

My sisters and I love enjoying a pitcher of Sangria here... we were in the area on Monday for lunch and we didn't quite make it to Cafe Buenos Aires for our sangria but I'm glad that we stopped by Andersen's Bakery instead as this place is now closed.  The number is out of order and I just read in another post that they were closing.  The links on their website are down too so I guess they are gone.  So sad.  I'm glad my sisters don't know as they would be very bummed about this.

Wow really?  More like Not So Good... I don't get how once can spend so much on not so lovely quality things... I do but at F21 prices... the earrings I saw here were $14.99, $12.99 and some on sale for $8.99 or $6.99 but the quality is the same as F21 and their prices start at $2.99... I just don't see how people can love this place... yes it is eye-catching and a lot of "pretty" and sparkly things but to me they are at rip-off prices.  I saw feather hair clip extensions that went up to $35 or more and they weren't even nice pheasant feather or anything... I saw a one feather clip that had one feather on it that was $8.99 and I got a bag of 200 (of the same feather) for $4.99 at Beverly's Fabrics last week... maybe part of the clip was missing?  When I went to touch it the feather wasn't even fastened correctly on the clip and the feather pretty much flew away... I was in shock.  

1 stars because it is a smart idea to pack a place full of "cheap" jewelry but it's also uber cheap quality and 1 star for the entrepreneur who is banking on the profit.
Stop in here to and from the mountains for a tune up or to check out what stuff they have on sale.  I got some tees for $4.99 can't beat that.  (Perfect for little gifts.)  Always friendly service.
Lightly toasted, cream cheese, red onions, tomatoes, smoked salmon, capers with lemon pepper served open faced was a blessing in disguise.  Unbelieveable and simply irresistable!

Oh Man.  Where do I begin?  My sisters and I hit this place up and it was better than I remembered from my visit before (but it had been at least 6 years).  

Great atmosphere and nice mixed crowd.  The order taker is an adorably cute gentleman and if you don't know what you want ask him to recommend something.l  We ordered about 6 items to share and I asked him to pick the last one and his was the highlight of our little lunch fiesta.

Here is what we ordered (and not in order):

Tecate with Lime

Horchata - Grande

Pechuga Suiza - Chicken/Cheese served between 2 corn tortillas

Carne Asada Tacos (a bit dry, but some salsa on it and make it wet)

Carnitas Tacos  (a bit dry as well)

Green Chile and Cheese served between 2 sheets of corn tortillas (my sister saw them charring the chiles on the grill and wanted to try it, super sweet but I wish we got them without the cheese)

Side of Today's Special - Arroz/Rice

Side of Guacamole

Today's Special - Tacos Deshrebada ( shredded beef served with a creamy avocado sauce, um yes please)

The Recommendation - Chilaquiles ( hot chips drenched in a spicy tomato broth mixture then topped with cheese and grilled green onions - just gorgeous)

After he placed the Chilaquiles for us then other people started to order and one lady asked if I special ordered them since she didn't see them on the menu.  Minutes later they placed Chilaquiles on the Today's Special Board. 

Um you could say we left full.  Salsa bar is a nice touch and the covered patio seating is awesome.  This place is always packed especially during lunch and it's funny to watch the locals practice their Spanish with the man in charge.

One of the prettiest malls from the outside however there aren't many stored there that I frequented when I went to UCSB.  Now State street has had an Extreme Makeover.  Tons of brand names stores right on State like Juicy (but who really shops there now? even though I think there stuff is adorable), surf shops galore and Betsey Johnson.

It isn't always the cheapest (quite the contrary) but I used to have a Chevron card so this was a no brainer.  Not only did I come to this location for gas but for food, Reality Bites style.  No joke.  I remember coming home with bags full of groceries.  Snacks more like it...

I was a regular here and it is the most convenient place to fill gas whether you want to admit it or not.  I always stopped en route to go home to Monterey.
My sister and I played Nationals here for Junior Tennis in '94 or '95.  Of course, with my luck I would lose to a girl from Mexico living in Fresno, I mean Fres-yes.

Yes, I liked this place when it was Anthropologie more... however it is hard to dislike a place that sells adorable clothing for cheap (and it's okay that the quality is cheap because even if you get one or two "wearings" out of your outfit it is worth it).  Once I start making $$$ again I will like this place less but for now, I heart F21 but this one is not as organized as several of the others I have been to.

10 years ago when I was 20, I walked in with another female companion with a group of 6 or 8  guys (I don't remember) .  It was a Bachelor Party and they prettty much dragged us innocent girls in.  I'm pretty sure we weren't served although I don't remember (this is becoming the theme of this evening)...

Next thing I know we made it to her apartment and I had thrown up as I opened the door of her 325 ti... who drives a 325 ti... baby hatchback BMW?!?  (No that is not nice Shiho!)  It was a very cute car and a lovely birthday present she got when she was 16.

I rarely threw up back then so something must have gone done during the night.  I do not recall all the details but thank Sandbar for getting an eventful (unfortunately not very memorable for me) evening started.

Initially I sat down to kill some time while I waited for my friends to arrive from their United flight from LAX.  I didn't have many options so I sat down at Outpost Cafe with my large check-in bag and my ski bag and got a glass of Pinot Grigio.  Why not.  

Now I know the elevation of Boise is nothing extreme in fact it's probably sea level but Google just said they are about 1/2 mile above sea level... maybe that's why the wine hit me so hard?!? Probably because I'd neglected to eat my honey roasted peanuts and pretzels on my Southwest flight, lunch and breakfast.

I ended up ordering the wings because I felt bad for just sitting there... I ordered another glass of wine and this one was a big girl glass and I had a hard time finishing it...almost.  The wings were good but not as good as they were the day after.

Yes, I had 8 leftover so I took them with me to McCall, reheated and served them with fresh celery sticks and their ranch and my friend and I thought we had the best wings ever.  Seriously, they will be my Wingstop moving forward but unfortunately they are in Boise and I live in California.  Not lovely.

I like this Chevron (which was under construction) not for their gas but their mini mart.  They don't offer a lot but this is one of the last stops before Mt. Rose so it was conveneient to pick up some ice for our cooler to keep our beverages cold enough to enjoy post skiing... tailgating style.

Clean new smoke shop in a convenient location (if you are going to school at UCSB and have a car that is) offering all of your smoking supplies.  Cigs, cigars, cigarillos, pipes, tobacco etc...

Kind gentleman owner behind the counter who looks like he'd be happy to help you but usually you know what you want when you are hitting up these type of places.  This shop just opened its doors 3 months ago so hit it up if you are into this kind of stuff.

I don't smoke, nor do I socially smoke (smoke after drinking) because some people think those two are different but I heard my sister make a comment of pooping and cigarettes and as a person who always had a hard time pinching a loaf, I thought hey why not(question mark).  I'm not promoting smoking but am promoting healthy and regular bowel movements.

Special: Marlboro Menthol Lights 2 packs for $8
Funny or not I didn't frequent this place until after I graduated and left UCSB.  It wasn't until I went to visit my sister did I get to enjoy a cold brewski and some bar grub.  Fun dive joint.

Back in the day I would coe here with some of my teammates after a grueling session on the court.  We'd hit the salad bar and grab a refreshing beverage and call it a day before getting ready to go out.  Gelson's provides good quality food and they are known for their great customer service and friendly faces.
Opened yesterday!! Finally an actual Chase Bank in Nevada and boy just an ATM. Californians thank you!

'Um... with some ranch and Wild Bread please' are the words that used to come out of my mouth.  Loved their pizza for their sauce stuffed crust and their ultra fresh ingredients.  So good that my girlfriend and I ate some random's table's leftovers the night of my 18th Birthday and I'm surprised that I remember anything from that night.  Best Pizza in IV when you are wasted!
Friendly neighborhhod book stop that was cheaper than the bookstore on campus.  It would help you save a few bucks so you can save it for beer or "notes".

Used to be one of my favorite place but it gets old even if you do try everything on the menu.  Still pretty good place to go for a good soup and or salad.  If you do crave a sandwich, my fav. is the Thanksgiving Turkey.

Would be a great place to get your stuff done but this place became the trendiest "study" spot.  Girls would come looking thier best dresse down.  Sort of how they would dress up and get their faces dolled up for the gym.  I loved hanging out there and spreading my books (that I borrowed from the place by the library) all over the tables until the store manager thought it would be a fun idea to blast the AC on so that we wouldn't park for more than 45 minutes.  We were smarter than that, we'd just come in sweats and Uggs.  Problem solved.

Even though I didn't have the best of luck with my entree I'm giving this place 4 stars for a killer ambiance in downtown Boise.  This place was happening Thursday night after we trekked into BOI from LAX, IAH and SJC, we were tired and a bit hungry and definitely parched. 

We wanted to grab something before heading up to McCall so we ventured into Bardenay.  This place was alive and they don't mess around on their drinks.  Especially their vodka in gin which they distill...

I got the Bardenay Bond... which was gin & vodka shaken and served up.  I love a fat stiffy but this was almost too much for me... or maybe it was because I've had so many bad experiences with gin that we don't mix well anymore?  Regardless, my friend finished it for me.  

I did something that I have never done and ordered that lame entree that one would if you don't have much of a palate or in some cases culture and got the Fettucini Alfredo... only putting it out there like that because their menu is extensive and impressive.  They have a whole section devoted to Satay Sticks which I found so sexy.  

I didn't have it in me, I wanted something plain, simple and comforting.  I'd been craving Alfredo Sauce all week so I just went with it.  Stoked I did as it was simple yet pretty tasty.  The only problem was that it was cold.  Not warm but borderline cold.  I had it taken back ( I rarely have things taken back) and it came out within minutes and it was still cool.  Not warm but cool.  Strange.  I should have said put it in the microwave for 60 seconds, that would have done the trick.  I pretty much ate it all anyway, I was hungry and it was solid.


Calamari was ordered as well as a deep fried Chimichanga among others.  My friends were enjoying the selection of beers as I worked hard on my Bond.  If I'm ever in this neck of the woods again, I'd definitely hit them up.

I still get giddy when I step foot into Woodstock's.  Although I grabbed lunch down the street, I ordered one of the Specials (we didnt' have those options when I was a student)... a Med. 1 Topping Pizza which comes with a Cinnabread for $14 or something... you save a few bucks... but I opted for the Wildbread with Ranch.  They have Killer Ranch and I got a Med. Mushroom Pizza... oh this was to-go so I could enjoy it with my friends in Monterey that have never experienced Woodstocks.

The man that helped me out must have been the owner or manager as he was definately there when I was (class of '02) and he grabbed a cup for me to put ice in for my ranch... I nearly teared up.  So smart and sweet!

The pizza almost didn't make it through the 3 hour drive.  See I gave my sister and her roommate a slice and I ate 3... It actually saved me from getting a speeding ticket.  I knew I was going way too fast so I pulled to the right lane and stuffed my face with a slice and let the PoPo drive past me on my left... I figured the faster I drove home, the more pizza and Wildbread there would be for the others.

I love you Woodstock's.  Thank you for the good memories.  My favorite is still the one of my friend Nini eating someone else's leftovers...

Four stars only because this quickly became my favorite late night study spot.  Library is great but too eerily quiet for me and at Denny's I could study for finals while being served coffee, salad with ranch and chicken tenders if I wanted.  Service was what you'd expect... young college students trying to make a dollar, service was slow at times but in general that was fine since I was there taking advantage of their 24hours.
I've been to a hanful of airports in the states.  And this is the least memorable. I love how it is an International Airport.  I was told that they only fly to Canada... does that count?
Always a pleasant experience here and I'm pretty sure I bought all my readers here.  Super convenient especially if you live in IV.
Oh man, I only rememebr being here for a few minutes but I'm sure I was there for an hour or so.  Trendy nightclub and sushi bar a little drive away from downtown.
Love and miss their smoothies.  Always hit up the one in IV and if I went downtown to run errands I'd usually have one of these in my hand.   Enjoy Blenders more than Jamba.  Sorry JJ.

Stopped in briefly on my way home from LA.  Friendly and they offer fresh organic produce and goods.  I was impressed with my Vegan brownie and Kombucha tea (the first time I bought although my sister makes a pretty mean batch).  In the state I was in, I should have saved the Kombucha for another time as it felt like it ate my insides.  I was hurting from 3 night bender in LA.

Any who, when I got the cash register I noticed someone behind the counter who looked just like me.   My little sister works there and she loves it.  I can see why.

When Costco ran out of LEIS... Albertson's came to the F-ing rescue with a fresh batch of leis scattered on a table by one of the doors... we were stoked!!!  We would have felt naked and worthles without a lei for our tropical looking sister.  Thank You Albertson's for having our back this time around (my sister's college graduation) but NO Thank you for the freshman 30 I mean 15 (back in 1998)!!!

Figured they were open but there wasn't a hostess since we crept in before 11pm on a Monday night.  I can see this place "happening" if there were people there but not so much tonight. The outside ambiance reminded me of a small condensed lounge in Vegas or South Beach but just for a minute... I enjoyed the loungy vibe outside, firepit and the outdoor bar makes for a perfect place to host a celebration like a birthday party or a fun party during the day.  Drinks were on the pricier side with the house Sangria being over $10+ per glass but we had just finished dinner up the street so we went in for desert.  The Chocolate Bread Pudding was perfect presentation wise but failed in taste.  It wasn't really warm or chewy and gooey.  More like dry, stale and reminded of an old cupcake.  The whipped cream was refreshing and the caramel created a beautiful design on the white plate but tasted off... over burnt or something.

Our server was sweet but our experience overall was not lovely.  The only reason why I'd ever come back would be either on a Thursday or Friday pre-partying to go out to a club or something on State Street which isn't in my plans in the near future.

I think this is the bar with 2 stages in 2 different rooms.  I knew I was in Nashville when I experience my 2nd culture shock of the day...

I had to tinkle and I walked straight into the bathroom.  There was a trough for men to pee in a plastic shower curtain for the ladies to pee in private.  Well the shower curatin really didn't cover the stall so it was hard to pee standing up crouched over the toilet with my thighs burning all the while holding the curtain up.

I thought it was a unisex toilet... I don't know, it was my first time in Nashville. 

Um... apparently it was the Men's Restroom and none of the 5 men lined up around the bathroom had the balls to tell me.
Stern's Wharf and the beach along Cabrillo is a nice stretch of palm trees and sand.  Catch people playing volleyball, rollerblading and cute boys skating their hearts out in the skate park.

I miss the days when my sister used to work here... this place is so up her alley and the staff is so happy and kind here.  Fresh organic fruits and veggies, bins filled with nuts and legumes, all your vegan and vegetarian needs, green toiletries and gifts, booze!  What more could you possibly ask for (question mark).

I saw 2 kinds of coconut water and was on a mission to buy as many as I could, they checked the stock room for me and they didn't have any cases so they special ordered me 2 kinds.  I'm so stoked!  They'll be in soon, just have to make sure my little sister has enough money to pay for these guys since she has to drive them up to me up north.  Thanks Miks!!!

I think this is the birthplace of the Breakfast Burrito.  No joke.  I know they were good but I must have ruined my tastebuds during my time at SB so I don't remember the taste.  I'll have to visit for a refresher course.

If you are looking for a great deal on a decent and clean place to stay then I highly recommend the East Beach Inn.  Although located next door to a Motel 6 this place is top notch for a budget hotel.  The place seemed newly renovated and is run by a lovely husband and wife team that are super welcoming and attentive.  Frank was a sweetheart and even though I pulled up to check-in after 11pm he greeted us with open arms.  

The hotel room was nicer than a lot of hotels I have stayed at.  I've stayed in hotels that are not as lovely in Vail and paid triple the amount at the base of the mountain.  This hotel is located across the street from East Beach, you could walk to the Pier if you wanted too.

Here's the kicker... I remembered that Frank said to have my sister stop by and she could serve me in bed...  Well I took him up on the offer and sent my sister to fetch some "continental" while I soaked myself in a hot bath.  I joked with her and said, "I'd like a chocolate muffin, blueberry muffin, a croissant, pumpkin bread, tea, coffee and some oj".  I was totally kidding my sister thought I was serious.  So she returned with a white tray covered in goods from Santa Barbara Bakery!

She brought me a chocolate/cream cheese muffin, ham/cheese croissant, pumpkin bread and 2 other muffins!  Oj and coffee too.  Unbelievable, then I felt bad but didn't when we finished it all.

Thanks Frank for your big smile, superior service and a way better than average place to stay.

Great service all around from the front desk, to the bellmen, to the housekeepers... my sister checked us in and was greeted by "B" who had assisted her during a previous stay and she was lovely and very welcoming.  Apparently my sister's boyfriend had severe sunburn and she was very helpful, well she was all smiles and took care of us very well.  

The rooms aren't big unless you get the suite but for us it doesn't really matter because we enjoyed the decor especially the amazing tile work in the bathrooms... our room had 2 ( I think I stayed in the same room last time too).  The pool was closed for maintenance but we didn't mind... we still enjoyed some libations outside under the warm sun and got a mild tan.  We usually don't have time to lounge around but my "baby" sister just graduated from UCBS so we chillaxed and caught up for old times sake.  As I was getting excited for lunch (yes I get excited to eat) my sisters said we needed a little exercise (I grumbled) so we borrowed a few beach cruisers (free) from Montecito Inn and went on a little bike ride (ended up taking 3.5 hours plus a 30 minute tutorial in the parking lot for my Mom who has never riden a bike without handlebar brakes... not lovely).  We biked up to mid-State Street and then walked about 6 blocks up...  we all wore short dressed and I had heels on so it wasn't a pretty sight for passerbyers but we didn't care.  Haha.

Anyways, I highly recommend Montecito Inn.  It's in walking distance to several pretty good restaurants and they serve killer food at the Montecito Cafe.
Oh man, this place was going nuts.  Great place to start off a long night out.  Not your typical karaoke bar, that's for sure.

BOI is a small and clean airport.  I think I went from being dropped off at the curb, checking in at the counter, to passing security, sending off a friend at one gate to sipping on a double Greyhound in 12 minutes.

When my sister mentioned this tapas lounge I was stoked to check it out.  It was late Monday night and there weren't many people dining but I enjoyed the ambiance although it was frigid cold (door open and fan going off) inside but the sangria warmed me up a bit.  Our server was lovely and personable but in general (the others) not so much.  The place was lined with a few couples mostly girls which made us think of Lipstick Lesbians especially when my sister pointed to her tits and said "Milk" and then her woohoo and said, "Honey".  OIC.

Loved the painting on the walls and in the bathroom.  Apparently my sister helped put them up during an internship so it was exciting to see "her work".  I can see how on the right night, this place would be vibing with the right crowd and weather.  (There is some construction going on, nearby maybe that's effecting business (question mark)).

As huge fans of tapas, my sister and I were content with our choices.  Our server was helpful and mentioned their, "sliders" which were literally pulled pork placed atop of mini corn tortillas and some slaw were scrumptious and easy to devour.  We loved the Porque-Pig... which was juicy shredded pork cooked in a tomatillo verde cream sauce and served atop cilantro rice, shaved Manchego too... as well as the Date with a Pig (you figure this one out, it's not hard).  The OMG salad with added beets was refreshing and solid.

The sangria was nothing to write home about and a bit sweet but we enjoyed and savored their unique blend with cloves and allspice.  I wanted more (something less sweet) so I ordered the Coconut Mojito (less sugar) and it was quite delicious.

They have a unique and fun to read menu as well as drinks list.  I'd give them another whirl for sure.

I kind of remember stopping, I know I was adamant about riding the mechanical bull or atleast stopping in to see it.  Everything was super hazy this night so I definitely know I was not mounting that bull.  Very unfortunate.  Maybe I will get the cahnce when I go back to Nashville for my turquoise cowboy boots.

So I revisited IV and did it up DP style and more so of course we had to go to th Cantina for their famous breakfast burritos.  Although it was good I've definitely had better.  What makes these burritos good is 1.) their semi-fried sunny side up egg and 2.) their Spanish rice.  Other than that just another breakfast burrito.  Oh and don't forget the sour cream it makes all the difference.

While I was at UCSB I took a class with Mr. Paul Orfalea who is the founder of Kinko's.  It was probably one of the most interesting classes I took and definately one of my most favorite and memorable.  Anywho, he actually revamped and renamed this bowling alley while I was a student there to Zodo's... a nickname he called his friend.  I beleive it was Zodo that nicknamed Paul ... Kinko.  Thought I'd share the story of how this place was named.  I've bowled here a few times during my four years and had a good time.  Love that there is a bar too!

Too bad I was too exhausted to run around in the hotel and check out the pool and bar.  Good thing I didn't I probaby would have been escorted out.    This historic hotel is a great place to stay if you are visiting Santa Barbara as it is only a few exits away off the highway and Coast Village Road has some great eateries and cute boutiques.

Huge!  I love this store for so many reasons.  The only thing that bummed me out is that we were on State Street with our beach cruisers.  The second I started walking through the door my sisters reminded me that I can't buy anything because I couldn't transport it back.  I was devasted!
