I knew exactly what I wanted too and it was a large colorful beach mat that would have been nearly impossible to lug back unless we had rented a 4 person bike... that would have worked.
This adorable boutique carries some luxe trends in the SB area.   Always stop in here for clothes and acessories.

Absolutely the greatest and healthiest place to go for a decent lunch or dinner.  I hit this place up a couple dozens time while I was a Gaucho and the food was always consistent and tasty.  The Ranch Salad and Aloha Bra are my favorite!  The tennis team would frequent this place after a rough practice or match and we'd relax and wind down with a good plate of food, healing atmosphere in hopes to gear up for the night of drunken debauchery ahead.   I love Natty Cafe!
Wow, Zodo's.  Strangely enough I know why it is called Zodo's.  I also know why Kinko's is called Kinko's.  I'm not psychic but if you want to know why I will tell you.

So I'm playing the Gas Game while driving back north to Santa Barbara from Santa Monica during my Big Bear Weekend...  you know the one where you are like, "I'll get off at the next off-ramp and get some gas"... then you are like "I'll pull off it 5 more miles" and then you realize there isn't anything for a few more miles and you are shitting in your pants thinking you are going to have AAA to tow you a mile to a gas station.  Or is it just me?  I think my mind is just playing games with itself.

Anyways, so I finally take this exit and boy was I in for a good surprise.  First off the bathroom wasn't sketchy.  It had some nice tilage going on... think rustic Tuscany... no not really but the tiles were pretty nice and it didn't wreak of pee!

Then I go in to pay for my gas (the CC slot wasn't working outside) and the gentleman behind the counter was so kind and sincere.  I was on a mission to get back to SB to see my sister so I didn't take my time but if I wasn't in a hurry I would have spent at least 10 minutes in there checking out all the goodies.

This place had a plethora of liquor and a decent cigar selection... I mean for a gas station it was great!  Everything was neat and organized.

A guy walked in and asked the gentleman for beef jerkey.  I took one look down the aisle and said , "the jerkey aisle is down 10 feet to your left".  I mean this place had everything.  Decent selection of deli goods in the fridgerated section, cheeses too!  

Impressive!

Wasn't too impressed with the flavor of the Latte that my Mom picked up as we were waiting for our Electric Shuttle outside.  It wasn't bad just not as robust.  I could see that this would be a hip place to hangout if I was a local.

A bunch of 925 everywhere.... I used to love coming to this shop as a Gaucho... I think I still have some stuff that I bought here from back in the day somewhere... but then again I may have lost it like I lost my memory every other night in IV.  Good times here for sure and you feel like you are hunting for treasure... with just a little patience you will find a real winner.  Walked by the other week with my sisters and we all got a little nostalgic.

Most happening restaurant in Reno!  We visited 3 times during our 3 night stay in Reno and we loved every dish, cocktail and the staff.  Honestly, one of the best restaurants I have ever been to in my life.  Everything is prepared from scratch with a lot of love and attention to detail.  Their mustard is killer and all their meats are from local farms/ranches and prepared in house.   I can't even go into detail about what we ate because we ate quite a bit.  Instead you can see what we ate... posting photos now.

I enjoyed them more when they were at their old location (aka where Forever 21 is now)... regardless, adorable clothing and accessories on the pricier side.  Great atmosphere and interior design here and the service was somewhat friendly.

Only downside is that their "on sale" selection here is weak compared to other stores I have visited in the past.

This particular Trader Joe's is the perfect place for students to grab a healthy snack or stock up on some cheap but decent wine and foods galore.  I picked up some individual wrapped tofu and a bottle of Trader Joe's version of Teriyaki SoyVay.  Told her to pat dry tofu and drizzle the sauce over the brick and microwave for a minute.  You have the healthiest and tastiest snack ever!     

Curry flavored Naan with a premade mini box of Indian flavored Eggplant - Bhurtha makes a great eat/snack.  Braided honey pretzel sticks with spicy hummus is deelish and the list goes on.

Ok I'm not going to lie... my Ralph Lauren duvet cover that everyone loved while I was a student at UCSB ... from Ross.  Most of my pop-collared Polo shirts (yes even the teal one) from Ross.  Bathroom shower caddy, Ralph Lauren bath towels and beach towels and even a few of my swimsuits (all well known labels as I used to be a label whore) from Ross.  My BCBG heels... you get the picture.

I know how to shop for what I want even in a zoo of a place like this.  You just need a little patience and you end up saving yourself hundreds in the long run.

Yep I sure miss Lazy Acres.  Perfect for starving students since it's cheaper than Wholepaychecks.  Actually come to think of it, I felt well-off while I was in college.  Then I entered the real world and now not so much.

I loved our stay here... finding a ski and stay package is the way to go if you like skiing or boarding.  Killer deals, great service and lucky slots!  I won some money off Wheel of Fortune... a friend of mine from my hometown won over a million dollars on my birthday the year before and we forgot it was at this particular casino until we saw the giant photo poster of him and his pretty giant check.  Must be nice.

Stay in the east tower if possible and the higher the better.  The first 3 nights we stayed on the 28th floor and we ended up staying an extra night and we moved down to the 11th I think... big difference.  Sounds like train tracks but I think it is a recycling plant located across the street and it's pretty noisy.  But the sweet deal we got for the extra night didn't hurt neither did the free cocktails while winning some money... didn't hear a thing when I passed out.
On a warm day there is nothing more satisfying than an Iced Coffee from Java Jones.  Super refreshing and a great uber low calorie (I like mine black) pick-me-up.

So not the cleanest place but just a typical family run nail joint with a service menu of manis, spa pedis and eyebrow waxing.  I was dying since my gels were overgrown and one had ripped part of my nail off (yeah like through the middle, not lovely) so I though maybe they could take mine off... all then faux nails.

They offered a "take off" service for $10.  Not bad considering they would do it in a timely manner (that is compared to if I sat there by myself trying to rip these suckers off).  I knew my guy in Monterey does a killer job but these ladies (yes they had a couple of them try and attack these stiffies off) asked where I got them done a couple times, mentioned how well they are stuck to my finger nails and just seemed uber impressed and shocked at the same time at how difficult this task was.  At times it was painful but what can I expect (question mark - the key is not working on this computer, lame I know).  Oh they also complimented me on my nailbed.... that was a first.  

Another Sidenote:  I've been asked if I have modeled before... hand modeled that is... not sure how to take that... but really over the years people have asked me or thought I should, right now obvi not so much.

45 minutes to an hour later they were off but my nails were thin, weak and torn up.  They asked if I wanted a mani and how could I say no (another question mark).  Clear and simple is what I asked for as I have a lot of cooking to do and I want to keep my nails clean etc... when I get back into town (my own form a therapy, cooking for people that is).

Side note: The night before I drove my sister down I was asked to make a quick Jicama Coleslaw since my significant other was heading to Bass Lake with friends for a few days and he had to work late.  I was stoked that he asked me to do something in the kitchen as he is the main chef in the house.  Oh so I forgot how long my nails were and as I was trying to saw through a head of cabbage I kincked a nail and almost lost a piece in the mix... Yeah gross I know!  So stoked to get the off once and for all!

Kind service, lacking the new stuff and ambiance but affordable and they've been around forever!

Um yes please.  My first BBQ experience in Nashville.  AMAZING!  I had the pulled pork sandwich and tried about 5 different BBQ sauces.  I heart condiments.  

Then I went back for more.  I ordered the Sausage Plate, obvi and washed everything down with PBR in a bottle.  

How classic.  Delicious grub, definitely recommend this joint.

Pretty sweet terrain and we were able to park and ski (literally) which was very convenient.  We skied on a Tuesday and Thursday so the slopes were empty and there was no waiting in line.  We brought a picnic and some hard cider and enjoyed lunch of pickled beets, olives galore and sardines while listening to some tunes next to our car.  Friendly staff too!
Best place to go for a sandwich anytime!  That and a pitcher or 2 and you are set.  Hang out and veg in the sun watching the beach cruisers and skaters go by.

5 words.

Like Free...


Not Vegetarian Friendly.

My sisters rave about this place which serves up California Nouveau Cuisine... one of them wouldn't shut up about their Goat Cheese Pancakes, Gravlax of Salmon and Caviar dish.   Unfortunately I can't remember what I had there and they weren't open until after 11am (so I couldn't try the goat cheese pancakes this time as it was still 9am)  so we enjoyed a few treats at their continental breakfast.

Their continental breakfast is served through 10am in a roped off section of the cafe.  The basic breakfast consists of goodies from Debbie's Delights (croissants, chocolate croissants, almond croissants), yogurt, cereal in a box, orange juice, apple juice, milk, bagels etc...  The gentleman manning the joint was a very kind man who was super attentive and asked if we needed anything every so often.  

The night we arrived this place was packed and I love all the windows so you can see all the action that goes on inside.

I'm going back to Nashville so I can pick up a pair of turquoise boots and to visit friends of course.   About 20 of my friends picked up some cowboy boots here.  They had a buy 2 get a pair free special during our trip.

Located in 5 Points Mall next to Rossi's (Ross)... I preferred hitting this one up over the others since it was less of a trek (on foot that is).  Just park and your there... I heart the one in IV but it's not easy holding a smoothie while navigating your beach cruiser in IV, although so doable (beer cans are easier, I could doublefist those and ride fine).

Actually prefer Blenders over Jamba...

The set-up was a bit awkward but I found some killer finds during my 10 minute visit including 3 BCBG sweater, 3 pairs of brand name sunglasses all under $10 an Adidas track jacket (a newer style) and much more... we stopped in because my gentleman friend forget his swim trunks on our mini vacay.

I'm lactose intolerant but that doesn't stop me from eating whatever I want.  (I'm not sure if this stuff even has dairy to be honest, they could be using faux creamer for all I know.)  My sister took me here after a breaky burrito from Cantina after a semi-rough night.  It wasn't bad but it's took bad this place isn't "happening".  They've secured a pretty sic locale and set-up.  It's just too bad they just sell frozen yogurt.

Service was lovely but we only ate here because none of the other restaurants were open and we were hungry.  Food is ok but like most casinos they have a central kitchen so all restaurants offer the same basic food for ex. breakfast sausage.  I love sausage and I've never not swallowed but for some reason I get this iron bloody flavor after taking a bite out of them.  I had it at 2 f their restaurants.  Still with eggs and bacon for breakfast if you can't eat gluten.

I had my college graduation dinner here back in 2002.  Chelsom told me their were some hot waiters and good food.  She was right.  Great place to go for a little celebration or just a good fine dining experience.
Came here for sandwiches when I was too lazy to go to Sam's or when I wanted to add a little variety to my sandwich cravings.

Just adored this little spot.  I think they moved to the corner across the street from Freebirds when I was there.  Even though they had a small selection they always had the best VIX bikinis in stock.

5 stars customer service! 

I think Brandon was his name, young, kinda hunky w/a cap on his head... he held down the fort on one of THE busiest nights in Reno... it was a Saturday and we left Black Rock City (Burning Man) at 3pm to arrive in Reno, starving and tired around 10:30pm normally takes less than 2 hours I think... anyways, show up and we stop at the John Ascuaga's Nugget because I'm a semi high roller not really but qualified for special room pricing since I dropped some dough on my last visit and we were told our first night would be $99 and second $25, I was like perfect, score.  When I head back in to book it, the young man said sorry we are booked.  WTF.  Why did the older lady to his left quote me a room mate... not very smart. 

Fast forward an hour, 3 casinos, 1 inn and 2 motels... we find ourselves at this Motel 6.  It's booked but the nice man (who was working the front office by himself with the phones going off every 5 minutes) was very honest and said that over 20 people hadn't checked in and that he'd start giving their rooms away after midnight.  So we waited and finally at 1:30am about 5 of us scored rooms.  

We were all very grateful although some were more appreciative than others.  Thanks buddy.  You could have just said you were booked, made the same amount of money for the hotel and had a stress free night.  You went above and beyond.  

Oh and the brand new shower was nice too!

When my sister declared that she left a whole bunch of her underwear at home (Monterey) I was on a mission to find her a new panty wardrobe while she was taking her final.  I thought, quick and affordable... Target!  Only because VS charges 3 for $30 for their lace thong and Tarjay offers a comparable one 5 for $20.  You do the math.  

Then I realized why I never got into Tarjay until I moved to Denver in 2005.  I wasn't into discount anything nor had I stepped foot into a Walmart ever for that matter but when you don't have money or cute shops to go to you become accustomed to these type of places.  Anyways, I realized the closest Target to SB was either backtracking to Santa Maria or heading south to Ventura.  Um not so much so Rossi's it was.

My mission of picking up 5 or so small pieces of cloth to cover my sister crotch became an hour of shopping bliss.  I went to town on leather flipflops galore, purple rugs, fish bowls, fish plates, tops to sleep in etc... No I'm not kidding, sterling silver earrings, comfort cover with matching decorative pillows and even Dr. Scholl's clogs (although yellow and plastic or something, I can garden in them right (question mark).

I actually went twice last night, yeah I'm that nuts.  The staff was very kind and helpful (when I needed help opening the jewelry cases) and a few looked familiar.  Loyalty.  I remember them from when I attended UCSB from 1998-2002... no joke!

Although I used to be a brand name whore (can't afford it anymore and I'm fine with that, you still can find BCBG, Ralph Lauren, Quiksilver etc...if you look hard and if you are a student this is a mecca for finding cheap good quality bed sheets, bath towels, bikinis (I've bought VIX, Roxy, Raisins and more here in the past), laundry hampers, headphones, pillows, down comforters... you name it, they might just have it!

Berrilicious to Korean BBQ House newly changed to Kogilicious!  Um... Delicious!

I wasn't in the mood for Korean BBQ but my sister insisted to take me here before I took off today.  When we arrived I asked her where the yogurt place went and she said that they keep changing things around here and I feel like they have found their perfect niche.

We ordered the #8 Beef Short Rib Rice Bowl.  The meat and the rice were cooked perfectly, flavor was solid and authentic and I loved that they even topped the bowl with fresh green onions and a nice dash of roasted sesame seeds.  Nice touch.  We got it to-go in a microwavable bowl but ended up enjoying it on one of their tables in their outdoor patio/lounge.  They offer the BEST cold water ever... I know strange, but I never drink water and I had like 5 cups of the ice cold stuff and I enjoyed the Siracha as well as their House Hot Sauce.  The mix of their hot sauce and the siracha made me cry for a minute but it was so very good and it hurt but it was still so good!  I love the outdoor ambiance with the wall covered with colorful paint... I couldn't stop taking picture of it... seriously.

The lovely young lady behind the counter was personable and I loved her aura.  If I was still a student there, I'd be here multiple times a week.  I played on the Tennis Team so I wouldn't feel guilty eating all that delicious meat and rice.

Our company took care of us very well while visiting Nashville.  One of the highlights of the trip was our evening at Bosco's.  We reneted out the whole top floor and dines on some darn good food.  Open bar didnt' hurt and we even had some of the most amazing live entertainment ever.  We even got their CDs as a souvenier.  This sounds corny but it was a magical night and the artists had some of us in tearts by the end of the evening.

Killer deal and great stop if you are skiing Mt. Rose.  My gentleman friend rented a pair of Performance skis and he kicked my butt on the mountain (he bombed the mountain faster than I could)... not because he is a better skier (haha) but I think his skis were freshly waxed and he is heavier than me.  Awesome service and a great selection of ski clothes and accessories next door and a full demo rental program too.

Another day, another dollar. Well, six to be exact. 

After reading the rave reviews about this place, I knew I wouldn't be disappointed. So, I didn't really go here for the pho (I already knew that'd be great--which it was). Instead, I came to put their yelp-famed speedy service to the test. As soon as our server left the table with our order, I started the stopwatch. Our pho arrived at 00:47.4 seconds. I'm not even kidding. Since I'm the first one to do this, I urge the next person who eats there to beat my score. Absolutely nothing will happen if you beat it, but it'll probably be fun to see if they catch on. Next thing you know, they'll be handing you pho on your way in without even making you order. 

As we ate, our server slammed down playing cards at the corner table with fellow staffers. Whatever, this place is awesome, pho real.

Dear Urbn,

Dr. Martens are cool again? Yesssssssssss. And Toms are made out of what? Regurgitated seitan? Cooooool!

Remember, remember, the 27th of December. Man that has a nice ring to it. I love my birthday. I don't want anyone to know how much I care for it though, just in case no one celebrates it or wishes me a "Happy Birthday!!" You know, that'd be more disappointment than I'm willing to hassle with. So, I don't make a big deal about my birthday. No week-long celebrations, no gigantic party with my extended family and famous friends, no piñata, no threesomes, no nothing.  

So far, I've read my "if today's your birthday horoscope" and it's shed some important light upon 2010. Make no major decisions in March, or at all if possible; fall in love during the first week in February, but no sooner, and no later, lest I desire no valentine; heed the warnings of the full moon and Saturn rising with special attention to Jupiter's orbit.

I know what you're thinking. "Hey! This isn't a review!" Yes it is. Yes it damn well is. You see, the last time I was in Harry's Occult shop, I was  begging for quarters - after all, someone needs to feed the meters. While the kind wizard satisfied my request, I perused the potions, incense, and spell books littered throughout the shop. I felt like Giles was going to come out from the back of The Magic Box and Willow, Xander, and Anya were going to bust through the front door with another demonic case to solve. I was Buffy, after all. 

Anyway, this store seems really cool and I'm probably going to pay it another visit when I return to Philly. They've got sorcerers there just waiting to tell me my future. And I love learning about my future, it means less work for me.

This review is specifically for the upstairs area, NOT WCL (downstairs).

I just can't get into it. Every time I've seen someone perform in the upstairs performance space, I'm disrupted by the chatty tables around me and I swear there's something amiss with the acoustics. I feel like the artists booked for the upstairs space lend themselves to intimate settings and I hate to say WCU(pstairs) doesn't make me feel like it's just me and the musician. That's the point of intimacy, right?

Don't be mistaken, all the World Café Live (downstairs) shows are terrific. In fact, I don't think there's a better venue out there to play. But alas, there's a lot left to be desired in the upstairs area. It won't keep me from seeing artists I like though; just wish there was a way to make them sound better. Also, the table that's off to the right of the stage is awful. Every group that sits there always feels entitled to personal banter with the musician. Good beer and food though.

While I didn't want to find myself in the Northeast at Walgreens at 9am on Sunday, "when the hangover knows no bounds," there I was with my sick friend taking advantage of their "take care clinic." She's visiting from out of town and needed to be seen "as soon as possible." Really, she's something of a hypochondriac, but I'm a good friend, so off we rode to get her seen by their walk-in clinic so she could walk-out with antibiotics. 

Visits with a doctor always mean waiting, but not at this Take Care Clinic. The lady in a doctor's coat (not sure if she was a doctor or what her credentials were) immediately walked out upon hearing us arrive, took my friend, and within 40 minutes, we were walking out with her medicine. 

I seem to be incapable of "browsing," so I got a flu shot to match her exam. My friend later informed me that flu season is, like, so over. As if.

My roommate asked me a few minutes ago whether I wanted pizza. I told her no thank you, I wasn't hungry. Without my knowledge, she called in for a large pie and 15 minutes later, it showed up at our door. I guess I wasn't expecting her to go through with it: order a pizza when I expressed my lack of interest. Clearly, she is a self-governing woman who doesn't need a party to support her decisions. She was an active feminist in college. 

As I sat at my computer, I took quick peeks over my shoulder to watch her enjoy the cheesy deliciousness. Finally, the craving kicked in. I tossed $6 in her direction and when she left the couch to pick it up, I stole a slice. Then another. And another. Paolo's pizza is good enough to steal.

You'd be surprised, but It takes a lot of me to get really excited about new restaurants. I love the fancy ones, but I'm not a huge fan of getting "dolled up" and throwing on my stilettos. When I heard Tommy Up was opening a burger and beer (B&B) joint, now that's my calling. I thought: what's the perfect B&B outfit? Elastic waistband preggo jeans? Nay. Muumuu? Double nay. I opted for the perfect paradox: beige and pink polka dotted, cleavage inspiring summer dress for the anticipatory burger, beer, and shot-fest...

Just as I expected, the place was crawling with "7s and 8s and 9s" (thanks Arthur Kade, you gross misogynist). Hotties all over! I even ran into Sam L of Yelp Elite fame! After waiting a brisk 10 minutes, my friends and I were seated in the small dining room. Sure, service was a little lagging, but it's understandable considering it was opening night. I ordered about 9 Miller High Life pints and the house PYT burger. 

The burger was fantastic! Served will all the right toppings (lettuce, tomato, white onions, BACON) and house special sauce. The patty was perfectly seasoned and all the goods came between two potato bread buns. Not all buns are created equal, and we all know potato bread is the way to go. Nicely done, Tommy Up.

On the downside, the music was a bit too loud and I couldn't really hear anything my friends were saying. It was almost like being on a reality TV show where tensions rise and people are pushed to their limits and you really get to know a person's true character based on how they handle stress and conflict. Well it was not a good showing for one of my "friends," and now I don't respect him because respect goes both ways and clearly he doesn't know how to treat a lady in a dress (me). Men.

I'll be back for seconds in no time; this place is one more visit away from a 5-star update.

I went on a lunchtime bender at Ron's this afternoon. As my stomach growled, I decided a sloppy, BBQ sauce drenched, pulled pork sandwich was the way to go. My eyes were bigger than my stomach though and I left Ron's feeling in serious need of horizontal couch time. Then I fell into a 2 hour food coma. I also added a heaping pile of mac n cheese to my order. Way. too. much. food.

When you're feeling gluttonous, perhaps Ron's is the way to go.

Ordinary people don't know about Tasty Twisters. My experience involved driving down small (almost nonexistent) street off Main Street. Then turning into an empty parking lot. I don't remember there being a sign, but there IS a door. You open the door and walk into a small, dilapidated waiting room. There's a small window and a man behind it. He'll say, "hello, how many?" You'll say "a dozen? half dozen?" Don't say one or two. Chances are that won't be enough after you taste these soft pretzels AND given the scenario I've laid out for you, do you REALLY think one or two is acceptable?

This place is a total secret, so keep the information I've just provided you with in the small, secret jean pocket. You know, the one you always wanted to put drugs in but probably didn't?

Plenty of sunshiney, outdoor seating, direct views of the water and if you're lucky, the glimpse of someone reeling in a nice catch! 

Seafood is the focus here, so try not to stray too far from that menu. The golden margarita is surprisingly great and the service comes from a sassy sally who'll charm you with her friendly banter.

A great local's watering hole that makes you feel like you've hit the islands. Cash only.
This chair massage was so good I fell asleep and drooled a little puddle onto the floor. 10 minutes in heaven and I didn't even have to take my clothes off.

Half of my closest friends are gay men. Don't get me confused though, I'm no "fag-hag;" I'm not that high maintenance and I'm also not very catty. Anyway, I always find we're flocking to Valanni. I love the diversity. When you look around the bar, you'll find gay men, lesbians, business professionals, cougars, UArts students - it's a true slice of Philadelphia life (minus the Mummers). 

The martinis are fruity and creative and they even feature a list of mojitos and house sangrias. I'm a fan of the X-Boyfriend cocktail. 

It's a lively scene at the bar and one of the only places in Philly that successfully caters to all walks of life. Oh and Kinky Jen hosts Kinky Quizzo on Tuesday nights. Winners take home a pot of erotic goods! Can't beat that. (ew)

Me gusta ir a Whole Foods, pero me da pena. A veces olvido mi bolsa  y cuando llego a pagar, siempre me preguntan "¿traiste su bolsa?" En este momento pierdo no solo mi dignidad pero tambien los cinco centavos que podria ahorrar.

-translation-

I like to go to Whole Foods, but it makes me feel guilty. The thing is, sometimes I forget my bag and when I go to pay, they always ask, "did you bring your bag?" In this moment, I lose not only my dignity, but also the five cents I could have saved [by bringing my bag].

Checked out Resurrection for brunch this morning. As my friends and I discussed the politics of squatters, and why they suck, we enjoyed a few items off the varied and veggie-friendly menu. While I typically scoff at scones, I found their black currant scone with creme fraiche and fruit preserves to be the first scone I'd ever consider paying money for. I'll keep stealing the less inferior ones.

Since I've been on a steak kick lately, I opted for the Steak (and Eggs) Frites. The grilled hanger meat came with perfectly runny sunny-side-up eggs and the hand cut fries were of the crispy, less potato filled variety. While it's not my favorite fry, I thoroughly enjoyed theirs.

My friend ordered the roasted cauliflower dish with sweet and sour onions. Yo, this was great. As were the 'Taters and 'Snips: crispy potatoes and parsnips with queso fresco and romesco sauce.  Double win there.

The biscuits and gravy looked fantastic, but my friend threatened to cut me if I dared dig in. They must have been good. 

Overall, fantastic brunch menu (they even have huevos rancheros!) and I can't wait to try more. Brendan, if you're reading this, could you please make a beef stew and call me when it's ready?

Arbolito, my little sapling, you make me so happy. This quaint little tree-house of a coffee shop serves up more than just café con leche and yerba maté. Their food is quick, their service comes with smiles, and their mini-lomito sandwiches gleam with goodness. 

Perfectly piled between the fresh and squishable buns you have: not just turkey, not just ham, but turkey-ham, a broken egg, a thin steak, and cheese. 

They accept only dollar dollar bills, but don't scoff, they accommodate to all walks of life and non-life. We probably would've stayed longer, but the zombies scared us off.

There's no better way to "build" credit than through shopping. But, after falling into the unapologetic pits of debt, I decided it was time to give conspicuous consumption a rest. Those were dark times littered with low-rent options like Daffy's, Buffalo Exchange, GAP, H&M. Gasp.

After making my mighty return to the land of milk and honey, I decided Petulia's Folly was the perfect place to flex my purchasing power. Imagine Anthropologie, 4 years ago (when it had less "mom" and more edge), in a space a quarter of the size with pricey, but oh so desirable ladies wear, sexy ladies wear. 

While I wanted to buy a ridiculously expensive top, I settled, where "settled" takes an enthusiastic tone, for a pair of Habitual jeans....on sale. Alas, even though I'm no longer in isolating debt, I still can't drop mad money on extravagant items. If I were an athlete's wife though, I'd probably spend a lot of time at Petulia's Folly. It's there for anyone with good taste and disposable income.

I'll be the first to admit that I've never considered Alfa a dining destination. It's always been more of a bar/lounge to me, and not one I regularly frequent. Consider me wildly mistaken though! I went to the Root Liquor Tasting dinner last night and found myself beside, well, myself. 

The creamed corn summer soup topped with fresh and slightly warm lobster, the scallop on steroids, the pork loin with golden raisins, the venison with Root mashed potatoes, the cream soda float! The whole meal was inventive and tasty and our unruly, drunk tablemate helped add the finishing touches to an otherwise food-focused experience. 

When he started slapping venison against his chest, well, we knew that was our cue to make for the exit.

Great cafe that gave me exactly what I was looking for this morning: a bacon, egg, and cheese, with a tomato slice on an English Muffin. My brother went with the burger special. Total came out to $8 and that's just awesome. Definitely a great spot for a quick hot meal, especially when calories don't mattah.

I was flooded with fearsome college memories upon entering South Street Mailboxes today. At first, I observed the employee with a keen, suspicious eye. Was she not the doppelganger of my sophomore year college roommate who attacked me with a kitchen knife (for eating a handful of her yogurt raisins) only to be fended off by her drug dealer boyfriend? The employee wielded the pen with the similar effortless knife-flare as my former roomie. Then she smiled and asked how my day was going and asked if there was anything else she could help me with. All too weirded out by their striking similarities, I failed to realize that she was actually really sweet. Especially considering the fact that I was on the phone during our transaction. I'm a jerk.

This mailbox shop is my neighborhood go-to for all things faxing/shipping/printing and they never cease to be incredibly useful and pleasant. Now I want to go back and hug my lady-seller of postage stamps due to the guilt I feel for not having obviously appreciated her customer service. Gah.

Modern Eye makes me wish I was blind. Not totally, but just enough to warrant a pair of sexy tortoise shell spectacles. I would undoubtedly buy them here, their selection is eye-catching. Har. 

Best in the city, that's all you need to know.

I love steak and whiskey. And sometimes, when the desire hits, I can't help but recall my last experience at Capital Grille when I met up with my former co-workers and Fred Noe - the rotund and jolly Kentucky whiskeyman whose face currently graces the side of every Jim Beam bottle. 

Our table kept to a conservative order of NY strips or filets. As the moment for my decision drew near, my thoughts wavered: tender and juicy filet mignon or the satisfaction of cutting into a lean sirloin. Just then, Kentucky's whiskey Santa Claus opted for the 24 ounce porterhouse, I had to follow his lead. In life, when you can't decide, pick the porterhouse.

As we all know, the sides at Cap Grille are plentiful and glorious. Parmesan truffle fries, Lobster Mac n Cheese, Lyonnaise potatoes, creamed spinach, fresh veggies. 

We were total gluttons, exchanging plates and sauces and belly laughs. Capital Grille is perfection personified.

Can we all agree that once you've experienced a California burrito, there's just no other burrito in the world (probably) that compares. There's just no way. Taco Riendo, however, is Philly's honest to goodness attempt at achieving that West Coast standard, and man, they do a pretty bang up job.

After catching the buzz on this spot, I finally made my way over. What I thought was going to be down 'n dirty, ended up being airy, bright, and adorable. My brother mentioned it reminded him of Miami - with guys standing outside, shooting Spanish slang and old men cooks in the open kitchen churning out the arroz con frijoles. 

While El Fuego, Qdoba, and Chipotle uphold the burrito to bicep-sized standards, Taco Riendo laughs, scoffs even, at the unnecessary Big-Mac-load-it-up style. Instead, my burrito de pollito came tightly wrapped in foil and no larger than, say, a turkey wrap. For once, I left feeling delightfully full, rather than overwhelmingly in need of a couch. 

The menu's loaded with options, but my brother convinced me that the platters are the way to go. I'd have to agree -- his chicken mole enchiladas outshone my mighty burrito, precious as it may have been.

I'll definitely be back to enjoy some outdoor seating...especially since you can bring your own alcoholic everything and enjoy!

If I wasn't so desperate to put something in my stomach at 2am on a Friday night, I probably would have waited, whipped up some Kraft Mac n Cheese and devoured appropriately. Instead, I watched my friend wait in the freakshow line for slices of gay pizza. 

I scarfed the BBQ chicken slice and then started on another slice of plain. As we drove away, Mutton Chop stuck her hand out the window and stole a drag queen's slice. Since it's not something nice girls do, I drove around the block and made her return the pizza to the "oh-no-she-didn't-figure-8-hand-waving-finger-snapping-sista." 

All's well that ends well.

*Yelp, why have you decided to make "snapping" two words? I think we both know there's no such thing as a "snap ping."

After downing one too many last night and waking up to find one shoe at the bottom of the stairs, the other at the top, my inside-out jeans in the hallway, the rest of my clothes in the shower, and my hair wrapped in a towel, nothing can get me back on my feet like a filet from The Capital Grille. 

Clearly the only class I have is the kind I can buy. 5 stars Capital Grille. Thank you.

Lovely gourmet items to go: salads, prepared food, fresh cut oatmeal, chocolate covered things, sorbets, and other delicious items that would satisfy any lunch belly or dinner party...albeit a little bit pricey.

After a serendipitous weekend of meeting random eccentrics, my main mate and I felt it necessary to round out our experiences with a visit to RIM - reading about your stories of Rene had us feeling like he'd be the pot at the end of a rainbow.

Rene is the best, he knows he's the best and he won't serve anything that isn't completely fresh and made to order. I enjoyed the most ambrosial chai latte. It came topped with freshly shaved chocolate, bits of pistachio, and other spices he scraped, drizzled, and dribbled into my steaming glass. Rene's got a culinary arsenal of spices and chocolate off to the side and it isn't until your drink is in the glass that he adds the final touches. He even has a chocolate covered block of Parmesan cheese!

My friend's chocolate cappuccino was ridiculous. First of all, Rene served it in a margarita glass and spread melted chocolate on the inside using a brush. I mean, yeah. Once he poured in the steaming milk and espresso, he added a circular airplane shaped chocolate piece to the top of the glass and used a BLOW TORCH to melt it into the beverage. To say it was the best thing ever isn't saying enough. 

While at RIM, we met a couch surfing nomad and her Spaniard boyfriend. She's been "surfing" for 10 months and swears it's how she's going to spend the rest of her life. Once my friend and I left, we just stared at each other and smiled. This weekend was sublime.

As its name would suggest, Resurrection Ale House is digging through the Grey's Ferry trenches and giving this blossoming neighborhood the quality bar it needed. 

The proprietors of Memphis Taproom and Local 44 have once again brought spectacular beer into an otherwise desperate (but growing) neighborhood. Same as they did with Memphis in Fishtown and Local in West Philly, it seems they have a knack for discovering these bustling communities of beer-starved zealots and giving them the finely crafted beer it they crave. 

My friend and I shared 6 glasses of suds: Brewer's Art Resurrection Ale (hurry and get some, they've only got one keg), Russian River's Pliny the Elder (a personal hoppy favorite), Schlenkerla Helles (tastes like nothing you've ever had before, bacon turned beer...awesome), Dogfish Head Pumpkin Ale (taste like autumn, gush), Lagunitas Lucky 13 (piney, slightly sour, and delicious).

We also sampled the edibles: beef sliders (!!), rich cheese spread over mini bread crackers (!), hoisin braised pork ribs (!!!), fried chicken wings with drizzled honey (!!!). Even though opening night brought out the entire neighborhood, the staff managed the crowd with the utmost grace and composure. 

Now I can bar hop in Grey's Ferry. 

Grace...Sidecar...Resurrection. This is awesome.

Deciding it was about time to start taking advantage of my health insurance, I scoured the interweb for a doctor. After a horrible experience with a local gyno (where she convinced me that I was depressed -I'm not, it's called PMS- and needed to be on happy pills), I've been a bit skeptical of docs. After reading Julia's review, however, I decided Dr. P sounded like my kinda woman, "someone I would love to have a beer with?" say no more.

So I scheduled my appointment on Friday and they were able to put me in on Monday. I showed up at 3:30 (my assigned time), fearing I'd end up spending my entire afternoon there. Within 10 minutes I was seen by a nurse and within another 5 Dr. P showed up. She's just awesome. Totally conversational, quick to put you at ease, thorough...

We talked about my medical history, she ran through a few exams, prescribed some medicine for my nagging cough, and sent me off for some blood work. I was out of the office by 4:15! She also referred me to a new gyno and dentist. All in all, Dr. P is terrific, thanks Yelp.

Until this afternoon, I had never enjoyed the quintessential Philly sandwich: roast pork with broccoli rabe and sharp provolone. 

If I was a pig being denied life, the Arista sandwich would be the right cause to die for. After eating only half of it, I marched myself straight home and into bed. That thing was big enough to satiate my pork pang for at least the rest of 2010.

I just had my first Vietnamese hoagie. It was the most toothsome sandwich this side of the arepa. The baguette was like Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson: hard on the outside, soft on the inside. The shredded carrots and cilantro blended in perfect harmony with the tofu and pork (?). I'm not sure of the meats included in my afternoon delight, but everything burst with crunchy flavor. 

It was cheap, it felt kinda healthy, and it didn't force me to unbutton my jeans. If ever there was a holy grail...

As for the restaurant, they abide by the 3 mandatory "c's:" cleanliness, credit cards, and cquickness.

Popped in at Apothecary last night after hitting my stomach's limits at Bindi. Just when I decided adding anything else to my already bulging Bindi belly was a bad idea, the swift bartender slid a Clever Club in my direction. His craftsmanship alone was enough to keep me put. I sat mesmerized as he sent orange essence sparks into a lucky patron's elixir. 

When I simply couldn't drink anymore, I spotted the bartender (dare I say his name is Nick) applying a fragrant foam to my neighbor's cocktail. Inquiring wasn't in my best interest. Or maybe it was? Minutes later, I was met with some Sage Wisdom: rhum, white grapefruit, sage leaves, gingko, pineapple-sage foam. One of the best things I've ever put in my mouth.

Aside from the drinks, my friend's favorite APO experience was the sage-slapping practice. Just ask or observe next time you're in.

I recently found out what Kung-fu Necktie means. If you stay at the bar long enough, the bartender might even tell you too. Actually, they're only allowed to tell 5 people every night. It's worth it.*

It's an intimate bar, not small by any means, but just large enough to comfortably fit 60 people or so. The lights are always dim and if you need a place to rest your bum, you might be lucky enough to snag a booth. The entire bar was gutted and remodeled by the owner apparently. Respect. 

The cozy patio is a welcome respite for smokers, and you're sure to find the tight pants folk in full supply. When it's open (which I think is often), the upstairs art gallery hosts an array of local and regional art. By regional, I really mean NY. 

With the EL tracks running right over the bar, there's no excuse not to get here. So do it, do it, do it.

*That was actually a lie. I have no idea what it means, and more likely than not, it's nonsense. But you know what isn't nonsense? Another bar/music venue/art gallery in Fishtown. Hooray!

Supa Fresh used to be the grocery store I'd run from. I'd actually shield my eyes upon passing and hurry at a ninja's pace to the Whole Foods down the street.

Since I'm all about conquering fears lately, I decided the recent Fresh face-lift deemed the store worthy of a visit. 

The vegetable section is categorized now? Like, all the lettuce goes in its own island unit? All the starches are together? They have a hot foods unit? Different types of rotisserie chicken? Bok Choy?

Having recently discovered my affection for caffeine, I raced (Supermarket Sweep-style) to the coffee section. When I saw all the different whole bean blends, I decided to go with a medley: Ethiopian, Vanilla Creme, House Blend, Hazelnut, Chocolate Raspberry, Colombian, Kenyan. I ground my selection in the machine and will report more on this decision tomorrow morning. 

To finish off my shopping, I went to the "10 items or less" line and read the tabloid headlines while I waited, "Elvis is Alive and Pretending to be an Elvis Impersonator in Henderson, Nevada!" How very meta.

I've been bringing Giles, my little dogman, to Seger since I got him last June. Aside from being the most convenient/closest dog park, it's great in that there's an even distribution between mulch and rocks. 

See, the thing is, after every visit to the glorified, however less-convenient Schuylkill River park, I find my tissues filled with gross black stuff. Relax, it's from all the dust (it's an all-rock dog park). So, as you can imagine, I'm a fan of Seger because I'm sure to come away with clean tissues after every experience. 

Just a warning for all the Seger virgins, don't park your car alongside the park. The bike cops hide in corners all day waiting for their next victim. I think it's a pretty big ticket too. 

All in all, Seger is a great park with tons of regulars. In fact, you'll be able to find me there about twice a day. I have a 1-year-old vizsla named Giles. He's really friendly and so am I, so say hi!

Oh my god, you guys. Let me tell you what. I went to Carnivolution last night for the first time and wow. The first thing you'll notice when you get to 3819 Hamilton, is that you're on a residential street. Neighbors are walking their dogs, pushing babies in strollers, watering their front lawn - normal stuff. Then, you step into The Tiberino Museum's communal backyard that serves as the setting for the night's performances, and you feel like you're in Never Neverland with the Lost Boys. 

The back patio is a common space shared between the 4-5 houses that neighbor The Museum. The yard boasts a number of eccentric features: there's a tree house, and even a crow's nest attached to a different tree. For those who don't know what a crow's nest is, it's the structure at the top of a ship's mainmast that serves as a viewing point. In another part of the yard you can sit your butt on a log. There's a few logs, so bring friends. If you get hungry, help yourself to the mulberries. They're delicious, but apparently not a hit with the residents (they're always falling and leaving a mess on the ground). 

The crowd you're bound to meet is diverse, and by diverse, I mean, "an old wooden ship used in the Civil War era." Anchorman, anyone? I digress...

You've got your new age hippies, your West Philly undergrads/grads, your West Philly we-don't-shave-our-armpits-or-legs kinda girls (one even ate a dirty burrito off the floor), your 19/20-year-old kids with backpacks full of PBR, and then your confused guy/girl who stumbled into the wrong (right?) party. 

The sideshow itself featured your standard array of the grotesque and painful. Some guy laid on a bed of nails, then had another bed of nails rest on his chest while a character named Betty Bloomerz put an anvil over the second nail bed; Betty ate fire, then blew it out of her mouth; the host drilled a hole through his nose; a fat guy (wearing a Mexican wrestler mask) got completely naked and drank a glass full of hot sauce; his female partner also got completely naked and revealed piercings in places I could've gone without seeing.

While I might not go running back to Carnivolution, it is, HANDS DOWN, the most unique experience I've ever had in Philly.

When I'm in the right mood (by myself, driving around on an early Sunday morning, listening to XPN's Sleepy Hollow), there's no place I'd rather be than Mugshots in Fairmount. The busy but quaint ambiance sets it apart from most other coffeeshops in the city. Green Line on Baltimore arguably offers a similar vibe. I think it's something about being a nice-sized, corner coffeeshop in a greenspace neighborhood.

The food misses though. One of my favorite things is a bacon, egg, and cheese with a tomato slice on a slightly toasted English muffin. They don't have English muffins, so that's the first minus and their eggs are often scrambled and flavorless. Their saving grace is the Jailhouse Rock. Fresh, organic peanut butter spread over multigrain toast with banana slices and drizzled honey. Nothing beats that. 

If I want to hang out by myself, read a book or the paper to the slight bustle of a coffeeshop, Mugshots is a choice spot.

Coming from Miami, I often find myself craving some serious Latin food. I'm talking palomilla with arroz y frijoles, maduros, cafe con leche, yuca, mojitos, ropa vieja, arroz con pollo...where to go in these fair parts? Mixto. 

It's also a great spot for brunch when other weekend heavy weights (Morning Glory, Sabrina's, Honey's) offer too long a wait - you'll likely be seated right away. Expect the standard late-morning options with ethnic flair.

If the robust menu overwhelms you with indecision, go with the Gallo Pinto: eggs, steak, rice, black beans, sweet plantains, fried cheese, and avocado. When you can't pick just one, have it all. Freshly squeezed OJ by itself or in a mimosa and attentive waitstaff with a cute accento. Just don't order the vegetarian frittata - blah blah bland.

The morning after can go one of two ways: 

1) I'm looking to pow-wow with friends at a long, drawn out brunch reviewing the night's transgressions. 

-or-

2) I wouldn't know because I'm buried in the haze of a hangover and looking to shove a cream cheese loaded everything bagel down my throat. 

When it's the latter, South Street Bagels is where I go.

I am obsessed with burgers. In fact, I'm defrosting one right now so I can eat it for lunch. After hearing all the commotion about Sketch, I decided I had to try one on for size. I wanted to start out simple, so I said, "just a cheeseburger with sauteed onions, lettuce, and tomato." 20 minutes later, I'm racing home, burger aromas overwhelming my car, Giles in the backseat threatening to steal my meat with one swift move...we arrive. Up the stairs, I hit the living room and unwrap my burger. Mushrooms ooze out the sides, bacon sticks out at all ends, bleu cheese encrusts the top of my meat, sauteed onions...

Let's just say this wasn't the burger I ordered, but it's probably best that it came home with me. Clearly, the actual owner of my mistake-burger was on mission: death by burger. I attempted to eat it, but found it nearly impossible to take a satisfactory bite. I could only fit half the thing in my mouth. 

For those of you who prefer size to compactness, this might be the place for you. I prefer the burger and toppings to be tightly hugged by the bread. Think: 5 Guys, In n Out, Shake Shack type places. 

I'm not knocking the mistake they made by giving me the wrong burger, I'm just saying their burger-style isn't my cup o'tea. Still, I'm willing to give it another try.

I pretty much go to Apothecary to remind myself that there are people in Philadelphia who are quirkier than I am. In fact, I go to Apothecary to hang out with them because being around them makes me feel at home. 

When you first look around the bar, you might be overwhelmed with all the foreign looking bottles (no Grey Goose?! gasp). Do not be alarmed, my little cheese, the bartenders at APO know how to cater to even the most *unexperimental of palettes. **The Booty Collins was my favorite cocktail, as it was said to produce euphoric (read: aphrodisiac) sensations.

If you take a date there, get him/her boozed up downstairs, then head upstairs to the rooftop lounge...that is after the Booty Collins, of course.

*I'm told this isn't a word...whhhhhy?
**It was pulled off the menu BUT I'm told it will make a reappearance in the next menu printing

If you're a fan of real Belgian beer (Blue Moon devotees, beware!), then Monk's might just be your new favorite watering hole. Boasting one of the best all-around beer menus on the Eastern Seaboard (familiarly referred to as the "Bible"), Monk's is a Philadelphia mainstay and a late-night oasis, known for a rare pairing of great beer and great food.  

A welcome departure from its greasy neighbors (think: Little Pete's), Monk's offers a refreshingly un-barlike menu until 1am every night.  Try the house special mussels (there are quite a few styles, each named after a Belgian city -- I recommend the "Ghent" mussels, which come in a beer-based sauce flavored with bacon, leeks, and blue cheese), or the braised veal cheeks.  If you're craving a more traditional midnight snack, order a burger with fries-- better than most burgers around town!  

Any way you go, Monk's promises to satisfy the palette and the gullet.  If you can deal with a moderate wait and a crowd, then check out this bar as soon as you can.

If I hadn't gone to Copa last night at 11pm, I never would have met Silk, the man who would later instruct my friend on how to pick up women.

Ferry (my friend), Giles (my dog), and I sat down to enjoy an impromptu margarita and fajita salad. Just as Ferry is talking about how effective Giles is when it comes to picking up women, our cute waitress (Sarah) walks over and starts gushing over his doggish good looks. She scratches his belly, he gives her his paw and kisses, and just when she's already impressing the hell out of us, she asks for his name.

Me: Giles
Sarah: Giles! From Buffy?!

Ferry and I are both visibly giddy. Another Buffy fan lives among us! She leaves our table and I start chatting up the two guys at the table next to ours. 

Me (looking at Giles): Don't mind him, he's really friendly
Guy 1: Oh, no bother. I have an Italian Mastiff. 
Guy 2: Yeah, his dog had me pinned up against a wall. 
Guy 1 (hollering at a group of girls): Hey, how you doin? (One girl turns around) I see you looking, that's alright, you can look.
Me: Do you really think that works? 
Guy 1: You just gotta have confidence, girls love confidence. 
Me: How do you think my friend Ferry can pick up the waitress?
Guy 1: Just say "I like you" 
Ferry furrows his brow in panic. 
Me: I like you? That takes courage...something easier
Guy 1: Just compliment her on something...(Sarah, our waitress, walks back out just as he's talking). 

Sarah: Hey guys can I get you anything else?
Guy 1: Ferry and I were just talking about your hair. He was saying a lot of girls can't pull off that hair style and you work it really well.

Sarah, blushing and clearly excited, moves to our table and makes a b-line for Ferry.

Me to Guy 1: Whoa, that was money!
Guy 2: Yoooo dude! That was smoooooth. I'm gonna call you Silk from now on!

As it turns out Ferry and Sarah end up exchanging geek comic book talk and other nerd code; it's clear they'd have a lot to talk about. Did he get her number? No...but here's why: an epic ending to an already memorable experience...the firefighters crowed the street and blocked  it off due to an electrical fire a few doors down, so we were forced to leave. Nevertheless, we found out she works on Friday nights.

Silk (hollering at another group of ladies): Excuse me, Ms. (one girl turns around). I like you. (She smiles). You have a beautiful smile.

As for Silk, he and I exchanged numbers and promised to reconvene at Copa soon enough. His farewell text? "We'll hang soon. Long live KING FERRY." Turns out he's a minister. Good things happen with the right combination of strangers, margaritas, and a good server. Well done, Copa.

Ok, if you can't afford a trip to Epcot Center to experience the "It's a Small World After All" ride, you can go to Wasabi House and enjoy the same kind of multi-cultural character. A Jesus crucifixion scene adorns one wall, a cat clock with the Star of David on it's belly on the wall across from Jesus, and then there's the sushi clock to keep things in perspective. Oh and there's an old photo of a few sheep for sale. It's 95 dollars. 

It looks like someone decorated this place with last week's yard sale.

The food was unmemorable. Our spicy tuna/salmon rolls were drowned in spicy sauce and the mochi green tea ice cream underwent petrification before arriving at our table. 

It would've been 2 stars, but here's 3 because the waiter wore a diamond studded marijuana leaf earring.

If you have impeccable taste in music, you were with me at Kung Fu Necktie on Friday night to see Land of Talk. I was visibly giddy. It's like, totally, oh my god, my favorite band, of like all time. And to be able to see my them in one of my favorite bars, that was all the better. 

My friend and I started with a big can of Old Speckled Hen. Then, we moved onto the Foster's keg-can and shimmied our way towards the front of the room, standing right below Elizabeth Powell (lead singer) and her man-mates. 

The thing that's so awesome about seeing your favorite band play at KFN is the intimacy of the show experience. Things got off to a good and rowdy start when two dudes (clearly not okay with intimacy) decided to brawl just as the band strung its first few chords. My friend jumped on stage to avoid getting hit and after a sock to the nose, the dudes were ejected with great fanfare. On with the show, we cheered.

And so it was, best show of my life (I'm not even exaggerating) in a super awesome venue. I'd be damned lucky if I get to ever see them again in such a cozy venue.

This can be our secret, but Copa makes my favorite margaritas in town. Fine, you don't go there for the ambiance, but if you're going for margs, this is the spot. Different than Cantina 'ritas in that they're not as sweet and twice as strong. Also, the regular, non-flavored route is the way to go.

I drank a double marg at 3pm and I didn't sober up until 10pm. Yeah, I really like them.

If you're lucky enough to shop at Sugarcube when owners, Eliza or Edward happen to be in, you're in luck. You can't help but be attracted to their energy. Theirs is the kind of friendly face you need on those less than extraordinary days. 

I'm so used to going into boutiques where the sales staff makes you feel like you're back in middle school, sitting by yourself at the lunch table and feeling generally ugly. Sugarcube isn't that kind of boutique... and thank god for that because their clothes are right on par with my taste.  

I'm the kind of woman (am I already a woman?) who wishes men's clothing was made for us ladies. Is that wrong? Either way, Sugarcube caters to this sentiment and hosts a wide array of androgynous (for lack of a better word) clothing. In addition to the fine ladies wear, they've got fedoras and ties and jewelry and even something for the men. Actually, there's a ton of men's clothes. Go check this place out.

A delicious little Parisian café with all the traditional trimmings. Eye opening espressos, belly satisfying crepes, and a darling Frenchman to serve you. 

Great spot to do some reading or tap away on your laptop. Reminds me of La Colombe with quality beans and that charming feel. With a location around 16th and South, you can be sure that this place isn't fraught with people and thus, a perfect spot to spend some alone time.

My Thursday nights could use some variety. After spending most of them within the dragtastic confines of Bob and Barbara's, I decided a visit to Tritone was necessary. 

Any place that serves fried Snickers covered with all the sundae gunk toppings deserves my nod of approval. $3 Citywide specials, yet another plus. Friends, after too many PBRs though, the stuff tastes awful. So spend 5 bucks and grab a Sierra, because thankfully, they have it. I have to cut them a star though because Heaven Hill over Jim Beam isn't the way our city would want it. Is it just me or does this place remind you of CBGBs?

If you thought The Franklin gave you lascivious thoughts, prepare yourself for The Ranstead Room, possibly better dubbed, The Randy Room. The walls look like their covered in fishnet stockings, the three paintings of nude women elicit that simple sense of carnal desire, and the intimacy of the room suggests an orgy is but a few drinks away. 

Snogging aside, Starr brought in the top players to guide the aesthetic and cocktails. Shawn Hausman (conceptual designer of The Standard and Starr's other properties) sets the mood just so, as he did with El Rey. Entrance to The Room is through a dark and dripping alley, but once the doors open, you'll feel transported into someone's seductive digs. 

Sasha Petraske (of NYC's Milk and Honey and Little Branch) created a simple but satisfying cocktail menu employing the necessary pillars of hand-crafted libations: fresh juice, fresh herbs, assorted bitters, and quality spirits.

If you're a cocktail connoisseur, the menu won't impress you; it's not nearly as developed as The Franklin's, but if you're looking for something approachable while still feeling swank, it should do the trick. They also serve vodka, so yeah, not -really- keeping with the speakeasy code. You'll be pleased by the pumpkin seeds over the usual bar nuts and the abbreviated food menu hosts items from the adjoining restaurant, El Rey. Order the gorditas! 

Well done, Starr, on your secret-not-so-secret slinky saloon.

Whoever said, "nothing good comes for free" has never "frolfed," or frisbee golfed. It's the best thing I've ever used my free money on. By writing this review, I'm disregarding my friend's wishes. "Whatever you do, don't tell Yelp about this!" they pleaded. They don't want everyone to find out about this local treasure.

Regardless, I'm about to let everyone in on a secret. If you haven't ever gone to Sedgely Woods for an afternoon of frolf, you're missing out on the most amazing experience. 

There are 18 holes and each person launches their frisbee from a starting point towards the hole. I can't throw a frisbee well, but after the first few holes, you pick up different throwing techniques. Hole 11 is where the fun starts because from that point on, you're in the middle of the woods, often at the top of a steep drop where you're hurling your frisbee into the gigantic tree abyss below you. THEN, you run into the forest to retrieve your frisbee (how we managed to find it, I have no idea) and launch it once again towards the hole. From starting point to hole, there can be close to 300 yards distance! That's like 8 football fields! 

The regulars are really friendly and can help you along the way if you need it. You can buy or borrow frisbees once you get there, but make sure to take a few with you because you'll probably lose one to the woods.

As always, make sure you bring beer, water, and mosquito repellent.

*You never really know someone until you run into them at a gay bar and they're dressed in red mini-shorts and prancing around like a little lollipop boy. 

After the less than stellar dance party at The Barbary last Saturday, I called up some friends to see what the next best option was. Well wouldn't you know it, The Bike Stop was bumping. Really? The Bike Stop? 

So the party was called Finger Banging (don't ask, I don't know, but I'm sure it's awful) and even though the memories from that night are a bit fuzzy, I remember inflatable palm trees flying across the dance floor, headbanging and singing at the top of my lungs (with everyone) when Hole's Celebrity Skin came on, and drinking beers with the gusto of a fiend out of rehab. 

All in all, it was a good night. **Now where are my panties?

*True story
**Thanks, I found them

This place deserves 5 stars for their sales alone. Never mind the vast expanse of regularly priced chic togs, sure to have Mary Kate and Ashley nodding their heads (simultaneously, like the twin-mutants they are) in approval, this store has unreal sale racks! 

My friend made away with a $20 pair of small-label designer jeans and I lucked out with an excellent shirt for $10 (originally priced at $55). I also bought a cute pair of shorts for almost full price, but even those were slightly discounted. 

This is one of my favorite stores around. Even though it's a boutique, it's got less of that "sales girl gone wild who wants to dissect every outfit you try on and tell you where it does and doesn't look great" feel, and more of the "help yourself to our stuff and let us know if you need assistance, otherwise we'll be here to ring you up when you're ready" vibe. Love it!

Oh and I got a free eco-friendly tote bag on top of my purchase.

Everything here is as it would have appeared in centuries past without one anachronism pointing to the current age. The staff's old timey attire, the artistry of old advertisements that decorate the walls, the homemade ice cream, the throwback soda fountain, even the milk dispenser looks like something found in a cafeteria of years past. 

A long list of simple and intriguing flavors offered. The Teaberry tastes like Pepto Bismol at first but then suddenly it turns into heaven wrapped in a blanket. My favorite touch might be their version of a "cup:" it's a small Chinese take-out carton. One scoop and it's filled to the brim, topped with my favorite: whipped cream and rainbow sprinkles.

They say you know it when you see it. Talent that is. 

When melted cheese and succulent bacon covers and smothers your delicately rugged, hand-cut french fries, this, my friends, is french fry nirvana...and way all pommes frites were meant to live and die. 

Finally, to be prepared within 8 minutes of you ordering it...that's talent. Respek.

They've been open for a month or so and already, this place is awesome. I tried them out for lunch today and left completely full and satisfied. 

I went with the BBQ half chicken and Jill A is totally right, that sauce is finger licking good. So good I even licked my friend's fingers. Then I poured it all over him and-

The beef brisket is awesome. Tender, meaty, topped off with what I think is just the jus. Each of these big platters comes with 2 sides and they offer a great selection of standard classics to chose from (mac&cheese, potatoes made sideways and every other way, veggies). 

The only thing I'd say I wasn't overly impressed with was the cocktail menu. What's missing? Two obviously southern-style drinks come to mind: a Mint Julep and a Sweet Tea cocktail (those are so popular now). Looks like they have a pretty awesome beer selection though.

Finished off the lunch gorgefest with a warm blueberry bread pudding. Sweet baby jesus, that thing was awe inspiring and left me wishing I had enough room in my stomach to finish it.

With so much to choose from on the menu, you'll need to make a quick return visit to sample the rest of their goods.

If I see you shopping at Foster's, I can deduce a few things about you. 

You love design, you offer guests bathroom reading material, you love Chilewich rugs, you throw dinner parties and appreciate fun salad tongs, your salt and pepper shakers are little ceramic characters that hug each other, you put your organic fruit in an oversized but tasteful crystal bowl, you like when guests ask if they should remove their shoes when they enter your house, you appreciate minimalist decor, you special ordered the birds on a wire wall decal and all your friends ask if it's hand painted, your wine glasses don't have stems, you own a cocktail shaker, the list goes on folks.

What I'm trying to say is this people: if you're looking to impress your friends with your taste, buy them a present here.

Every time I step into Foster's I think on an old proverb: "if a tree falls in the forest and crushes a woman...why is there a forest in the kitchen?"

Last time I was here was to see The Bird and The Bee (best duo ever). In the past, I've never been able to enjoy a show here because I've been towards the back of the room or someone's spilled an entire beer on me or I lost a shoe. So there I was, woe-is-me-style when I saw TBATB was playing at North Star. "I'm never going to enjoy it," thought I to myself. Either succumb to defeat or devise a plan. I felt like a champion on that particular day, so I went with the latter.

I got to the show early. Well, early enough. My friends and I squeezed our way towards the front and had an awesome time. Inara George (lead singer of TBATB) is mesmerizing. If you have a chance to see her, please go. So, what have we learned? If you really care about the performer, get to shows early so you have a good view. Sure, this goes for any venue, but North Star is a stand out in the awkward room category. If you can work out the early arrival, you're in for a treat.

The seats creak because they're old, the screen is diminutive in comparison to what you're used to, and the walls and floor are mucky. 

Nevertheless, I have a great date idea. 

If you're with someone who appreciates grit and novelty, here's what I suggest:

1. Blindfold him/her, take a walk to the beer shop on 21st and Chestnut; look both ways before you cross the street.

2. Open a fridge and have your date blind-pick a 40oz. 

3. Walk over to the Roxy for your movie (bring a satchel to hide your booze).

4. Maybe unblindfold your date once you've entered the theater; keeping the blindfold on might defeat the purpose of enjoying a movie.

5. They'll probably think your quirky spontaneity is really cute and say something like, "wow, you're so Michael Cera or Ellen Page."

6. After the movie, maybe you'll be drunk and have a guitar and sit on a stoop while performing a duet to Kimya Dawson's "Anyone Else But You."

An instructional on how to play disc golf really well.

Hole 1: Fling your disc directly into the back of Silvie's head but pretend you didn't mean it. You obviously didn't. Silvie will trip a little and pretend it doesn't hurt. It does hurt, but pain is good. We grow from pain. Lesson one of disc golf.

Hole 2: Dan launches his disc in the most perfectly angled manner and it lands 10 feet from the hole. He pumps his fist with purpose, grunts "yeah," then races off to finish his quick victory. No one likes a meathead. Don't be an outcast.

Hole 3: Silvie gets angry and throws her disc in the woods. She lights a cigarette, puts it out and scarfs a bag of "granola." Make sure the food you eat is food you prepared. Unless of course you're homeless and hungry, in which case eat whatever you can.

Hole 4: Mutton Chop's airborne torpedo whizzes by Linda's face and nearly wipes her eyebrows off. She submits and digs for her 40. Always bring beer, you never know what'll get you down.

Hole 5: Afro Sprout tosses her disc underhand. It's airborne for .0000002 seconds. Bringing along a less than stellar player by which to judge your substandard performance is advisable. 

Hole 6: It seems you've miraculously gotten the disc within scoring distance in just one throw. That's really well done. You deserve a drink. In fact, several. Bartender, make it one for my friend and one for me. 

Hole 7: Aren't the woods beautiful? Yeah, for rapists. Wear bright clothes that contrast with the trees. Neons work well. 

Hole 8: Brauny expends all his flaming man-power and the disc soars out of the woods and into the parking lot. You don't have to be straight to love disc golf. 

Hole 9: You're thirsty for beer. Take a 20 minute recess to go buy it. No one judges you in disc golf.

Hole 10-14: Silvie's been missing since hole 3. She turns up for a minute, half naked wearing a bloody fox, then slips again into the forest. Linda's disc lands in a bird's nest. Oh wait, that's Silve's hair. Disc golf is like interpretive dance. Make it your own. 

Hole 15: You're getting so good you throw 2 discs at the same time. Double hole in one. Well done, you.

Hole 16&17: Ask for the Coviello cookie special. Thank me later.

Hole 18: Wow, you've really made it. Congratulations. The sun's probably setting and the trees sway with desire. Go ahead, give it one last go. Hole in one like it's your birthday.

I spent many months hating my iPhone. Hating the fact that I'd given into their marketing and joined the Apple toting masses. Today, however, everything changed. I decided I'd try using my phone intelligencia to locate some Yelp advertised "sales and special offers." It GPSed my location and told me Sailor Jerry was offering 50% off most merchandise. 

So, I dragged my mom and brother, on Black Friday, to the store. What did we find? Tons of stuff...50% off as promised. I made away with a few gifts and now every time I look at my phone, I think about all the precious dollars it's trying to save me. My phone cares and so does Sailor Jerry. Unlike most of the other Center City stores we checked out, Sailor Jerry understands the concept behind Black Friday. Most other stores were just trying to give me 10% off cashmere. Really? No thanks, I don't care about cashmere when it's only 10% off.

I wandered in to the Rocket Cat Cafe on Saturday after checking out the kinetic bike derby. Fishtown/Kensington has such underrated charm, I kicked myself for having overlooked it in my recent search for a new place to live. Alas, I stepped in to find a large open, sunlit room with people seated throughout. I completely forgot I was in Philly. It's a coffeeshop you'd more likely find in Portland or Seattle. 

My iced chai latte was only ok, but the ambiance compensated for the latte's lack of awesomeness. I'm going to make more excuses to go to RCC. Oh! And apparently free wireless?!

I've grown up eating Spanish food and my expectations have been marked by my dad's cooking: he's from Spain and was also a tapas chef. I knew Bar Ferdinand wouldn't disappoint, but I certainly didn't expect them to measure up to my pops. Thankfully, I've found a home away from home.  

I wasn't ready to splurge, so I stuck to my favorites: patatas bravas (similar to home fries, but topped with aioli), carne a la parilla, the short rib (I don't remember the fancy name) and churros con chocolate. Everything was perfectly cooked and perfectly balanced. Nothing was too salty or sweet and the flavors popped as they should.

In an effort to stay within budget, I asked the waiter to recommend one of the $8 wines. He suggested the tempranillo/merlot blend. One of my favorites so far. 

The ambiance can't be beat either. They have mosaics with bulls and I have an obsession with the phrase: el toro heroico (the heroic bull), I feel like it conveys the perfect image and paradox. Anyway, that's neither here nor there. 

All in all, last night's meal came as an unexpected surprise and will lead me back for many moons to come.

Let me tell you what, VIP is -it- when it comes to mochi ice cream. Did I not run in hair rollers and a robe to Whole Foods last night in order to make it minutes before close to buy mochi ice cream? Did Whole Food -not- deliver? Yes, no mochi. 

Because I don't live within walking distance of Trader Joe's, there's literally nowhere for me to find mochi ice cream.  Whilst in Miami, I even paid $10 for a pack of 8 (or 10?) at the corporate eco-friendly-organic megaplex (Whole Foods). Obscene! 

Now that I've been drinking and feeling careless with my words, I'm willing to say that the mochi god (God) shines all his mighty light upon the venerable VIP Food & Produce. I have no idea what Very Important People have to do with Food & Produce, but this place is delivering way more than it promises. Perhaps VIP stands for Very Important Products...mochi ice cream sells for a mere $4. Go buy it, but if you see there's only one box left, I call dibs.

A very special person, let's just call her close to my heart, and I ventured through my old Philly roots. Familiar smells and sights with a few newly established and welcoming respites received our eager to be used wallets. We dined and drank til our innards simply could no more, and I finally exclaimed, "a trip to Philly isn't complete without a sprint up the Rocky steps."

She, ever the photographing adventurer, found this to be the perfect opportunity to pose in her finest atop the most panoramic pitstop fit for any tourist. 

But then, walking along 13th Street, a once familiar watering hole looked a lot different. The giant antlers visible through the large open windows compelled me to investigate and upon first glace, a New American menu greeted my now California palette. Honestly, we weren't hungry and with a few hours to kill before flying off, a mimosa was in order. 

So we sat at the small bar and looked on as Sonnet shook tins with powerful grace like the delicate Albuquerque flower she is. We chatted and learned of the staff's secret code (a serving of bacon from the open kitchen receives a bloody mary; a murmur of the words, "liquid gold" gets a sip -- and only a sip -- of Sonnet's morning pressed orange juice). 

Then, after a few drinks (the first mimosa was free thanks to their brunch promotion), we ordered Sonnet's suggested crab cake eggs benedict. Perfect and portioned, the single serving was just the perfect morsel to tide us over. Despite Apothecary no longer living within these walls, the amiable staff and food menu are an absolute divine reincarnation of what this place once was. Still serving expertly artisan food and drink, with an impeccable eye for design, I hope The Corner stays put.

Tritone's the kinda place you go to when you're looking to feel like you haven't spent any money (stuff here's -the- cheap) and it'll leave you wondering how you ended up naked in the corner grinding up against strangers but it doesn't matter because no one's looking, no one's judging, and those two straight boys are making out anyway. 

It's like a more spacious Bob and Barbara's without the Ivy Leaguers and drag queens. Just pick the right night (when there's a good show) and go. There's lots to dance, love, and sing to at Tritone, so you'll be living proof that Mark Twain was onto something when he said, "Dance like you're Boy George on fire; love like it's the apocalypse, and sing like the hills are alive."

Stir wins for being my favorite overall bar in Rittenhouse, not to mention my favorite gay bar in all of Philly. The crowd is always relatively mixed, but the gay men typically outdo the everything else category. Men, women, gay, straight, bi...they're all there though, so don't worry. Located in an alley coated with restaurant kitchen grease, you'd probably not expect much, but prepare to be impressed, the interior is swank, clean, and respectable. 

For those of you on the prowl, who think Woody's/Bump/Pure/Sisters is too obvious, check out Stir. Chances are there's someone there just like you who's classier, more city savvy, and less cheesy than the rest of them. I can't promise you won't find the meth-heads gunning for a hotel room orgy, but I can say that by taking the Stir detour, you're on the road less traveled and Robert Frost would be proud.

You know those days when you randomly decide to shop, and all the stars to align in your favor and present you with "must haves?" That was my afternoon. I had major success at Arcadia Boutique (review to follow) and Fabric Horse. 

High on my spending spree, I decided to allow Print Liberation to offer up the finishing touches to my shopping mania.

Attention: Print Liberation makes silk screened t-shirts with random, meaningless words printed on them. [Insert: oh, ah here]. If you shop here, you inherently have a hipster sensibility.
