To the best of my knowledge, this corner beer spot had the moniker bestowed upon it as a result of the previous owners being former police officers. This was all before my time but that's the version I've heard batted around the most. Good ol' local Philly lore.

What can I say? It's a corner store that's open till 2:00am with beer and an assortment of other necessities. Snacks, drinks, few canned goods. Just about every trip I've made has been completely uneventful (except being able to holler "hello" to John, the clerk). There's something to be said for consistency, advantage Town Food Market. As far are convenience stores go, it's open later than most others in the area so it's a clutch player.

The in-store ATM does come with a wallet lightening $2.50 fee but insomniacs & drunks can't be choosers.

Giles (my dog) has been going to Central Bark for 8 months now. I drop him off early in the morning (around 8) and pick him up anywhere between 4:30 and 6. Without fail, he's always completely exhausted by pick-up time. It's a real feat too; Giles is only a year old and he's a vizsla (if you know anything about this breed, you'll understand).

The staff is friendly and incredibly easy to work with. I never have to call in advance to make a reservation and they even offer the dogs lunch (if you provide the food). The facilities are kind of a stretch to get to (29th and McKean), but I haven't been able to find anything better closer. I've never had an issue with this place and it provides great peace of mind knowing my dog's out of my hair and in good care. 

Know before you go:
bring a snap collar if you have one (if not, they'll loan you one for the day)
bring your dog's lunch if you want him/her to eat 
It's $26 for the day and they offer a 10-pack for a discounted price.

The best part about losing your wallet is nothing. There's nothing good. It means pet peeve phone calls to Bank of America, PNC, Amex, Vicky's Secret, etc. That's what my morning consisted of. Because I was silly enough to put my wallet in my back pocket, it fell out or someone swiped it. 

Nevertheless, I went to this particular PNC, showed them my passport and walked out with a chunk of change. Watch out cause I'll be throwing up the huuuuuunnnnnnnnnneds. Huneds.

Sometimes I wonder what goes through women's minds when they reach out and grab other women's boobs, often when the other women are strangers. This is the first thought that came to me while waiting in line for the Victoria's Secret dressing (or undressing) room. 

I watched as one woman, in her respective room, publicly angled herself to introduce her boobs to the mirror. She bent over, so as to see how the bra dealt with gravity, she lifted her arms up, so as to see how the bra handled bounciness, and then she asked another woman in line for her thoughts.

"Do you think I need a larger size?" Her voice picks up, "I just got them done and this is my first trip bra shopping!"

The other girl, maybe in her mid-thirties gushes, "Oh my god! I've been wanting to get mine done too," she glances down giving her boobs a punishing scowl. "Can I feel them?"

"Of course!!!" 

As I stand there, trying not to look, they notice my boobs. I give them a smile and a nod, in a please don't engage me kinda way. But they do. They engage me.

"Are yours real?!" 
"Yup" I look down, "real."
"Oh my god! Can I feel them to compare?"

I buckled and ultimately agreed. I stretched out my arms like I was being patted down by security and looked away as the pawing ensued. 

When it was over, they insisted I feel the fake boobs. So I did until it was finally agreed, mine felt the best. 

I just couldn't buy a bra after that.

This morning offered some awesome news: I am a complete champion. I got a wisdom tooth pulled out at 9am with the aid of Novocaine. No laughing gas, no painkillers, just straight up tooth plucking.

I was a little skeptical when I called asking for directions and Dr. Halpern himself answered the phone. Then, I walked into the 4th floor suite to find he shares an office space with an optometrist. Weird thing #2. Lastly, his office decor reminded me of the doctor's office in Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. Muted beige colors abound with no real aesthetic clue pointing to the fact that we're in the year 2009.

Dr. Halpern is incredibly personable though, and he went over the procedure thoroughly and gave me a chance to ask questions. I really appreciated his confidence in his skill. He promised I wouldn't have chipmunk cheeks and the pain would be minimal. I was in an out of there within 30 minutes and things went as he said they would. His secretary was out, so he did all the billing himself...he even entered my information in the computer. Finally he gave me a sheet to take home with care instructions. I should be all healed in no time and if I have any concerns, Dr. Halpern's cell number is on the bottom of the sheet. He's now my new dentist. If you want to "go under" or have a hankering for a painkiller scipt, Dr. Halpern isn't your man. Painless procedure though.

All you need at 3 in the morning after dancing and drinking for hours is creamed chipped beef and a santa fe omelet. If my blurry vision didn't deceive me, I'm pretty sure the sign said this place is open until 5am. Nolibs has been starved for a clean, late night diner option...not to mention it's within stumbling distance of your last call location.

The lights were a little too bright though...

One thing I'm sure to miss when I'm away from Philly long enough is my banana/chocolate Bonte waffle. For those of you reading this review wondering, "what's a Bonte waffle?" You're way late in the game. Simply put, it's a warm, chewy goodie served with your choice of filling (bananas and chocolate) and comes sprinkled with small sugar crystals.  

Bonte's disguised as a coffee shop, but anyone who says they're just going for the coffee is just looking for an excuse to succumb to the waffle. Since each waffle is made to order, you'll likely wait a good 8-15 minutes, maybe even 20 if there's a line. That's the only downside. Upside is you can grab the Citypaper or PW to pass the time.

Hold the phone! Union Trust is offering a $7.17 lunch menu!! While I had trouble choosing between the three options: Duck salad tossed with cranberries and candied walnuts, fish and chips, and the Kobe beef burger, I ultimately caved into my beef calling. Delicious brioche bun, perfectly seasoned meat topped with melted American cheese. Simple but awesome.

To think you can now experience UT without have to dive deep into your wallet. Wonder if Tommy Up's going to pull another receipt stunt.

Ok, clearly I'm not the first person to feel this way. Mad Mex food and Mad Mex cocktails warrant two separate reviews. 

If you order the Big Azz frozen strawberry margarita, you're in for a treat; there are real strawberries in there...ish is tasty. 4 stars.

If you order the food, you're in for it. Blah blah bland. 2 stars.

To compensate for my lackluster meal, my date devised distractions to keep me from whining over my food. So we played seven minutes in heaven in our booth. 7 stars, 1 per minute.

To properly celebrate my 300th review
Off I went to Olde City Tattoo
Clean and friendly
Quick and gently
I have something I'll never show you.

It's been so long since I last wandered into Avril 50. Years ago, when I was a regular, Jonathan, the owner, used to hook me up with fancy cloves. The thought of smoking cloves now gives me a stomach ache. Either way, if I couldn't get to the store before closing time, I'd ring him up and he'd hide a pack in the bushes for me. If that's not service, I don't know what is. 

The store is no different today than it was years ago, and Jonathan still maintains that foreign charm of his. His little shop is a European beatnik's refuge. I mean, you don't have to be European to be in his store, but if you have a foreign sensibility, you'll feel right at home. 

You can find everything from coffee to chocolate you've never seen before, international fashion magazines and communist press. Even though it's a pint-sized shop, you can get lost in there for hours.

I have a Northern Liberties food formula: Honey's for brunch. N 3rd for dinner. With a varied menu (fish tacos, hummus, salads, dumplings, and nightly specials), N 3rd takes a step up from traditional pub/bar fare and offers enough creativity to satisfy the foodiest of foodies, but enough simplicity to appease even the picky eaters. 

Their cocktails are pretty stellar too and the beer list boasts all the local favorites plus other microbrew staples. With the giant projector in the backroom, this place is going to be my post-season spot.

I don't want to start this review off on the wrong foot, but I broke my ankle last night (heh, see what I did there). Anyway, reviewing a hospital is much like reviewing an airport or the PPA, you don't want to be there, you don't want to be at their mercy, but there you are, crippled, moaning, and dreaming about Puerto Rican sunsets and piña coladas.  

The waiting room wait was a short one and once my friends and I were led to my hospital bed, we were awarded with the company of quick-witted male nurses and a female doctor who realized she knew my name because she now lives in my old house (and still gets my mail). Everyone was jovial and pleasant to say the least.

After about 2 hours of being there, I had my x-rays, I got splinted up in this fancy fiberglass, and prescribed a bottle of painkillers. 

If I could yelp about my friends, they'd certainly warrant a 5-star write up. They all sat in the waiting room with me, then next to me on the hospital bed, and later drove me to CVS for necessary pain-killers. These are some lady gemstones.

As for my broken ankle, well, that just sucks.

It's like my friends and I were cruising down a long desert road, kicking up dust with our Chevy tires, when we stumbled upon a crooked wooden sign reading "bar" pointing into the questionable, arid horizon. 

Walking into Baja Room was like walking into the vampire bar in the movie From Dusk Til Dawn. With the exception of the two diners in the patio area (where they allow dogs!), my two friends and I were the only living souls in the kitschy Mexican themed dining room. The owner who greeted us wore aviators and a Top Gun camo t-shirt. At any given moment, I expected him to go out back and return with a bevy of seductive vampire women. Instead, he bought over a complimentary vegetable appetizer and a bucket of peanuts. 

The menu was bizarre (cactus burger, mussels, french fries, lobster quesadillas, black bean succotash burrito) and the "specials" board had hamburger, cheeseburger, grilled chicken breast making the cut. 

We ordered the mussels (at a Mexican restaurant, really?); corn tamales topped with beans, cheese, and a heaping scoop of guacamole; and the World Series nachos. Unlike the Phils, everything won except the nachos (the ground sirloin lacked flavor and the spice caught us off guard). 

For our margarita pitcher, our server ran across the street (to Pico de Gallo) to fetch it. When we settled up and asked to take our margaritas to go, they gladly obliged and put it in a plastic container. 

This place is just so bizarre, I love it.

Even if you live nowhere near West Philly, Dock Street's worth checking out. Tucked away on the corner of 50th and Baltimore, this monstrosity of a building offers the yuppies of the now gentrified West Philly an oasis for freshly and finely brewed beers. The building's exterior looks like a bank turned brewery.

I'm a fan of the pilsner, and the pizza even lives up to its reputation. I only tried a slice of the plain, but the rest of the menu's offerings looked pretty appealing. The desserts, not quite as tempting and should I say, slightly boring.

It's great to sit outside and enjoy the soundtrack of kids playing in the park across the street. It's definitely one of the best spots for beer in the city, and being there makes you feel like you've discovered something no one else knows about...until you run into a fellow yelper.

There probably isn't one thing in 10th Street Hardware that appeals to me. Paint, keys, locks, cleaning products, hoses, wrenches. No thanks. I will say though, when I do need any of the aforementioned items, there's no other hardware store I prefer to shop at.

It would've been 5 stars if they had given me the correct paint both times I needed it. Instead, my newly painted wall dried in 2 different tones of grey.

Then again, it would've been 3 stars if Andy hadn't given me a gallon of the grey for free. 

As far as your neighborhood hardware store goes, this place is pretty great.

There's a warm, neighborhood vibe going on here. All the employees are exactly what you'd expect in Fishtown: locals with rough-around-the-edges, boisterous, but affable manners. I love it here. Sitting with friends, clinking pints underneath dimmed and flickering lights, we rattled on about future plans and experiences yet to be had.

Our cherub, aka: waitress, offered up dishes she swore would "change our lives" and while I thought I'd never savor a tofu club, I found myself stealing bites off my friend's dish. That said, you should order the Smoked Coconut Club (it's as exotic and delicious as it sounds). My roast pork sammy was sloppy and savory, while my other friend's seitan steak was good, albeit a slight bit too salty. 

This place rules and they have Racer 5 on cask.

There's a lady in your life. She's your fashionable mother. She's your wife. She's your secretary. She's really special. She has amazing taste. Say what? You don't know what to get her this holiday season? 

Get to Head Start Shoes now! They're having a $50 off every pair of sale-shoes sale! I just bought a pair of Ixos (very imported and sexy) boots at a $150 discount. They're the dreamiest pair of foot protectors I've ever owned. 

Head Start carries a small inventory of boots, so after a purchase, you can rest assured that your fellow city-mates won't be toting your identical footwear...random compliments from strangers are bound to ensue. People will gawk. Just expect it. However, don't go here expecting Uggs.

The friends I once caroused with are now nesting. I'm not sure if it's the dropping temperatures or their new relationships that have their party panties all in a bunch, but either way, I'm not going down without a fight. Last weekend, I urged them to unlock the shackles while I squared away some solid dance floor plans. 

Low and behold, they were all in. We huddled up, headed out, and hustled from one bar to the next. Once 2am hit, the pack started diminishing. I, for one, wasn't about to end my night without the obligatory cheeseburger. Dancing is like exercise and they say you should always eat within 30 minutes after your work out, so I felt totally justified with my craving. 

My last two friends and I waited in a 15 minute line outside of Pete's until we were ushered in and escorted to our counterside stools. Our waitress was cheery and my burger was the best thing ever put between two buns that's ever been put into my mouth. I really liked their steak fries too. 

Bottom line: Go after 2am, observe the sloppy party kids, get the burger. Just a warning, this isn't actually a goooood burger, it's just a great burger after 2am. Ya dig?

I don't go dancing often these days, but when my favorite crew from the olden days gather, dancing is the most obvious choice. This weekend, after unsuccessfully attempting to cut a rug at a list of other 7th Ave bars, we made Honey Pot our last ditch effort. 

Cover was $5 and what we walked into could only be described as a dark, neon, drag queen's mecca. It had all the trimmings of a true nightclub (except this one had friendly bartenders!). A large stage throughout the middle of the dance floor went from hosting talented patrons to decked out drag queens (there was a performance after all) and nearby, go-go dancers took to the other elevated platforms throughout the dance floor. 

Genrerally, this isn't my kind of scene (pulsating EDM and all), but the people watching was excellent and everyone filled up their dance card in no time. Straight people, gay people, old but mostly young people packed the room. Only thinking we'd stay for 20 minutes, we ended up dancing until our feet gave out. Nicely done, Honey Pot.

They were open on Thanksgiving (which is when we all went) and the food was fine. Service was fine. Portions were large. Seafood was fresh. Interior is a little tacky (think: sponge painted cream colored walls and faux columns), but I was charmed when all the staff and family gathered to enjoy turkey and gravy once we paid the check. Good mom n pop spot.

In the summertime, when the weather is fine, you can stretch right up and touch the sky...da da da whatever. I find it difficult to spend my Honey's waiting list time at The Random Tea Room when it isn't cold. Hot day, hot tea? Eh, not so much. So instead, I offered up North Third.

The agreement was to sit at the bar and order a single cocktail, an appropriate, hair of the dog mimosa (or Bloody Mary, but those are gross). 

Instead, while we waited for our Honey's call time, we got drunk. The Blood Orange Margaritas were soooo good and perfectly balanced between tastiness and strength. By the time we finished our pitcher, we staggered over to Honey's, double hungover and halfway full. You win North Third, you win...for now.

Even though the first bite into my Maoz falafel-hummus sandwich was a bit negative (I was slightly on the meh side) I found that I devoured the entire pita contents (and the pita as well) leaving little carnage to clean up. So, something must have been good. Maybe it was the marinated carrot slices, or the cold chopped mushroom/corn salsa, or the fried broccoli and cauliflower toppings? 

Or maybe it had everything to do with the garlic-mayo I poured into my pita cup of goods. 

My Belgian pommes frites came out shortly after my sandwich and upon retrieving them, I noticed a promising pale red sauce in the toppings counter. Yes, it was ketchup-mayonnaise. 

For six dollars and change, I would highly consider this a viable lunch option. I also like how you can turn a completely healthy lunch into a vegetarian McDonald's bingefest. Even though it's got the "healthy vegetarian" vibe, it's easy to alter a conscious lunch into a fat-trap. Whatever calories I might have been saved by having a non-hamburger lunch was made up for with my mayo servings, rest assured (but rest satisfied).

And they're open until 3am on Fridays and Saturdays.

Let me preface by saying that I truly love Pumpkin Café and I go there all the time. I'm someone who really appreciates their local, farm fresh approach, but sadly everything changed today when I went in for my regular Café Salad with a chicken cutlet on top. 

Their menu was different and the problem? I'm a creature of habit. You mean no more salad with crumbled bleu cheese, topped with pumpkin seeds and fruit chunks? They still offer a Café Salad, but it's not the original and while it's okay, I'm not a huge fan of arugula and there was something heavenly about the old dressing no longer apparent in the new dressing. I've been torn from my comfort zone and thrust into a new, bizarro salad world.

Alas, I sighed and order the strip steak tacos and those were quite good. My friend's turkey sandwich came stacked with bacon, avocado, lettuce, and mayo and man that was great. 

Ironically, as I write this review, a song by The Thermals plays in the background, what's being sung? "I Let it Go." And so I say farewell to my very favorite salad in the world. No big.

As it turns out, being a bad girl isn't all it's cracked up to be. I was promised that by reversing my good girl ways, I'd become instantly popular, revered, and emulated. So far, I have nothing respectable to show for long hours logged at the bar and nights in North Philly. So, I'm putting away the brass knuckles, setting down the aluminum pipe, and handing over the switchblade. 

When you decide you want to get your life in order too, meet me at Fusion. Their bootcamp and cross training regiment will transform your body one muscle at a time. And you'll look gorgeous for it.
This is a soggy grossfest excuse for a slice of pizza. Alas, it's also my desperate late night default. Like sleeping with an ex, you always regret it after the fact.

Four months have passed since my original review and I'm just writing an update to inform you of my consistent obsession with the Café Salad. Lately, I've been on a two-time per week bender...that is: 2 salads per week. I dare you to find better lunchtime lettuce in the city. The marriage of the simple flavors creates an unparalleled midday experience, so get one already, but remember to add the chicken cutlet.

This is yet another item to be added to the mandatory meals list.

When I'm not pounding specials at Bob n Barbara's, I'm grinding it up against Philly's finest in the rathskeller that is Medusa. It's a dive but those are the best and it's in Center City, which amid its neighboring posh and refined establishments, Medusa's a godsend. 

It's always a friendly crowd and the only bar in this area where you'd likely find the alternative folk. It often features a famous array of my favorite local DJs and when you're in the mood for a sweaty, crowded and deliciously filthy dance floor, Medusa is like none other.

I once thought it'd be a good idea to wax my armpits. I know, ewwww. But whatever, I have clean armpits, so it's not that bad. 

Anyway, years before the discovery of Yelp, I relied on a friend's recommendation and went to International Salon. I couldn't even get all the way through the door when a stern Russian woman with huge black hair grabbed my hand and pulled me inside. 

Halo. Vut vuud you like today?

I'm not shy by any means, but I was a little intimidated by her demeanor. It definitely wasn't one of those soothing spa environments with sounds of the rain forest. 

Anyway, I agree to follow her to the back room where she instructs me to lay on the bed. I do as I'm told, I take of my shirt (cue the sexy music), and observe her as she piles wax onto a tongue depressor. From the stick to my armpit, the Russian spreads burning hot wax over my sad, little hairs. 

I take a deep breath. 

Vut are you doing?

Me: I'm getting ready.

Oh! No no no, not ready yet. 

She then tears a piece of DUCT TAPE, sticks it over the wax and counts: VUN, TWO, THREE. She tears away. I see white light and then I don't remember much more, except for the fact that I never again stepped foot inside International Salon and never again waxed my armpits.

At 8am this morning, I was sound asleep. Until suddenly, my roommate creeps into my room and jumps on my bed, pulls off my covers, and rouses my dog. From downstairs, I hear her friend hollering about getting somewhere. 

"Broad Street Run, bitches!!!! Let's gooooo" My roommate, Mutton Chop, puts socks and sneakers on my feet and throws a sports bra at my face. "5 minutes, hurry it up!"

After drinking a handle of whiskey last night, I had no intention of running the Broad Street Run the following morning. There was no month long preparation, no pre-race detox, I didn't even get my bowl of spaghetti for dinner. But there I was, half-asleep, lacing up my kicks and heading out the door to run rogue-style.

My friends would have registered, but it was all sold out by the time they tried to opt in. There was a sea of runners, wheelchair-bound hellcats, and even some dudes in ridiculous costumes. In wise fashion, the city turned on all of the fire hydrants and after one block of running, my friends and I looked transformed: our dry shirts now wet, our tidy hair now dripping, and our shorts now sticking to our fresh legs. 

On the sidelines, the Mummers performed an old timey set, some band sung the hits, South Philly played the Rocky soundtrack, and volunteers handed out cups of water and gatorade - it was awesome!

In typical post-race form, we all went to brunch and regaled our waitress with colorful stories of our morning run. I've only run one race, but this is probably the best one; quite the entertaining challenge!

Last night at the bar, I learned about friendship, revenge and discovery. The ultimate trinity.

-A note about friendship-

You don't really know someone until you've seen them drunk. That said, don't marry or exclusively date someone until you've seen them drunk.

-A note about revenge-

If a drunk person is acting like an asshole, buy them a shot. Just make sure it's Baileys and Rose's lime juice. It's called a cement mixer and it spreads like a virus throughout their entire mouth, while congealing into a rancid sludge grossfest. This gets all up in your gums, in between your teeth, coats your throat. Ugh, just nasty. Last night's victim (might I say he rightfully deserved it) said it tasted like his grandmother's curtains. Best. Revenge. Ever.

-A note about discovery-

Was introduced to a delicious new cocktail, thanks to the talented bartender, Andrew (as per another friend's request). Called a Rosita. The traditional recipe calls for slightly different ingredients, but this was his take on it last night. Check it:

    * 1 1/2 oz. Gin
    * 1/2 oz. Campari
    * 3 oz. OJ
    * 2 dash Angostura bitters

Stir with ice, strain into an iced filled Old Fashioned glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.

So, what have we learned? Drink with your friends before you're ready to call them friends; devise alternate, non-violent, but equally satisfying revenge plots for assholes at bars; drink only as much as your guardian angel can fly.

I appreciate the restaurants that still offer a comment card. So here's my response to theirs:

Questions, Comments, Concerns:
I wish I had known about the once free parking lot across the street no longer being free. I got a $26 ticket, *&$#!)@($*^ PPA. Unrelated, I quite like your jukebox.

About You (they mean me):

Name: Well, Monica.
Birthday: December 27th
Favorite Food: Whatever's fresh and cooked for me. Unless it's beets.
Favorite Drink: Sidecar
Favorite Song When Drinking: Major Lazer "Hold the Line"
Favorite Song When Drunk: Only if I can scream it, Hole "Celebrity Skin"
Song that Makes Me Feel Cool While I'm Walking Down the Street: Folk Implosion "Natural One"
Song of My Hangover: "My Alcoholic Friends" Dresden Dolls
Who I Would Like to Meet: A dreamboat I can call my own.

Let me know when pitchers are going to be half-priced and other special events:

Yes.

I'm always skeptical of -really- nice people; the ones who are always smiling and laughing. Call it the cynic in me. Mrs. Young is this person. As a patron of her dry cleaning service, and upstairs neighbor, I see her almost everyday, and without fail, she's always peppy and sweet and nice and who's like this anymore!? 

As far as her services are concerned, she's an expert at turning things around within 2 days, maybe even 1 day if you need it badly, and she does all my hemming. As I sit at my desk, I can hear her below me (seriously):

Mrs. Young: Oh! Hi! Nice to see you so soon!
Man: Hello, here are some shirts for dry cleaning
-no dialogue...I presume she's collecting his clothes-
Mrs. Young: Ok, will see you ok? Say hello! Goodbye!

Even if she doesn't really make sense, her enthusiasm is awesome.

How is it possible that no one's written a review for this place? It is seriously the best shoe store for awesome boots. Every time I walk in I fall in love with a pair of unaffordable footwear.

The last time I stopped in, I discovered Fiorentini & Baker boots. They're close to $500, so yours truly didn't purchase a pair, but don't think I'm not still thinking about them. I even raced home to see if I could find them cheaper online. Unfortunately, Head Start seems to be one of the only outposts that sells them. 

Ladies, if you're ever in search of that perfect Fall or Winter boot, Head Start has the best selection. Hands down.

I took a walk over to Pumpkin Cafe yesterday for my favorite salad. Low and behold, the chairs inside were stacked, the gridiron bars were locked, and the sign read "closed." I feel to my knees and cried to the heavens, "why do you hate me?!"

Because I'm persistent, I threw a rock at the window and made my own Cafe Salad. No, I didn't. I went back today (Tuesday). I couldn't decide whether to get the Cafe Salad or the Chicken Cutlet sandwich, so I combined the two. Cafe Salad topped with the Chicken Cutlet. Its deliciousness came as no surprise. 

The Salad comes with crispy romaine, bleu cheese, PUMPKIN SEEDS, chunks of pear, and an ungodly good dressing. 

You should go here for lunch, just don't make it a Monday.

Checked out this new spot over in Headhouse Square. They're making fresh cupcakes! You can pick your base (vanilla, chocolate, marble) and then your icing (vanilla, cake batter!, chocolate, red velvet...), and finally your topping (fruit, sprinkles, oreo cookie...). I got a vanilla cupcake with half cake batter/half vanilla frosting and a giant, delicious mess of toppings. The lovely cupcake maker put it in a plastic travel container and it's currently sitting on the kitchen counter, waiting to be consumed for dessert later. 

Giles (the dog) has his sights set...maybe I'll give him a taste. Cupcake tasting results to follow after dinner...

Despite no changes to the menu, I've discovered a new way to appreciate Morning Glory: don't go there for a really long time so you can appreciate it like it's the first. 

I was joined this morning by a vibrant group of former college roommates. While we laughed our way through brunch, I enjoyed the egg white Gardenkeeper fritatta, a side of bacon, fresh squeezed grapefruit juice, and a steaming cup of coffee. 

If you're looking for that cozy, breakfast-time experience, this place has the vibe. Imagine a movie where Janeane Garofalo and Paul Rudd split french toast while discussing their wild and crazy Friday night, Ingrid Michaelson cooing overhead and The Waitresses shuffling plates from table to table. This place makes me feel warm inside.

Bill Murray was the first person who popped into my mind last night when I checked out The Franklin. Bill Murray would like this place, I thought. It got me reminiscing about the cinematic moment he and Scarlett Johannson shared in the hotel bar as he swilled scotch and discussed life's shortcomings. This dimly lit, Prohibition inspired bar will leave you feeling swank in no time.

As you enter, sit in a banquette with your friends or cozy up to the bar in the rear. I always recommend sitting at the bar because it's probably more fun watching the bartender handle bottles than it is listening to your friends, let's be honest. You would probably want to start with a cocktail on ice. A bartender informed us the glaciers are disappearing at an alarming rate ever since they opened; it's a battle of ice chunks versus glass and ice wins. I'm serious. They use a single ice cube that's the size of your fist (each one is hand cut from a 75 pound block).

I had La Rosita, it's like a tequila Negroni, and then followed up with an off-the-menu beverage. There was cacao and mezcal in it....it was smokey and refreshing and awesome. Bartenders here are no joke; they know their stuff so don't you dare ask for a vodka red bull. 

The ambiance gives it a slight pompousness, but it's fitting and nothing you or Bill Murray couldn't handle. Now go imbibe.

A Sunday night that ends at 1am with bike spills, bloody knees, and far too many B&B specials is, well, a great Sunday night. Especially when it's someone else's knees that are bloody and someone else's bike that's crashing.

I was hanging out with two "sprouters." For those who aren't familiar with the term, Urban Dictionary will give you an idea: it's "a group of girls who 'sprout' other girls into what they call 'popularity.' The activities they participate in include: ruining songs for everyone by making provocative videos, uniting for closet parties, passing out every weekend, and calling themselves the 'Line Bitches.'"

I think they were trying to initiate me into their girl gang, but Bob, our able bartender kept giving me looks suggesting, "are you sure about this?" I danced with them on a completely empty dance floor. I don't even think there was music. 3 other girls, sitting across the bar found our behavior applaudable so they bought us Fritos. We bought them tap water. 

You know you're rolling with a good team when they're willing to rage on a Sunday night. Maybe I'll join the gang after all. If this sounds like something you'd be into, meet us on the B&B dance floor this Thursday.

Thanks to the awesome bundle package offered by Hotwire, I scored an $90 room at this incredibly comfortable business hotel. Nestled smack in the middle of downtown, the Hyatt Regency is within perfect distance from all the primary points of interest in Tampa. 

But what really put this hotel over the top for me? There's an electronic kiosk where you can speedily check yourself in and out of the hotel; overnight valet for your vehicle is a reasonable $18; there's a travel-sized tube of Aquafresh toothpaste waiting for your in your bathroom; a plush and heavenly bed; an iHome alarm clock where you can listen to your own iPod tunes; and a complimentary yoga experience via your On-Demand TV.

It's certainly no boutique hotel with flashy, loungey amenities (like the W), but for what it is, this hotel is top notch.

Something to respect about The Latest Dish is its staying power. While other neighboring Nouveau American-esque restaurants have shut their doors, TLD remains an off-South Street respite. You can come here to expect an accessible and quality menu, think: fish tacos meets spinach and goat cheese salad, without breaking the bank. 

Even though you probably won't flock here if you're coming from, say, the Main Line, any nearby resident has a devout appreciation for this restaurant. Also noteworthy, upstairs (at Fluid) you can cut a rug to sporadic DJ sets by ?uestlove (pretty cool).

Looking for a cheesy, salty, beer swilling refuge in PHL? Look no further than terminal E. 

In simplest terms, they top salads with crab fries. I love fries - specifically ones tossed in Old Bay seasoning - but these suckers are lost in a salt overload AND they're on a salad? It reminded me of the time my roommate put panties on her cat. "Hey! I'm pretty sure those don't belong there!" I offered. 

I leave my pretensions at door whenever patronizing Chickie's, but my taste buds know better and they're not fooling me with bad bar food. Thankfully, they have every domestic light beer imaginable to compensate for their lack of quality consumables. You know? I don't know.

My friends and I came here for tonight's dinner and started off with the obvious must haves: a Mexican Margarita and a Singapore Sling. They served us the Margarita with two Sapporo's instead. My friend asked about the Sling and the waiter simply shook his head "no..." Puzzled, we began to feast on our 19 appetizers: garlic shrimp, Chinese greens, Vietnamese sausage, summer rolls, Papaya steak salad washed down with a steaming bowl of delicious pho. 

As we slurped the last bit down, and patted our bellies good night, the Sling arrived. It tasted like someone had liquefied orange Starburts and blended them in a boot. But what can you expect from a cocktail menu where all drinks are $4 and club soba is listed in the beer section?

Listen up Philly pizza haters, I've found the good stuff. Not only does Little Italy serve up my favorite slice, they also make my favorite cheesesteak. 

So, here goes: 

BEST PIZZA.

BEST CHEESESTEAK.

Yeah, I said it.

Dear Kelly Drive,
I rode you yesterday and I just want to say thanks for the eye candy. With the weather breaking, all the fine Philadelphians have been making their way to tread upon your tracks and it's a beautiful thing. I must say, these long winter months made me nearly forget about you. Alas, the good times are back.

On a serious note, I really can't wait to visit Valley Green. I take my dog on long hikes there and I feel like it's a really cool way to spend a first date. Then again, a friend of mine went on a first date there and suddenly had to get to a bathroom, emergency-style. That was probably not the best way to spend a first date. So, note to self and others, save the prunes, fiber, or whatever gets it done for later.

It seems I'm one of the few and proud to have made it to Honest Tom's before the famous taco sell-out. I rode my bike up to Clark Park this morning to check out two markets (the Farmer's and the Uhuru Flea Market) and stumbled upon Honest Tom's food truck. The sign read "Breakfast Taco" (something about giving your taste buds a treat) and "Iced Coffee." I paid my $2.50 and waited for 30 minutes to receive my taco. I sat in the grass; I talked to an anarchist; I ate a peach; I read the City Paper; I ran into someone I met on a dance floor...finally, my taco.

It came with the freshest guac, little potatoes, chopped tomato, white onion, and an egg. Next time, I'll order 4. You've got to get here early and try one for yourself, they're right, your taste buds will be pleased.

On any given day, until 11 post meridiem, you and your friends can take your laundry quarters and spend them at Mako's, where 49 cents gets you a bottle of Miller High Life (the beer with the best name and motto). In fact, you're better off bringing coins than you are bills: 4 quarters to play on one of the two pool tables, and 4 quarters for 2 songs off the iPhone-looking jukebox. 

On the downside, the women's bathroom is diminutive and deplorable; its level of squalor is repugnant. And what's worse, there's no hand soap to wash the grime off your previously less-germed mitts. They've got food to offer, but there's no menu, just ask the bartender who'll rattle off the "specials." 

As for the scene, expect skaters and smokers. I've yet to meet a retired surfer.

A brief exchange with a mumbling homeless man really defined my experience here.

"Come here, my Spanish garden. Take off your shirt," he waxed poetically.

I'm pretty sure he meant: "come, stay a while, take off your shoes." 

Anyway, I was in a dress and how he knew I was a Spanish garden, I'll never know.

I have a friend who's been to every "cool/unique/off the beaten path" spot in Philly. So, while I can impress my less in-the-know friends with random urban discoveries, this one buddy keeps me on my toes. I finally one-upped her at Carman's. It was actually the first time I'd been there too. 

We walked into this diminutive diner (there's bar seating for about 4-6 people -there's no liquor though- and a few tables) and were seated right away. Our server came over, asked for our names and proceeded to rattle off the specials. I can't remember exactly what they were, but I got the feeling that Carman's the type of woman who goes shopping the day before and buys whatever's fresh. Figuring out what to make with it seems like an afterthought. Somehow she manages to pair the most unlikely items together and keep it delicious.

There's subtle penis iconography strewn throughout the diner. It doesn't come off as tasteless though. While I was sitting at the table, I remember looking out the window and glancing over a little plush piggie. How darling! Upon closer inspection, his little bits were hanging out.

"Carman puts the C U N(ext) T(uesday) back into country." That's what the sign reads, folks. 

Oh! You can call in advance and have your name put on the waiting list. There never seems to be too long of a wait though.

Decided I was in the mood for some kebab delights and hit up my magic 8 ball (aka Yelp). Based on the rave reviews, I decided to try it out for today's lunch. I live less than a mile away and I never even knew this place existed. 

When we arrived, my friend and I were greeted by the nicest hostess. She gave us the option of sitting indoors or out, and since the farmer's market was going on next to the outdoor tables, we opted for the outdoor seating. While we waited for our waiter (which took no time at all), the sweet scent of strawberries wafted in my direction. It piqued my appetite for sure. 

The real astonishment came when I looked at the menu and saw little starburts filled with the numbers "7.95." Wait, seriously? All this food for $7.95? Yes! It's part of their lunch special. I ordered the Chicken Adana Kebab with the hummus plate as my app, and my friend went with the Lamb Adana Kebab, babagannush as her app. When the apps arrived, she and I housed them in seconds flat. The kebabs were just as amazing. 

This is my new favorite lunch spot. Skip the South Street hype and head to this side street treasure. Oh and if you lunch there on a Tuesday, you'll get to check out the farmer's market too. Joy!

In need of some serious brain-clearing and brainstorming, I jumped on my bike and took a ride on Kelly Drive this morning. I rode up Kelly and went over East Falls bridge to enjoy the car-less West River Drive. During the warm months, the city closes down WRD so bikers/runners/rollerbladers can play without worrying about cars. The whole ride was such a breath of fresh air. I left the phone at home and got to listen to some of my favorite music. Sometimes we just need to disconnect. Ya know?

Here were some songs that enhanced my biking:
Sufjan Stevens - Casimir Pulaski Day
The Innocence Mission - Lakes of Canada
Passion Pit - Sleepyhead
Rouge Wage - Maps (Yeah Yeah Yeahs cover)
Sun Kil Moon - Carry Me Ohio
Passion Pit - Moth's Wings
We Are Scientists - After Hours

Happy Saturday :)

Yes, the beer. Yes, the wine. But, really, the fries. I would travel for miles to get more of those freshly cut, lightly truffled shoestring  creations. They were sublimely divine. On the particular Sunday that we stopped by, the bar only had 2 other patrons and then us. If we're getting aquatic, I wish there were more fish hanging around the reef. 

Nevertheless, we had a quiet time sipping on some craft brews and throwing back fries. I'd imagine this cooler-than-thou spot bumps on select nights, so go give it a look-see.

I've been going to Morning Glory for 6 years straight and while I love love love it, I'm ready for some change. I would love to see a few new items added to this menu. I vividly remember my excitement when I saw a meaty fritatta on special. It had caramelized onions, chorizo, some kind of cheese. Anyway, that was YEARS ago. 

All I'm asking for a little something new. Sure, the staples are great, but it's time for a face lift, methinks. I'll still wait for an hour to eat, but you know, just make it worth my while.

This is the way things go. Wolf Parade on the jukebox. Pitchers of blood orange margaritas. Nachos topped with homemade pulled chicken.
Someone at my table making shameless attempts to hit on our server. Our server offering herself up for a threesome. Me refusing said threesome (I'm a lady of virtue). My mom pointing out that the girl would be prettier if she wasn't covered in tattoos. Someone ordering far too many house specials (Tecate and Sauza tequila). Someone ordering far too many specials for the next table under my tab. Staring at the other patrons deciding who's sexy, who's sexy-ugly, and who's faking it. Analyzing all the first dates. Analyzing ourselves. 

Lots of stuff happens at Cantina. And for just being a restaurant, I can spend an entire night here only to wake up feeling like I've smoked a carton of Reds (when I haven't). It's a rowdy place and you should go there to feel like you're in Reality Bites.

After being away for nearly a year, it should tell you something that despite being in a new place that bleeds Mexican food, I hurried, nay, raced to Cantina Los Caballitos directly from the airport. 

Lured by the promise of a frozen blood orange margarita, bottomless chips and salsa, platanos machos and a very basic but very satisfying mixta salad, Cantina is to me what I am to most, a beacon of delicious indulgence.

Ah! I thought referencing the ultimate hamburger heaven (In-N-Out) was going to be original, but it seems I was beat to the punch. Five Guys is our East Coast alternative. And there are no religious ties. Nothing wrong with religion...I just don't like to get it mixed up with my burgers. Oh, good buns too.

I don't know another late night happy hour like this around town. You order drink after sophisticated drink and suddenly, though your legs develop cocktail bruises, your wallet doesn't. Before you know it, you've bought drinks for many other bar patrons and your bill doesn't exceed twenty one dollars. Am I just really charming or is this place just -that- special? It's that special, and my charisma merely won me smiles from the bartender, not any special discounts. $3 drafts and half off specialty cocktails.

If you appreciate an aesthetically pleasing ambiance with in-the-know folks, go here on a Tuesday night between 9 and 11 when Meghan is behind the bar. Most likely, you won't be sorry.

As repair shops go, Via is terrific. Rushed in early this morning when I realized I needed a new tube for my front tire. Katie (an awesome 3-day-old employee) swaps out the busted goods for the proper stuff and I'm out of there within 5 minutes. She also insisted on giving me a tube changing lesson. Greatly appreciated but quickly forgotten. 

I go to leave and on my way out, I realize the rear tube is retiring itself as well (must have loved the front tube). So I get serviced by another employee who runs over the pricing and hurries back inside to repair and  pluck out the glass from my tire. With his bare hands.

10 minutes and one Summer Soda later, I'm cruising on my restored ride, back against the wind, with one hand in my pocket, and the other one giving a high five.

Anything The Franklin's bartenders touch turns into perfectly balanced, liquid gold. They're so good, they could probably make a Long Island Iced Tea taste like cupid's kisses.

There isn't a sub par cocktail on extensive menu, but the last one I tried (something with mezcal, reposado, fresh lemon, agave, and maybe something else) was pure magic. Served over a single iceburg cube, this concoction transported me to Playa del Carmen.

Listen up haters, Via is terrific. If you've ever looked for a hard, honest opinion, this is the place and Curtis + staff are your men. They're not the kind of guys who will tell you you look pretty in that dress when you don't. They won't say you're having a good hair day if you're not. And they most certainly won't try and sell you something you don't need when you don't need it. You see what I'm saying here?

Take my situation, for instance. I'm looking to trade/sell my Diamondback road bike because it's outgrown its sexiness. I thought it was really cool when I first bought it, but now, I'm seeing the wrinkles and sag...so it's time to part ways. I also want dropbars over the flat ones my bike currently has. I thought I liked Curtis' vintage Giant, but then when I asked, "am I a fool to sell my current bike for this one (referring to his $300 bike)?" In so many words, he said, "yes." He then told me to sell it on craigslist for $300 and recommended that I shop around to really find what I'm looking for. 

He then even asked his repair guy to get me a quote if I were to swap out the flatbars for dropbars. When that came out to $225, I decided I might just want to get a new bike altogether.  

I can understand Curtis being a little short with people, but they're probably going when he's the busiest. I recommend trying them out in the morning or early afternoon during non-peak hours.

Simply known as "The Loop," it was here where I experienced my first "oh wow, this is pretty" moment. Blazing a trail on my then super cool mountain bike, speeding past runners, rollerbladers, bikers; taking in the out-of-city air; and grinning like a fool at the sight of the rowers, I can't help but think how much I love Philadelphia every time I ride this trail. 

If you're just moving to the area or if you're a local, get acquainted with The Loop. During spring and summer weekends, they close off West River Drive to cars so you and yours can ride/run/blade with ease...feeling the breeze...looking at trees...

Heavens to Betsy! I completely forgot to update this review. The offerings here are Christ in a cupcake: completely divine!

Just like with the froyo craze, here at Cupmakes, you can pile on as many toppings as you'd like. Thankfully, they offer kind suggestions before you decide the chili con carne might taste great with drizzled strawberry sauce and sprinkles. 

As for the sweet options, the banana's foster and vanilla cupcake with vanilla icing and sprinkles are my picks. 

Now, if only I could plant their cupcake and grow a cupcake tree.

A restaurant is only as good as it wants to be and this one is mediocre at best. If you can hide the food in gobs of cheese and sauce, it's decent. That said, the quesadillas were our pick. The margaritas, on the other hand, were quite bad. C'mon guys, you can do better!

Despite the recent Yelp dissatisfaction with this place, I had a better than average, dare I say exceptional, experience last night. My friend and I sat at a table outside, the place was busy, but entirely manageable (it was a Tuesday night). Our hostess/server greeted us the moment we walked in and brought out our drinks promptly. She was attentive, but not overly/annoyingly-so and engaged in friendly banter when it was called for. Turns out she's from the Bellevue restaurant XIX: Nineteen (read: she has experience).

I'm thinking the overwhelming complaints about service might have moved these guys into action and they're starting to tighten up their business. 

The one thing I will say is their burgers and onion rings are FANTASTIC. The rings are soaked in Kenzinger! 

If you're interested in going there to take care of burger business, check it out on an off night, you'll probably be treated with excellent service and awesome food.

Dear college students drinking on mom's allowance,

I was once like you. I thought it was really fun to get shit-faced at Bob & Barbara's on Thursday nights with my newly 21-year-old friends, getting rowdy, and pushing the shyest friend toward Liza Liza (the hostess with, you know, the mostest) so she might pick said friend to awkwardly dance on stage. I'm older now, some might say, wiser, and I have a few requests of the "new class."

1. Just because you're armed with an arsenal of equally drunk and obnoxious friends, do not think you have the right to command the room and steal the show from Liza. She's been doing it every Thursday night for 12 years. Rezpect. 

2. Do not tastelessly gawk at the performers deciding whether or not you can see their chest hair or kibbles n bits. If the junk is there, it's well-hidden, trust.

3. Do not take pictures of the performers without their permission. 

4. Do not dance with them during their song. 

5. Move aside when a performer takes the floor.

6. If "it's your birthday," and Liza selects you to dance, do not take a beverage with you to the dance floor and do not try to drag unsuspecting friends or strangers up there with you. It's your moment to (er) shine. Revel in it and dance terribly. We all have.

7. When the dance music comes on during intermission, dance your ass off, grind up on strangers, spill your drink all over the place. Get sloppy. This is when you can get sloppy. 

8. Once the show resumes, please adhere to rules 1-6.

I still give BnB's 5 stars, but for you newbies, you've still got a lot to learn.

As they say in Thailand, the food here was comme ci, comme ça. My Pad See Ew was dry and flavorless (to their credit, or discredit, they ran out of  fat noodles so I was stuck with the thinner ones). I love the simplicity behind a palate cleansing mixed vegetable soup in clear broth, so that was pretty yummy. 

For those of you who appreciate a bottle of Singha with your noodles, you'll be pleased to know beers are $3.50.

Today was quite possibly the most beautiful day of winter - is winter still even happening? I scurried along the sunny side of the street to my neighborhood brunch spot after a 3pm hankering for one of their frittatas. I sat at the counter, shoveled down the eggie creation and listened to the quiet bustle of a near empty restaurant (a rarity for Morning Glory). 

You should also try a slice of their homemade pie, I hardly ever have room after a godzilla frittata, but their stuff's worth it. 

I love that you can go alone and not feel alone - most of the diners there this afternoon were by themselves. And as the saying goes, never drink alone unless you're by yourself.

To be fair, I haven't been to every beer distributor in the city, so I can't say this place is the bee's knees. What I can say though, is that Bella Vista not only carries beer from my new favorite brewery (Russian River), but it also conveniently categorizes beer by region of origin. 

So, much like you'd see baby diapers and light bulbs in the same grocery store aisle, you'll find Mid-Western and Great Lakes craft brews in the same section. That kind of organization isn't something one can take lightly, especially when shopping for something as serious as beer. 5 stars Bella Vista. Thank you for making life's important decisions that much easier.

In an effort to quell the debaucherous fire within, I thought I'd win points with god by taking my dog, Giles, for a romp in Freedom Park. The drive through South Jersey isn't a pleasant one, Rt 70 is full of stop lights and strip malls, but once you arrive at Freedom Park, it's field and games for as far as the eye can see. 

There's beach volleyball, a skate park, an organic community garden, a disc golf course (not super impressive though), a basketball court, a soccer field, a kid's playground, and of course, a gigantic off leash dog park...so big that we didn't even cover it all. 

The legions of dogs and their owners making the mass exodus from the gated area means you're headed in the right direction. Once inside, you can hit up the agility course where your talented animal can wobble on the see-saw or dart over hurdles. Giles steered clear of the smart dog area and opted for the swimming creek; he's pure brute. Take a short hike over the wooden bridge and just when you think you're in the middle of the woods, you'll find all the adventurous water dogs plunging into the creek to fetch wooden sticks or tennis balls. It's a sight to behold.

Make your city dog happy and take him/her on a 30 minute drive into the wilderness. This place is like a theme park for dogs and not too bad for the humans either.

It's a real shame you weren't with me at The Franklin last night. We could have sampled delicious cocktails together. You would've turned to me and said, "wow, this is the coolest bar in Philadelphia." I would've been like, "yeah, they're unmatched in mixology and doesn't your drink make you feel special?" 

You would've been elated. The drink's potency and tastiness might end up costing us a pretty penny but we'd leave feeling like a silver dollar. 3 drinks for you, 7 for me and who knows what we'd do after; The Franklin's an aphrodisiac personified. 

With drinks that'll put hair on your chest to those delicate enough for a white gloved lady, the new menu runs the gamut of all spirits properly mixed. The Pirate Slave for the burly man or forward-thinking woman; a glass of punch for the effeminate man or girly girl.

I made a few new friends at Outback. One was a small cockroach that greeted me at our table. The next was his winged kin who fell to drunk death in a pool of my rotten margarita. The sour mix tasted like it'd been wrung through a sock and mixed with tequila. Our server greeted us with a nervous over-zealousness and when the table behind us asked to speak with the manager, this was their exchange:

Woman: I ordered the mixed green salad. This ain't mixed greens. 
Manager: Well ma'am I'm very sorry about that. This is the salad featured in the menu though.
Woman: No, the salad on the menu says "mixed greens." This is iceberg.
Manager: Oh. Well. Ok. Would you mind if I asked what exactly you mean by "mixed greens?"
Woman: What?
Manager: Um. We only have iceberg and romaine lettuce.
Woman: Mixed greens is different shapes of lettuce. It's like spinach. But it ain't spinach. 
They proceed in a stare down contest and ultimately the manager, who is no match for her downtown sass, quivers and backs down.

The broccoli that complimented my New York Strip tasted like it had been frozen for four years, the ketchup that came out of the bottle tasted fermented, and I actually refused to eat the mushrooms.

If this is what Australia tastes like, you can count me out.

Hotel Provincial was a wonderful addition to our vacation in New Orleans! The front desk was very accommodating. We weren't supposed to check in until 3, and we arrived a few hours early. We were only expecting to check in our bags and return later on, but the desk found us an open room and let us check in early! Very nice!!! 

I love old, historic hotels. The architecture was awesome. We actually stayed in the 500 building, which used to be a confederate hospital. It's said to be haunted, but we did not spot any spirits during our stay. There is a nice courtyard with a fountain for outdoor seating (even though it was too cold and rainy for us to enjoy during our stay). 

They served a continental breakfast every morning, and provided tea and hot coffee 24 hours a day. Very good coffee (Community Coffee) I might add. 

If you are mainly going to NOLA to stay in the FQ, this is the perfect location. A couple of blocks from touristy Bourbon St., a couple of blocks from Frenchman St., and a block over from the French Market. The atmosphere and decor of the hotel kind of takes you back in time. It was very relaxing and accommodating. I would definitely stay here again when I come back!

Greatness! 

This was the best meal that I devoured during my NOLA visit! 

We came across this place totally by accident. It was a rainy Sunday, and we were taking a walk down Frenchmen Street. It was lunch time, we were hungry, and The Praline Connection happened to be right in front of us! We hadn't heard of it before, but we took a chance and entered. Not only did it turn out to be a shelter from the rain, but a haven for gorging and overeating. 

The wait staff was excellent, very helpful and friendly. The establishment is separated into two parts, the candy store where they sell pralines, and the restaurant. The walls were decorated with antiques and paintings, it had a good vibe. There weren't too many people inside at the time, so I was kind of wary...but that all changed once the food came out. 

I had the seafood platter...shrimp (great), oysters (great), catfish (great), deviled crab (great), half of my friends bread pudding (OMG sooooo awesome!). The seafood was seasoned perfectly and the bread pudding had a praline sauce on it that consisted of pralines and bourbon I think. She had The Taste of Soul platter that consisted of ribs, chicken, catfish, etc... When I think of the amount of food that we both ate that day, I almost get sick. The words gluttony and greed come to mind. So, my lesson for you, the reader, in this review, is please try to not overeat during your visit here. It not hard to do!

I want to start this off by saying that I only came here to eat, I didn't listen to the live music...so if you are coming for the music, you may have an altogether different experience than I had.

On that note...we came to Snug Harbor on Monday night (1/10/11) to get a quick bite before going to listen to music along Frenchmen St. The show at Snug Harbor had a cover of $15, and there is so much awesome, free jazz along that street, we chose not to partake.

We entered, and the person who was supposed to greet us, didn't. I wandered inside and asked the guy at the bar if we could eat, he told us to ask the dude up front with the hat on, he told us that he would seat us. We went back up front. I had to ask him if he could seat us. He took us in the dining area. There was a large party and another couple near the cold window in the front of the dining area, the other half of the room was empty. Naturally he squeezed us in between both parties where we were literally rubbed by people getting up from their table. Eventually the big party left along with the other couple. That's when everyone else was seated on the opposite side of the room, away from the cold window, except us. I asked the waitress about the seating priorities, and she mumbled something and laughed incoherently. When we were done, I had to turn around to search for the waitress. A group of them were sitting in the back of the dining area at a table (the warm part of the room), and I had to wait patiently for her to notice me staring. She then got up and got my tab, not even asking if I wanted another beer or anything.

I know that I'm bitching, I don't like people that bitch and moan all of the time either, but shit...I was on vacay, and I wanted to have a nice night out. The wait staff obviously didn't want to be there.

I ordered the shrimp sandwich with a baked potato. It was decent. Not bad, but not worth the frustrating staff. This is based only on my personal experience on 1/10/11 at around 9:30pm at the small table by the window next to the pole. Too much good food (Prailine Connection) and too much good music (Spotted Cat and La Maison) nearby to have to go through that shit.

After a night on Frenchmen St., hanging out at the Spotted Cat, we decided to call it a night and head back to the hotel. As we ventured out onto the street, we heard music. Granted, on Frenchmen St. at that time of night, it's not abnormal to hear the sound of jazz music coming from every direction...but this was different. As we approached Maison, the sounds of The Jackson 5 poured out of trombones and saxophones, and onto the busy street. The open doors and people dancing inside the large windows beckoned us to enter. When we went inside, we had one of the best experiences during our trip to NOLA. 

That night happened to be a "open mic" night. A night where locals brought their own instruments, jumped up on the stage, and joined the group, ad libbing and free styling r&b, jazz, and any other genre that was requested. You could tell that these were regulars, some of the musicians on stage would call others in the crowd, asking "Where's your trombone?", and telling people that they need to "Hurry up and get up on the stage!" The jam session quickly turned into a trombone vs. trumpet battle. Both sides taking turns trying to top each other....blaring notes, clapping hands, and shouting filled my eardrums as the audience watched. 

This is a part of NOLA that I always heard about, and was so happy that I got to see. I heard that the food was good as well. I didn't try it, but next time I definitely will. Great spot!

3 points:

1. The food was edible....even though there were some egg shells in it. I guess technically you can eat egg shells and not get sick.
2. There are too many awesome restaurants in the vicinity to settle for mediocre!
3. The service was ok, nothing great.

I really don't have too much to say in this review. There was nothing that stood out except the location of the restaurant. We hadn't heard anything good or bad prior to our visit, and I really can't say too much good after my visit. 

It's not awful, but then again, it's not good. Especially if you are on vacay and trying to experience the city. Not a good representation at all.

Greatness!!!

The whole time we were in New Orleans, my plan was to get a killer Oyster Po' Boy. Carla, who went with me, heard my plan over and over several times. My first attempt was at Desire on Bourbon....blah! Nothing special at all. On the last day of our adventure in The Big EZ, I was thinking that my plan would not happen. That's when Carla thought about a spot where she ate on one of her previous trips. We began to search frantically (our plane left in 4 hours) for the place that she ate. She couldn't remember the name, and she could only remember the general area that it was in. All of a sudden we turned the corner and she pointed, and then shouted "There it is!" (cue the angels singing)

What I saw was a sign that read "Johnny's Po-Boys". A sign I would soon equate to many other great symbols witnessed by mankind...the North Star, or a light house during a rough storm at sea, or that awesome video of Joe Namath running off of the field during Super Bowl III holding up his finger stating that the Jets were indeed #1!!! (Soon to be done again by Sanchez) But back to the point...... 

We entered the shop, which was very small, but had a very long line..it was packed! (Great sign) We ordered, snagged a table, and waited. Finally our number was called! The Oyster Po Boy was great!! The fries on the side were great!! Fried food...a lot of it...stacked on a nice roll. It was nothing less than I would expect from a true N.O. Po' Boy! Please don't come here looking for a healthy meal, or say that something is too greasy. You should already know what you are getting when you go in there.

I highly recommend Johnny's!!!!!!

Ok, I'm in St. Louis on a business trip, what to do for dinner? Hooters?  Nah, not really interested in wings and orange short-shorts.  How about some ribs?  I stumbled on Masterpiece and got pulled in by the smells, who can resist ribs?  Order at the counter and grab a table, within 10 minutes I'm greeted with a large slab of ribs over white bread along with a side of cheese bread and baked beans.  

Overall Masterpiece made some good ribs but not great.  A bit drier than I expected, I'm guessing they were sitting outside for a while.  Sides were ok but nothing to write home about, nothing particularly fresh.  I do enjoy my KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce at home but can't really say that you've got to try the place when visiting St. Louis.  There are probably better and more authentic rib joints in the city.  But I have to admit, the Gateway Arch on the walk back to the hotel was VERY cool....

While drive from NYC to NC, I planned on dropping in for my first real Philly cheesesteak and picked John's given its reputation and location off of I-95. This little foodie mecca had about a 25 minute wait at 2pm but wait I did. 

While the lines can get long, they have an efficient operation here. If you wanted anything but a cheesesteak (roast pork, meatball, etc) you were fast-tracked up front. But I grabbed a fresh cheesesteak and roast pork sandwich for my ride back home. And wow, so good! Lovely sesame seeded roll, about 11" long, stuffed with flavorful steak, provolone and onions. Loved the sliced roast pork that's simmered in a wine broth and spiked with sharp provolone. You can get it with spinach (not broccoli di rabe) at John's. 

I devoured half of my two sandwiches (they are big) on my 8 hour ride and then finished them off for lunch the next day. So simple but so good! Hope to get back up here, some day...

Gosh, there was a time when I loved Chili's chicken crispers but it's been years.  A group from work stopped in at this Chili's for a quick dinner and let's just say it was a reminder of why I haven't been to one in ages.  The appetizers were ok but nothing interesting, ribs were lacking meat and the margarita was a bit weak. Add in a less than clean interior, average service and I'm not sure why people eat at chain restaurants like Chili's.  

There are so many better places and ways to spend your money even if the commercials may be catchy.  I'm guessing I won't be baby-back, baby-back in a Chili's again for at least another couple of years.  Underwhelming food and dining experience, end of story...

I have to say I was a bit worried about booking a room at the Hyatt Regency New Orleans because of the Yelp reviews but I've been pleasantly surprised.  The facility and hotel is huge, very nicely appointed.  Huge glass foyer spanning twenty floors with an impressive view of the Superdome at night.  Staff is pretty service-oriented and easy to deal with, no complaints on check-in.  

But it's not all perfect!  The elevators are sorta odd with touch-sensitive panels that don't always work.  You press your card up against the door lock to open it and the rooms are a bit on the small side. No coffee maker, no stocked fridge.  But they have nice 40" HD TV's and the plumbing is fairly new and modern.  The pool on the fifth floor is quite nice with a handful of cabanas and outdoors bar.  And the StayFit gym has a very impressive view on the 32nd floor, it has some decent LifeFitness machines and circles around half a floor, very cool. 

Overall I think this Hyatt is quite good and from what I understand, has served Superbowl teams in the past so it must be half-decent, eh?  And that's been my experience so far, 3.5 to 4 stars but I'm rounding up today!

So I'm in New Orleans, eating to my heart's content and what do I spy?!  Krystal burger on Bourbon Street!  Even after eating at some acclaimed Food Network type places, there's always room for some sliders, right?  I go with my special of 5 cheese Krystals with chiil-cheese fries.  As I wait, I grab my fountain drink and check out the interior.  With a second floor in this Krystal, it must do some serious business.  

I get my sack and grab a seat by a street window, yum!  Same great soft little sliders with just a bit of mustard and ketchup.  The chili-cheese fries are also up to snuff so I'm a happy boy.  While it's not cheap at near $10, I'm guessing that's the going rate on Bourbon Street for lunch.  And I hear they do a $3.99 breakfast which can save you some dough. So thanks Krystal burger for dinner the other night.  Because man can not live by Food Network type places, alone...

Maypop Restaurant is open all week long for lunch, dinner, and even happy hour, but personally I'm all about their weekend (read Saturday AND Sunday) dim sum brunch. I want to praise, laud, glorify, and extol whatever creative genius had the innovative idea to take Southern ingredients and stuff them into Asian dim sum dumplings. Compact pockets of self-contained addiction, these perfectly portioned bites are a delicious way to get several different tastes of New Orleans. The sheer brilliance of this combination cannot be understated. Get some plates and be ready to share!

While all the dumplings are tasty, the pork and cane syrup sausage stuffed sesame balls were our standouts. However, the "Baodin" pan-fried cheesy buns with a citrus mustard came in a close second. They've got other playful options like turnip cakes with smoked andouille, and head cheese and blue crab soup dumplings as well. 

The normal menu continues along a similar path of fusion. Picture a spicy red coconut milk curry with lemongrass sausage, blue crab and fermented black bean gumbo, and your typical "Hot Chicken" kicked up a notch with vindaloo curry. All distinctively Maypop, these well-balanced dishes make for great twists on the traditional. During our brunch we were lucky enough to have a speckled sea trout on special, which came with roasted pumpkin, smoked ham hock, and a red bean salad. It was a feast of flavors and textures, and the staff even pre-split the plate for us (recognizing we intended to share).

Desserts really deliver the finishing knockout punch, with the Dreamsicle (pandan semifreddo, fennel, citrus, and black cardamom, orange meringue), and their version of King Cake (thai tea & cream cheese chantilly, coconut pecan streusel, praline caramel). Definitely be sure to wash it down with one (or more) of their cocktails as well. The Keefe 46 (pumpkin washed-tonka infused xicaru mezcal, joto yuzu sake, averna amaro, lemon, st georges nola coffee liqueur) is a particularly potent combination of refreshing with a bit of smoke. The atmosphere is funky and trendy, while still boasting refinement, perfect for a date, or to rally with a group of friends. New Orleans may have a lot of options, but Maypop is one restaurant not to be missed.

Eureka!

I must say when in Tampa I tend to be a creature of habit, often gravitating towards the same tried and true favorites. I've never been happier to step outside my routine, since Edison: Food+ Drink Lab truly is a revelation. The cocktails, the food, I cannot remember the last time I tried a new restaurant that left me so impressed.

Placing an emphasis on local to Florida ingredients, Edison sets the gastropub bar high with innovation on the culinary front. Chicory ice cream? Curried tropical fruit? While some claim its best to keep it simple, I am all for some outside the box culinary creativity you can't find at every restaurant in town. 

Although I cannot guarantee the menu will always be the same, to give you an idea of what to expect, we particularly enjoyed the:

- Faroe Island Salmon Poke with coconut, rocoto, yuzu, peanuts, and prawn chips. Moreover
- Avocado Leaf-Seared Yellowfin Tuna with Homestead green mango salad, aji amarillo sorbet, fish sauce caramel, and tamarind peanut crunch
- Black Lime-Seared Foie Gras with chevre-stuffed phyllo, toybox tomato picholine olive preserved lime salad, passionfruit vinaigrette, and truffle honey
- Boniato-Crusted Keys' Yellowtail Snapper with key lime basmati, rainbow chard, heart of palm, curried tropical fruit, and mango espuma

I feel like not every dish is a home run but most certainly are, and I give them credit for inventiveness, presentation, and flavor combinations. The cocktails too are a step above your average watering hole, delivering such libations as the "Smoking Gun," a drink which includes duck fat-infused Bulleit Rye 'Frontier' whiskey, TeBella Lapsang Souchong-infused simple syrup, Crude 'Sycophant' orange + fig bitters, and Jack Rudy aromatic bitters. The "Whiskey Business" is made with Rough Rider 'Bull Moose' rye whiskey, Barrow's 'Intense' ginger liqueur, Destillerie Purkhart 'Nux Alpina' walnut liqueur, Yzaguirre dry vermouth, Fever-Tree ginger beer, and candied walnuts. Both are excellent, as I'm sure are the others on the menu.

I'd strongly suggest sharing to get to sample more, and possibly making reservations in advance. The only complaint I have, and let me just say I'm really reaching to not sound like I'm completely over-the-top positive on everything (which it is hard not to be with Edison), is that I could see parking being a problem on the weekends when they're full. This isn't the end of the world, just something that may be worth considering so you allow extra time "just in case." That being said Edison is one of the best options on the west coast of Florida, and I'd highly recommend giving it a try.

As Oscar Wilde once said "I can resist anything but temptation." 

Indeed, Oxford Exchange offers enough to entice even the most abstemious patron.The perfect combination of refinement, tea, and blueberry syrup, the brunch is the ideal way to spend a leisurely Sunday morning. Make sure to plan ahead with reservations though, as I think all of Tampa is already in on the secret.

From the lovely bookstore to the impressive coffee bar area to the chic boutique offering all kinds of treasures you didn't realize you needed but suddenly can't imagine being without, Oxford Exchange is practically more mini-mall than restaurant. The ornate wooden staircase and marble floors, also give the distinct impression that it is actually a posh British manor that managed to find itself relocated in Tampa. I could spend hours browsing in the shop, and even longer curled up in a high backed chair sipping an Iced Carmello while poring over a good book. The cheery glass atrium is my favorite spot to dine, although the main dining room is exquisite as well.

Unlike many restaurants nowadays partaking in the tapas style-trend, OE does actually deliver their plates with more than enough food to fill a person up. The menu seems to change every-time I go (likely since they use local and seasonal ingredients), so making specific recommendations is difficult. If it is available though, the Monkey Bread French Toast (with salted caramel drizzle, candied pecans, and cinnamon mascarpone) is pure decadent breakfast bliss. Also be warned that whatever flavor you get, the pancakes (most recently a Lemon Poppy Seed with blueberry maple syrup, sweet cream, fresh and strawberries) are a huge order, and that the fluffy mountain served may be enough for two to share. The do also have more savory fare like panko-crusted avocado wedges, and an assortment of sandwiches, salads, and flatbreads.

The checks come pressed inside a novel, and you can pick up a bookmark with witty quote as a remainder of your visit. Whether stopping in for a refreshing iced tea, or indulging in a full meal, the refined experience at OE is sure to tempt guests to return repeatedly.

Are you in Nashville, or planning a visit to Nashville? Go to Bastion. 
Looking for a laid back spot to grab a quality libation? Go to Bastion. 
Trying to find a decent happy hour to meet up with friends or co-workers? Go to Bastion. 
Looking for some of the city's best cuisine? Go to Bastion. 

Bastion is the answer whether you want something quick and causal or a more formal meal. Upon entering you can fork left if you want to hang out with a cold drink, play a game, or order a plate of nachos. The atmosphere is pretty laid back, and the drink options are solid. They have old fashioneds, a punch of the day, cocktails, wine, and beers (ranging from the more commercial to the local). Make reservations in advance and fork right to access the not so secret "private" bar, and the sit down dining area.

Although you can book a normal table, personally I'd suggest a counter seat for dinner and a show. The chefs work in choreographed synchronicity to ensure each plate goes out perfectly executed. The menu works a bit differently than some other tasting menus, and changes regularly. Although you can order items a la carte by course, you can also opt for the "Let's try everything" should you desire the full experience.

I have to admit I was a bit skeptical since some dishes sounded more appealing to me than others, but this option is well worth it. I was pleasantly surprised by plates I didn't think would appeal, and ended up liking almost every one that came out. Another splurge that should be considered is the addition of the "Fly Blind" pairing option. In total we got 6 or 7 wines to compliment the food, and each matched impeccably. If you are looking to  moderate more, you can also get wine by the glass, or a cocktail from the "Classics" or Fancy Classics"  list, which included higher quality liquors such as the "Fancy Bobby Burns" (made with Dalmore 18 year single malt).

With enough accolades certain restaurants often end up with a bit of a haughty attitude- but Bastion is not one of them. Truly humble for the level of quality, it is definitely worth visiting Bastion when in Nashville.

Lauded, praised, extolled, glorified, Bern's has become the deity of dining experiences.  Every time I mention a visit to Tampa, I'm often asked, "Have you tried Bern's?"  No joke, this has happened at least 6 times.  Now typically I'm the type who tends to find most steakhouses are identical copies of each other, often competent and guaranteed a well cooked hunk of meat, but usually indiscernible from each other with the small variance in their exorbitant price tag or wine list.
