Good, but rarely great, and frequently less enthralling for me than an innovative gastro-fusion restaurant that really pushes the boundaries of culinary dining.  So it definitely took some coaxed before I finally was willing to try "the steakhouse that will change your mind."

I have to admit, I have never been more wrong...

Bern's is the Disneyland of steakhouse, unparalleled in its decadence.  From start to finish, the entire meal is a masterful presentation, culminating in a superlative overall experience.
The main parlor looks like it stepped straight out of the Haunted Mansion, complete with gilded paintings, a curving staircase, and velvet thrones for patrons to wait in.  After waiting, even with a reservation, for a couple of minutes, they lead diners through the facility, to their personal table, which is likely in a unique room.  

Wine can be chosen by the glass, or the bottle, and the"book" of options definitely will make even the snobbiest of wine enthusiasts salivate.  The beer menu is better than average, but definitely could use some work, and Bern's also has cocktails for those craving a classic libation like a Blood and Sand.  Entrees come with a soup and salad, and in addition to the renowned steaks, they do offer seafood, poultry, and vegetarian options.  The french onion soup so often revered I found to be quite average, although the salad was a bit better.  Perhaps it was the vanilla macadamia dressing, but I also really appreciated the array of fresh items from avocado slices to shredded carrots, and of course the mountain of freshly grated cheese didn't hurt either. I'm not going to say it was innovative, but it was competent.

Personally, I opted to forgo the steak tradition to try a lamb risotto with lamb sausage special.  I swear one day I will get to the steaks, but I am a sucker for risotto.  It turned out to be a magnificent choice, indulgent shredded meat and slices of sausage atop a luscious, and al dente risotto, with some orange zest and sweet onions to enhance the flavor of the lamb.  It also paired quite well the the 2010 Hess Select Pinot Noir, which had notes of red berries and caramel.  Together it quelled some of the spiciness of the entrée, and managed to absorb some flavors from the dish as well in a perfect harmony.

After completing the main room dining experience and closing out my bill, I was given a tour of the kitchens and wine cellar (claimed to be the largest restaurant wine cellar in the Universe).  I was flummoxed about how much work their empire takes.  From owning metal work facilities to create their countertops, to the over 100 years old coffee bean roaster that they still use, to the fresh sprouts their grow in their kitchens to top each salad...they run like a well-oiled machine.  Just watching the meat cutter work or the staff pirouette around each other becomes like watching a fine ballet performance.  

Finally I made my way up the stairs to the dessert room, where I was given a private booth near the piano player.   After quite a bit of indecision, I went with the sampler, so that I could try a small bite of several of their famous dishes.  Truthfully this was probably the biggest letdown of the evening for me, as I didn't really think anything was particularly remarkable, with the exception of their macadamia ice cream.   It was the singular saving grace with a creamy mouthfeel and some toasted nuts for texture.  Glad that I tried it, but not sure I'd save room for dessert next time.  They were all perfectly well executed, but they lacked a bit of creativity I had been hoping for, and the bit of vanilla cheesecake was just plain bland.

Overall, with the exception of my dessert disappointment, I would consider this one of the best steakhouse experiences I have ever encountered.  Their meticulous attention to detail, the spectacular services, and the overall quality of their food just can't be beat.  So mark a couple of hours off on the appointment book, make a reservation, and come indulge in an absolutely decadent Bern's experience.  It really is as good as everyone says.

Before coming to New Orleans I had read online that this was a great breakfast place.  Not really close to the main touristy areas, my friends and I followed my GPS to find it and at first thought maybe we had entered the wrong address.  From the outside, it seemed like an older building without much to offer, let alone a quality meal.  How quickly I learned not to judge a book by it's cover!  Inside was cozy and filled with quaint Southern flair.  The menu boasted lots of tantalizing choices, so of course we each had to order something different so we could try as much as possible!

DRINKS:
- Bloody Marys were well made and a nice start to the morning.
- Coffee was a bit watery and nothing out of the ordinary. 

STARTERS:  
- The praline bacon was a scrumptious (albeit not for the healthy eater) balance of sweet and salty with a thick gooey glaze on crisp slabs of bacon.  
- Calas (fried rice fritters) were different and something fun to try, but I thought they were a bit too dry

MAIN DISHES FOR BREAKFAST:
- The duck waffle was huge with a pile of whipped sweet potato and duck that was not only visually interesting, but also really unique.  Taste wise though it wasn't anything overly fantastic though.  My friend did however love the pepper jelly it came with (personally I'm not a spicy fan).
- The shrimp and grits was the perfect savory start to the day covered in a thick brown sauce and the shrimp were large and fresh tasting. 
- Fried green tomatoes were tender perfection in the redneck breakfast.
- Hands down though our favorite dish was an egg, spinach combo with fried ipswitch clams.   A spectacular combination of flavors and textures, utterly delicious!

   Not everything was incredible, but was definitely lots of wonderful dishes and I look forward to returning for another Southern breakfast!  Be warned they don't take reservations, so you may have to wait a little bit if they're full!

A much closer to home version than the Figueres counterpart, The Dali Museum in St. Petersburg is worth checking out, at least once. While the museum in Spain boasts golden loaves of bread stuck into the walls and eggs adorning the turrets of the museum's castle corners to deliver the whimsy, the St. Pete museum counters with a 4 story, massive glass egg, boasting spectacular views of the harbor.

As far as museums go, the work is somewhat limited since the focus is of course Dali. However, they do often offer another rotating artist to fill the floor. On my most recent visit, this was the equally impressive M. C. Escher whose harmonious blend of art and mathematical precision was nothing short of breathtaking. However, no pictures were allowed in the exhibit (even with the flash off) since the collection was on loan.

While I do really appreciate Dali for his unique perspective and I respect his contribution to the art community, I have to say that relative to the cost of admission and the size of the building itself, I found the Dali section a tad underwhelming. Considering the magnitude and scope of the museum, you really can only actually view Dali's work on half of one floor. The free audio guides do help to provide further insight on each piece though, and I was grateful for the information. It also allowed me to move at my pace and linger where desired, rather than having to move along with the group as the guided tour does so I'd strongly recommend considering it.

After viewing the art, you can head down to enjoy a bite from the cafe on the first floor, and I'd suggest a walk in the back too. The hedge maze isn't particularly challenging since there are no wrong steps and you go in and out the same way, but it is still fun to walk through. I also loved sitting on the melting clock bench while watching the wind blow the paper bands on the wishing tree. Oh and be sure to pose for a picture with the giant mustache. Sure it's cheesy, but it's a lot of fun too.

Before you leave be sure to check out the massive gift shop. Sure you don't really have a choice if you want to exit, but they've got everything from puzzles to mustaches on a stick, and it can add to the day's enjoyment. So give it a shot at least once when you're in the area.  The Dali Museum makes for a great way to spend an afternoon in St. Pete.

Need a jolt of caffeine to get the day going? Looking for a socially acceptable way to have ice cream for breakfast? Want to grab some tea while you check your email? Drip Affogato Bar is serving up coffee, tea, ice cream, WiFi, of course (as the name would imply), Affogato-style coffee-drenched ice cream.

The traditional Italian dessert-beverage hybrid, includes a scoop or two of chilly vanilla gelato/ice cream topped off with piping hot espresso. However, Drip offers an additional assortment of less-classic options. You can order one of their pre-made "desserts" combinations, or you can also build your own. Get creative and select your preferred flavor of ice cream with toppings like crushed pistachio or a stroopwafel cookie, add a drizzle of caramel, chocolate, or condensed milk, and select your desired drip, either espresso, matcha, chai, etc. Another great option is the flight, which lends itself well to the indecisive, and comes with 4 different versions of their desserts.

We went with the classique (crushed pistachio, maldon sea salt, stroopwafel, and espresso) and the bananas foster (caramel drizzle, brûléed banana, whip cream, and espresso), and both favored the foster. While I prefer other places in New Orleans for a straight up chai or morning cold brew, Drip Affogato Bar does make for a break from the norm with a unique concept.

Come in for an early morning treat, or later in the day for post meal dessert, either way you can't go wrong. Drip Affogato Bar is a great option to combine energy-giving coffee with a side dose of sugar rush.

Informative, interactive, and incredibly impressive, The Sazerac House is a well-executed museum and distillery worth visiting in New Orleans.  Whether you love cocktails, or just because you're looking to learn a bit more about how different liquors or bitters are made, be sure to book your reservations online in advance. Ignoring the hand grenades and frozen daiquiris that permeate Bourbon, they pay homage to the classics like the Ramos Gin Fizz and namesake Sazerac. 

Check in by the door upon arrival, before proceeding to the top for a self-guided tour. How long you read and/or choose to engage with the exhibits will determine how much time you spend overall. With several floors of exhibits, recipes, and yes, samples as well, they not only present historical facts, but in addition, offer up a dash of flair. Digital bartenders await to serve up your (virtual) drink of choice, coasters become tokens for interactive storybooks, and touchscreen monitors offer recipes based on your drinking palette preferences.

At the present entrance cost of completely free, it is hard to beat the caliber of experience you get in return. The Sazerac House is one stop that any history buff or libation aficionado should not miss out on, and even if you aren't, you may still find it enjoyable and informative.

Does Angry Chair have the most comfortable tap room in town where you want to sit for hours sampling the entire tap list? Nope. Are you guaranteed to find a wide variety of styles that will satisfy everyone in your party? Nope. Is parking plentiful and easy? Nope. Can you growler the more coveted varietals? Usually not.

So in spite of all this, what is the appeal? Simply put Angry Chair makes some of the best beers in the country. Whether you're looking for a mouth puckering sour or a dense pastry stout, Angry Chair can and does knock it out of the park. Producing some of the most flavorful and unique barrel-aged beers I've ever tried, Angry Chair sets the beer game bar high. Burkitshi, an Imperial Sweet stout with cacao, toasted coconut, and Japanese sea salt remains one of my penultimate favorites, rich and laden with flavor it reminds me of an Almond Joy. Another winner, Barrel Aged Popinski with Peanut Butter & Marshmallow tastes like a fluffernutter. A bottle we got lucky enough to enough to happen upon by pure happenstance, Bourbon Barrel Dave's Barleywine, had an excellent malt backbone and tasted like toffee.

The taproom itself is trendy and industrial, with cool metal bone seats that are more decorative than comfortable. Funky art scattered about, and of course the many references to "angry" chairs make for a laid back atmosphere. While by no means a spots bar, they do have a couple of televisions as well should you want to watch the game with a cold brew. Be warned though, the space itself isn't particularly large, so it may not be the best spot for a big group (although occasionally you can snag one of the coveted few more sizable tables).

While unfortunately I don't live close enough to synchronize my visits for every release, Angry Chair is my "must do" brewery every time I'm in Tampa, just in the hopes that I will strike the jackpot and pop in when they've just released something sinfully delicious. If it isn't already on your brewery bucket list make sure to put it near the top, Angry Chair produces the kind of stuff that both well seasoned beer geeks and novice drinkers will dream about.

A girl walks into a bar right as a band prepares to play, and goes to take a look at the drink menu. Vintage and seasonal cocktail options? Check. Interesting ingredients (like eucalyptus or Thai spice bitters)? Check. Then the music starts, upbeat and jazzy, and it feels fitting for the French Quarter. So she decides she should order a drink...

Quite some time later and I must admit, I was sold on 21st Amendment at La Louisiane. The drinks are solid, the atmosphere is lively without being raucous, and the music is exquisite. While it is a more intimate venue, seating routinely becomes available as the crowd ebbs and flows, making it a comfortable spot to hang out for a spell. 

Come with friends, come for a date, or come alone just to hang out at the bar, indulge in a cocktail, and enjoy the performance. 21st Amendment at La Louisiane offers a seductive scene with the winning ingredients to make a delightful night out in The Big Easy.

A small city unto itself, Gaylord Opryland is a sight to behold on par with some of the larger resorts in Las Vegas. A conference center and hotel, Gaylord Opryland offers ample walking paths, multiple restaurants, a river boat ride, a salon and spa, and now a water park as well. It is quite the labyrinth and is easy to get lost despite the signposts peppered throughout, although this often makes for the best exploration. While the hotel isn't located in the heart of downtown Nashville, it isn't a terribly far drive either.

Taking a stroll through the atriums is like being in a tropical oasis. There are multiple waterfalls, streams, and lush foliage. While I have no idea what any of it has to do with Nashville itself or its history, it is quite lovely. The strategically placed oversized guitars feel a bit out of place, and yet seem more authentic to the local flavor. Compared to Gaylord Palms in Orlando which actually has decor centered around Florida (Evergaldes, Key West, and Saint Augustine), I felt less of the connection to the city here. However, I can't deny that the hotel is still quite picturesque. Visit around Christmas, and the entire hotel is bedecked in holly and strings of twinkling lights as well.

Like any major hotel, Gaylord Opryland  comes with its pros and cons. The parking is high on my annoyance list, because although it is ample, it is pretty steep extra on top of the cost of your actual room. Whether you are a short term visitor, or a hotel guest, expect to pay around $32 a day. Also the restaurants are plentiful (think Italian, Mexican, sushi, and a grill), but none are particularly great. They do have Starbucks on premises if you are short on time, but walk or drive across the street to Nashville Coffees for a better selection and more interesting options.

If you are staying on business or at the hotel for a conference, the conference center is massive and quite convenient. There is more than enough space for an exhibition hall and smaller rooms for more intimate talks. WiFi is available throughout the area if you need to sneak away to get work done on your laptop. Speaking of the WiFi, you can also connect throughout the grounds or in the hotel rooms, and they have a direct wired connection if you need something faster, which makes a better choice if you need to connect to a VPN or are on a call.

The rooms themselves are comfortable, although certainly some sections are better than others. For example, a room in Magnolia may have you in a fairly basic look (your standard outdated hotel) and a view of a courtyard/pool, whereas in Delta the rooms seem to be a bit more modern, and if you're lucky you can get a view of one of the domed areas, which makes for great people watching.

Worth visiting at least once, even if you aren't a hotel guest! At the very least make a stunning venue to get some steps in...

Honey + water + yeast= mead

What seems simple enough, a historic combination standing the test of the centuries is still a popular beverage in modern times. However, Garagiste is not your average mazer, and the meads they produce are anything but ordinary. Well balanced Reboog Vitis is an elegant take on a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Other varietals include adjuncts ranging from vanilla beans to maple syrup to raspberries. If that weren't enough to entice, then they add barrel aged versions that add additional complexity from Madeira to Cognac.

Many of the meads take on almost a wine like quality, balancing honey laced sweetness with a biting acidity. For those unfamiliar with meads, or those just wanting to try more of their masterful libations, I highly suggest grabbing a flight. The menu is ever changing, and often includes limited offerings that may not be available otherwise. Each mead is quite distinctive and may range from fairly dry to on par with a Sauternes. They do offer some snacks as well, which can provide balance to an otherwise saccharine tasting.

Truly one of the best meaderies to be found, Garagiste is undoubtedly worth a visit when in Tampa. Even those that think they may not enjoy sweeter drinks may find themselves a convert.

Okay, I'll admit it. I may enjoy an art project here or there but I have zero woodworking (or power tool) experience. Zero. Zilch. Nonexistent. I am also pretty klutzy in general, so the idea of making anything using sharp objects vaguely terrifies me. That being said, the Florida School of Woodwork in Tampa is outstanding. A valuable resource for fledgling newbies (like myself) and for those who are more advanced.

I signed up for the cutting board course with my mother. Apart from both leaving with all our fingers and toes present and accounted for, we learned a lot and had fun too. Our instructor walked us through the entire process, and allowed us to flex our creative muscles (within the scope of the intended project). We glued, sanded, cut, and other far more technical terms I cannot pretend to recall. Even better, we left with two beautiful and functional cutting boards (complete with my own pyrography pen design) and a lot of great memories.

Book in advance for an afternoon, or even a weekend workshop, their classes are outstanding. Very well organized, and safe too. It is also a delight to work alongside instructors who are not only knowledgeable but truly passionate about their craft.

As St. Pete continues to develop and thrive, it is really nice to see the influx of some great bars and restaurants.  The Mill is one of my brunch go to places when in the area, offering some of the more innovative items I've encountered. 

First, you should know that they do not take reservations, so if you would like a table, I'd highly recommend arriving early.  The only tiny niggle in an otherwise perfect plan, is that you cannot order a cocktail in the city before a certain time, so although you may be guaranteed a seat, their delightful libations may be out of your reach.  I actually first tried some from this restaurant at a cocktail competition in Miami, and they definitely know their stuff. So for the drinks at least, you may want to make a return visit. 

As for the food, I typically struggle with what to order as the changing menu is filled with tantalizing dishes. Typically I end up sharing with the table so as to increase the number of options I can sample.  If they have it let me just say that the Vegetarian Crack cakes are sure to hook you whether or not you actually are a vegetarian.  A combination of zucchini and squash pancakes, topped with preserved lemon crema, guava onion butter and a sweet pea salad, they make me believe that I could give up meat and still be blissfully unaware of what I'm missing. Thankfully this item seems to be a menu constant.  Although the sweet options change too often to recommend a particular choice, I'd like to note that options like the banana bread french toast with rum raisin compote and coconut dulce are worth ruining your diet for. Although not every selection is total nirvana, you're more likely to find hits than misses, so be sure to give them additional chances if your first experience seems to be a bit lackluster.

Whether you are a local seeking for your regular breakfast place, or a visitor looking for a high caliber new choice, The Mill is undoubtedly the restaurant you want.

Wine bar meets restaurant, it sounds like a perfect match.  

After doing some research, I discovered that this is a Illinois based chain, where they produce their own wines, and then serve them in the restaurant as well.  If you want a table, I would recommend making reservations in advance, or just resigning to sitting at the bar.

 The wine tasting room is right at the entrance, and is definitely a lovely piece of tasting room eye candy. Style-wise it competes with any number of higher-end wineries.  Wine tastings are fairly inexpensive, and ranges from $7-$12.  They do seem to offer quite a broad range of wines, with an especially large number of sweet wines.  Personally, I decided to spring for the "Lux" flight and found almost none of them to my liking, but everyone has different preferences.  I don't think there is anything wrong with cheaper wine, and in fact, I believe there are many great wines that are relatively inexpensive.  That being said, there just wasn't much complexity, and there seemed to be unpleasant lingering aftertastes with many that I tried.  I also didn't appreciate that my entire tasting was a sales pitch for my server, during which time I was forced to endure endless droning about the perks. 

When I finally got around to dining, the menu seemed on par with your average chain.  They have a variety of options, and large portions.   The food is quite competent, and will definitely satisfy hunger.  Cooper's Hawk isn't organic, gastronomic, or tapas-style, so don't expect it to be.  Also, yes, they only serve their own wines, but this makes sense to me considering that is the whole point of the venture.  Additionally there are some cocktails if you really are not feeling wine.    

The pretzel bread that is served before the meal is a bit more interesting than the standard crusty Italian bread loaf.  It is a large soft, pillowy bun of pretzel dough, which can then be slathered with the slightly sweet butter.  Also, I did receive excellent service throughout my meal. 

Cooper's Hawk is not the place to come for wine experts, nor for a truly gourmet dining experience.  That being said, it is a fun girls night, or a unique venue to go with friends or on a date.

Commander's Palace is one of those spots so often raved about I felt I simply couldn't miss dinner here for an authentic and tasty New Orleans meal.  It's a nice excuse to get dressed up, and as they will remind you when you make a reservation, jackets are required for men.  The decor was charming and beautiful (although the many stuffed birds were a bit strange), and the service was without a doubt, completely stellar!  Our waiter was friendly, full of suggestions and quick without being overbearing.
       Despite the great company, staff and ambiance though, I have to admit that by the end of the meal I left a bit disappointed.  I know it's an institution and everyone loves it.  The food wasn't bad by any means, but over the multiple courses I just found myself leaving feeling like it was nothing special.
      The gumbo was warm and hearty, but I had better elsewhere while in New Orleans.  I had never tried turtle soup before, but I figured if I was going to this would be the place.  Maybe it was my lack of knowledge, but it seemed a bit bland, the sherry too overpowering, and it lacked much actual turtle.  The entrees were completely forgettable.  The best part of the meal (apart from the really great service) was the dessert.  The bananas foster wasn't the most amazing I could ever imagine, but it was a really fun tableside presentation and a nice palate-cleaning finish to the meal.  The bread pudding souffle was decent but again, nothing so epic I'd have to rush back.
         Perhaps my expectations were too high, but I really did have much better meals elsewhere while in New Orleans.  It wasn't a price thing, and I did have a good experience with everything but the actual cuisine.  I wanted to leave in a food-coma induced euphoria with lasting memories of a magic meal that opened me up to all that the city had to offer.  This is a great way to get to try lots of traditional dishes, but don't expect to necessarily be blown away with incredible execution or taste.

Oh Cigar City. You lured me in with your beers and special releases at Hunahpu Day, tempted me with rotating taps in your cider and meadery, and now, a brewpub? You're on fire.

Reservations can be made online, although there is seating at the bar if you can snag a spot as well. While the brewpub does offer some of Cigar City's brewery beers, they also have a selection of their own unique beers as well. Not only can you drink a cold brew there, but you can also fill a growler to take home later. In addition to the standard Cigar City fan memorabilia, you may also be able to snag a bottle of something special (read "rare") from the fridge on your way out.

Not really in the mood for beer? No problem, they have wine and cocktails as well. You can even combine the two with their beer cocktails. 

Feeling hungry? The food menu is quite varied, with some Latin-flair and plantains thrown in for good measure. Burgers are offered a couple of ways, or you can chart your own destiny and choose the toppings. The Cuban (Ham, mojo pork, Fiorucci salami, Swiss, mustard) is a great version of the classic sandwich, and the upgrade to yucca fries with aioli is well worth it. The Chicken Saltimbocca delivers grilled chicken breast wrapped in prosciutto, fresh sage and smoked gouda, served over a wild mushroom risotto with a choice of vegetable. I thoroughly appreciated the addition of the sage, and the creaminess of the risotto. They also made a very tender Ropa Vieja (a slow stewed flank steak with peppers, onions, and tomatoes served over black beans and rice, with sweet plantains). For dessert, Hunahpu's Imperial Flourless Chocolate Cake is quite dense, but the acidity of the berries cuts through some of the richness nicely. I wouldn't say all the dishes are the best I've ever had, but they are solidly enjoyable and better than your typically bar fare.

The venue is very laid back, with a cool use of Cigar City beer cans and barrels turned into lighting fixtures. Definitely a cool place to grab a bite with friends while watching a game, and I'm sure we will be back to see what other bottles they've got stashed in that fridge for sale.

Bakery Bar is the spot to come for doberge, and they've also got a solid collection of cocktails, non-alcoholic beverages, and non-sweet, regular dishes as well. Never heard of doberge? Neither had I before our trip to New Orleans. The basic premise is that one takes thin layers of cake and slices into seven layers, sandwiched by six layers of pudding, custard, or ganache, and topped off with fondant or icing. The overall effect is a balance of dry and wet ingredients that essentially just adds lightness to a more dense cake- plus it is pretty easy on the eyes as well, making for a fairly Instagram-worthy dessert (I'm looking at you Rainbow Surprise Wedding Cake).

For the indecisive, the Petit Fours (aka Dobites) can be a great way to sample some of the flavor combinations before committing to an entire slice or order of the cake. However, be warned this method does mean a higher proportion of the outer fondant to actual cake meaning each bite is substantially sweeter than the ratio you'd get from a normal slice. Carrot Cake was our winner, along with the Red Velvet Elvis (red velvet cake, peanut butter, banana pudding, and peanut butter bacon icing). The drinks and other dishes can provide some balance if you're dining in. There is French truck coffee, wine, beer, and even cocktails. The Moneypenny (blended scotch, smoky scotch, creme de banana, and walnut liqueur) was one of our favorites. As for the savories, in a town filled with grits, theirs was one of the better versions we encountered. They also have a brunch menu on the weekends, with some more interesting than your average options.

So whether a local looking to place an order for an event, or a visitor looking to satisfy your sweet tooth, consider checking out Debbie Does Doberge at Bakery Bar. They certainly have cornered the doberge market, and they've got a solid happy hour as well.

Chaatable is Maneet Chauhan's take on Indian Street Food. While I'm highly skeptical the street food actually looks and tastes anything like these elevated plates, it is so sensational, that it is irrelevant. 

The flavors, the colors. Every dish and cocktail is a delight for the senses, managing to be not only visually appealing but a resplendent treat for touch, taste, and olfaction. Consider ordering tapas-style to get the most off the menu. Thankfully it is broken up into sections to make the decision process a bit easier: snacks, cold apps, hot apps, mains, and veggies. My favorite drink and dishes are the following:
- Cocktail: The "Sunshine Daydream" is made up of Maneet's Chai, Cardamom, Egg White, and Honeysuckle Vodka. It is dangerously easy drinking,
- Itty Bitty Bites: The "O.M.Ghee" is a tiny but flavorful snack of toasted toasted in clarified butter, along with curry leaves and chaat masala. 
- Cold Apps: The "Puff Puff Pass" is made up of moong daal, potatoes, semolina puffs, and a tangy sweet & sour yogurt. Pomegranate seeds add an extra burst of balance. Pop in your mouth in a single bite to enjoy the full combination of the ingredients.
- Hot Apps: The "Hand it Over!" are Jason Pollock worthy plating of samosas, AKA spiced potato hand pie samosa chaat, served with green peas, and a tamarind and mint chutney
- Flashy Mains: The O.G. stands for "Original Gravy" and is actually a traditional butter chicken sauce. Get with half a roasted chicken for the typical take on the dish, or go with paneer for a delightful cheesy twist. We definitely did need more rice though to fully soak it all up 
- Dessert: The "Full on Falooda" is not your typical banana split, instead you get a pistachio-cardamom kulfi sundae, with saffron rabri, and rose noodles. The balance is exceptional, and the noodles add a great texture.
- Dessert: The "That's What Cheese Said" is a beautiful marriage of two of my favorite Indian desserts...a carrot halwa and rasmalai sweet cheese dumplings. Stacked into a beautiful tower, this dish is like a more exotic, distant cousin of carrot cake.

The ambiance parallels the food and is enticing and vibrant. There is something to look at in every direction from the colorful wall of bangles to the hanging umbrellas. The bar is a tapestry of ornately carved panels.

While I'm sure you can find more traditional Indian dishes elsewhere, Chaatable's spin on things definitely left a good taste in my mouth. It is something different not just in Nashville, but across the board.

The trendier and a bit funkier relative of Bern's, SideBerns manages to maintain Bern's quality while ampying up the creativity.  The atmosphere is sophisticated, and they have a happy hour that can't be beat from 5-7PM.  

On a recent visit, I managed to snag a bar seat, and I ordered a couple of the happy hour plates at $6 each, and a Violet Revolver cocktail for only $5.  First up was the "tofie pasta" with game bird confit and herbs.  The pasta was shaped a bit like worms, but tasted phenomental in a light and savory tomato-based sauce.    Also, the seared scallops with radish confit and green onion butter were beautifully presented and the two massive scallops were impeccably prepared.  I have to say, I was very impressed, and found that these were more than enough to satisy my hunger.  No need to order anything else.  Yet somehow, I still managed to make room for the green apple mille feuille.  A traditional French dessert with layers of paper-thin crepes and crème, Sideberns made it a touch more creative by using almost an applesauce-type filling between each layer.  It lightened the dish, and managed to keep from becoming cloying with a slight tartness from the green apples.  They also included Pernod ice cream and ginger meringue, which added additional texture and complexity.

Overall, I found SideBern's a less stuffy, yet no less impressive, counter to Bern's.  With sublime cocktails, excellent service, and a killer execution of unique dishes, it is truly deserving of high praise.  I really enjoyed the scene, and I definitely would recommend coming in for happy hour too.  Looking forward to trying the tasting menu as well (when I can eventually abstain from eating the enire day beforehand)!

Okay yes it is right off Bourbon Street. But wait, don't give up just yet. Tucked just off the main touristy drag is a true gem for absinthe aficionados, and for those that may be completely novices to the green fairy. La Belle Epoque literally translates to "the Beautiful Age" and pays homage to the period around the twilight of the 19th century. Meanwhile the Belle Epoque in New Orleans revives the glamour and decadence of the era.

Whether craving a libation, or looking to dine in Belle Epoque is prepared. The drink menu offers quite a few cocktails, single pours of absinthe, as well as tasting options for those looking to sample a mix of varieties. The staff are quite knowledgeable, and more than happy to make a suggestion for new comers. Among the many hedonistic edible offerings, the Parisian Gnocchi with lump crab, sweet potato, chilis and mead were truly one of the best plates I've had all year. I would have ordered multiple servings had they not sold out- be sure to get in your request as soon as you are seated. True to their name, the "ugly dumplings" may not be much to look at, but make up for their humble appearance with a generosity of umami flavors. They had quite a few other dishes, such as the sumptuous raclette cheese that was melted straight off the wheel, and a crispy duck breast glazed with spicy honey. Sadly we missed out on the chicken foie-lipop, but that just gives me all the more reason to return. They've also got a later happy hour for night owls looking to keep the evening going, and offer a "baptised in butter burger" with swiss cheese, tomato jam, and crispy onion rings or a "divine mac and cheese" along with some other delightful cocktail specials.

Belle Epoque sets the standard for absinthe enjoyment. Truly a delightful space for date nights and for meet ups with friends. Also, a great way to celebrate any occasion (even if it is just that you made it through another weekday).

Certain cities have their staple dishes that it is a crime not to get. In Chicago it is the deep dish pizza. In Philadelphia it is the Philly Cheesesteak. In Liège it is the waffle. When in Nashvile, the hot ticket item is the hot chicken. Now whether you are a fan or Hattie B's or a Prince's loyalist is a matter of personal debate, but either way, it is something you should try at least once.

Hattie B's has quite a few locations, and each and every one seems to involve a line. Is it annoying? Yes, but if you want to consume your hot chicken on the spot, you need to just queue up and accept that it is what it is. Getting a table may be tricky, especially with larger parties, but with a bit of luck or some questionable ethics, you can persevere. If you don't care where you dine and even possess enough restraint to wait till you are home/at your hotel, call ahead and take your order to go and avoid the waiting game. At this particular location parking is fairly limited, although there are several lots you can pay for just behind the restaurant.

Chicken ranges from the mild to the "Shut the Cluck Up!!!" level of heat. Personally I liked the tenders, although you can also get breast/wing quarters with a choice of white or dark meat as well. Should you go with the tenders, they come three to an order and you can choose to mix the "heat level"  if you want to try a range. Each plate comes with two sides, as well as bread and pickles. Options are the fairly ubiquitous Southern classics including things like collard greens, baked beans, and mac and cheese. It is all about personal preference here...

Definitely consider trying the hand squeezed lemonade to offset the heat of the chicken. They have also got iced tea (sweet and unsweetened), as well as the typical fountain soft drinks, and beer. Yes you can get refills as much as desired (well at least for the non-beer beverages).

So come and do what everybody else is doing- hot chicken is the exception to the "don't be peer pressured into doing it" rule.

Disclaimer: If you are the type of person who likes to complain, or who doesn't like listening to others complain, it is probably better to take your order to go. Lines may include, but are not limited to: people smoking, people whining, people who have no concept of personal space, people who are very drunk and border on unruly, and people talking way too loud on their phone

An upscale option for innovative twists using more typical New Orleans ingredients, Atchafalaya Restaurant should be included on any New Orleans itinerary. While it isn't located in the more touristy district, it is an easy Uber/Lyft trip that is well worth the journey. 

The interior is intimate, warm, and charming, in what feels like you're sitting to supper in what was once someone's living room. They offer dinner as well as brunch, and although many menu items rotate, others tend to remain as regulars. Among our favorites are the Free-Form Blue Crab Raviolo and the Home Place Pastures Pork Loin Schnitzel (served with apple and cabbage slaw, crispy black-eyed peas, Wisconsin cheese curds, and a mornay sauce). The sauce is lick the plate clean kind of outstanding...

Also, I'll come right out and say that I tend to be among the subset that finds the funk of blue cheese appealing, so for me, no matter how stuffed I am, there is always room for the blue cheese flan. It is even better than anticipated, although the tang of the cheese is much more subtle than might be expected. That being said, my takeaway is that even if blue cheese isn't typically your thing, consider giving it a shot in this form.

For a modern take on Southern cuisine, Atchafalaya Restaurant is a massive success. Make reservations in advance, as it continues to gain renown and will fill up otherwise.

New Orleans does many things well; Creole and Cajun (which are apparently not the same thing) cuisine, beautiful architecture, and cocktails all play to the city's strengths. In a town known for it's revelry you find everything from virulent $3 punches and Hand Grenades to more upscale selections. Sazerac? Hurricane? Vieux Carré? Ramos Gin Fizz? Arnaud's French 75? In a town rich with cocktail history and culture it can be difficult to decide where to go to indulge.

Cure serves up the best libations in the city. They are less about showy presentation and more about the seamless blending of liquors and adjuncts to create a smooth and well crafted masterpiece. Typically the menu skews more towards classics and variations on classics. However they do them very well, and they are more than capable of mixing something ideally suited to each patron's palate. I've been several times over the years, and each visit has led to absolute satisfaction. I appreciate their creativity, and their ability to take an ingredient and a flavor profile, and then to turn it into something captivating. Personally I enjoy just sidling up to the bar, and soaking up all the information I can from their affable mixologists, although the outdoor patio is a lovely place to hang out with friends as well when they are a bit too busy to stop and chat. 

While I know every has their own preferences I'll share just a couple of my cocktail successes there. During my most recent trip, I was thoroughly impressed with the balance of their Sidecar. Moreover, I found their punch of the day to be bright and refreshing with rum, sparkling wine, red wine, strawberries and citrus. Also tried the Dark Passenger (a Sidecar variation with the flavor of lemon curd, raisin, and almond) which reminded me of cross between lemon custard and sticky toffee pudding. Kind of sweet and sour with maple syrup. On another visit, I tried The Peripheral (a take on the classic flip with grape-based spirits and Holland style gun with notes of coconut and cocoa). I've never had anything quite like it, I got some nutmeg and allspice, almond, and almost a hint of cucumber. Somehow the combination worked well. Color was fairly light but it tasted like a dark and winter-y cocktail. In addition, the hot buttered rum on special around the holidays was one of the best I've ever tried.

If you can make it from 5-7 Cure does offer happy hour specials, although the cocktails included are the more standard options. However, their superlative Sazerac is nothing to scoff at, and is so smooth you won't even realize how strong it is until it's too late. Also included on the happy hour menu are a small selection of bar bites. If you'd prefer to stick to the full menu though, they do have an eclectic array of snacks and a variety of cheeses to pair with the libations.  

Unwind, sip, and find the Cure to what ails you.

It was our last night in New Orleans and after a somewhat victorious visit to the casino Harrah's we decided that food was the next step - especially since we had a verrrrrrrry early flight the next morning.

We had been passing Daisy Dukes throughout our time in New Orleans and decided it was finally time to try it.

Daisy Dukes is quite magical. Breakfast is served all day (love!). They're open 24 hours (swoon!). There's never a wait and the staff are kind. And basically - they gotchu - whatever you need  - they gotchu.

I ordered a plate of blackened fish - and it was great. The rest of the group had a salad, a biscuit etc. The food wasn't mind blowing - but it was definitely good - especially considering the time that we ordered it. Our waiter was helpful and patient. We had a clean booth. And the price was also very reasonable.

If you happen to be in New Orleans - and need food at very early or very late hours - just make your way over to Daisy Dukes. 

Trust.

It's been well over a year now since I first encountered One Eyed Jacks during JazzFest. Crazy how time flies. My husband played here with a David Bowie Cover Band last year- but we also managed to catch two other shows here during our time.

During our visits, I appreciated the space was multi-level, that there were two bars, that there was some seating throughout the space, and that I could grab my own water. My favorite aspect of this space though - was their diverse line-up of acts. Jazzfest always brings variety - but after browsing through One Eyed Jacks' website - their show calendar was pleasantly full of a mix of performances.

We came here during a particularly hectic time in New Orleans  - so it would be interesting to see what One Eyed Jacks is like on a more low-key night. 

Trust.

We both knew that we wanted to avoid any lines for dinner, and we both knew that food should be manifested soon. Hanger is never a good look on anyone. 

My husband spied Cafe Sbisa and we decided to step inside. Instantly - the cool air hit us. It was a welcome relief to the humidity outside. The staff were exceptional and made sure to get us seated right away. Our waiter was professional, patient, and helpful with all of our questions. 

My husband ordered steak topped with crab - and I had the blackened fish with a side of asparagus. The fish was seasoned beautifully - and the asparagus was incredible. My husband also thoroughly enjoyed his steak.  We both finished everything. 

Cafe Sbisa's atmosphere was magical. Our water glasses were refilled consistently throughout the night, we were able to relax and enjoy our meal, and each staff member that we encountered, was exceptionally kind and personable. 

If you're looking for a classy - yet unpretentious meal in the city - with fantastic food and service - come here.  

Trust.

I couldn't have been more excited to stumble upon this darling wonderland on our humid explorative trek around Nashville.

I felt like we were experiencing a sliver of San Francisco at Kellie's healthy delectable oasis. I especially appreciated all of the gluten free options on her menu. I don't have a gluten allergy, but i always find myself having an easier time digesting things, when things happen to be gluten free.

Our first meal here we had the  Mediterranean Vegetarian Sandwich (sans feta cheese) on fresh Gluten free bread - consisting of eggplant, roasted red pepper, sun dried tomato, and freshly made pesto, and the Spinach Salad (sans feta cheese) consisting of spinach, dried cranberries, sliced almonds & balsamic vinaigrette. Kellie even went out of her way to replace the feta cheese with some additional vegetables like tomatoes and cucumbers. Both were excellent, reasonably priced at $6.00-$7.00 and you could taste the love embedded in each. We washed down both with A Matter of Taste's cold refreshing fruit tea.

We were so impressed with our experience at A Matter of Taste that we decided to venture out here again the following day. We decided to try their regularly rotating lunch specials. We went with the Pumpkin Brittle and Watermelon adorned salad, as well as their Fish Tacos. The salad was outstanding. A Matter of Taste makes their own salad dressing and you could tell. The fish tacos were also very flavorful. 

A Matter of Taste's eating area is intimate, but if you take a look in the back you can see their sprawling immaculate kitchen where all of the magic happens.

If you're looking for quality and healthy food for reasonable prices - A Matter of Taste is outstanding. I recommend them wholeheartedly. My only regret is not sampling one of their gluten free desserts - ranging from moist looking cupcakes to large rockin' cookies.

Trust.

Bliss.

Absolute bliss.

Thanks to Katie B's gushing recommendation - we joined her, Farrah A, and Tomas R at Bacchanal for the most delightful afternoon - full of chilled rosé, stunning cheese plates, and beautiful music. 

Sitting in the comforts of the shade beneath elegant overhanging trees - while beaming faces - enjoyed the enclosed oasis of fantastic wine and wonderful company - I felt abundantly thankful.

Bacchanal is worth the Uber ride. It's non-pretentious, full of great vibes, and it's always graced by lulling live music.

I recommend coming on the earlier side- since I've heard it does get busier later on in the early evening. But definitely don't sleep on this New Orleans gem. You could easily spend all day here.

Trust.

It was late. We were headed back to our hotel, when my husband spied some people devouring pizza slices. Our hotel plans were momentarily dashed - as we embarked on a new mission to hunt down after-hours pizza. We chased down some at Outlaw Pizza. We showed up just in time to buy their last slice.

My husband said the pizza was solid - in between taking big bites of his pepperoni slice, as we headed back to the hotel. Just then -we heard someone running up behind us. It was the gentleman from Outlaw Pizza who had sold us his last slice. He had run all the way from Outlaw Pizza to give my husband back his forgotten credit card.

Thank you Outlaw Pizza for saving the night - when it came to greasy evening sustenance and for allowing us to make future late night purchases for the rest of our stay in New Orleans.

Trust.

Desperate to bounce out of Bonabooooooo on our epic Tennessee adventure we scanned Yelp fervently on my dying Iphone for a hotel room.

With no battery and only seconds to spare - Club Hotel Inn came up on my phone screen and I just dialed. Their room rates were reasonable considering the busy week that we were inquiring about (CMA awards, Fanfare, as well as Bonnaroo all happening around the same time) and they had a room available that night.

We booked it. And then my phone died.

With no expectations -  we rolled up to Club Hotel in a dusty cab. Despite sporting unwashed clothes and hair, the staff were exceptionally friendly. We were led to spacious room with a comfortable bed, comfortable couch, big screen TV, a mini fridge, a microwave, and some standard toiletries. 

The first thing we did was shower. After washing off all of the Bonnaroo yuck - we began to explore the place. Club Hotel Inn not only has a convenient work-out area, but it also has a great outdoor pool area. Our second night there - we asked for a room with a balcony and were able to perch ourselves on it, read, and overlook the pool. So relaxing and such an exhilarating feeling after grueling Bonnaroo. 

Some of the exciting perks about Club-Hotel were their mini fridge and microwave, which allowed us grab some groceries and make some make-shift lunches for ourselves, their on-site laundry facilities - which allowed us to bring back clean smelling clothes for our journey home, the complimentary shuttle which took us back to the airport, and their complimentary wowing breakfast spread.

Each morning we would tiredly drag ourselves downstairs to indulge in a breakfast display that made our hearts beam. With a waffle maker on hand, hot eggs, sausages, homefries, cereal, muffins, bagels, fruit and more - we would go to town every morning - fueling ourselves up for mid-day pool lounging. Definitely key for those on a tight budget.

The only drawback for this place was the location. It's convenient if you want a spot near the airport - but if you want to go downtown - expect to pay about 25 dollars for a cab ride over there. Other than that - it was perfect for our needs and a much needed break before we headed back to SF.

Trust.

We'd heard from a number of in-the-know locals that The Bluebird was a sure thing for an intimate encounter with great musicians. 

On one of our last nights in the city we took a pricey cab out here for their open mic night. 

We were advised on the phone to arrive early, due to the intimate size of The Bluebird. Walking in around 6pm - we grabbed a table, just as two guitarists finished their set.

The whole place was full, so we were lucky to snag some seating. A waitress quickly came by to take our order. We ordered some sweet potato fries, the blackened sandwich and the chicken sandwich. The catfish sandwich was great. Spicy and bursting with taste.

The Bluebird Cafe is a big deal in Nashville. If you have the opportunity to play here - you savor it. All of the performers were so genuinely honored to be playing at such a love filled spot, in which people give their full attention to those playing. Everyone around the room appreciated the talent that glided around the room in smooth chords and octaves. 

While we had a great time here, I wasn't always fond of some of the more new-country ballads that were performed during the night, and preferred more of the closing soulful country stuff. I would definitely love to come here again, but would maybe try to go on a different night other than the open mic. A good time, but sometimes it's nice to know what kind of music to expect when you make a night of it.

Trust.

I felt so fancy in my silk dress and perched upon Virago's bar stool. 

Virago's interior design is jaw-droppingly sexy. From smooth-soft-to-the- touch wood accents. Sleek bamboo tables, low lounge-y booths, to come hither lighting. Their newly added bar rooftop - is just as stunning as the evening Nashville view from it. 

It was our first night of vacation, and we were with folks who knew Virago's menu well - and so we went big.

We ordered:

1.) PISTACHIO HAMACHI 
crushed pistachio, maldon sea salt, serrano, yuzu, unfiltered olive oil

2. V2 EDAMAME 
wok-charred, togarashi, sweet soy

3.) CRAB AND SHRIMP DUMPLINGS 
carrot-ginger sauce

4.) BLACKENED AHI 
sushi-grade tuna, mango vinaigrette

5.) BIG ISLAND HEARTS OF PALM 
spiced Marcona almonds, strawberry papaya, mojito vinaigrette

6.) RISING SUN 
crab, salmon, shrimp, tempura crunch and spicy mayo rolled without rice, tempura-battered and fried, topped with pepper tobiko and honey fire sauce

7.) EQUADOR 
tuna, hamachi, cilantro, cucumber, avocado, chives, jalapeño, masago, tempura crumbs, wasabi mayo, sesame seeds and sriracha

The Blackened Ahi, the Rising Sun, and the Crab and Shrimp Dumplings were the standouts for us. Each melted in our mouth with pronounced flavor. The Edamame was also excellent - spicy and sweet and the perfect way to start our dramatic feast of quality sushi.

Our meal at Virago was a tremendous was to start our blossoming Nashville adventure. If you're in the area and looking for a swank spot for the night - be sure to make reservations at Virago. 

My only advice is to ask the server for recommendations  - since some of our ordering items, though tasty, didn't wow us - as much as others. I would also recommend trying to check out Virago during the weekdays, since like all hot-spots - the weekends are the busiest. Also, while it's often suggested to sit at the bar at sushi spots, I would suggest holding out for a table. Our server - was traditionally a bartender at the space, and though he was friendly enough, he didn't seem as well versed in the menu as he could have been.

Trust.

The impressive array of diverse flat-breads, convenient outdoor seating, and massive interior here - should be enough reason to check out Urban Flats Flatbread.

Urban Flats carries everything from spicy Thai flat-bread to lobster mac and cheese and a wealth of other colorful dishes as well. 

If you have a big group - Urban Flats is ideal. They have a wealth of big tables and their menu is big enough to accommodate all particular food fancies.

I just wish that I'd stuck with the straightforward sure thing items such as hummus and the veggie flat-breads, instead of feeling adventurous and ordering the salmon. My bf looked at me hard and even politely challenged my order. 

"Are you sure you want to order fish? Ya do know that Tennessee is land-locked."

But I was not to be swayed.

He was  - of course-  right. My salmon was dry, lacked pronounced flavor and was dwarfed by a strong tasting mustard sauce. Fail. That being said  - his Spicy Thai Flat-bread was quite good, and the chocolate lava cake we had to finish our meal - was decent.

Sitting outside on our last evening in the city - we wished we'd been more adventurous with our final Nashville meal, but the warm friendly service and the easy walk to busy-tourist-filled Broadway for some live music was worth it.

Trust.

My husband lived off of the frozen Irish Coffees here - during our New Orleans stay. While I didn't partake myself -  I always enjoyed the walking adventure of getting to this quaint bar.

Molly's At the Market is perfect for reviving the tired, hot and thirsty on a busy New Orleans day. The staff are always quick and welcoming, their customers are always laid back, their bathrooms are clean, and their frozen Irish Coffees are beyond dreamy.

Like others have recommended - if you stop in here - for a frozen Irish Coffee - get the large. Just do it. Everybody that we took here during our stay - was so thankful for their caffeinated treat - and it proved to be a perfect sustenance pick-me-up for strolling through the humid New Orleans streets.

Trust.

Despite being in a mecca of fantastic food - I was still craving some of my favorite grocery staples  - so I took a brisk walk over to Rouses.

There are a handful of Rouses in New Orleans - but this one- proved to be one of the biggest in the city, one of the more organized - and had the best selection of the two that I visited. 

I appreciated the fresh looking prepared food and I managed to find some obscure healthy finds - that I didn't expect to discover in New Orleans. 

I walked out with everything that I was looking for and enjoyed my purchases throughout our stay in New Orleans.

If you're looking to pick up some grocery items - or even just want to enjoy a healthy salad, while doing some people watching in a modest shaded - outdoor seating area - come here.  

Trust.

A friend had recommended Peche before our trip - so when I spied it on one of our leisurely walks around the city - I was excited to manifest a meal here.

We came for a mellow lunch - and it was an indeed a lovely meal. The space is bright and light - and their menu is full of fragrant fish and seafood dishes. 

I ordered the baked drum w/ mushroom broth + calas  - and my husband had a chicken skewer side. We both split an order of their fried brussels sprouts. I thoroughly enjoyed the drum, though I was a little disappointed that there were no calas to accompany it (I had promised them to my husband) - and I was not expecting the dish to be topped with a big dollop of cream, which I personally found made the dish a little too rich. The brussels sprouts were flavorful and my husband was impressed with his side. 

Like all of our dining experiences in New Orleans - we had no wait - and our server was attentive and friendly.

If you're looking for high quality seafood in a breezy -sunshine graced room - Peche is perfect. That being said - if you prefer lighter fish fare - I would suggest clarifying with your server what sauces accompany your dish. 

Trust.

There's a reason that most of the reviews for Robert's are from people not from Nashville. Located on the busy tourist heavy Broadway strip, Robert's regularly boasts a diverse and out of town crowd. But that doesn't make it's charm or caliber of music any less spectacular.

We came here on two nights during our stay in Nashville and each night boasted phenomenal artists putting their all into the microphone and into their music. 

The place is always poppin', the servers are always on top of their game (running around up and down the stairs on the regular to grab stuff for customers), and the unique  - real atmosphere in this place is undeniable. Lined with photos of classic Nashville stars, posing with their instruments, amongst rows of character crafted cowboy boots.

If you go to Broadway - don't miss out on Robert's. We went into a number of spots down this way and Robert's was by far my favorite.

Trust.

There was a brief period when I graduated college - when I moved back to New Jersey with my sister and brother - and did absolutely nothing.

Nothingness in San Francisco is fun. But nothingness in New Jersey - when you don't know how to drive, and are in walking distance to nothing - would be like eating the fifteen pack of hot pink marshmallow Peeps, sitting on my desk at this very moment -  ALL in one sitting. So NOT what's up.

(the above paragraph may sound familiar. If so - thank you for reading my reviews :) - and sorry for the repetitive New Jersey review beginnings...)

During this brief time  - my interactions with the outside world were limited to Friendster, the Maury Povich show, and marathons of Real World. 

Surreal - to the power of 5.

Until one day, my younger brother - who also resided in the same said world of nothingness (outside of the ability to drive), was kind enough to offer to take me to Red, White, and Blue on a warm New Jersey afternoon. He even let me control the radio. Massive win.

We pulled up to a large thrift store - with only an assortment of people combing the aisles for bargains. Always a good combination - if you're hoping to score some cheap treasures.

With a strict time limit (imposed by my brother) - I went big. I scoured the aisles with diligence  - and managed to find some old sports jerseys, a sorority sweatshirt (which was cut apart and modified), and some solid T-shirts. 

Red, White and Blue is vast and their inventory is constantly being rotated out. So while you may have poor luck one day, come another day,  and you may find yourself with heaps of solid wonders strewn over your arms in front of a semi-jaded cashier. 

The hunt here - is what makes this place so appealing. Shopping here - is like a video game (which actually if you think about it - a thrift store video game would rule.  I would definitely rock the high score) - you gotta have fast reflexes, quick eyes, and momentum to win Red, White and Blue.

All of which I have  - thanks to my mad badminton skills (http://www.yelp.com/biz/bay-badminton-center-burlingame#hrid:ebHKVvWAgyoPV5m8l5yD6w s). 

That is all.

Trust.

This place was our spot during our brief stay in New Orleans.

It was perfect for us.There was never a wait. It had a solid breakfast menu for my husband - complete with mimosas and Bloody Marys. They had a great lunch menu for me. There was lovely live music during their morning/afternoon hours (a great saxophonist). And the staff couldn't have been more attentive and personable during each of our visits here.

Our visits to Gallier (for three breakfasts and one dinner) - set the tone for our day. Amongst the bustle of Jazzfest and the contagious rambunctiousness of New Orleans -  our brunches at Gallier were our meditative moments of the day. The staff began to recognize us - and I was delighted to discover that despite ordering the same thing each time (their blackened fish with double veggies) - that it tasted a little different on each occasion and that they even mixed up the veggies too.

There are a slew of amazing eateries in New Orleans, but if you're looking for a laid back spot without a wait, that serves up solid food with love and attention - come here. 

Thank you Gallier for making us feel at home in New Orleans.

Trust.

I don't gamble. 

My husband on the other hand - definitely enjoys a spirited game of blackjack every now and then.

And so - after a festive music filled evening - we happened to pass Harrah's. It's quite a spectacular looking venue. Well lit, grandiose, and to be honest, unlike some casinos - it's full of life.

We stepped inside (you will need to show ID to enter). It was air conditioned, clean, and completely free of smoke. The crowd is diverse and everyone genuinely seemed to be enjoying themselves. As a music venue (we listened to some fun live music for a little bit), a restaurant complete with karaoke (one woman nailed it with a Whitney Houston cover) - and so much more - Harrah's can be a lot of fun (especially if you keep your money close to you)

With free drinks as you play, and a slew of talkative characters at their array of game stations  - Harrah's is more than just a casino. It's a scene. My husband and I had a  great time meeting people here at the various tables. We didn't necessarily come out on top at Harrah's - but we did leave in high spirits - despite our losses. 

Trust.

The oven-roasted gulf fish "fisherman's style" at Cochon is one of the dreamiest dishes that I've had all year.

I know Cochon is known more for their stellar "meatier"dishes - but trust me on this one - get the fish. 

The portion is massive and the fish is so tender, fresh, and moist. My dish was seasoned with so much love - that I never wanted the meal to end.

Cochon is particularly nice - early on in the evening when big occasions are manifesting in the rest of the city. Around dusk - there is rarely a wait and the service is always friendly and helpful.

Trust.

We stumbled upon this place late at night, in an attempt to score some live music in the Five Points area. The place was pretty empty, but the staff were incredibly accommodating and sweet.

They opened up their back patio just for us, and even spent a good amount of time, making sure it was lit just right. The humid Nashville heat began to cool down with a nice pleasant breeze.

I ordered the vegan black bean burger on gluten-free bread, which came with a side of sweet potato fries and my bf ordered the sweet potato enchiladas. The bread was a little bland and didn't hold up the bean burger too well, but I still enjoyed my meal and the dipping sauce with the fries was excellent. My bf was pleased with his dish as well.

I wish we could have experienced Mad Donna's when it was more bustling and had more energy, but it was nice to mellow out outdoors and bask in the Nashville warm air.

Trust.

I was absolutely famished- a morning of traveling will do that to you. So I was quite excited for anything from Southern's menu.  

My party of 3 started off with the deviled eggs...well at least the 2 egg lovers at the table . I've yet to taste a deviled egg that's not uh-mazing, but this totally hit the spot.

As for my meal I went with the crab cake salad, which was really good as well. Unfortunately, I think I was a bit too hungry for the 3 little crab cakes in the salad because an hour or so later I found myself famished yet again.  I'd order the salad again, but perhaps add one of their delish looking sides next time. And oysters are a must next time as well!

Our first stop in Santa Barbara- lunch! Our stomachs were growling so we walked a bit and discovered Jeannines - sold by the adorable white picket fence.  

We placed our order at the counter and samples a piece of a pecan bar. Ok, we sampled a few pieces of a pecan bar...but shhhh.  Lunch consisted of some type of wrap for my husband and the granola/fruit/yogurt for me! Homemade granola (yum) and fresh fruit that I certainly wouldn't find in Chicago. 

The people who work here were super friendly, but I'd be very smiley too if I lived in beautiful Santa Barbara year round.

My husband went back the very next day for one of those pecan bars and didn't get me one. Boo to him, but yay to Jeannine's!

On par with the other Palomar Hotels I've frequented in Dallas, Atlanta and Chicago the Philadelphia Palomar is clean, slight flunky, spacious and has a nice gym.  And on the weekend I stayed there I was lucky enough to have the gym all to myself!

I was a bit disappointed not to receive a gift for being a Kimpton In Touch member. In the past, I've been greeted with fruit plates, bags of sweedish fish (my fave gift to date) and even a cute little card telling me to take what I'd like from the mini bar. Spoil me, Philly!

However, I think what may have been more disappointing was the fire alarm that went off around midnight on a Saturday night, just as I was getting into bed.  I climbed down almost all 19 flights of stairs with my friendly Palomar neighbors when they announced it had just been a problem with a toaster oven! And then I turned around and climbed up the 19 floors again...remind me to stay on the 2nd floor next time! Whew- at least I worked off some of a very yummy yet fattening dinner!

Regardless of the issues I had a very nice stay here and wouldn't hesitate to book the Philadelphia Palomar again. Next time I'll just request a room on a lower floor!

Restaurants like this piss me off because I can't find Mexican food half this good in Chicago! Grrr...

In the interest of full disclosure I didn't actually dine at Los Arroyos, but was fortunate enough to eat their delicious food when they catered my best friend's rehearsal dinner at the Cabrillo Arts Pavilion:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/cabrillo-arts-pavilion-santa-barbara

As soon as our bus pulled up to the Arts Pavilion I knew I was in for a treat because the staff from Los Arroyos was busy cooking on the grills outside...and it smelled delicious! And if possible, it tasted even better than it smelled. 

I couldn't stay away from the chips and guac (best guac EVER) and all the passed appetizers were fabulous. For dinner they just set up a taco bar and while I skipped right over the pork (ick) I was quite happy with my chicken tacos filled to the max with all the toppings a gal could want. Flan was for dessert, which was just ok...but flan has never really been my thing.

Oh, and I can't forget the margaritas! I've been taking it easy on the alcohol lately cause it gives me major heart burn, but I'm not one to turn down margaritas when celebrating my best friend's wedding. And i'm not one to stop at 1...or 2. :) I woke up in the middle of the night thinking I was having a heart attack thanks to all the heart burn, but I'd gladly suffer for another meal at Los Arroyos.

I notice they have a few locations in the area...perhaps their next location could be in Chicago?

I don't think I've been to an Olive Garden since I was 5 years old, but we stumbled upon this Olive Garden in Tucson today when we were very hungry and there wasn't much besides chain restaurants around us.  My pasta was actually pretty good. However, the service was horrendous.  The waitress tried to remember it all without writing it down (if you don't have a good memory please just write it down!) and just couldn't seem to get it straight.  At least she was very nice about it, which made me feel bad about getting frustrated.

I've found great food, great nightlife and much more in NOLA...but yet to find a hotel that I can't to visit again. I'm typically a starwood girl, but the only reason I'd return to the  Westin New Orleans Canal Place is for the points.

It's comfortable, has a lovely view of the river and I found the people who work here to be very friendly. And the gym is adequate, which is necessary after all the fried food you'll be eating in NOLA.

Overall, this hotel could use a facelift. The carpet throughout my room and entire hotel was dirty...and the walls could use a paint job. There are other improvements that could be made to bring this up to the standards of other westins, but new carpet and paint would be a good start.

I'd probably book it again if I were to return to NOlA, but only for those points to put towards starwood properties deserving of 4 and 5 stars.

After hearing/reading the rave reviews of las paletas gourmet popsicles I was a bit skeptical. I like my popsicles on hot days, but how can a popsicle be so much more amazing than others. I'm still not sure, but las paletas has figured out the secret.

Word is out that they've got the best popsicles in town (or perhaps the world) because it was quite crowded on a Thursday evening. They had lots of flavors to choose from, but I went with watermelon. For a second I thought about getting it dipped in hard chocolate (dairy queen style), but decided to keep it healthy.

After just one bite I knew I'd be adding yet another 5 star review. So tasty and so refreshing. I'll be craving these on hot Chicago summer days. In fact, I'd even go for one of these on a freezing January day in Chicago.

While in Santa Barbara getting some Mexican food was a must. It was a bit difficult to get a Friday night reservation for a party of 9, but Cielito came thru. We also ended up having our own private area upstairs so we were less of a disruption to others after a few spicy margaritas. :)

Normally I would  be all about the spicy margarita, but after a dreadful stomach flu a few days before I opted to stick with the wine. My dining companions kept the spicyritas coming though so I'm assuming they were fans. 

We asked the waiter  just to bring out some of his favorite dishes. He most definitely took care of us...and think he may have counted 15 people at the table for all the food he brought out. It was fun to try a bit of everything. I stuck with the vegetarian & pescatarian menus and it was all very good. I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu, especially if you go the waiters choice route like we did.

It's rare that I have a kidless Saturday afternoon so when in NOLA my friends and I decided to take advantage by booking massages. I turned to Yelp and after reading the reviews was deciding between an appointment at Spa Atlantis and The Ritz.  Based on the reviews I didn't think I could go wrong with either option so opted to book 4 massages at Spa Atlantis since it was $90 vs $160 at the Ritz.

The people who work here could not be nicer. They booked 4 massages for me online. Easy peasy! When I had to cancel one of them because one of my friends decided to shop instead (her loss) they canceled it at the last minute for no additional fee. And when my now party of 3 was running 15-20 minutes late they accommodated and still gave us the full 50 min massage.

They were just as friendly when we arrived in person. The actual surroundings weren't quite as luxurious as I was hoping, although it's accurately represented by the pics on Yelp.  However, this ended up being one of the best massages I've ever had. My masseuse (how I wish I could remember her name) applied the perfect amount of pressure, got me to relax (not an easy task) and even cleared my sinuses (have had a horrible cold for weeks). I thought I had gotten lucky to have 50 min with their star masseuse, but my other 2 friends agreed this may have been their best massage yet. So I really don't think you can go wrong with any masseuse here.

It's also a full salon so if they are half as good with hair and nails you'll be in very good hands!

I wasn't feeling well... and if I had my choice it would have been a matzo ball soup type of night. Or I may have just skipped dinner and gone straight to bed, but felt like I needed to eat something while pregnant. 

My colleague and I opted for dinner at Wildflower Grill, conveniently located within the Matrix Hotel we were staying at. We made our way downstairs and were seated immediately (no reservations necessary on a Tues night).  

By no fault of Wildflower Grill, but thanks to my stuffed up nose, there wasn't much on the menu that sounded appealing, but I finally settled on a caesar salad. And of course I couldn't pass up on ordering the bread appetizer that so many yelpers raved about.  Both hit the spot, especially the very warm bread that practically melted in my mouth.

I'm sure there's even better food on the menu that my bread and salad, but I"ll have to wait until my next trip to Edmonton when hopefully I'm feeling 100%.

Thank you Comcast Wall for keeping us entertained for 3 hrs while working the check-in table at the fabulous Yelp Spring Feastival. Fortunately, the Philadelphia yelpers are one cool bunch so getting bored wasn't a problem, but when have to sit at a table for 3 hrs staring at a wall of a building it's pretty awesome if there's a show occurring right on that wall.

This is one cool wall! You'd think I'd be sick of watching it after 3 hrs, but not so much the case (maybe just a bit dizzy).  I do still question the tourists I watched stare at the wall for several hrs at a time. Yes, it was a rainy day in Philly, but surely there's cooler stuff to do than spend a day staring at a wall even as awesome as this one.

Traveling with a bad cold is not fun...I was totally that person full of germs that I typically avoid on planes. Fortunately once I arrived in Edmonton (after passing my germs to everyone on the plane) the Matrix Hotel provided me with a clean spacious room and a comfortable bed so I could get a little bit of rest during my short trip.

Overall, I liked this hotel and wouldn't definitely stay here again. My colleague and I were in town to do interviews and they have a nice lounge upstairs that was the perfect spot for them (and it helped that it was empty too). 

It's also centrally located near lots of restaurants, shops and more...so there's no need to rent a car in what I believe is typically a driving city.

The restaurant downstairs was also solid if you happen to visit during one of Edmonton's infamous cold winters.

It's your typical country bar, but considering I never go to country bars in Chicago I thought it was great! My friend had her rehearsal dinner here and it was a blast. A low key atmosphere, BBQ food that didn't do much for me (but my fiance and others seemed happy), and most importantly fabulous service (I had a drink in my hand at all times).

So apparently I visited Posh on the wrong day because there were not $9 suede boots like the ones Caitlin D snagged...lucky gal.  I didn't happen to snag any shoes, but that's  probably because I didn't save any room in my suitcase for yet another pair of shoes...even shoes as cool and funky as the ones at Posh.  If I ever do make it back to Nashville I'll be sure to save some room in the suitcase for a stop at Posh!

I was about to give up on Tampa after a few visits to Ybor City. No offense to the locals, but that street is Austin's Sixth Street Gone Wrong.  Then I discovered the lovely Harbour Island area and realized that I just haven't experienced the good parts of Tampa. Phew!

We found ourselves at Jackons's for dinner in Harbour Island, which was conveniently located behind The Westin my in-laws were staying at.  There's a little something for everyone on this menu: burgers, salads, and even sushi for raw fish addicts like myself.  I'm usually a bit suspicious of sushi from nontraditional sushi restaurants, but the yelpers raved about it so figured I couldn't go wrong.  And the yelpers were right (as usual)!  I truly enjoyed all of the fresh sashimi and crab roll that came with the Jackson Sushi Dinner.  Everything else seemed to be a hit at our table as well!

I hear this place also turns into a club late night. Clubbing isn't quite my thing these days, but I'd definitely come back for more sushi and other good eats.

I'm not typically a fan of Marriott Courtyards, but when I needed a hotel at the last minute due to attending a funeral anything would do. I noticed this Courtyard happened to be attached to the country club where they were holding a celebration of life following mass...and so I booked it! $200/night seemed a bit expensive for a Courtyard in the Philly burbs, but you can't put a price on convenience.

Overall, the hotel was fine. The staff was friendly enough, the room was comfortable enough and even spacious enough for 2 since my colleague and I opted to share a room. We weren't in the hotel very long, but got a bit of sleep, a quck workout in the adequate hotel gym and a coffee downstairs. There's a restaurant attached to the hotel as well, but we weren't there long enough for a meal.

If visiting Philly for fun I"d opt to stay downtown. If I had to be in the Springfield area again I probalby would look for other options, but this was A-Ok for what I needed.
