My day trip to Nashville meant I didn't have to spend too much time away from the fam (yay), but it also meant I didn't get to explore much of Nashville (boo). I spent the entire day in the lovely Hutton Hotel and visited this onsite restaurant not once, but twice.  Yep, that's twice..once for lunch and once for dinner.  

I'm typically wary of hotel restaurants, but have to admit this one was pretty good. During a working lunch our party of 10 enjoyed their private room, which even had a TV that we were able to use for a presentation.  I started my meal with the corn gazpacho (eh) and then followed it up with the flat bread (yum). And my colleague was sweet enough to share her fries that came with my burger.

When I stopped back in later that night for dinner I decided to get my own fries and burger. I'm usually not a burger type of girl, but this one was so good!

The lunch service was a little on the slow side, but they were on their game during dinnertime, which allowed me plenty of time to get to the airport and head back to the fam.

Not quite a country music fan (although I should be after 3 days in Nashville!), but have to say I enjoyed myself at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum.

Warning- they charge $20 to get in (slightly less for students and triple A members), which I thought was quite expensive, but I guess Nashville has to make their $$$ somehow!  

Many of the exhibits were pretty cool, but I didn't look at anything in too much detail because I was busy chatting away with my 2 friends and was having trouble multi tasking. 

And I probably should be embarrassed to admit that we spent more time in the gift shop of the Museum than looking at the exhibits....but if you're looking for a cowboy hat or anything else country related this is the place to get it!

I first dined here 15 years and it was easily the most delish meal of my lifetime. Then again, my standards weren't quite as high when I was 22, but it was tasty. Really tasty.

When I arrived back in NOLA 5 years later I planned on having a few less hurricanes, but did plan on going back to Emeril's.  Not sure if the quality had gone down or my standards had gone up, but it was just A-OK. 

And I went back again this past weekend after 10 years this time with 20+ friends in tow to celebrate a friend's 40th bday. I was hopeful it would live up to the initial 2002 hype, but the overall experience was more A-OK 2007.

I was starving so ate every last bite of food, but was almost annoyed to be wasting calories on mediocre food (besides the 6 pieces of delicious bread that I couldn't help but devour after a long travel day). As for the rest of the meal:
Crab cake: 3 stars
Mushroom pasta: 1 star 
Salad: 2 stars
Salmon: 3 stars
peanut butter pie: 4 stars (next time i'll be ordering JUST wine and peanut butter pie)

While serving a group of 20+ women who have had too much wine is no picnic, it was painfully slow...and we were receiving our yummy peanut butter pie when my friends at the table next to me where just getting their entrees.  Thank goodness I had good wine & even better company so it was still a memorable evening.

Stayed here, as well as attended a friend's wedding, here this weekend. The wedding rate was $149/night and for that this is a 4 star hotel, but the usual rate is over $250 so in that case it's probably more like a 3 star hotel.

The good:
- Nice sized rooms with a separate living room area
- Comfortable beds
- A huge bathroom to primp myself for the wedding
- Right in the middle of downtown Nashville, as well as across from the country music museum
- Plenty of cabs always available even though Nashville isn't actually a cab friendly city
- elevators that move at lightning speed
- $13 breakfast buffet that I didn't try myself, but my fiance has mentioned what a great deal it was at least 10 times (it's the little things in life that excite him)

The bad
- unimpressive workout room
- pretty gross indoor pool that you couldn't pay me to step foot in
- they need to learn how to make a latte...I could hardly drink the one they made for me downstairs

For those of you looking to plan a special event in Nashville I"d also recommend the grand ballroom- my friend had a beautiful wedding here last night! It's a simple, yet elegant ballroom...the type where any decorations will work.  

Would I return to the Hilton during my next trip to Nashville (if there ever is another trip to Nashville)? Yes, probably...but it would depend on the price. I would be happy staying here for under $200, but over that I'd seek shelter elsewhere.

I had already eaten an early dinner, but when colleagues suggested late night sushi I wasn't going to pass up raw fish. I have to admit I was skeptical of finding really good sushi in Nashville, but I was proved wrong. 

We called while on the way and were told there was a 15 min wait on a Thursday evening at 9pm. But then when we arrived literally 2 min later we spotted at least 10 open tables and were seated immediately. Perhaps pretending to have a wait makes them seem more popular? 

Sam, our fab waiter, helped us make the perfect choices for the 2 of us (myself included) who eat anything related to sushi and our other 2 colleagues who are vegan. 

We started with the crispy rice app, which I can't ever pass up when I see it on a menu. So good. And from there ordered 2 rolls. Both were fantastic. I'm blanking on one of the names, but would never forget the tasty kuro scallop roll.  And we could get enough of the crispy Brussels sprouts. I may even be able to get my "I don't touch vegetables" 3 yr old to eat these. 

I left so full (2 dinners will do that to you) and so impressed with Nashville's sushi scene.

After waiting FOREVER for my iced latte I was expecting the best beverage ever, but it turned out to taste quite disgusting and I opted not to waste my one caffeinated drink of the day on such a drink.  Even Starbucks can do way better than this! I would have been happier at a SB, but my colleague and I had booked a few meetings at Transcend Coffee and were camped out for a few hours. 

I found myself waiting in another long line there just hours later when I got hungry, but wasn't impressed with any of their food options. I chose a muffin, ate a few bites and decided to hold out for lunch at MRKT.

Hello good food! Actually Meme has more than good food...it also has an adorable atmosphere and awesome service (thanks Tim!).

But let's get back to the food since I'm pregnant and food is what's on my mind 24/7 these days...

The menu isn't very big and I think my party of 4 managed to order most of it.

Appetizers: 
Mussels: I only had one since I'm not sure if they are on the pregnancy OK plan, but they take them out of the shell here and cook them in garlic deliciousness. The 1 mussel I had was heavenly.
Arugula Salad: The lemon vinegarette dressing was nice and light..and the manchego cheese on here was  very nice touch.
Ravioli: My goodness this pea filled ravioli was good.  
Foie Gras: Compliments of the chef and our server (thanks Tim!). It was crystallized on top and some of the best foie gras I've had. 

My 3 dining companions ordered the steak with blue cheese butter for dessert. Since I'm not much of a red eat eater I opted for the chicken instead. I can go either way when it comes to chicken, but this was pretty awesome. I liked that it came with carrots and peas so I didn't feel guilty about all those appetizers...and desserts we were about to order.

As for dessert choosing between the crème bruelee, chocolate cake and strawberry something (can't remember exactly what it was) was impossible! Therefore, I suggested we just get them all since we were celebrating a bday...and I happen to really like dessert.  All were super, but chocolate cake trumped the others!

After this meal the 4 of us had to be rolled out of the restaurant, but it was definitely worth the extra workouts I"ll be putting in this week. During my 30 hrs in Philly I only had time to visit 1 restaurant and this sure was a good pick!

Omni Hotels aren't typically my first choice, but it's definitely the place to stay in Nashville. Between Yelp's Spring Break, 3 weddings and (what seemed like) a zillion bachelor/bachelorette parties this was a happening place last weekend.

It's a very large hotel with a grand looking lobby. My room was modern, spacious and clean. My view wasn't anything special, but then again Nashville isn't known for it's scenery.

I did make use of their massive gym, which has every piece of equipment you could need to get in a good workout. I also spotted a nice outdoor swimming pool. Note to self: bring a bathing suit next time.

Unfortunately, I had to cut my trip to Nashville a day short due to an emergency back home. They couldn't have been more accommodating at the front desk and didn't charge me for the night I skipped.

Overall, it was a very pleasant stay and they'd be one of the first hotels I'd look into for future visits to Nashville.

I should probably mention before writing this review that I'm a huge hotel Snob. And yes, that's Snob with a capital S.  That's what happens when you travel pretty much every week. You want the places you stay to be almost (if not more) comfortable as your very own home. 

The Montecito Inn is a fine hotel.
It's clean
It's charming
It's got history behind it- Charlie Chaplin built it
It has a small, yet adequate workout room
It's in a great location- centrally located to many good restaurants/bars/beaches in Santa Barbara

I may even give this hotel 4 stars if it was in the $200/night range. $200/night is pretty much what this boutique hotel is worth. However, my hubby and I paid $315/night while in town for a wedding this past weekend.  And for $315/night I'd expect
* a nicer comforter
* Larger room besides the little box we slept in
* A larger bathroom with some more shelf space. My beloved chi iron fell off the very small shelf and broke. Sad.
* And housekeeping service that knocks a bit later than 8am on a Saturday morning. 

While I was performing bridesmaids duties on Saturday afternoon my husband found his way to the Four Seasons, which is apparently very close to the Montecito Inn. He said for the price of the Montecito Inn we'd have been much better staying at The Four Seasons. And that's exactly what we probably will do if we ever find ourselves back in Santa Barbara.

I travel almost weekly, which can get a bit tiring. However, if every airport was this cute, had outside waiting areas, and 5 minute security lines I'd gladly pack my bags twice a week!

However, while charming there are only a few airlines that fly into this tiny airport and those flights can be pretty pricey.  And the small jets aren't good when it comes to my new fear of flying. But all that may be worth it for the tan you'll get while waiting for your flight.

You know they make a good sandwich when you're waiting in line for 30 minutes on a Friday at 2:30pm. I had such high hopes for their sandwiches my dining companion and I were ready to enjoy ours in our rental car because I highly doubted we were going to get a seat in this tiny restaurant.  We got lucky because just as we approached the counter 2 seats opened up at the bar. Score!

Once we ordered our sandwiches were made pretty quickly so it's not slow service holding up those lines! I kept it simple and went with a turkey sandwich, which was most definitely the healthiest meal I enjoyed over my few days in NOLA. It may sound boring, but the ingredients were so fresh that I was quite happy.

I'm not a fan of waiting for anything, but may just line up again for Butcher.

I was on my way from a work trip to spend Saturday with the fam when I heard my least favorite words "flight cancelled."  I immediately dialed my friends at United (sadly I know the # by heart) and begged to be put on a new flight. Unfortunately, I was out of luck on United for that day, but they hooked me up on a US Air flight later that day.

I had a few hours to spare and made my way to the US Air terminal, which is ten times better than the United terminal. At this point I realized it was 4pm and all I had eaten all day was an unappetizing Auntie Anne's pretzel (pretty much the only option in the United Terminal).

And that's when I saw Sky Asian Bistro. The sushi was saying "eat me. eat me," but I'm skeptical of sushi made in an airport. I played in safe and went with veggie dumplings and fried rice instead. It totally hit the spot and for about three minutes all my anger towards United was forgotten.

I scarfed down my food, but then spent another hour or so catching up on work at their bar. The waitresses were super friendly and didn't rush me at all.

Hopefully your experiences at the Philly airport turn out better than mine, but if you find yourself with some spare time Sky Asian Bistro is one of the better airport restaurants I've discovered.

Pool, spa, sleep...I hadn't experienced a weekend this relaxing in quite a long time (thanks to the munchkins who stayed home for this particular trip). A weekend away at any hotel would do, but staying at the glorious Bacara made it extra special. 

The grounds are absolutely gorgeous and quite large. While exploring we came across a few different weddings and I can see why this would be a popular spot to get married. 

Our room was fab as well. When we checked in we were suckered into an upgrade and had a beautiful (partial) view of the ocean. The suite itself was spacious, but I really just wanted to spend most of my time out on the balcony....hello sunshine! 

Big fan of the spa and Jacob, who gave me a much needed massage. My only complaint was that it wasn't long enough, but I continued my relaxing morning in the hot tub. My husband raved about his massage as well.  I would have loved to check out the gym and complimentary workout classes (trx, etc). I had checked the schedule back home to confirm there were spinning classes and only brought spinning shoes (left my sneakers back at home). When we arrived they had changed the schedule and no longer had spinning...those sneakers back home would have come in handy. 

During our stay I ate and drank (shoutout to the skinny margarita!) at the pool and spa cafe. The food was good, but the service was a bit slow. Speaking of service this is where the Bacara lacks in comparison to other resorts within a similar price range. Based on the prices I would expect better   service both at the pool and throughout the rest of the hotel. While all the staff was friendly they don't really go out of their way for you. In fact, the pool guy (not one of the friendly ones) literally rolled his eyes at me when I asked if he could put up an umbrella near my lounge chair. They could learn a few things from the service at the four seasons. 

The hotel is located about 10-15 minutes (driving) from downtown Santa Barbara. I liked that it was a bit remote and it's an easy enough drive but may not be for you if you're hoping to walk into a nearby town. 

I would be thrilled to go back (next weekend perhaps?) although for the price range may explore some other nearby options as well.

I wasn't sure if I would like this hotel since it's right next to University of Arizona's campus, but it's  a fabulous hotel! The service is excellent....the valet guy has my car waiting for me within seconds, the check-in process took less than a minute (that never happens), and everyone is so nice and friendly!  The room is absolutely huge- it's by far the biggest Marriott room I've ever seen!  I would definitely come back to this hotel again, especially if they are still charging under $200/night.

I know from personal experience that finding a venue large enough for 150 people to attend a rehearsal dinner can be tough.  My friend chose this Art Pavilion as the venue for her rehearsal last weekend and it was perfect.  It was spacious (their website says they can seat up to 200 people) with an absolutely gorgeous view of the water.  One of those views that made me think "why do I live in Chicago?"

The Spanish style of the venue was just perfect for the mexican fiesta theme of this rehearsal dinner, but really any type of theme would work in this type of space.  The groom's parents had the event catered with one of their favorite Santa Barbara Mexican restaurants so bringing in food is definitely an option, although not sure if it's the only option. The mexican restaurant was busy cooking away on grills outside.

Surrounded by good friends this would have been a special night no matter where we are, but a cool venue like the Cabrillo Arts Pavilion made it extra special.

A good option for biz travel, but just eh if you're headed on vacation. However, it's worth noting that the hubby and I had just come from an amazing & charming hotel in St Martin so most hotels would pale in comparison.

The good:
Very clean room
Comfy bed
Adequate gym: treadmills, elliptical machines, bikes and even some weights
Across from the mall
Short drive from the airport
$159/night on New Years Eve during the Outback Bowl- not bad

The eh:
Tiny room/bathroom
Very dark rooms- could use a few more lamps in there!
Our "lovely" view was the inside of an office building...depressing much

I would consider this Intercontinental again for biz travel, but if I'm back again for pleasure I'll be looking for something with a bit more personality.

Julie arrived in Santa Barbara from SF to do hair and makeup for my best friend's wedding. I had my makeup done by the other stylist, but Julie did the bride's makeup and she's never looked prettier. And the bride's bridal do was absolutely gorgeous as well.

I got my hair done when in a wedding a few weeks ago and wasn't thrilled with the results so I figured I'd do my own hair for this one. But when I saw the beautiful hair styles (thanks to Julie) on all the girls I decided I wanted my hair done too. 

My request was simple...I wanted a Jennifer Aniston do. No, not the Rachel haircut. This isn't the 90's! I was thinking the one-sided braid that she sported during a recent award ceremony.

And Julie had me looking like Jennifer (or at least my hair) within 5 minutes top. And it was so well done that it still looked perfect at the wedding brunch the very next morning.

Julie also stuck around until after the ceremony to make sure all of our hair and makeup (most importantly the bride's hair and makeup) was just perfect for the reception. She followed us around with combs, hairspray, and makeup brushes. And I thought this was pretty cool considering I've seen many makeup/hair stylists take off as soon as the pre-wedding photos begin.

I know from my own wedding experience that very few stylists can do both hair and makeup perfectly, but Julie is a rare find.  Definitely recommended for SF Bay Area brides or anywhere else since she seems to be happy to travel!

After landing in Nashville my fiance and I went searching for a bite to eat. We were in the middle of Nashville and had our choice of many bbq joints, but somehow ended up at the fancy schmancy chain, Palm Restaurant, in tees and flip flops.  

Knowing that there would be more food at the rehearsal dinner later in the evening and this was just dinner #1 we decided to split the crab cake entree.  It came out within minutes and it was delicious! My fiance probably would have preferred a pulled pork sandwich from Rippy's down the street, but the crab cake at the Palm hit the spot for me!

Merchants is located in the middle of the rowdiest street in Nashville (apparently happy hour starts by noon on Fridays here). For that reason alone I was skeptical to eat here, but I liked the vibe once we stepped inside.

We scored a table immediately for lunch, which was ideal since I had a flight to catch. Our waiter greeted us with some delish complimentary popcorn. We devoured it and asked for more.

My meal was as tasty as my popcorn. I ordered the fish tacos (yum) and they came with a side of sweet potato fries. My favorite! I ate the entire thing and it was really filling, which was good since I didn't get a chance to eat again that day. Traveling will do that to you!

Based on my recent few days in Nashville it seems there's no shortage of amazing restaurants, but I'd stop in Merchants again if I found myself on this crazy street.

We recently did a quick family getaway to Sarasota to celebrate the big 6-0 for my mom. Since the entire family would be getting together (a rare occurrence with everyone living in a different city), I thought it would be nice to get family photos. I reached out to a bunch of photographers via Yelp, including Gold Sun Studios.

Allison responded immediately and when she explained her pricing model ($100 for 15 photos) I immediately asked what the catch was because I've hired several professional photographers in Chicago and that's by far the most affordable pricing I've seen. Not to mention her photos on Yelp and her website were really good!

When she promised me there was no catch I booked Allison for an hour long sunset session on the beach of our hotel.  She was very responsive leading up to the session and arrived right on time. And for once I even got my kids somewhere on time too- vacation agrees with us! We took a few photos of the entire family and then she ended up taking a bunch of candids of everyone. My kids were having a blast playing in the sand and getting wet; it was definitely one of the more relaxing and fun photo shoots we've done.  

The very next day (speedy!) I had all unedited photos in my inbox. I think narrowed it down to my 15 favorites and she returned the edited versions the very next day. And they perfectly documented this special trip/birthday.

We really liked Sarasota so think we'll make our way back at some point and I would definitely call Allison again. in fact, I've already recommended her to everyone I know taking vacations there and/or are lucky enough to live in the area.

We had time for one last meal in Santa Barbara and I turned to my fellow yelpers for help. Finch & Fork was the clear winner, but I worried like most popular brunch spots there would be a long wait on a Sunday morning. The friendly guy who checked us out of our hotel confirmed a) we were guaranteed to have an uh-mazing brunch here and b) there would be no wait due to the price point.

Based on the price point commentI feared we'd be spending our kids college savings at lunch, but I didn't find it to be all that expensive. Yes, more than the typical brunch, but after eating here our kiddos back home would be happy to know they still may have a bright collegiate future ahead. Phew.

The restaurant itself is attached to the lovely Kimpton Hotel, Canary Hotel. After checking out their beautifully ornate lobby (& restrooms) I may just need to bookmark for a future trip to Santa Barbara.

After a run in with a yucky stomach flu earlier in the week I hadn't felt much like eating during my vacation, but on this particular morning I was starting to feel like myself again. Annnnddd I was famished! I decided to keep it simple and ordered the wheat french toast (bring on the carbs), which couldn't have made me happier. The portion was quite large, but I somehow managed to polish it all off. And there went my stomach flu diet! 

My husband ordered was also quiet happy with his short rib & sweet potato hash. He said the fresh horseradish was especially a nice touch.

The service was a bit slow, but fortunately we weren't in a rush to leave Santa Barbara. Thank you yelpers for yet another good meal! I'd definitely head back here if I found myself in Santa Barbara again...for brunch or any other meal!

Thank you Café Adelaide for reminding me how much I enjoy a good dirty martini. Two kids had made me forget and all it took was a few days in New Orleans to remember. 

If I ever moved to New Orleans I'd have to have a personal trainer come live with me. They may have some delicious food, but it's also ridiculously heavy. And the food here at Cafe Adelaide is no exception.

My party of 4 did a nice job of trying several things off their tasty sounding menu. Some of it was awesome such as the fries (I was totally guilty of eating them all), flat bread app and even the brussel sprouts. And some of it was just OK such as the bacon wrapped oysters and shrimp and grits. If I were to go back I'd likely stick w/ a few apps and sides...and of course a few of their dirty martinis.

New Years Eve dinner is a production wherever you choose to dine. After I couldn't get my party of 10 a reservation at Berns (sad!), my fam thought Columbia may be fun.  And yes, this place sure is fun! There are many decorative rooms to dine in (I got lost finding my way back from the restroom) and they even give you an option of seeing some sort of show.  I figured dinner and drinks with my  crazy family was enough of a show for us. 

We were seated at 9:15 for our 8:30pm reservations, but I guess that's to be expected on New Years Eve.  I loved the cool looking red room they put us in- very festive for a special night of ringing in '10.

Unfortunately, I didn't find the food or service to be anything to write home about.  I've had better sangria, although you wouldn't know it based on the several pitchers I downed. Hey, it was New Years Eve!  We tried all 4 appetizers listed on the special New Years eve menu and the crab croquettes was the only one that really excited me. For my entrée I had the Pampano, which was a bit too fishy tasting for me. 

Our waitress didn't seem thrilled to be working on New Years Eve. Can't say I blame her, but she could have done a better job of faking it....especially since it's a big tip night!

Dessert was the best part of the meal. While most of the table ordered the flan I decided to try the white chocolate bread pudding.  So worth the extra lbs I'd have to tack on to my New Years resolution. 

The best part of the meal was the company...especially after several pitchers of sangria. No need to see a show with my family!

Ordering a hummus plate and a side of sweet potato fries may seem strange to the average person, but anything goes while pregnant.

I could have shared my hummus with 10 other pregnant women because they gave me the entire bag of pita. After a piece and a half I called mercy- too much pita for even this carb lover. However, I did put a pretty good dent in their sweet potato fries. 

We were in a bit of a hurry, but Blue Plate did a nice job of getting us in and out (and made sure we were well fed) in a timely fashion. I was also happy to see they took amex, which doesn't seem to be the norm for most businesses in Canada.

While I've never experienced the pool, tennis courts, or golf courses of the Montecito Country Club, I did attend my best friend's wedding here this past weekend. My best friend actually isn't a member of this country club herself, but they actually let non-members get married here. Pretty cool cause I know from my own wedding research that you usually need to be a member (or at least get sponsored) to have a private event at a country club.   MCC is one of the smarter clubs because weddings can definitely bring in a lot of money.

The views from the MCC are absolutely breathtaking. The ceremony took place on the grounds located above the tennis courts and it was the most beautiful view of the mountains, water, and everything else that makes Santa Barbara special.

The cocktail hour and reception took place inside. There were about 150 people at this wedding and it was just the perfect amount of space for that many people. The Spanish styled atmosphere has a rustic feel to it and it looked especially beautiful with the bright colored flowers my friend chose for her décor (see attached pics).

MCC may require it, but if you happen to get married here yourself (lucky you!) make sure you have a day of wedding coordinator because I noticed the people from the venue weren't very involved the day of the wedding.  Fortunately, my friend's Day-of-Coordinator made sure everything ran smoothly.  The service was pretty good and the food was tasty. My meal consisted of a strawberry arugula salad, wild mushroom risotto (a bit rich for my weak stomach, but really good), and sorbet for dessert. And my husband ate every last bite of his filet with a smile on his face...and he's someone who usually complains about the food served at weddings.

Highly recommended if you're looking for a beautiful venue for a Santa Barbara wedding. And if belonging to this club is anything like the weddings they put on I'm guessing it would be a pretty nice place to tee off as well.

20+ of my friends took over the Hyatt this past weekend! While we assumed there would be other guests from around the world joining us there, we weren't expecting the bed bugs that my friend woke up to in her bed on Saturday morning. Yikes! 

The Hyatt was very attentive and sent her clothes to be cleaned, sent her to the spa for a much needed hair wash/blowout and had the exterminators come out to confirm it was bed bugs. Fortunately, the rest of us didn't see any bugs in our rooms throughout the weekend. I'm pretty sure this can happen at any hotel (no mater how nice/clean it is) and what really matters is how the hotel takes care of the situation, but I'd recommend looking under the mattress before going to sleep at night...here and anywhere!

The hotel itself could use a bit of a makeover. I thought it was pretty rundown. Most of my room was clean and bug free (whoo hoo), but the looks of the shower made me wish I traveled with waterproof flip flops. 

As for the good this hotel is centrally located within the French Quarter if you're looking for a good time (maybe too good of a time) in NOLA. The restaurant downstairs also had tasty food and coffee, especially their sweet potato fries.

If I were return to NOLA I'd likely splurge on a room at the JW Marriott not too far from here

It's been 2 days and I'm still full from the delicious lunch we had at Shaya. My party of 20+ lovely ladies took over their private room upstairs and had quite the feast.  I wasn't sure I had room for more food after gorging on beignets at Cafe Du Monde, but I quickly made room for this deliciousness.

My friend had pre-planned the menu, which kept the food for so many people moving relatively quickly. Favorite included the pita (best pita ever) with dips, short rib and berry meringue dessert. The only dish that didn't really meet 5 star standards was the snapper, but probably just because I"m not usually a fan of snapper.

There are so many good restaurants to choose from in NOLA, but I wouldn't want to visit without coming back here.

We attempted to eat a late lunch here during our first day in Edmonton, but were disappointed to see that it closed right at 2pm. Not wanting to make the same mistake two days in a row we were the first customers the following day at 11:30am. It may have been empty when we first walked in, but got very crowded right around noon.

I ordered the beet soup, although it had a fancier name, and an amazing salad with asiago cheese.  I can go either way when it comes to beets (depends on the day), but this was absolutely delish. I gobbled both the soup and salad up...and even stuck around awhile to take advantage of their complimentary wifi.

The Patterson House's execution of the decidedly Southern approach to the speakeasy is simply masterful.  After passing the unadorned entrance multiple times, we entered the hallway replete with period paintings and bookcases lined with outdated legal research material.  The inside of the bar was shrouded by a simple blue curtain so we waited in the foyer.  We perused the "rules" which basically comprised of not taking photos and being polite.  The Patterson House's clientele consisted mostly of individuals in the 27-35 range with some excited young women in tight fitting yet sophisticated dresses for some appreciated eye candy for the admittedly lecherous tastes of myself and Viper.  There were also some older couples as well as some college aged girls whose sartorial choices appeared to be patterned after their grandmothers.  

We finally made it past the vaunted curtain and entered the bar.  Dimly lit, it probably best serves as a date place.  However, I was in the mood for a higher end experience regardless of company.  I started with the Bacon Old Fashioned.  While my experience did not border on the subliminal, this drink was certainly well crafted by our knowledgeable bartender.  I tried a delicious seasonal Sidecar, the Black & White, and a number of other creations that brought a novel approach to traditional drinks.  I ended with Patterson's House approach to the hotty toddy which was nothing short of amazing.  

The Patterson House's reputation is not simply built on its libations but also on its culinary offerings.  The tater tots tasted like McDonald's hashbrowns and were perhaps a bit too salty for my tastes.  Having said that, they were tasty enough and the light aioli was a decent complement to the dish.  More impressive was a delectable fried goat cheese offering served with a gorgeous red pepper sauce.  The crowning achievement, however, was the hallowed Elvis Panini; they use Benton's bacon, peanut butter, and banana to provide this updated approach to the legendary musician's favorite treat.  

For those looking for a classy, quiet night out with a sophisticated, "Old South" clientele, The Patterson House is a great start in Nashville.

3.75 stars.  There are two locations for the Camellia Grill, but this is the one you want to visit.  Here, you are not only getting wonderful food, but you get to do so within a stately house where the people who have been working the restaurant clearly understand the concept of customer service. Sure, the wait in line can be monumental, but when the payoff comes in an exceptionally sweet pecan pie served with a dollop of ice cream and a colossal double cheeseburger topped with an artery clogging fried egg, you've done well.  While it is only slight hyperbole to note that I was barely able to walk after ingesting all these calories, you certainly won't hear me complaining about eating here.  This is worth a stop if you are in New Orleans for a few days.

There is only one thing you need to know and only one thing you will remember about your night at Broadway Brewhouse.  Order the Bushwacker.  Any thoughts after consumption of said concoction shall be relayed to you only through the maniacal, hyena-like laughter on your so-called friends.  While this might sound like a mistake, what in God's name can go wrong if you order a chocolate vanilla milkshake like concoction apparently laced with copious amounts of Bacardi 151?  Hint: Nothing.  You will be better for it.  Truth.  

I could deal without the entirety of the rest of the Broadway Brewhouse "experience".  The bartenders, save for one awesome middle aged brunette, were having issues handling the New Year's Eve crowd.  The drinks outside of the Bushwacker at the small bar were routine is not completely mundane.  The beers at the front bar were basically inaccessible due to the aforementioned overworked staff.  The food was paltry, at best.  I wasn't a big fan of the crowd and neither was Viper.  Incidentally, at least some of the crowd wasn't a big fan of us either.  To wit, some girl's boy "friend" who thought he was her "boyfriend" absolutely despised the Viper given his cute friend's instant attraction to that most eccentric of Alabama lawyers.  I guess as the night progressed I became a bit more enamored with all the people around me as my later behavior would indicate.  You see, apparently, the Bushwacker makes you more friendly and the people around you friendlier as well.  Go alcohol!

Would I suggest this place for anyone to visit in Nashville?  Not necessarily.  But if you are a local, it's definitely worth a visit for the Bushwacker.

3.25 stars.  Monk's is probably best known for an extensive beer list, and I was not disappointed with their selection.  Indeed, not only was the list massive, but they had all of their beers in stock.  We sampled obscure beers from throughout the world (as well as American seasonals) while devouring an assortment of mussels and burgers.  

The best mussels that I sampled here were the Thai Red Curry Mussels.  The peripheral heat from the curry base provided an excellent compliment to the shellfish.  I thought the mussels here were slightly dry (probably from overcooking) and small, but they were fine for the price ($9.95 for 2 dozen).  Still, I wouldn't necessarily go for the mussels, but rather I would potentially order them as a food item to pair with my beer.  

Two of my dining companions ordered burgers.  While both of them seemed to enjoy them, I wasn't too impressed with the bites I took out of the goat cheese/Trappist burger.  Then again, in a city where the Five Guys chain still apparently reigns supreme (please prove me wrong Philly!), the bar hasn't necessarily been set very high for burgers.

I was really impressed with the fries at Monks.  Light and flavorful, the fries were served with a spicy mayo based sauce that provided an excellent finish to each tiny potato morsel.  If I went back to Monk's, I might just order a huge plate of fries with my beers.  While they were not subliminal, they were definitely solid.  

Overall, Monk's is a fine location for grabbing a few drinks over a casual meal with friends.  Given that was our goal, I would deem it a success.

3.50 stars.  

Gabby's wasn't open.  I knew that.  Neither was Rotier's.  But my handy Yelp app had assured me that Fido's was open.  Imagine the disappointment when I realized there was a very real possibility that no burgers would happen on this trip down to the Deep South.  Would I really have to wait two more weeks when I would find solace in East Texas?   

"We can try Burger up," I mentioned.  

"Why don't you just call them?" hissed the appropriately nicknamed Viper.  

True.  We didn't have to keep driving around aimlessly.  So I call Burger Up, and a very pleasant, sweet voice assures me they are indeed open.  

Viper: "What was her name?  She sounded hot."
  
Me: "Paige."

Viper: "Yeah, she's definitely hot.  Have you ever met an unattractive Paige?"

Me: "Good point.  At least we have that going for us."

Paige was indeed attractive, but this review isn't about a photogenic individual who happens to work at Burger Up.  It's about what ended up being a visit to our fourth choice for burgers in Nashville.  

Burger Up follows a national trend towards upscale burgers.  My particular order consisted of a medium rare patty served with aged cheddar, Benton's bacon (very good), and ketchup served on an artisan bun.  Basically, it was a gussied up bacon cheeseburger, but it was a rather tasty one.  My major complaint is that I wish the actual meat itself exhibited more flavor.  Having said that, the burger was cooked properly and the flavors worked well together.  I ordered some wilted spinach on the side (mediocre) and truffle fries.  Let's talk about those truffle fries for a bit.  I know more people are apparently into the sweet potato fries here, but I think they are missing the boat.  Burger Up's truffle tries have pleasant aroma, taste great, and are the perfect texture for soaking up oil.  If you are on a diet, it is true you should skip these delightful fries.  But if that were the case, why are you at a burger joint in the first place?  Seriously, if you get nothing else out of my review, please do yourself a favor and order the truffle fries.  

Burger Up also boast an interesting beer menu with semi-obscure breweries from the Deep South included in the list.  I tried a pecan-infused amber from Mississippi - not bad.  I could imagine Burger Up could be a decent place to drink for a bit after eating.  

If I attended Vanderbilt, I would probably go here on a moderately frequent basis.  If you want a change from the dive bar hamburger, Burger Up is a decent change of pace.

3.50 stars.  I was told to go here for the shrimp and grillades (grits) and fried chicken, but I ended up loving the gumbo more than anything.  Located in Mid-City, Li'l Dizzy's is a cozy diner serving up an all you can eat breakfast/lunch consisting of fried chicken, trout, shrimp creole, rice & beans, grits, gumbo, omelettes made to order, fruit, and maybe a few other items as well.  It was all pretty standard until I reached the gumbo.  

Li'l Dizzy's gumbo is heavenly.  They don't hold back on either the sausage or the seafood as you have generous cuts of andouille sausage and crab legs in the wonderfully thick dark brown soup.  They got the flavor so perfect I felt no need to add any tabasco to my order.  I'd definitely come back here for the gumbo.  

Overall, you have plenty of options for breakfast/lunch in this city, and Li'l Dizzy's is a good one if you are in Mid-City.  It's a great option if you just want a cup of gumbo.

THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!!!!   I grew up two hours from this place, and it was my favorite restaurant within reasonable driving distance of my house.  If I was limited to giving five "five star" ratings for restaurants nationally, Jacques-Imo's Cafe would certainly be in the discussion.  Simply one of the best places in the entire country to eat Cajun Food (like every other poster on here, I'm going to tell you to try the shrimp and alligator cheesecake).  If you can pick only one place to eat in New Orleans, this should be it (Arnaud's and K-Paul's are also great selections for the uninitiated).

I'm in love with the "hot chicken" concept, and I hope it goes national.  Nashville's unique contribution to Southern cooking entails the preparation of fried chicken basted in a fiery combination of peppers and spices that absolutely will send you running to the closest fire hydrant to squelch the burning sensation where your lips and tongue once resided.  Mr. Bolton will make you hot chicken from almost any part of the bird, and he will even do it with chicken tenders should you choose (which comes with the welcome addition of ranch sauce to alleviate some of the heat).  I opted for wings and a call to the fire department.  

Aside from the heat, it should be mentioned that Bolton's approach favors flavor.  The wings themselves were fried perfectly and reminded me why I frequently hold my head in only mildly feigned agony when eating "Southern food" in places like my current hometown of Washington DC.  The green beans at Bolton's, flavored liberally with bacon, were so impressive that I ended up ordering green beans at nearly every single restaurant and dive that I visited in Nashville.  I assumed it was a Nashville thing; I was wrong -- it is a Bolton's thing.  Maybe some pseudo-celebrity chef should visit Bolton's and say it was the best thing (s)he ever had; it certainly was the case for me when it comes to green beans.  The mac-n-cheese is also very nice with heavy use of white cheddar and liberal amounts of black pepper.  If you like a "bready" mac-n-cheese, this is probably not your style.  I thought it was delicious.  

Mr. Bolton himself was an appreciate and friendly man who probably should have been annoyed that two rather inebriated individuals were awkwardly ordering (ex. me: what's the one that is hot chicken?  Bolton: i can make any of them hot chicken?  me: ok, i'm confused now) but he helped us out anyhow.  I know Nashville loves this business, but if I ever find out how to teleport people, Mr. Bolton is coming to Washington DC.  But at least you got my lack of an advanced degree in any engineering on your side.  Outside of a moment of idiot savant-like genius on my part, you are probably safe.  

Finally, although it rarely happens, there are a few somewhat misguided reviews that lament that the chicken wasn't spicy enough when they ordered MILD or make similarly obvious patently illogical complaints.  There is a saying that the inability to appreciate the Mona Lisa speaks more about the criticizers than the actual work.  I feel the same way about the plebeian fools that dare to defile a culinary gift from the Gods (or, in this case, a gift from the able hands of Mr. Bolton and his staff).  Bolton's is divine and is a foodie must for anyone visiting Nashville.  Unless you are vegetarian or hate chicken, to visit Nashville and not try hot chicken from Bolton's is about as despicable as going to Vanderbilt and cheering for the University of Tennessee.  It simply should not happen under any circumstances.  As for locals, if you haven't been here, then I would highly recommend that you support this culinary gem of a local business.

While I will readily admit that gelato isn't exactly my first love, I can still appreciate the obvious work that goes into the preparation of the creations at Capogiro.  First and foremost, like Jeff W. and Michelle P. point out in their respective reviews, the actual substance is unparalleled within the frozen dairy industry (even surpassing the treats at DC's beloved Dairy Godmother) and the consistency in unmatched as well.  Second, the breadth of flavors is impressive.  While I was enjoying a more traditional Bacio, some of my dining companions were getting gelato spiked with all sorts of Thai spices and exotic fruits.  I commend Capogiro for providing both options.  Third, the price point is correct.  While spending $4-7 certainly may seem expensive for gelato, the generosity of the serving size is beyond reasonable debate.   Finally, I thought the individuals working the counter were quite patient with our group (which consisted of both grizzled Capogiro veterans and first time visitors).  The bottom line is that gelato is rarely a destination point; this is one of those rare spots that bends all your existing paradigms and rewrites them in an entirely positive fashion.  If you are in Philadelphia, it's worth a visit.

3.25 stars.  I always think of those old Road Runner/Wiley Coyote when I see the word "ACME" so I was rather hesitant based on simple nomenclature when we happened upon this branch of the famous New Orleans eatery.  In fairness, I eschewed the local specialty (the charbroiled oysters) in favor of fried oysters and seafood gumbo.  The fried oysters were quite good; the light, flavorful, and slightly spicy coating taking precious little flavor away from each underlying oyster.  The seafood gumbo was likewise a solid offering combining generous portions of backfin crab meat and shrimp with a satisfying roux.  I would have loved jumbo crab meat or plump shrimp especially at this price point, but the food was undeniably tasty.  Overall, I wouldn't call this destination cuisine, but then again, I haven't tried the charbroiled oysters.

4.25 stars.  Yes, it's absolutely touristy.  Yes, the trashy shitshow that is Bourbon Street spills off of the street and directly into this venue on a regular basis.  But if there is a better karaoke experience than Cat's Meow anywhere in the country, I've yet to see it.   

Now I've seen some people complain about the drinks here but Cat's Meow knows its audience.  Namely, the idea of serving drinks in glass is simply a terrible idea when you have patrons so obviously beyond their usual limits.  To wit, by the time we reached the second floor to take a Roman Colosseum view of the events below, two girls from a bachelorette party - one the bride and another an aging bleached blonde with a silicone chest - were fighting for crowd attention and eventually each other (silicone kicked the bride on the karaoke floor!).  No one wants glass in a venue like that.  

By the way, if you don't particularly care to karaoke or dance, may I strongly suggest this second floor?  From our original vantage point, you get a bird's eye view of all the lunacy.  For example, we watched a horrific breakup (the girl grabbed another man's you know what right in front of her man), people falling on stage, the best drunk dancing ever, and the obligatory drunk people coupling from the balcony.   

The range of songs offered by Cat's Meow is quite good.  But what really makes the event are the MC's who bring the party back every single time after a bad song.  These dudes can sing, dance and are pretty much a bachelorette's dream as they are pretty sculpted too.  Their ability to bring energy back into a place is borderline magical.  

It was my friend's b-day, and I was proud that she left the second floor and was having fun dirty dancing with the MC's.  Eventually, all of us participated in either dancing or singing, and just had a great overall time.  

If you're looking for a place where you're encouraged to leave your inhibitions behind in a positive manner, Cat's Meow is the appropriate tonic.

3.75 stars.  Conjure up images of New Orleans and at some point you are going to think of the humble "poor boy" sandwich (po' boy) consisting of a soft French style baguette, lettuce and onions, and a fried seafood interior.  At Domilise, you can get a number of these sandwiches (including the popular roast beef with debris gravy), but I went ahead and stuck with the seafood versions (if you order the half and half, you get a shrimp po' boy and an oyster one as well).  

Everyone has their favorite po' boys (mine happens to be at Darrell's in Lake Charles, LA), and I'll say Domilise is solid.  Both the shrimp and the oyster are satisfying, and you can get them dressed to your liking.  For essentially 12 dollars, you are served a rather generous sandwich.  This little shop is rightfully famous, but I'm still saying the best ones I've ever had are outside New Orleans.  

Still, that isn't to say you shouldn't come here (or Killer Po Boys or Guy's up the street or Parkway or really any other awesome po' boy in the city).  You will receive an extremely satisfying sandwich here and you'll even get some friendly service and LSU love from the people who operate it.   It's worth a visit if you are in New Orleans.

Unfortunately, the Green Goddess was closed so we happened upon this place.  I'm surprised Arnaud's places their name on this travesty of a bar/restaurant located in downtown New Orleans.  While Remoulade delivered on their BBQ shrimp (a nice, spicy blend with tender, plump shrimp), the remainder of their offerings were paltry at best.  

The crawfish etouffee was a watery mess of bland spices and small, hardened coils of crawfish.  While the turtle soup had a nice swirl of sherry, the salt content was overboard.  I would like to never revisit the crunchy topping on the stuffed crabs.  Service was a bit spotty.  The complimentary bread added nothing to the meal.  

New Orleans is a culinary town.  In this city, I expect a whole lot more out of a meal.  While it probably would bode well for the happenstance tourist looking for a casual meal and a beer, it misses as far as everyone else is concerned.  There are tons of places to eat in New Orleans; this should not be on your list.

The question between South Philly always comes down to Geno's and Pat's.  It's like Giordano's versus Lou Malnati's for Chicago-style pizza -- both might be great, but you have to pick a favorite.

For me, I'm going with Geno's because they focus more on the meat rather than the Cheese Whiz.  I'm also going to say the use of the whiz for philly cheese steaks has got to be the most overrated culinary concept of all time (dodges lightning bolt).  

I think the attitude at Geno's and Pat's further accentuates life in South Philly.  It's not only about the sandwiches, but there is also a distinct Philly flair to the service which makes this place great. 

And now time for my little moment on the soapbox.  If a restaurant requests their patrons to speak English to them, that is their right.  After all, freedom of speech includes the right to state beliefs or ideas that might be construed as offensive (by the way, English is not my first language).  So, basically, if you are going to interpet a sign in the most offensive manner to you, then that's your business (and you probably won't like this place).  However, my review is based on the actual sandwich and it's stellar.

4.50 stars.  I have no inkling why the signature po-boy at Avery's is named after a miniscule town on the border of Mississippi, but the Pearl River, with its lusciously soft perfectly fried oysters drowned in a figurative river of roast beef debris gravy and bacon, certainly qualifies in the upper echelon of all po-boys I have ever eaten.  And that's to say nothing about some of the other amazing menu options including an absolutely mind-bending preparation of seafood gumbo, a roast beef po-boy stuffed with fried pickles, and apparently Yelp's favorite, the fried potato salad.  Really, you should get all of it.  

The seafood gumbo is absolutely startling with pretty much everything under the sea finding its way into your bowl.  In the style of Chef Paul Paul Prudhomme, Avery's opts for a modern preparation and starts with a heavily cooked roux with the complexion of dark chocolate.  As mentioned, the soup is absolutely studded with wonderful sea creatures and topped with a humble serving of white rice.  The texture is incredible - it's neither too sticky or too soupy.  I could live off this gumbo for years.  

The po-boys I tried are all dressed and served on Leidenheimer bread.  What really separates Avery's from other places is their creativity.  Sure, the oysters are amazing but surprisingly, I haven't run into a whole lot of places that are drenching them in debris gravy and topping them with bacon.  The roast beef and fried pickles po-boy was also outstanding and even better the next morning.  

The fried potato salad is somewhat more of a novelty item, but I thought it was quite good and also worth your time.  Like the roast beef po-boy, it held up very well the next morning.  

I don't live in New Orleans (grew up nearby), but if I did, I'm pretty sure I'd try to make Avery's part of my regular rotation.  This is outstanding even by Louisiana standards.

Jack's is consistently rewarded as the best BBQ in Nashville.  However, do not expect that to translate into one of the best BBQ meals you will have in Tennessee let alone the Deep South.  

Out of the three meats that I tried, the ribs were probably the best.  Unlike another poster, my ribs were not fall off the bone but rather were cooked properly (with a slight pull off the bone).  The brisket and sausage were decent if you paired them with the right sauces (you should take advantage of all the different sauces that are available).  Both the mac and cheese as well as the green beans here were quite disappointing.  I wouldn't order either of them again.  

I hear there is a place in nearby Nolensville that makes some mean BBQ.  That would be my destination of choice on a subsequent trip to Nashville.  If you are looking for great food in Nashville, I'd say stick with Southern cooking and hot chicken.  Those are the real wins in this city.

As a concept, Dinner Lab is food heaven.  It essentially takes chefs from around the country, gives them free reign to create a themed dinner (usually 5 courses), and sets the dinners in odd locations (underground, abandoned buildings, art galleries, etc.).  Membership isn't too expensive, and the dinners are reasonably priced (around $60-$70 for each person).*  

My first dinner featured two mind blowing courses (an extraordinary ahi tuna dish paired with luscious squares of tomato and avocado and a crab xiao long bao in a kombu mushroom broth), two solid dishes (24 hour pulled pork cooked in banana leaf, a modern take on banana nut bread with ice cream), and one average dish (hot chicken wing with numerous sweet accents).  It is all-you-can-drink which is always a big plus.  Moreover, this dinner featured a few pairings covering a wide swath of spirits.  

My biggest complaint about Dinner Lab is the difficulty of getting reservations.  If I'm going to pay a membership fee, I'd like to think that I wouldn't have to scramble and hope that I can actually attend a dinner in a similar fashion to a sample sale on Gilt.  However, if that is the biggest complaint I have about the whole experience, it's safe to say that it's one I will repeat a number of times.  

* This review is for Dinner Lab DC which is the DC version of the New Orleans original

Many people will tell you there is no such thing as a bad meal in New Orleans.  That isn't necessarily true, but certainly, the number of culinary gems in this city are hardly rare.  Still, even amongst immense competition, Willie Mae's manages to shine by offering what was clearly some of the best fried chicken I've ever eaten.  

The skin is what first catches your taste buds.  Subtly crisp and lightly crunchy, the texture itself is a sight to behold.  The cooking method retails a significant amount of oil, and the spice mix is stupendously satisfying.  The chicken stays juicy throughout the entire course of your meal.  I've eaten at a number of fried chicken joints in states such as Tennessee, Alabama, Texas, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi and South Carolina.  Other than an absolutely perfect rendition of fried chicken from regionally renowned chef Jeff McInnis in Miami, FL, this was the best I've ever eaten.  

As your side, I would suggest skipping the more common orders and going with the butter beans.  When they are prepared appropriately, they can be divine and Willie Mae's knows what they are doing.  We also really liked the green beans and the others at my table seemed to take a liking to the mac and cheese as well.  Still, the butter beans are on another level. 

In a city chock full of Cajun food, it's a little surprising that this meal was the highlight of the culinary aspects of the trip.  All that said, it's definitely worth your time.

When the highlight of my waltz into a museum is to make sophmoric comments concerning the size, age, and condition of a green, syphilis-infected penis, you can be assured that I have dropped to the basest form of entertainment.  While I have no question that medical information can be gleaned from the paltry three rooms that comprise the "museum", I felt violated paying $14 to view the offerings here.  

I'll add that I didn't find the museum enjoyable either.  There was an inordinate focus on medical trauma without associated examples of it.  I found the skulls exhibit mundane, and I thought the much anticipated soap lady (which I oddly kept calling the soup lady) was jarringly boring.  Probably the most interesting item to me, other than the unintentionally funny diseased penises, was the comparison between the giant and dwarf skeletons.  I literally spent 15 minutes in the museum before realizing that it was one grand disappointment.  Sadly, I was able to see everything in that short time period.

Maybe my expectations for museums have skyrocketed as a result of living in a city known for having world class ones.  In that sense, I'll state that it's possible that I simply have a misunderstanding of what one should expect to receive from a museum.  But the simple truth is that I would not have enjoyed this museum if it was free.  Despite the glowing recommendations, I would avoid it.

3.50 stars.  The opposite of love is indifference.  And that is fully clear at Loveless as you will find delight in nearly everything that they serve.  Probably the most amazing part of the Loveless experience is the sheer size of your plate.  I had pulled pork, fried chicken, fried okra, mac and cheese, and cheddar grits all on the same plate - sort of.  The portion I ordered was so large that it did not all fit on the plate.  As for the actual food?  Aside from being tremendous, it is also delicious though I would give a definitive edge to Monell's for best breakfast I have experienced in Nashville (note: I haven't been to Arnold's Country Kitchen yet).  Still, this is the place that most people will talk about in Nashville, and it's at least worth a visit.

4.25 stars.  Monell's is exactly what makes the South so special to those of us who have lived in the area for any tangible amount of time.  Are you looking for a special treat?  Look no further than the beautiful mansion at Monell's for some of the best breakfast you will find this side of the Mississippi.  

You are led to a lengthy table in a Southern-formal room where you eat family style with other patrons.  They start you off light with a plate of biscuits, but you have the option of making them quite heavy with a think and creamy peppery white gravy that hearkens back to a time when nutritional labels had no bearing in cooking.  After the biscuits and gravy, we were treated to a number of different carbohydrates - the corn pudding that everyone mentions is quite divine but I wasn't too thrilled with the cheese grits here.  What was exceptionally well prepared on the carbohydrate plate were the homestyle potatoes and the sweet apples.  I had to have second helpings of both of those items.  Next, we were treated to a big plate of sausage, bacon, and country ham with the sausage and country ham both exceptionally prepared (the sausage squirts all over the place - it's that juicy - and the country ham has an impressive sweet finish).  However, if you are at Monell's, you are saving room for the fried chicken.   Monell's does a fantastic job with this decidedly Southern dish with an absolutely perfect crunch for each piece.  Sadly, I could only eat one piece given all the food I had eaten during the sitting.  

If you want an impressive Southern meal at a very reasonable price, Monell's is a great bet.  My mouth is salivating just thinking about my next visit.

3.50 stars.  Raz'z is slightly off the beaten track for those who are visiting Nashville, but it is worth your time if you are in the mood for some solid Cajun food outside of the Louisiana area.  While Raz's sported a much more formal interior than I would have imagined (darkly lit, tablecloths, etc.) and certainly offers more than just your few traditional Cajun preparations, the waitstaff is exactly the type of super friendly and helpful types that one would expect at a Cajun dive.  

The reason we came to Raz'z had everything to do with the fact that it had been featured on the Food Network's "Best I Ever Ate" program.  Given that I grew up just outside of Cajun country, I was curious to see how a place in Nashville, TN could possibly be ranked the number one jambalaya by a professional chef.   The short answer is that Mr. Neely should probably try the jambalaya at Jacques-Imo's.  However, this is not meant to be an assault on Raz's preparation which is easily one of the best jambalaya meals I have had outside the state of Louisiana.  The decadent and creamy jambalaya sauce at Raz'z was peppered with chunks of sausage and chicken and served over a plate of wild rice.  Also delectable was Raz'z preparation of etoufee where the Viper remarked that he was happy that they hadn't toned down the heat factor.  I ordered a gumbo and while the roux was thicker than I would have liked, it made for a pretty nice and authentic presentation.  

While I'm sure that a number of reviewers will chastise this place as not living up to the best jambalaya in the entire country, it's a bit absurd.  The fact is that the cuisine here is solid.  If you take out Lousiana and its bordering states, Raz's is definitely one of the top three Cajun meals I have had.  Bottom line: You can find better in Louisiana, Texas, and Mississippi, but Raz's is absolutely worth your time if you are a Nashville local.  I'm not a local and I'd certainly go again if I was spending a week in Nashville.

4.50 stars.  Cochon is one of the most heavily reviewed and highly rated destinations in New Orleans and for good reason.  Aside from sporting a trendy look with great wood paneling and exterior brick as well as nifty indoor balcony seating overlooking the restaurant, the cuisine is stellar as well.  Start with glorious bites of alligator drowned in a thick mayonnaise based sauce featuring notes of chili and garlic or maybe the house boudin balls (essentially, a deep fried pork and rice ball) for a Cajun treat to start.  Or, for those seeking a more seasonal treat, we also enjoyed a wonderful pork cheek dish paired with tender slivers of yellow squash, English peas, and green onions.   

There are a number of excellent choices for dinner though one would be hard pressed to beat the beef short rib over corn grits.  The tender short rib absolutely melts in the mouth and pairs perfectly with the grits.  While I only sampled the rabbit and dumplings, the meat was exquisite and this warm hearty dish would make a lovely choice especially for a cold day.  The catfish courtbouillon also impressed with a flavorful base subtly adding layers to an already nuanced preparation.  

Don't miss out on dessert either (I think we ended up trying all of them).  While the pineapple upside down cake was absolutely devoured by our party, I was perhaps most partial to a rather decadent chocolate hazelnut pudding.  

At least on this visit, Cochon ended up being my favorite overall meal (even besting general favorite Jacques-Imo's).  Even with all the places I've yet to visit in this city, I would be hard pressed to pass up a subsequent visit.

If Frenchy's Rockaway Grill is even better than Big Ray's Fish Camp, well then you have two exceptional businesses serving grouper sandwiches in the greater Tampa area.  

What I can say is that the grouper sandwich at Big Ray's can barely contain an absolutely gigantic fresh piece of well-seasoned grouper.  While the grouper itself is perfectly cooked and the seasonings provide bite to each bite, I think the bun can't hold this massive undertaking and probably is the only part of the experience that can be criticized.  But wow, what an absolutely incredible piece of fish!  

As great as the sandwich is at Big Ray's, I think I may have loved my conch fritter appetizer even more than the sandwich.  A perfect marriage of conch, breading and remoulade, each bite of the fritter was magical.   

The fried Oreos that I included with my order were probably unnecessary but nonetheless delicious.  The dipping sauce which tasted like a liquified version of an Oreo center was the highlight of a delightful dessert.   

I ate at a number of wonderful places in Tampa, but this is the one where I'd want to go back over and over again.  As such, there is no other rating that I can give other than those five red Yelp boxes with little white star cutouts.

"We have to stop here" the Viper insisted.  I took one look at the exterior of the warehouse, scrunched by eyebrows while simultaneously rolling my eyes, and made no effort to hide the annoyance in my voice.  We had just finished eating at Monell's and I was kind of ready to head back to the hotel.  "Really dude?  I'm paying for all the drinks on this trip, but you realize that none of these drinks are covered?"  The Viper understood and did not care.  For as anyone who lives in the South will realize, Frugal MacDoogal's is basically subsistence priced alcohol.  For people who drink in the same absurd quantities as my friend, this store is absolutely essential for that single reason.  

Having lived in DC for awhile now, I wasn't enamored with the prices.  One of the most ridiculous aspects of my city is that our cost of liquor is very low whereas the price of cocktails purchased on a night out is very high.  DC almost begs the consumer not to go out.  The South is the diametrical opposite - cost of liquor consumption within the household is rather high but markup within bars is minimal at best.  It makes no sense NOT to go out because the chances of encountering a cocktail prices over $15 simply doesn't happen on a regular basis.  

The prices are great for the South though and the selection is actually decent.  I found nice bottles of Redemption Rye, Rocky Mountain High West, and Yamazaki 18 at very reasonable prices.  The beer selection wasn't outstanding, but some of the offerings were rare for the area.  I wasn't able to find any Pappy Van Winkle, but who is able to find it these days?  Overall, the selection was reasonable and the prices are more than fair.  

At the end of the day, you are here for cheap alcohol.  You will find that at this appropriately named discount liquor store.

4.25 stars.  If I lived in New Orleans, Shaya would very likely be my go to restaurant for a date.  The cuisine is casual, fresh, healthy, mildly exotic, and GF and vegetarian friendly.  The space is light and airy and sports a rather charming outdoor patio.  The staff is warm, patient and very knowledgeable regarding excellent wine pairings.  And hey, if your date is going poorly, at least you are having a great meal amongst lovely people.  If that is your worst case scenario, your life is going pretty well.  

I visited Shaya because we had been in town for an extended weekend, and I think the entirety of my vegetables on the trip consisted of some green beans at Lil' Dizzy's and smothered greens at Cochon.  Needing a bit of a cleanse and beginning to feel like a moderate dick to our one vegetarian companion who had patiently been eating bread at pretty much every single restaurant we had visited up to Shaya, it was time for a vegetarian friendly meal.  Shaya is definitely capable of delivering that result in epic fashion.  

We started with five small plates all of which ranged anywhere from solid to outstanding.  I'd highly recommend the pickled ramps if they are still in season.   Matched with generous clouds of feta cheese and crumbled pecans, the pickled ramps provided a satisfying textural and flavor profile balance.  The result was a complex dish that presents simply and tastes fantastic.  The spicy Moroccan carrots interlaced with mint were another standout from the small plate menu.  Shaya's salad used fresh heirloom tomatoes of numerous varieties and is rather enjoyable to eat.  The baba ghanoush is light, fluffy and a perfect match for their house-made breads and the tabouleh is well-balanced.  

For our main dish, we ordered shakshouka, an amalgam of tomatoes, egg, artichoke, chili peppers, egg, and various spices.  I've been enamored with this dish ever since I saw a photo of a North African version of it at Emmer & Rye in Austin, and so I was pretty excited that we ordered this dish.  It reminded me of a spicy Indian curry except with slightly difference spices.  It was a fun, spicy dish that combined a number of my favorite flavors in manners I hadn't previously contemplated.  Nice job Shaya.  

For those who like to compare restaurants that receive the highest of accolades, the James Beard award winning Shaya perhaps wasn't as mighty an experience as that of 2014 Bon Appetit Restaurant of the Year Rose's Luxury, but both are spectacular in their own right.  And, in fairness, I went to the latter restaurant approximately a dozen times and have only had the privilege of visiting Shaya this one time.  The real takeaway should be that Shaya lives up to the hype and should certainly be placed on the short-list of restaurants to visit for denizens of the city.

4.25 stars.  Turkey and the Wolf has received a good deal of positive press from locals in its relatively short existence so I thought it might be worth a look.  Not surprisingly, the locals are correct: Turkey and the Wolf is an extraordinary combination of hip and casual and the food is exceptional as well.  

The space itself is very inviting with light cream colored interiors, ample spacing, and a couple of plugs for those of us who suck and need to charge our electronics while eating.  With respect to the food, it's clear they take a good deal of time sourcing ingredients and selecting exceptional flavor combinations.  Really, everything worked but the standout for me was a crab boil po-boy.  I've only had one other similar po-boy (in Lafayette, LA) but this one was even better than my first foray into this somewhat pristine territory.  The filling was generous on the crab and delicious enough that we strongly considered requesting a to-go container chock full of it.  Expect potatoes, corn, and a dollop of a mayo-based sauce served on top of your order.  We also ordered some fried chicken skin deviled eggs which only intensified my wonder that more places don't focus on chicken skin dishes (it had been somewhat prevalent in higher end dining in Washington, DC circa 2015 but haven't seen much of this food trend elsewhere).  In any event, whether you are ordering a glorified Egg McMuffin, a crab boil sandwich, or a Thanksgiving themed creation, you are going to be happy with the food here.  

Also, from what I remember, the beers were quite cheap and they had excellent selections.  Sadly, memory fades slightly on this note, but I would suspect they have a rotating menu of beers anyhow.  The takeaway is that it was a well-curated list.  

You may find yourself holding wild game while waiting for your order or perhaps Hillary Clinton riding a pterodactyl like a modern day Daenerys Targaryen.  Yes, in addition to being super casual, Turkey and the Wolf has simple yet effective surprising elements.  

If you are looking for something simple, cheap, and outstanding, Turkey and the Wolf is a great choice.  That's really all you need to know.
